Settling on a new phone is a life-decision for me because it's with me more than anything else that I own. I was looking for a short-term phone before the upcoming Galaxy 9 announcement and decided on the Honor 7x because of the reviews - the 7x was oxymoronically termed the "premium budget" phone. Once I bought a new flagship, I'd let the Honor 7x become a backup phone.

Wow - I was not expecting this phone.

What's great
* Built Quality - it feels like a flagship
* Snappy performance - enough said
* Headphone jack - I'm a big user of bluetooth, but many times I don't want the hassle
* Included case - another $20 that I don't need to spend
* MicroSD slot - I like the option of more memory without having to pay extortion pricing for embedded memory
* Low phone stress: At this price, I don't need to guard this phone like a Faberge egg (yes, I had to look up the spelling for that)

What's not great and why it doesn't matter to me (i.e. would I pay an additional $400+ to get these features)
* No Type-C: Yes, I'm trying to standardize on this but I've got plenty of microUSB devices now. I'm living in a mixed charger world for a while so I'm okay with it (but only this time)
* Not OLED: Yes, my Nexus 6P was brighter. But, fixing a cracked OLED cost more than this phone (so I lived with a cracked screen)
* Camera: I'm sure the camera isn't as good as the flagships but it doesn't move my $400 needle
* Bezel - it has a small bezel. Who cares.
* No fast charging: You need fast charging when your battery can't get you through the day - this battery will more than get you through the day
* No 5GHz WiFi radio: It's loading apps and streaming videos plenty fast for me now.
* No NFC: Since I can't depend on vendors accepting Android Pay, I've always got my credit cards with me.
* Not waterproof: I'll just continue to be careful with the phone.
* Not SnapDragon latest: As long as the performance is good - it doesn't matter.
* I can't remember how to spell Hawui: But, I feel superior to others in that I can pronounce it.

What's not great and may not matter to you:
* Comes with Android 7, not Andriod 8. Given that only .2% of devices were on 8 you probably don't care about this. For me, it's inexcusable for a manufacturer to release a phone on an old OS. This is why when I transitioned from Apple to Android, I settled on the Google Nexus because I knew I would always get the latest. As a tech enthusiast, when I read about a new software feature that's available, I need to have it. But, the reality is that, unlike the old days when new major versions of OS's contained exciting and life-altering features, the last set of major releases have been kind of a yawn-fest. But, it's still important to me and how Huewai keeps pace with the latest releases will be a factor if I choose them again.

Summing it up, great phone at a fantastic price. I would pay more if I needed to, but with the Honor 7x, it don't. IMHO, if you are buying a flagship phone from Samsung/Apple/Google, you're making a fashion statement.

(but, I'll let you know if I change my opinion)

I bought this phone after finally having to give up on my iPhone 6's battery life. That thing barely lasted half a day and if I used something heavy like maps, it would be instant death. I wasn't sure what to expect from this phone, but I couldn't afford a pricey iPhone X or Google Pixel. I have been so far pleasantly surprised. I'd say this phone works better and faster than my old iPhone ever did. I can now open apps and type words into search bars without it having to think about it and my battery lasts all day long. It's also extremely touch sensitive, something I had to get used to after my less touch sensitive iPhone. I can't say good enough things about this phone. The only downside is the screen will be less crisp than a more expensive one and the camera isn't top of the line crystal clear. I've added a photo to give you an idea. Still this phone is great and definitely is an exception to you get what you pay for. More phones should be this reasonably priced. I will recommend to everyone who wants a new phone that feels like an expensive top of the line one but can't afford it. Also I had cricket and switching over was as easy as taking my SIM card out of my iPhone and putting it in this one.

As far as size, looks, screen resolution and touch response, the phone seems excellent.

However, the only reason I bough this phone was for the dual-SIM capability. What Huawei and almost every other phone provider doesn't tell you (and it takes a LOT of digging to find out) is that the first SIM operates as you would expect (LTE/4G/3G), but the second SIM operates ONLY on 2G.

No big deal, right? WRONG. 2G is being phased out in the US. In fact, the cellular communicator for my home alarm system was 2G and ceased working 2 YEARS ago. There is no 2G in my area. Maybe there's 2G in your area (very few areas), but that won't help you when you travel nor will it help you when 2G finally ceases to stop working in your area (and it will).

You can switch which SIM is the active SIM through the phone configuration, but you will only receive (or make) calls on the active SIM.

If you need a phone with dual-SIM and 3G on the second SIM, the Samsung J7 and one of the Sony's will do it. Make sure you get the specific model, as there are multiple J7's.

If you have read any of my other reviews, you know I like phones and test drive MANY in search of really good phones, were kind of s phone family. Having said that, I am a Huawei fan since the Mate 2. They just build good phones for an incredible price. We have owned all the high end Mates and everything since the Honor 5 to this phone, the 7x. I say that to say, I don't mind paying more for a good phone...but the Honor line has made it so I don't have to pay more for a quality phone with really good specs. I never would have imagined a $200 phone could be this good.

The photos are a side by side comparison to the Honor 5, for size comparison.

The first thing I noticed about this phone is how remarkably thin it is for an almost 6 inch screen, with three cameras (two on back, one forward facing) It's much lighter and thinner than the 5, yet feels more solid in the hand. This phone has a nice large battery and I'm sure it will last my husband all day, with moderate text and web use. It uses a micro USB charger, which is fine for most people who still have a ton of micro USB chargers around (I personally prefer type C, but my husband hates change and likes the micro USB). Even though the screen is almost 6 inches, it doesn't feel too large..and definitely feels smaller than my Mate 9. The screen is bright and the resolution looks great. ALL my husband's apps and data transferred over (all 64 apps) within 16 minutes with the phone clone app that Huawei uses for data and app transfer. The phone is super fast and switched between apps quickly with no freezing or lag (yet). The UI is typical Huawei, but you can download the google launcher or other launcher of your choice to give a more familiar feel. We use cricket (which is AT&T prepaid) and had no issues with the APN, it configured automatically. Placed a call and the sound was good and definitely loud enough on speaker.
The camera is good...it's not the Mate 9 Leica but it's good and I didn't feel the need to mess with any settings. Is plenty good for social media pics, selfies and pics of the kids, pets, life's most embarrassing moments, etc. It still has a headphone jack, which I prefer to an adapter or even wireless. The finger print sensor is lightning fast and works before you even realize you have pressed your finger against the sensor. Not too much bloatware, certainly not as much as carrier locked phones! It has 64 GB of space, AND room for a memory card. Comes with Android 8 which is pretty similar to 7, but nice to have updated out of the box. It encrypts the SD card so be aware if you choose this option that you won't be able to just pop your SD card out of this phone and into another without changing the settings.
Time will tell, but based on prior experience with Huawei, as well an Apple, Samsung and various bargain phones, I believe this is another keeper! It's a shame AT&T backed out of the deal to bring this phone to the carrier, but it may work to the consumers advantage by keeping prices competitive.
DAY THREE of heavy use and no glitches, lagging, freezing or resets.
Love this phone more worth each passing day.
Months later and I still believe this is the best sub $200 phone out.

I waited to do this review until after using with the EMUI 8.0/Oreo 8.0 Android update, as the previous Nougat software had some lag issues. On my phone, these appear to be fixed now.

The phone is smooth and fast for everything I do everyday (I am not a gamer). I have not missed the extra gig of ram I would have gotten with the Huawei Mate SE or the international version of the Honor 7x. The fingerprint sensor is blazing fast and accurate. The new face unlock, not so much. It works about 70% of the time. But for me it's not an issue. The fingerprint sensor not only unlocks the phone but can be set for other things as well, like taking a pic or scrolling in some apps.

It feels like a much more expensive phone. Solid in the hand, very much like IPhone 7. The screen is bright and clear, with fairly good viewing angles, usable but not great in bright sunlight. The speaker is loud enough but a little tinny, but hey, it's got a headphone jack, and good sound though it at that! Calls are loud and clear, GPS works great.

I like EMUI 8. It's fast and pretty customizable, with lots of themes available on the Google store. But if you prefer something else, this is Android, so there are many other launchers available. I do wish they had kept stock Android's ability to move apps to the SD card, however. As it is, data can live there, but apps cannot. Still, I've got pretty much all the apps I'll probably use, and still about 12 gigs of space.

The cameras are great for pictures in good lighting, with lots of options and a good manual pro mode. In low lighting things fall off significantly. And video takes clear shots and great sound, but no optical or digital stabilization, and only 1080p, no 4k.

Downside? No NFC (so no Android Pay), A Micro USB port instead of USB-C. Charging not as fast as some others. No official waterproofing (though there are some YouTube vides that show it to be pretty resistant to an accidental dunk. Not going to test it myself). Still it is amazing how much phone you can get for under $200. I would recommend it to anyone who does not need ultimate gaming performance, Android Pay, or absolute top-level camera. Or, If the camera is the issue, Buy this, and use the money you save to buy a real camera.

Update 04-08-2018: I've had the phone for over a month now and it's still great. Every few days I have to reboot it because it does seem to slow down...but rebooting a phone every 5 days it's a problem to me at all. It does charge slowly, but again, not an issue for me. Plugging it in at 10% easily gets to 100% overnight. The battery life is still amazing. I use it heavily throughout the day and it's still at 50% or more by the time I go to bed. Typically I charge it every two days or maybe top it off a little bit if needed.

I had an Axon 7 (which I absolutely loved) but the battery would only last a few hours so decided it was time for a new phone. I couldn't find anything with the nice specs of my Axon 7 so decided to settle for this phone until something better came along. I was totally shocked how good this phone is. It totally buries my Axon 7 on boot up and is very responsive. I didn't particularly care for the UI so replaced it with Nova launcher. I was a bit worried whether it would work correctly because other reviewers said they had problems getting it to work. I had no issues at all. I use T-Mobile and MMS wouldn't work at all the first day, but by the next day it was working...not sure what's up with that (I'm using Textra).

The phone does lack a few things that would be nice, but they are absolutely not deal breakers. USB-C would have been nice, but I have a ton of the old cables, so that's not a problem. An IR blaster would be nice, but to be honest I haven't really used those on my old phones and they had them.

My biggest gripe at this point might be the sound. It's ok, but nothing special at all. Perhaps it's because I was spoiled by the Axon 7, but I'd rather have a phone with a mediocre speaker than one I had to charge 3 times a day.

The battery life is amazing. I started off the day with 67% charged. I listened to an audio book to and from work (40 minute commute each way), had waze on for 40 minutes, made a few phone calls and listened to music all day...about 8 hours (screen off). By the time I got home the charge was down to 45%!! This beats the heck out of any other phone I had and used this much. The phone looks and feels great...it doesn't feel like I only spent $199 on it.

The great part is watching others go spend $1000 on a new iPhone and realize that my 7x is just as functional and I could have 5 of them.

For $200 this phone is a absolutely a bargain. Pros: battery last long, screen are big resolution are good....
Cons: no 5G WiFi and speaker is a little weak, no Android 8.0 yet. The GPS chip is pretty junky, I don't use the gos often so it not a big deal to me, other than that its a perfect one for the budget I'm really happy that I bought it.

I bought this phone on March 6, 2017, I received 2 updates, currently with Android 8, Emui 8. the only problem is the GPS, it does not work with Google Maps or Waze, it is a pity that a quality team like this present this problem

Here's a review from a total phone newbie without all the fancy, smart lingo that usually comes with phone reviews.

My phone history: I was an apple user. Had four iPhones.

So it's a nice change... It was hard to get use to an Android phone after so many years of using iPhones but here are the pros:

1) Big phone. Great for games, watching things and browsing. You will need two hands.
2) Soooo much storage... more than I am used to. And you can add MORE storage? Sign me up.
3) Definitely durable and comes with a case. I tend to drop my phones. A lot. So it was nice they included a semi-transparent case and there isn't any (big) damages to the phone yet despite a little slip from my hands at least once a day.
4) I fell on the phone. This thing BENDS. It contorted to the shape of my butt. The glass made it out no scratches. I just had to bend the phone back to its flatten shape.
5) You can withdraw your texts a few seconds before it sends.
6) You can do split screens.

Cons:
1) Camera quality is horrible. Selfie camera produces blurry, or at least not very sharp pictures. The back camera isn't that great either. Colors come out looking overly-saturated and doesn't capture a lot of details like I'm used to with the iPhones.
2) You cannot delete system apps like shitty Google Duo app.

This is a beautifully designed and impressively priced phone that I would be more than satisfied with if one crucial aspect was present... It is NOT unlocked. I have spent the past two days trying to locate the source of my problem with my carrier to understand why my phone will not connect to my network. I originally assumed it was an issue with my SIM card, but it turns out my phone is still "locked" and will not be supported by another carrier until I contacted the company to resolve the issue. I reached out to them and did not receive any response. It has affected my work and I wasted $200 on a phone I had considerable hopes for.

OVERALL - Great phone for the price. As of the date of this review, the phone is hard to beat in this price range. The mid-range processor can handle most app's and games without issue. However, there are some issues that'll be addressed below.

SOFTWARE - The software, EMUI 5.1, will definitely leave you polarized. You'll either like it or you won't. It has an iOS look and feel to it. I bought Nova Launcher Prime and use that as the replacement launcher. The Honor 7x is set to receive Android Oreo updates sometime in Q2 2018.

HARDWARE - The Honor 7x has Huawei Kirin 695 processor. It's mid-range spec and is definitely capable of handling the day in and day out's of your average consumer. I've been able to play each game I've downloaded flawlessly. My issue is that the phone gets very hot in the back right corner at the top after an hour or more of intensive use such as playing a game, and I'm assuming the processor throttles itself in response to the heat, which will cause a noticeable performance drop.

There also seems to be random performance drops unrelated to what app's I'm using or how long I've been using the phone. They're rare but when they do occur, they're very noticeable and annoying. Sometimes app icons will disappear and will only reappear when the performance stabilizes. Other times there is a noticeable delay in starting apps after clicking them. I can't really explain how or why it's happening because I've been unable to recreate the issue intentionally other than when playing an intensive game for an hour or more and letting the phone get very hot.

BUILD - The phone is beautiful and feels great in the hand. It's not slippery feeling but is very smooth. It feels very solid. I used to worry with my last phone that if I sat down with it in my back pocket, that I'd bend it. I've no concern of that with this phone.

CAMERA - The camera's are average at best. They're not terrible. They're not great. The front-facing camera will get the job done for selfie's as long as you have good lighting. The dual-camera setup on the back is is also decent. With proper lighting and a steady hand, you can get some decent pictures.

SCREEN - It's not an AMOLED but that's not really an issue for me. The black's aren't as deep or rich of course, but that's an acceptable loss for this price range. The screen does auto-brighten in day light, which makes it a little more easily used outside. My only complaint is that the screen is very, very sensitive to touch. So sensitive in fact that if I'm scrolling through the app drawer and barely touch the edge of an app icon for even a split second, it'll launch. Coming from an iPhone, the sensitivity difference is going to take getting used to.

Had this phone for just over a week now and I can honestly say that I have zero complaints. It does exactly what I wanted and then some. I was previously using "BLU" phones and after quite a bit of researched decided to switch over. Where as my BLU phone was sluggish and laggy this phone is fast and takes almost no time to load anything I ask of it. I also really really love the double screen feature it has. The camera could be better, but the pros definitely outweigh the cons for this gem.

If you want a modernized looking phone that can do the basics like social media, web browsing and e-mails, but less than half the cost of flag ship phones; this is a phone to consider.

-Looking Sexy
Back of the phone looks very similar to an iphone 6/7 with horizontal antenna bands on top/bottom,and thin profile. But also has a fingerprint reader.

Front of the phone has a very nice with bezel-less 18x9 screen ratio

-Screen Quality
No AMOLED display. so you're not going to have the best HD/4K movie viewing experience. But the 1080p LED display is very high quality despite that. Unless you're really accustomed to AMOLD Quad HD displays you won't notice a significant difference especially if you watch lower quality videos like on youtube.

-Speakers/Headphone Jack
Speakers are basic. Have one bottom firing speaker. As long as you're mindful placing your fingers when viewing video horizontally you won't have any issue.

Sound coming out is similar okay. Doesn't have enough bass, but loud enough to listen to vocals of songs and podcasts in a quiet room.

Has a headphone jack which some $800+ flagship phones abandoned for blue tooth only (unless you have an adapter). Very nice inclusion for those who still use wired headsets

-Duel Sim/Micro SD expansion
Self explanatory. Like the headphone jack, missing from most flagship phones nowadays

-Camera
Produces very good photos in the right lighting conditions. Not going to produce the highest quality photos like the Pixel 2, Note 8, or iphone X, but decent enough to share photos on facebook or instagram without being criticized about the quality (unless your friends are really nit picky).

Duel camera makes for a nice Bokeh effect (where the background is blurred, making more focus on the subject). At times it can look a bit artificial though (especially if the subject is far away), but most of the time it does it's job well. You can adjust this post snap shot.

No optical image stabilization when taking pictures, so best not to move around a lot for a second or two after taking the snap shot. You can use the finger print sensor instead of on-screen capture button to take pictures. Have to turn this on from settings.

Video is good if you have a steady hand, and not walking/jogging while filming as it does product a shaking cam effect if you move around a lot

-Finger Print Sensor
Works 100% of the time for me with dry clean hands. Scans instantly, no need to wobble my finger back-and-forth or hold down for a second or two.

You can also use finger print sensor to take a picture, scroll down webpages, or press and hold to pick up a call

-Gaming
Can run most 2D/less graphic intensive games really well. For 3D, high graphic intensive games; frame rate might dip a bit depending on how much is going on screen.

The phone also doesn't have gyro controls, so for games that requires it; it's unplayable depending on how much is implemented

-Operating System
Runs Android 8.0. So up to date as of this review. There are some custom firmware, but it doesn't take away from core Android experience.

It's mixture of iOS and Android leaning a lot towards Android. So good transition if you're thinking of switching over

An awesome feature this phone has is ability to do twin apps. Great if you have dual accounts for one app as don't have to switch users every time.

There is some bloatware apps, but you are able to remove/delete them from your phone, but most are very useful in my opinion. Best to test it out before deleting

Scrolling through apps is very smooth. May get a half second stutter if you view webpages with a lot of things to load.

There's no performance issues even when multi-tasking

-Works With T-Mobile
Have Tmobile as phone service provider. Network data and phone calls come through fine in my area.

-What it comes with
Phone, Wall charger/cable, instructions, and case. The case is very basic and makes the phone scratch resistant (minus the screen) in case you put your phones and keys in the same pocket/bag. I recommend getting a replacement case if you're the clumsy type and drop your phone often

-Missing features compared to Flag Ship Phones
Being 1/4 the cost of most flag ship phones like the latest Samsung, Google and iphone. Some features are bound to be missing. Here's a list of what's not included compared to top of the line smart phones out there:

1. No NFC. Not able to make mobile payments or physical touch data transfers.
2. Not water or dust resistant. Can get around this with phone cases that provide these features
3. No gyro sensor. As mentioned before may restrict some of your gaming
4. No wireless charging
5. Uses Micro USB instead of USB type C
6. No fast charging. Takes around 2.5 hours to fully charge from 10% battery life. Battery can last up to 2.5 days as long if you're not a heavy user. Idle time on this phone is really good. If you binge watch Netflix, it'll last 4-5 hours.

Overall, very good phone that's able to hang with the big boys (flag ship phones) with Android 8.0, modern exterior design and ability to run the usual apps.

Super affordable and excellent phone for the price. Highly recommend to anyone who just need the basics when it comes to Android.

Overall this was an amazing phone. Was. Rarely had issues with apps loading, switching etc. Had plenty of storage to hold pictures, music and apps. Fingerprint scanner worked great as long as you kept it clean, and your hands were not wet or too dirty. Dual sim worked perfectly and was little hassle to switch between the two sim cards. Picture quality is fantastic, although it would be nice for more editing options. Sound quality was okay with the speakers, but I rarely had issues using Bluetooth and the headphone jack. Call quality was about standard, nothing out-of-the-park. It was hard to find a decent screen protector for it because of the 2.5D screen, the tempered glass ones never stayed on, but the soft ones worked perfectly. Same thing with a case, there are not a lot of options out there for a case. Battery life was nice, only had to charge it about every other day, with Wi-Fi, mobile data, and location services on. Without those running, it was about 3 or so days between charges.

However, this phone has barely lasted a year before failing. I bought this in February 2018, and just now in December it no longer charges, no longer connects to a computer. There has been tons of dirt and grime buildup in the charging port, as well as the headphone jack, which constantly needed to be cleaned out, which will wear out the contacts inside the charging port over time. A case that covers those would have prevented that, but there are very few options when it comes to phone cases. In addition to no longer charging, the phone will not unlock once the screen times out. Pressing the unlock/power button on the side ends up rebooting the phone and shutting it down instead of unlocking the screen, even with a single press. The fingerprint reader will not work either.

Everything about this phone was nice, except for the lifespan. Save the money and put it towards a phone that will last longer than a year.

I've been using this phone for about a month and I really like it. The battery lasts a good deal of time (around two days with normal activity, or one day if I watch videos or play games often), it has a nice camera and memory capacity, and very convenient settings. I love the fingerprint sensor in the back, it makes super easy for me to unlock my phone. I also really like that it allows me to call my contacts only by saying their name; everything is very accurate.
By far it's been the best, yet the least expensive phone I've ever had.

If you are the type of person who doesn't care about brands and trendy technology, and you just need a good reliable smartphone with a good camera THIS IS THE PHONE FOR YOU. I am a college student at UT and this phone is my saving grace. It does everything my friends iphones can do (minus facetime, but my friends and I use google duo). My phone also has more storage, a bigger screen, a longer lasting battery, and was a fraction of the cost of an iphone. I can go a whole day and a half without charging it. For the record, I'm not just being idealistic about the difference between iphone's and this phone. The reason I even had to buy this phone was because my iphone 7 was a piece of ______. I was barely able to use the phone for a week. It was sooooooooo glitchy and the IC chip or whatever was faulty (a problem apparently VERY common to Iphone 7s), so I couldn't even make calls, only text. However, the phone I had right before the iphone 7 was an honor 6, which I gave to my younger brother and after about 2 years of use is still going strong. So, I figured why not just get the upgrade of the honor I had. Now I finally have a phone that works well. I would give this phone five stars, but its just a little bigger than I expected, but that's not really a problem because I also ordered a rose gold case with one of those adjustable metal rings in the back and I just keep my middle finger in there all the time so I don't drop my phone (its actually quite comfortable). So yeah I hope this review helps you make a decision and save your coins.

Love it at first, but 8 months into the ownership, screen starting to detached from body. I contacted support and they claimed it's a physical damage that will not be covered by warranty. I have been careful about my phone and never sat on nor dropped it. There is not a scratch on the phone and no crack on the screen.

It is a perfect phone ever. I have briefly used honor 6x preciously, but not impressed that time because of the low end body and laggy performance. This time I decided to give it another try due to the shiny body and ovehemeingly good review. It really didn't dispoint me this time. The display is even better than I thought when I got the phone. I have heard view angle issue of phone but I don't see anything noticeable. Clarity of display are top notch!! Even feel better than iPhone 7 or 8. The performance is greatly improved from last generation. What is even better is it flies after I turned on developer option and limit the background process.
I haven't tried the camera seriously, it is ok. But if care about camera, it is not the phone for you.
I don't really have too much cons for it. The micro USB ports, lack of fast charge don't seem like a problem because I have plenty of old cable and battery is well enough for serious one day use.
One con I have is that edge of the screen is not very sensitive , but not a big issue to me.
So seriously, even without considering the fact of price, it is still a perfect daily driver phone.

Purchased this phone to replace my father's outdated SS Note 3, and he is quite happy with the upgrade. I've been an iPhone guy since the 3G back in 2008. I have to say this phone has sincerely WOW'd me for the price. I've looked up reviews and knew I was expecting a similar design to my current iPhone 7+, but for $200 I can say the display's quality is similar to my iPhone 7+, the build quality feels similar of an iPhone, the buttons for volume and lock are clicky and satisfying to press and overall better than my iPhone's buttons! (and Honor includes a FREE CLEAR CASE in box vs headphones which has more value to me imo) UMEI is a great skin, it is very iOS-like which felt very familiar out of the box, and great to have the app drawer enabled by default. Seriously the only drawback I can think of is the camera quality, for a dual lens system I was expecting a little more sharpness and color reproduction but I noticed most photos, were lacking in light/color. It gets the job done, but I highly recommend Honor/Huawei to spend the extra $ on their next model and increase the msrp by $20 to include an improved camera module and this would easily replace my iPhone next year. NO NFC so no Android Pay, but my father is very old school and could care less about it, but it could be a dealbreaker for those who frequent contactless payments. But most modern credit/debit cards are going contactless, so there's that. Anyways thanks for creating a great phone for the price Huawei you knocked it out of the park in almost every department in my book.

I needed a phone, the price was good so thought it was worth a shot. It's only been a few days and I'm not sure if I will keep it. It has many good qualities but has some major problems that could make it unusable in the future. The first is the screen doesn't respond. Sometimes it takes several tries. Also battery life is short. I start my day at 7am and the battery is dead by 4pm. I'm not a heavy user and my 3 year old phone last longer even now. But I'll give it more time and see how it goes.
Update. It's only been a week and it has lockup twice once during a phone call, and went dark once and It was hard to restart. The thing that makes me sad is I really liked this phone. It maybe a defective one but not sure I'm going to take a chance a replacement.

The eye catching distinguishment for the 7X is that 18:9 aspect ratio screen for the $200 price point you are paying. But there is definitely more in this budget phone than just the screen. Inside the aluminium unibody holds a Hisilicon Kirin 659 chip with 3 GB of ram and 32 GB of storage. There is micro SD card support for added space as well.

And like all Huawei and Honor phones, the 7X runs a custom skin running Android Nougat called EMUI 5.1, which weâve taken a look at often on this channel. I personally have grown used to EMUI and you can adjust the settings to make it more of a traditional android experience. Options are good especially for the budget field.

But going back to the screen, Honor is calling their 18:9 screen a âFullViewâ display which in laymens term translates to a 5.93 inch 1080p IPS display that has thin bezels on the sides. Viewing angles and colors reproduction are perfectly acceptable and are actually quite good for this price range.

Something else that is really good for the price is the build quality. Weâre very aware that Chinese phones have been providing solid budget builds for years now, but never have they been easily accessible in the western markets. This is sold on Amazon, Bestbuy and basically every accessible electronics e-commerce. The only budget aspect of the hardware is the use of micro-usb instead of USB C. Although as I said before about this phone, I do suspect most potential buyers looking at the 7X are coming from a micro usb phone anyway. Its one extra cable you have to carry for those who have made the switch to USB C with all their other electronics.

The fingerprint scanner is located a little bit on the high side on the rear of the phone. I have to alter my grip to hit it. It is rather accurate and fast to unlock though. The 7X also has one set of fingerprint gestures that allow you to bring down and up the notification shade. Little features like this that it shares with itâs more expensive Huawei siblings makes this phone feel a bit more expensive than it really is.

Now the Kirin 659 performs nowhere near where I expected it to even when considering this $200 price range. Apps are noticeably slow to load and multi-tasking is near impossible on this phone. This is one of the few phones Iâve used the last couple of years which have fully locked up on me multiple times and forced me to do a hard restart. If you have absolutely nothing running in the background though, the 7X actually has passable performance in comparison with midrangers which is a level above its pay grade.

These mixed results play in with the dual rear cameras too. Like many of the Huawei produced phones, we have a 16 MP f/2.2 sensor accompanied by a 2 MP one that lets you do some neat things with the aperture. Oh and they look like googly eyes popping out of your phone.

The camera and gallery apps are slow to launch a majority of the time. What you see here is already considered fast through my usage. Even clearing up available ram doesnât seem to speed things up for me. This is a big letdown seeing as the results of the photos are really good. I was extremely impressed with the photo quality the 7X produced. Landscape photos in optimal lighting are sharp and detailed with rather cool true colors. Iâm going to have to say this is probably the phone camera in the $100-300 range Iâve used in a couple years. It falls short in low light situations and the selfie camera adds too much processing, but overall this was a reliable camera.

Another thing that was surprisingly reliable was the 3340 mah battery which lasted me for about 14-15 hours a day. I took this 7X and pushed it to itâs limit on my recent trip to Hong Kong and it kept up, at least in the battery life department. Almost 6 Hrs of Screen on Time, which by my standards of usage is very good.

My last couple of notes before I wrap the review up is that the Honor 7X doesnât have NFC. Most budget devices donât. Iâve been using Google Pay at ATMs and stores, and ironically in Hong Kong where mobile payments are a huge norm, I brought on the trip the one phone to test that didnât have access to it.

I really loved this phone for a while until I started having issues. The camera is not that great but I did not expect much from a 200 something phone. It looks and feels like a premium phone despite being cheap on price. When I first got it, it was kind of slow when multitasking. Other than that, it worked fine. After few months, they issued a software update which solved the slowness problem. I could not feel any lag when using normal day to day apps like browsing, Facebook, photos, maps etc. Until that point there were no major issues. Then came another software update after which the gps started having issues. It would not lock on the satellites when using maps . Even when it did occasionally lock, it lost the lock pretty fast. I have had horrible incidents where I tried to go somewhere and the GPS signal got lost and I had to stop the car and reset the phone. I did a factory reset, calibrated the compass, used gps apps to reset the gps but nothing seemed to work. I went to online forums and other people are also having similar problems.

I contacted Huawei and since the phone is under warranty, they issued me a RMA to send it in repair. Now, I have to wait until I get my phone back. They said they do not have a loaner phone that they can provide until mine gets repaired.

So bottom-line, if your phone works, it is a great bargain, but if you have to send it in for repair, prepare to have a backup phone until you get your phone back.

I will update once I get my phone back.

* Update 12/11/18 : the phone came back from repair and they did expedited shipping. Now, the GPS works but it has never worked quite fast and well like iPhone and premium phones from the very beginning. I used an old iPhone 6 plus while this was going through repairs and had gotten used to IOS. After I got this phone back, I realized that this phone is much more slimmer and is overall a better form factor than the iPhone. However, GPS was always spot on, on the iPhone.

* Update 01/29/2018 : I am having same problems with GPS again. Even though the phone was supposedly repaired under warranty. Phone still has few days warranty left so I will try to send it in for repair. I am staying away from Huawei products for sure.

Many reviews on this device reassure you that this device is a great device for $200 but the truth is if you forget the price this device is a good device at any price compared to what is out there. You already know the specs so my experience with this phone has been great. I have had alot of smart phones high end and low end this is definitely a mid-range performing phone however for day to day usage like web browsing, watching movies and even playing games it offers a great experience especially if you haven't experienced Android 8 or the 18:9 aspect ratio as yet. The cameras are okay and can produce great photos in good lighting. Low light performance isn't great but I guess it's usable just not impressive. Am not a selfie person but I guess the same can be said for the front cameras they're good but suffers in low lighting. Gaming on this device isn't the best but it's good enough for almost everyone. the only game I play is pubg and it's runs pretty smooth but there are at time noticeable glitches but they don't hinder game play for me at lease. Build quality is great. Sound quality is solid one speaker but it's gets the job done. I have no complains about this phone. Buy it it's good. if you are looking for a flagship you know where to find them but if you are looking at this chances are your looking for something that is affordable and gets the job done this is the most affordable phone you can get that gets the job done. [After 6 months update:] the screen started to have a yellowish tint it seems to occur when the phone is placed under heat. it's 2019 I do not recommend this phone anymore

If reviews are important to you, then I'll cut to the chase. I love this phone except for a huge flaw that I want corrected. If you are not into texting, then I give you my 4.5 star blessing. Mazel tov! If you are into texting a lot, keep going as I explain my low rating...

As a person who likes to own her own phone and wants the best quality at an affordable price, I researched this phone for a long time before buying. I don't like to change phones often and I don't like being held hostage at a phone company with high payments for months! So after reading some great reviews on consumer and computer magazine sites, decided to buy the Honor 7x.
Overall, I really like it! I have to take all kinds of pics for work, so the camera function was one of the most important features to consider. It really gives iPhone a run for the money. The sound quality could be better, especially louder, but it isn't poor...could just be a little more powerful. I live in New York, so sometimes in a crowd, I just cannot hear.
Why the low rating then? Because their customer service could not give me an answer to my problem!!!
Situation: I text far more than talk on the phone, so there are two time-consuming and frustrating issues going on.

1. There are several colleagues with whom I group chat using the text app that came on the phone. (They all have iPhones -don't know if that matters). Whenever we get into a dialogue, I go berserk because if I need to scroll backward to catch the beginning of the conversation, then every time one of the others responds back in real time - even if just to "like" what someone else said - I can't scroll anymore because the page jumps to the most current comment. So I try scrolling again, then boom! Back to the most current comment. Cant respond if I can't follow! So I just drop out all together until they stop. Then they wonder why I don't answer when they needed my feedback sooner.
2. The second issue is along those lines, but involving all texts. At any time I want to review a previous text with anyone, as I scroll backwards, the page is jerky whenever I lift my finger up to start another downward swipe to scroll. For every five or so comments I pass backwards in a scroll, then it jerks forward three more (i.e., take three steps forward, step back one). It takes forever to scroll. It's never one continuous flow. Definite glitches.

I've had this phone since April, but kept thinking a system update might fix the problem and it never did, so today I decided to contact customer service. We did a text chat on their site. At first the tech guy more or less said it was too bad: it's just how it is....maybe I should try a different app! But I shouldn't have to ask my colleagues to install a different app just so we can have a flowing text chat! I told him it was unacceptable and that I would write a negative review on Amazon. So then he wrote back with some instructions to try involving the cache. I tried it twice and it didn't work. So basically I think the company's response is I'm SOL! To me that is still not an acceptable response for such a large company, even though I know in phone world this is a cheap phone! I had an Amazon Fire Phone previously for which I paid less than this one and I never had this issue!
If Huawei people read this and can come up with a better solution that works, I will be happy to edit this review and give a 5-star rating, because in every other aspect, I'm very happy with this phone, especially given the price. I had literally spent 3 months researching phones and felt like I was making the best investment possible, so to have this type of malfunction going on is a huge disappointment and a huge waste of my time when I'm trying to conduct business.

Bought this phone because this was the best bang for my buck. I don't have a lot of disposable income, so when I am buying a phone it has to tick the necessary boxes for me at the great price.
- Great build quality (if all goes well may be using it for 3 years plus)
- Updated to Android Oreo (not Android P but its as close to being updated as it gets without having a Google or android one phone
- Decent Battery
- Decent Camera
- 32 GB internal memory(any less is a deal breaker)
- headphone jack (another deal breaker)
- expandable memory
So it ticked the above boxes and many others, it's by no means super fast and I have noticed that there are some hiccups in usage but nothing too annoying.
Overall, it great package.

I would not recommend this phone if you counted on having the ability to move apps to storage (to expand the limited 32gb of RAM for apps with Micro SD sticks). It has been a long time since that functionality was implemented on stock android, but Huawei has not enabled it in their OS. Huge disappointment for me, because otherwise the phone is quite nice.

I would suggest that everyone look at the Mate SE which has more internal memory (64gb) and RAM (3gb) making the lack of functionality less of a problem.

Very fragile phone. Screen cracked in the second month. I went through 3 glass screen protectors and three cases since getting the phone 14WEEKS ago. I had the previous honor and loved it...infact I'm using that one now since the honor 7 didn't survive a water incident. I'm not particularly rough with my phone. This is the first screen I've ever cracked. Who wants a phone that can't survive daily life?

The phone is light but not too light. Its all aluminum so it feels real tight in our hand. The screen is bright and clear. Its not quite a good as the Samsung AMOLED but still pretty good. It has a small bezel and no stupid "notch". Here the best -This phone is FAST, LIGHTENING FAST. It can switch apps quickly, storage is adequate, the OS is simple to use - you will have no problem. It works with AT&T (any GSM carrier) and can take any SD card to expand the memory. I know it doesn't have the cache of Apple of Samsung but it also doesn't have the price tag either - and it does Everything those phones do. It runs the latest Android and gets updates faster than most. It costs $199 and you can have next day or same day if you order early. The best part for me is I own this phone. No payments plans. And there is a warranty. A 100% recommended buy.

If you want to have some cheap fun, just read reviews. Reviews of any product. Amazing. Some say it was sent from above. Some say it absolutely sucks. How can it be so opposite? Funny. The truth i think lies somewhere in the middle. I like more about the phone then i don't like about the phone. i am comparing to other phones in the same basic price range i have compared it to. Of course, this is only my personal opinion like all other reviews...

The likes and don't likes:

- I like: That it is because it has little bloat wear.
- I like: That because it is totally unlocked it works with virtually ALL phone services AND even in Europe.
- I like: The strong processor for only 199.99.
- I like: The overall quality of the phone.
- I like: The loud, clear, phone reception when speaking with someone.
- I like: The camera. Not great, but for 199.99 it is great. If it was an 800.00 phone i may give it less stars.
- I like: It is fluid and smooth when using it. The screen scrolls well, i have NEVER had it freeze as some reviews say.
- I like: As other reviews state, it is just a great phone for under 200.00. I have seen some phones that are new like this one that are dogs in comparison for the same price. After using it you would believe you have a much more expensive phone then it is.
- I like: The big screen. NICE screen too....
- I like: There are other things I like also about the phone, but will end it here..

- I don't like so much: I feel like i am getting real picky here, but i have to come up with some negative. I didn't care for the onboard email app. and text app. I found a couple of third party apps that seem to work well, so i am using those.
- I don't like so much: The fact there is no fast charging USB port.
- I don't like so much: That there are a couple of software 'leave-out's' that could be mentioned, but not worth the effort to post. Piddly little things i think for under 200.00. If it was 600.00 it would be worth the complaint.

I am going to SHOCK many people who read this review.................. I bought the phone................. TO BE A PHONE. I want to call someone and have the call quality be GOOD. The first time i used the phone my son called me who was on a business trip across the U.S. from where i am. The call was so loud and clear it was as though he was standing a few feet from me. Amazing. If I want to text someone I want it to work good. If I want to email someone I want it to work good. I want to be able to take a decent photo now and then. I could give a rats rear end whether i can play a video game. I will use my X-Box if i want to do that. IF i want to take professional pictures i will use my "Camera" for that. I want a phone to be a PHONE first and foremost. I occasionally have need to Google something when i am out and about. I want it to not crap out on me while i am in a browser. I want the processor to power through and not die on me and the phone freeze while trying to surf some website. This one has been super in that regard. From that standpoint this phone works GREAT. All the other goodies are all pluses...

So the overall review for me is that phone, for the price deserves 5 stars. How could i NOT give it 5 stars? it is a great phone for 200 bucks. Unbelievable really. That is why it is so highly rated. Do the math. It has much more in features then not. Did i mention it is just plain outright good looking phone too. I love how the processor powers through everything i have thrown at it most of all.....

FOOTNOTE:

This is a foot note my first review above. I have had the phone for over a month and it has worked just super. Happy with it as can be other then the negatives i gave it, which really were not negatives at all. Something i found out that worked for me regarding the BATTERY not holding up as advertised. I bought the phone with "Nougat 7.0." I took the suggestion of one of the reviewers that said they found that before you do anything, you immediately install the 8.0 upgrade. THEN after doing the upgrade IMMEDIATELY do one more reset of the phone.

I found that initially my battery did not seem to hold up well as i expected. I was a little disappointed. I did as one reviewer suggested and reset my phone one more time. I noticed a REAL difference how the battery performed. No doubt about it. It made a real difference. 1. IF you buy the phone new do the update FIRST THING. Before doing anything. IF you have had the phone for a while, still do the reset. 2. RESET the phone AFTER the update. Made a difference for me just as the reviewer suggested...

I love this phone! It's my second $200 phone (the first was the galaxy j7 prime) and this one is miles better. The camera is much better and that was my biggest concern. The screen is really big but it's still easy to use one-handed. The fingerprint scanner is incredibly well placed and works immediately every time. The battery also easily lasts all day and I'm on my phone constantly. Something kind of funny is that the stock keyboard come with what I assume is Chinese emojis and they're hilarious.

I originally came from the galaxy s7 edge and this phone really doesn't feel like that much of a step down for saving $700 dollars. The camera isn't as good but that's a lot of money too pay for a camera. As you can tell, I've been a Samsung girl for a while and switching to an almost stock Android has been great. I always thought I liked the little changes Samsung made but now I think they would just get in the way.

There are a few cons. First is that you need to either put the free case on it or get a screen protector immediately. The corners of the front screen got scratched up after having the phone for less than a day just from setting it face down on tables. Also, Snapchat occasionally runs slow. And finally, I would suggest resetting your phone every so often because it does get bogged down sometimes.

This is the third Honor xX I have had. My wife and I each got a 5x, I got the 6x while she was still using the 5x. After a departure to other androud devices in the same price range I'm very happy to be back with the Honor brand. My last phone before this was the Revvl... By far the biggest pos I have ever had, and it cost $40 more then the 7x.

The new phone is thinner, lighter and easier to use one handed. I'm 6'4' and have pretty big hands. My wife at 5'1" can also single habdes us the phone. I believe it has to do with the new aspect ratio. Seems taller and thinner than the old ones.

Fast, bright and beautiful. Don't think you can do much better at the price.

I have been using it for quite a bit now and I absolutely LOVE it! My phone before this was a Samsung Galaxy S5 and I had has all the previous ones of that so I was a little nervous to go with a different kind of phone. To be honest, I like it even better! The picture quality could be better but it's not bad for everyday use! It's better than the S5 for sure, more comparable to the S4 which I loved as well.
I haven't had any issues with the phone as of yet! There is a ton of memory which is good for me because I take a TON of pictures! Internet capability is great and I have no issues! It does have a google keyboard and is google-based, which I do not mind. I would definitely buy this again, best money I have spent on a phone yet!

I've had this phone for about 7 months now and I really enjoy it for the money. I previously had an iPhone 6 plus that was just not aging well and needed a new phone but didn't want to pay the premium price. After looking around, I came across this one and took a chance.

I already knew I wanted to switch to Android so that wasn't an issue for me. I work in digital art so having a large screen mattered most and the screen size on this was bigger than my iPhone so that was a big relief. Finger print sensor on the back was much more convenient than on the front and I quickly got used to it. Love that it has expandable storage, a headphone jack, and is very thin and light weight. Not having fast charging or being water resistant isn't that important to me especially at this price point. I haven't had it previously, so I don't miss it. A lot of people are put off with it using micro USB instead of USB type C, but even as a former iPhone user I ended up with more micro USB cables than lightning cables so I'm actually glad I can put all those cables to use and don't have to carry different types when on the go. At the time of this review, most electronics and accessories still use them so it's fine for the time being.

Pictures come out alright but it seems like there is some kind of Instagram filter that makes everything paler and if anything moves slightly there will be a blur. Sound isn't great either and headphones don't make it any better, so audiophiles will be disappointed. My main issue with this phone is that we got the 3/32 version instead of the 4/64 version like other countries get. This phone lags and crashes frequently and I think the extra memory would've helped tremendously. I can fully understand having to cut corners and that there will be things that need to be comprised especially for what this phone costs, but if I know that other countries are getting a better version for roughly the same price then it's not going to get a five star review.

All in all, I am satisfied with my purchase and can't wait for the next model to come out. If you are like me and think that smartphones reached a level of refinement that works for you a few years back, then this is a great purchase.

At the beginning a five stars phone. It's nice; well designed, but one month later everything it's changing. The camera takes a long time to open. Sometimes the touch screen does not respond. The pictures quality's are not like a 16 mp camera. The Bluetooth connection works but I lose the connection with my smartwatch each 15 or less minutes. If I turn off the Bluetooth or the phone I can not reconect again the watch. I have to start pairing again and again several times. I do not recommend this phone. It's a nice face but it's like cheap Chinese phone.. Try Nokia; Samsung or other brands. I am sorry for my English.
Updating may 25: due problems with the bright I tried to send the phone to the warranty center. I had to call them about seven times and took them six days to send me a simple email with the return label shipping. I decided do not send because they do not like very serious . I do not recommend to buy this phone. The phone is good but if you need use the warranty you are going to find is not easy

Just got this yesterday and I really like the phone so far. Previously I had an LG G5 but, after less than 18 months, the fingerprint reader stopped working, the power button was iffy, the software seemed to be getting slower, and overall the phone became a paperweight; I couldn't even get it to properly connect to the Honor 7 to do a proper data transfer.

So far, the Honor 7 is worth more than it cost. The power button is separate from the fingerprint reader, and is actually in a good location on the side of the case. The inherent functionality of the OS is great. I can use fingerprint, double-tap, or power button to turn it on; the fingerprint reader doubles as a swiping mechanism to register gestures; the keypads can be changed for one-handed operation; etc.

The OS appears to receive updates fairly quickly from the mainline Android tree; I believe it was less than a week before Android Oreo was made available to users. An added plus, in my eyes, is the inclusion of a standard headphone jack; it's nice being able to use cheaper headphones rather than having to either carry a BT set with me, or buying multiple ones for home/work, with the inherent issue of charging.

The single biggest complaint I have now is the lack of USB-C, but that's only because the G5 had it and I was used to it. Using regular USB Micro isn't horrible, as I have plenty of cables available.

So far so good. Had this phone for almost 2 weeks and I think it is a good phone. This is an upgrade from Samsung Galaxy S5. I am not a super techy person and am past the point in my life when I was willing to pay big $$ for a flagship phone. I researched phones for awhile and decided to take a chance on the Honor 7X since the predecessor did pretty well. Glad I did. No regrets so far.

* UPDATE *

ALL MY FAULT. DROPPED IT ON CONCRETE WHILE NIGHT WALK WITH MY DOG. CRACKED MY SCREEN. DRATS! THIS WAS ONE OF THE BEST LOW END$ PHONE I'VE EVER PURCHASED. tip: I gave up on included clear case ... Never a problem ... Of course until it is hard dropped. KEEP CLEAR CASE ON ALWAYS.

UPDATE NOV 29 2018
Still very happy with the phone. I'm not a gamer, but the old school quick games do LAD (Zuma - color balls streaming ... Really lags. Free game worked on all other lesser phones, but that I notice (but for me, I don't care).

BATTERY still surprised me how fast it recharges. Great battery life. THIS BRAND HAS FLAWLESS! FINGERPRINT RECOGNITION!
Speakers could be louder, but not a tech, music, game, photo person.

UPDATE: OCT 2, 2018
>> Compared to 6x THIS HONOR 7X HAS WAY WAY WAY! BETTER CELL SERVICE/CONNECTION WITH T-MOBILE. So much better (works everywhere in my home, but with 6x, had many indoor dead spots). Great regular phone w/T-.obile. upped to 5 stars.

First: I have had excellent experience with the HONOR phones, unlocked, no service plan, but pay as you go via T-mobile has saved me a fortune.

HONOR 7: WAS VERY WITH HONOR 6X but with all new smart phones, they start out fast, and between APP updates, New Apps for new needs (smart door bell for example) .. it was just too burden and needy for better processor & ram (and a new phone seems the only way to get the BLOAT WEAR that unknowingly get into your system, hide, and slow everything.

I especially liked the idea of the larger screen on the honor7 over the 6x.

1. DON'T GET TOO EXCITED FOR THE LARGER SCREEN:
- you can choose to apply or not to each Android app. It is just more vertical space & MOST Android Apps are made for the normal non extended screen. It adds no usable space for MOST APPS
>> But it does leave an unused horizontal portion, that just perfectly accommodates those ANNOYING SPAMMY ADD POP UPS THAT HAVE MOVING IMAGES (LIKE CHERIES FROM A SLOT MACHINE with flashing in a narrow but edge to edeg box about the size of an empty headline box for review headlines.

THUS ... THE SIZE INCREASE IS NEUTRAL TO ANNOYING AND REALLY IRRITATING WITH SOME OF THE POPUPS.

ALSO, ALL THE VIDEOS I HAVE, OR HAVE WATCHED STREAMING, ALSO ARE FORMATTED FOR THE NORMAL SIZE PHONE SCREEN, SO MOST FULL SCREEN VIDEO WATCHING HAS TO BLACK "pillars" on each side of the video screen.

2. HONOR HAS LONG HAD THE MOST AMAZING FINGERPRINT TECH. IT ALWAYS READ A PRINT, ANALYSES IT ISLNSTANTLY, AND THE PHONE UNLOCKS. (side note, try washing your hand in hot water, dry them and the finger print I'd picks up the natural slight swelling of skin to hot water& and will reject your fingerprint until fully dry and cooled back down. It sounds bad, I just just think it's interesting).

PERFORMANCE:
it will take some time before you can even try out it's performance. There is a major update to 8.0 I think, along with having to get, migrate, transfer or reload all you apps and all but a few require screen name and password with no auto fill, for app after app, after app.

ME: THERE WERE TWO TERRIBLE GLITCHES DURING SETUP (I don't know what caused it) but apps we're popping open and closed, while others piled up open and freezing the screen all touch sensors and can only reboot with the full 15 second undisturbed constant hold my the power button.
It seems like a so what, but there is no warning, you phone and setup seem in peril, and may happen again.

BUT IN THE 36 or so hours since it was fully charged, there was much greater speed of apps & the ability to have more open at once than my previous 6x.

I will update as It goes. It is thinner and sleaker than the 6x, but I don't use my phone as a fashion accessory.
(and no matter how you transfer apps ... There is always that AMAZON not being "universal" with apps not bought/downloaded from Amazon app store ... Which leads me to forget, you have to find the Amazon app store app itself via the chrome browser and not via the Amazon Shopping Store App(s) that may be there. I wish Amazon would give up on trying to get a kind of Monopoly on their apps store. Google has so far exceeded and dominates Android apps, Amazon will never get anything but loyal Amazon customers like myself, repeatedly annoyed & irritated when some app gets pissy because you removed any one of several Amazon specific apps (I use Amazon for everything, but I still don't need or use all the apps and services Amazon offers. (I am not a reader, and if I did want to read one of the hundred of Amazon book stored in Amazon's cloud (all free and collected over years when a freebee book showed up) because I am now over 50 years old ... And people, it's real ... All the sudden and really fast they get bad, and daily it seems my vision worsens .. so a phone would been too hard to read from ( if I ever did read).

I would NOT say to run away from this phone if considering it, but neither would I give a full thumbs up as there are things yet to learn)

AS FOR FACIAL RECOGNITION. THE UPGRADE TO 8 HAS IT. IT'S KINDA D STUPID USELESS. FIRST YOU HAVE TO PUSH THE POWER BUTTON TO TELL THE PHONE TO TURN ON CAM AND CHECK (WHICH IT DOES FAST) BUT THE FINGERPRINT ID IS SO MUCH FASTER. A LIGHT SWIPE ALERTS THE PHONE TO CHECK ID, WHICH IS INSTANT. THE FACIAL RECOGNITION TAKES STEPS ... AND THEN IT SHOWS YOU OWN PIC WHEN CONFIRMED. I AM NOT PHOTOGENIC AND A BAD SELFIE LOOKING AT ME WHEN I TURN MY PHONE ON EACH TIME IS NOT ENJOYABLE AT ALL)

I absolutely love being able to flex to friends and coworkers that I paid $200 for the same features that they have on their $1k phones. The phone is very stable and smooth, the aesthetics are great. The UI is awesome and clean, at the same time as very customizable. I 11/10 would recommend this phone to anybody and everybody. Huawei should be a AAA brand alongside with Apple and Samsung.

The only cons to this phone that i've noticed after a few months is maybe the picture quality when zooming is a little rough, and the on-board speakers are a big OOF; but honestly are you going to ever use the built in speakers?
Great phone for $200. Comes with a clear tpu case as well. Very nice android phone for the price. Just don't expect too much, does have occasional hiccups on some apps.

This is the most expensive phone I've ever bought so perhaps take my review with a grain of salt. I absolutely LOVE it. Normally I don't pay more than $50-$100 for a phone, but I can definitely see what I've been missing out on. It's lightning quick and I noticed that people were complaining about the camera, but I think it's excellent and it fascinates me how it can give me a crisp, detailed image upon max zooming in on an object.

I was debating between this and the Mate SE, but I didn't want to pay $50 more for just a 1 GB RAM upgrade. 3 GB RAM is more than enough for what I need. I also bought a 128 GB microSD card to bump up total storage to 160 GB for my music and pictures.

FYI this fits 2 nano-sims and 1 microSD. My carrier is Lycamobile.

This phone was great, I bought it four months ago and it worked very nicely except for a couple Bluetooth and lag hiccups. Nothing terrible. Then all of a sudden it started rebooting randomly and now it barely turns on before it reboots. Terrible.
Amazing phone for $200 this is my second one had the 5x now 7x is fast I don't need a$500 phone looks great feels great and fast

I am using honor 7x from last 7 days. I am very satisfied after using this. I was using samsung galaxy j7 prime, but suddenly it's mother board crashed. It was asking for $150 to replace that, I was searching all the way and came across about honor 7x. At first I was bit hesitant, after reading reviews I purchased this, with $200, it is really a flagship phone. Camera quality is pretty good both front and back. It has finger sensor, face sensor, pattern match, security lock code. It is very sleek mode, pretty first as per performance, very good looking, touch screen is very sensitive which I personally like very much. Even I installee 2 3 games and it did not degrade any performance.
Though some of the features has some challenges like it does not have oled display which we can bear without that,
It doesnot contain snapdragon, battery charging is not fast. But battery stays long with this phone.
So for overall honor 7x is a hit model according to me and it is really worth to have a phone like this in this money.

Screen: The screen is bright and colorful, but I think it's LCD and not IPS as the viewing angles aren't the best, but even then it looks fine.

Camera: The default camera app is trash. I downloaded HedgeCam2 and activated Camera2 API and some advanced options like saving in RAW. In this mode, the pictures are really sharp and clear after editing them in Lightroom Mobile (Snapseed works well too). It makes the pics taken in the default app look like they were taken with a potato, especially in low light conditions. I really recommend taking your time to do this as the phone takes better pictures that you may realize at first glance.

The Dual Camera is a joke as it doesn't look that good, the blurry part looks more like it's 5 Mpix than 16. Honestly, it's just there for marketing, like in most budget phones, but if you're into blurry effects on your selfies, I guess you can get some use out of it.

Video: Limited to 1080p by the default camera app, you can go a bit higher with an app like HedgeCam2 (2048x1080 or 2K).

Speed: Seems fluid so far, but that's because it's new. I will update this review as it gets slower (or not) after some use.

Customization: This phone comes with EMUI and I'm not a fan of it, but it works well. Hopefully, future updates will make it better.

The main things you look for in a phone these days: Screen, camera, speed, stability. All of it is fine on this phone and for 200$ that's great, the camera is a win if you take your time to learn how to get the most out of it.

P.D: This is not my phone, it's my sister's, but I tested it just like if it were mine.

I got the Honor 7x because I really enjoyed the 5x. The first 5 months were great. Then I started getting GPS lost, which while annoying wasn't a total deal breaker. Now (month 8) the phone is completely unusable. The phone will randomly freeze up with any amount of usage and reboot for anywhere from 12 to 45 minutes. And good look trying to get Huawei/Hihonor to honor the warranty.

If you check messages or change tracks from your lock screen ignore this phone. Huawei makes it impossible to expand notifications on the lock screen with their recent updates. Oh, but Android allows apps to create different groups of notifications so that player notifications don't get collapsed with other app notifications right? Nope. Huawei decided to group all app notifications regardless of what app developers specify. Ok, but you can disable non-player notifications so your music/podcast player doesn't get collapsed into them right? Nope, that _is_ an option, but if you disable one notification type on the lock screen, it disables all lock screen notifications for that app, because apparently Huawei just puts out broken software.

Uless Huawei stops breaking Android, I absolutely can't recommend this phone.

So far so good. It booted fine, ran through the setup and got me logged into Google. The expected bloatware was there naturally but I was surprised to be able to uninstall a lot of it. It came with Android 7.0, but 8 was available for immediate download. One thing I'm really liking is the fingerprint sensor. It's on the back where your index finger naturally finds it and unlocking the phone that way is very fast and easy. The only hitch I had was my old sim is a micro sim and this phone requires a nano sim. I'll have to go to the Cricket store and get a new one.

Edit: The Oreo and GUI download went just swimmingly and Cricket was glad to charge me $10.50 for a SIM card. One thing I can't get working though is the notification LED. It works when charging, but I can't get it to flash for any notifications. I Googled the problem and one solution was to wipe the cache partition. That didn't work, although I did get a bunch of texts that hadn't come through before. Today I did a factory reset and that didn't work either. It's in the software someplace. Maybe they'll fix it with an update at some point.

Edit 2: Apparently the Notification LED only works with the screen off. I got red, blue, and green to work with Chomp.

Edit 3. I get much better reception with this phone than I did with my LG-G4. Usually 1 to 2 bars better in fringe areas.

I will only ever be in the low end of Android phones, but this really is a good phone, and great for the price. (Prime Day deal!!)
Going from a Moto G3, I really am pleased at how much faster things run on this phone. I actually do like their version of Android.

I'm pleasantly surprised by the camera as well. I would imagine that anyone who's had an iPhone or Pixel would find it to be slow or whatever. But this is just a nice little phone that takes decent pics, and allows me to run several apps without it crashing. I imagine heavy duty gamers and such would probably not enjoy it, I just want to be able to listen to music and have one or two other apps running.

This is a GREAT Android device for the price. We were hesitant as the on line reviews trashed the camera, but that's just NOT true. This camera is great. Takes nice NORMAL pictures. We are not too interested in taking photos in the dark, or underwater... just nice family event photos. This one excels at everything. Great screen, good looks, fast processor and a fast fingerprint scanner to unlock the device.
The ONLY thing that MAY be a deal breaker for some is the lack of NFC. Google Pay won't work here.
It also is a dual sim phone but we elected to put in a 128GB Micro SD card into that slot. This, together with the 32 GB on board, gives us a total of 160 GB of storage.
No dumb "Bloatware" either... almost a pure android OS that we came to love over some manufacturer's "skins" that do nothing more than duplicate what Google has already done... and done much better too.
Friends have already mistaken it for a new "Something, Something 9" phone that costs $500. more.
Nope.... and we are very happy that it is what it is.

(OLD REVIEW NEW ONE BENEATH)I'm ONLY giving this device 3 stars because it's so pretty! The screen is just gorgeous, and on first impressions (just got it in the mail) but man...it won't let me connect to wifi so not sure what to do now. I've been googling stuff for a few hours with no luck. So yeah :/

OKAY SO AN UPDATE: It connected to the wifi like right after this but I wanted to wait a bit before updating this review just in case. ALSO want to add: this baby has amazing standby; I literally leave it on when I leave for work in the morning, and returning at 7pm it still has between 100-98% So yeah...definitely keeping for the moment. Only thing is, when I restart the device sometimes it takes a couple tries before it connects. So yeah.
This is probably the best phone I have ever owned. Coming from a Samsung Galaxy S5 is like going from a Corolla to a Porshe!

First of all build quality is on par with flagships. Fingerprint reader works great, screen is great and visible in direct sunlight. Battery holds up all day with plenty to spare with non gaming use and the processor is fast. The camera is excellent, it works well in low light and the dual cameras bokeh effect is spot-on. Zero regrets with this purchase.

I bought this as a prime deal and paid $166 for it. This outperforms my old iPhone 5C in nearly every way. I would give it 5 stars if it weren't for the slow charging battery and the less than ideal sound quality. When you use the aux Port with headphones the sound quality is reeeeeally bad, even with the best quality headphones. It sounds like an old radio. No bass, and no fullness to the sound. But even though the battery charged slowly it is very long lasting. I would say this is a solid 4/5 star product.

The photos are clear, selfies mode has a built in beauty filter that evens your skin tone and such. There's a fingerprint unlock feature on the back of the phonr, very cool. I love the blue color, and the screen is huge. Also, as a bonus, the box included a clear silicone case and a lanyard. I still got a separate case for it anyway, but it's great that they included that.
I highly recommend this product. But be sure to buy a case and screen protector.

Just arrived - review might change after some use. But, first impressions are that this is a very nice, near flagship quality phone. In the past, I've had Samsungs, Xiaomis, a variety of off-brand (in the US market, at least) phones like Cubot, etc... and this is the only phone I've used so far that seems to rival the 2nd gen Xiaomi that I was using a few years ago.

I promised myself after my last phone (a vendor-locked Samsung Galaxy S7) that I would never again purchase a US market phone, nor a Korean branded phone - I have no idea how most Americans tolerate the crap Samsung & their telecom cronies sell. I am not disappointed in this decision.

FYI: I live in the US (rural New England) and get adequate 4G LTE service via AT&T. Any issues with connectivity are - as I know from much experience - AT&T's fault, not any manufacturer. However, service overall is 10x better with an unlocked phone. You'll be sorry if you put that SIM into a US-market retail phone from AT&T!!! Buy unlocked!

The phone was ok. I have mostly used high spec flagship phones but I needed a phone in a pinch but this want what I wanted. There was quite a few things to like about this phone, like the finger print reader on the back which is super fast and accurate. The screen brightness was good fit a lower end phone.
But just after a few days the phone started to feel laggy. I don't much care for the EMUI skin that Huawei puts on top of Android. I feel like this may have been one of the reasons for the lag. I bought another phone that was cheaper with no skin on top of Android Avd they was running Android 8.0 Avd ir Geely like it ran another then this one. I have since passed out in to my daughter but she still is quite enjoying that phone.
Great display, takes Micro Sd, has Gorilla Glass, & comes with clear case in the box. Very happy with my decision to buy the Honor 7X!

This is a wonderful phone. I'm a tech person and the phone works flawlessly with big ram the screen is very beautiful and big the battery is very large last me about whole day. Definitely would buy a again

Great phone for the price. I definitely miss a few thing about my old phone this one doesn't have. Like copy and paste drawer and it connectivity issue to WiFi and Bluetooth. But for $200 but deal out there

This is the absolute best phone at the current price mark. If you like multitasking however, depending on the apps you are using, you might have some issues with speed. I used a remote desktop app to control numerous computers while on the phone, and noticed significant lagging. However most phones would be much slower under that kind of workload. For the everyday user, this phone is an amazing buy. Do not listen to people when they say that this phone does not take good pictures and video. Out of the box, it is great for pics and vids. There are plenty of apps that can take the camera to higher levels of quality as well. The only thing I do not like about having this phone is.....Huawei does not issue updates quickly or consistently for the US version of this phone. All other versions seem to get updates, but not the United States version. Outside of this small issue, the phone is a must buy for anyone on a budget. Huawei has the potential to take over the US market, provided our government allows them to make deals with the major phone carriers. Go ahead if you are thinking about this......and buy this phone. You will love it!

My wife needed a replacement phone after her Nexus 6P was biting the dust with its abysmal battery life. We got the Honor 7X on Prime Day and also bought screen protectors and a couple cases -- we paid right at $200 for everything. I transferred her data and disabled the minimal bloatware on the phone. It runs like a dream for a $200 phone with little to no lag for everyday usage. She plays Pokemon GO and some other casual games (Catan, Ticket to Ride, etc.) on it and they run butter smooth. The screen is fantastic for the price and colors pop out. Battery is probably the best feature though -- she is able to consistently have quite a bit of battery left by the end of the day after moderate usage (playing Pokemon GO, Facebook, Instagram, YouTube, etc.). This phone honestly holds its own against 2018 flagships and is a far better deal. Think of it this way -- for the price of a Galaxy Note 9, you can have 5-6 Honor 7X phones. It blows my mind that you can get this quality of phone for such a low price now.

This phone is an amazing value! I took my SIM card out of my other phone and placed it in my Honor 7X and it just...worked. Towards the end of my work day, my signal was in and out.
