In my comparing, the iPhone 7 has 4k video recording, and 1080p recording with the front facing camera. However, the front facing camera of this Mate SE has 720p recording which is still high quality. The Mate SE does not film in 4k, however, in my opinion, it makes up for this with the variable apperture. The screen for the Mate SE is very large and has a good brightness with auto-brightness adjustment sensitivity. It is very clear and responsive to your touch. Day to day tasks are a breeze, email, internet, YouTube, etc. You will enjoy your new phone, even if your coming from the top brands.

P.s. this phone has a document explorer with a great UI. I know this will come in handy for downloading files and reopening them.

Overall I rate 5 ð. You just can't beat the quality for price.
My GPS stopped working and when I sent it in for repair, I received a notice indicating it had been damaged by liquid. The phone has never sustained any damage by liquid.

Totally blown away....... I was going to buy a Samsung S9 and so glad I didn't pull the trigger. This phone has to be the biggest secret out there. I had no idea that budget phones were of this quality. Seriously, this looks and feels like a $900 phone. I couldn't be more pleased.......if you are on the fence on buying this, don't hesitate.

I've had the phone for a couple of weeks now and I love it. Fingerprint sensor is instantaneous, the phone is fast as heck, the camera takes incredible photos, the bluetooth has good range and is dependably stable. I bought another case but haven't even unpackaged it because I like the clear gel case that comes with it so much. Plenty of memory to keep everything snappy. And enough room to load more than I need. The price is unbeatable and I couldn't be happier with this phone. If there's a better phone in this price range I haven't seen it.

Not much to add as far as what others have already said about this phone. I too was coming off a 3 year old Galaxy S6 Edge which is now in its time to fail period. This phone blows it away in almost every aspect and the S6 was the premium flagship that outclassed the previous versions by quite a lot. Now budget phones are beating the former best phones on the market not that long ago, truly amazing. This modified Android I actually like better then stock, it's simple and intuitive. Internet, fingerprint reader, everything is just fast! Love that it still has a straight headphone jack! Don't you dare change that please!
Camera is more then good enough but I'm not a picture fanatic so it might not work for those looking for real high end photos from a phone. The AMOLED screen of the old Galaxies are still better then this but not enough to not still make this phone overall better hardware/price wise. The only con I see is not directly related to the phone, and that is case availability. I used to love that Otterbox Defender with a built in screen protector available for previous Galaxy versions. Sadly Otterbox has mostly given up on that and making cases for any other manufacturers besides Apple and Samsung. I ordered a soft pouch for extra protection. I do like that this is a plus size phone, I will never go back to smaller. Buy this phone, you will not be disappointed.

I got this phone yesterday on 6/2/18 and am mostly very pleased. I will update if things change but here's my initial opinion on this phone.

Screen/display: 10/10 - crisp, bright, beautiful display. It reminds me of using an iPhone OS.

Speed: 10/10- no lags, fingerprint sensor opens lightning fast. No hiccups so far. I like that I can add multipe fingerprints and can use the fingerprint to open certain secure apps on my phone.

GPS: 6/10 - I've only used it once, but I think it was a little uncertain as to where I was. Good thing I actually knew where I was going. But GPS is something I highly depend on so I'm a little disappointed. Will use more and update as needed.

------ 6/5/18 UPDATE: GPS 10/10 - I've since changed some settings on my GPS to make it more accurate. It is very fast with finding my location,and re-routing if necessary, and GPS signal seems to be accurate.

Camera: 7/10 -coming from a Blu studio one which took pretty decent pics (I think was 12 mp) and a Samsung Galaxy amp prime which took very average pictures (with an even lower mp rating), I'm not overly impressed or disappointed. The camera is ok, but nothing too incredible in my opinion.

Sound: 5/10 - I feel this is very quiet. I had alarms wake me which I barely heard. I turned the volume up so we will see if that solves. Sound clarity on calls appears decent. As someone who connects phone to car via Bluetooth daily, I was pretty disappointed in lack of bass while playing songs. I will test it out more and update accordingly.

Battery: 8/10 - I got the phone about 60% charged and when I went to charge to 100, it took at least 2-3 hours. I was surprised at how slowly it seemed to charge. I slept with it on the charger last night since I like to start the day at 100% so today will be the first day on full battery to test the battery life.

------ 6/5/18 UPDATE: Battery 9.5/10. I just used my phone from 100% to 2% (it wouldn't discharge below that, and gave a 30 second warning stating the phone was shutting off because the battery is empty). It lasted 2 full days ( I was hoping I could get 2.5 or 3 days) without additional charging and that it with a lot of screen-on time surfing the web, downloading apps, social media, etc (nothing too heavy like gaming). While I was at work today I did not check my phone however the charge seemed to stay pretty much put as I hoped it would do (even with syncs, wifi, GPS/location, and Bluetooth all turned on). I have had phones that would discharge as much as 10-20% just sitting in my purse/locker untouched. Also, I put it on the charger tonight when it died and it charged up from 2% to 75% in less than 1 hour. I'm not sure why the initial partial charge took so long, but this seems promising!

Again, I've had the phone for less than 24 hours, so this is just my initial review and will change as I use and experience it more.

They want you to agree to give up all of your information to their company and affiliates in order to use their phone any way they want to and can change the terms at anytime and do whatever they want to with your information. There isn't any other way to bypass it. If you value your privacy, don't get this phone. It is amazing how many people have no problem trading their info for a cheaper phone. I had no idea they were going to do that when I bought this, but I'm returning the phone.

Overall I'm pleased with the phone. It has just about every feature I'd want at a price point that is sane. Updated to Oreo right away. Not perfectly responsive but way better than I'm used to. I've read about a lot of problems with Huawei and Fitbit devices, but my Charge 2 seems to be working fine after some patience with it's first sync. EMUI is fine; just a different flavor of essentially the same stuff as stock Android. A nice surprise was FM radio is supported with wired headphones plugged in and a preloaded app. Also it comes with a decent clear case.

Can't necessarily complain about it having USB micro, non-AMOLED screen, GSM only, single speaker. If you want the whole enchilada go buy a phone that is four times the price.

My few unpleasant surprises:
* The biggest one: no support for wake with "Ok Google". You'll have to press a button on screen every time you want to give voice commands. I actually miss this from my Nexus 5X that died and kind of expect it on any Android phone now. Kind of a big deal. Otherwise this might have been five stars.
* The automatic screen brightness tends to adjust too dark fairly often and I need to turn it back up.
* Bluetooth seems to stutter audio streams randomly (half second of silence then continued audio occasionally) but not often or consistent enough to warrant returning the phone.
* Camera is not great for low light or even moderate motion is bright daylight. Your dog will need to be still if you want crisp pictures.
* Huawei has their own OS-integrated versions of basic apps such as contacts, dialer, SMS, music that you can't uninstall. Whatever though. Maybe someday we'll get stock Android.

So this is the 3rd or 4th phone I've ordered from Amazon lately. The first ones simply died/froze up all of a sudden. Just got this one a few days and it's operating OK so far. HOWEVER, I've discovered it doesn't support 5G Wifi, which I just assumed ALL phones did now. AND I just discovered it doesn't support Wifi calling, which, again, I thought ALL phones supported. So this means if I'm in an area where the cell coverage is weak, too bad. I can, and do, have an excellent Wifi router, which I could use to make Wifi calls with many, many other phones, but not this one. Back to the drawing board or, more likely, another retailer, and I am an AVID Amazon shopper. More lessons learned, the hard way..

There is no other way to put it, this is an excellent device at excellent value. The only complaint I have is the confusion with how many devices there are from Huawei for different markets. I purchased 2 phones BEFORE this one. First a Nexus 6P (more for Google, but because Huawei built this phone I was more comfortable trying a pure Huawei phone afterwards) then an Honor 7X. This is where I had some trouble, because I purchased the international version, which was not made clear as to what networks it supports in the U.S, and many different websites have conflicting information based on whether you pull up the 3GB RAM model VS the 4GB RAM model. It's difficult to have confidence in your purchase when buying elsewhere, but buying the Mate SE from Amazon definitely gave me security and confidence in the choice I was making.

As for the device. WOW... I knew I wanted to get it for the extra gig of ram and the Octa-core processor, but this phone continues to impress. I haven't had a single hick-up or issue with anything so far, if it weren't for the network issue I would have never gotten rid of the 4GB RAM 7X, the Mate SE makes you very happy that Huawei is working with American distributors because this is a very underrated device. Shipped and arrived next-day, effortless sync, Android experience is smooth, and I do like the skins though I haven't changed any themes myself. Camera is ultra-responsive, finger-print is incredibly accurate and unlocks quicker than half-a second, which is hard to comprehend for the price and something I noticed was also equally responsive on the 7X. Just overall incredibly impressed. Oh and there's a free case which ships with the phone as well, which is just an unexpected plus that makes you happy you chose to support this company.

In all honesty, I feel like if OnePlus weren't trying to compete on upper-tier financial markets they would be cranking out phones like this no problem, but they're missing a chance to compete with yet another market that is making unparalleled devices for an unbelievable cost. For the first time my phone has as much RAM as my laptop and I didn't pay too much...

This is a great phone! Apps are fast, it's great at multitasking, and battery life is pretty good. Some things took a bit of tweaking to get right, which I never had to do on my Moto G phones, but now that it's setup more or less completely, it's just a pleasure to use. I got the gold color, love it, and the clear plastic case that came with it is really very good too. I also got Oreo 8.0 just about right away, against what the reviewers had said. The phone is a little bigger than I wanted, but it's really easy to handle and the back fingerprint reader is perfect. I highly recommend this phone!

Oh my goodness I love this phone. Why would you play 700 800-900 $1,000 for a phone when you can get this one. It's fast it's easy. I love it much more than my Samsung S6. I have Cricket as my carrier and all I did was take the SIM card out of my S6 and put it into this phone. I'm very very pleased with this phone

Good phone for the money with one MAJOR flaw for me. This phone can't stream to Bluetooth and do WiFi at the same time. WiFi speeds become unusable. Tried to figure out why. Looks like they share the same antennae on the phone. Bummed out as I use Bluetooth headsets daily. (I have had other budget phones that handle the Bluetooth and WiFi issue just fine.) Other than this it's a good phone for the money. Surprised because the build quality other than this is good.

2nd radio/issue found - GPS. GPS is less accurate than other phones. I compared to 4 other phones I own and this one is the furthest out of calibration/inaccurate. I expected it to not be as good as my Samsung Note 5 but it also got beat by a phone half it's price. If GPS is something you depend on (especially in the vertical/alt side) then this may not be the phone for you. I tried with 2 different Mate SE's and both have the same problem. Maybe they can add some correction in software but I am assuming it is an antennae / metal body issue.

So much about this phone is great but it really struggles on radios which is essential to a phone. Disappointed because otherwise would be great!

I upgraded from the Motorola Nexus 6 (2014). I wanted a phone with good specs that would be a significant upgrade, however I was not willing to pay the price of a laptop for a cellphone. I believe these Huawei phones represent an excellent value due to the current state of trade relations between the US and China. Because of political uncertainty, Huawei has had to alter their original plans of distributing their phones via popular US retailers like Best Buy. They are basically selling direct to consumer now. I'm guessing that Huawei probably has too much inventory on hand since the Best Buy deal fell through. Without marketing or any significant US brand-recognition, these phones are selling CHEAP. You might think there's something wrong with them... there's not. This is a great device! I'm considering buying a second one just to have as a backup. Huawei and Foxconn (Taiwan based manufacturer that handles a lot of the manufacturing for Apple) work closely together. I believe they even share some of the same factory space.

The phone takes two SIM cards at once, it's globally unlocked, and it doesn't come with too much Huawei customization to the stock Android experience. I disabled all the Huawei apps from receiving updates and changed the default preferences back to the Google apps. The only thing I wish this phone had is wireless charging, and that I can live without for a $200 iPhone clone. Oh, it uses regular USB instead of a lightning connector, and even has a standard headphone jack... image that!

Take my advice and give it a try, if you don't like it return it.
it worked for 2 hours and went black after that.

Bought this for my wife after her Samsung finally gave up the ghost. I am one of those cranky old farts that feels cellphone prices are close to obscene. That being said I did some pretty extensive research on affordable phablets/phones and kept coming up with Huawei. While it lacks some of the uber cutting edge whiz-bangery of the latest iFarce or Samsung Pocket Lighter, it does have an excellent camera and a processor that is fast enough to work any app one would use.
Aesthetically pleasing, easy to work and about five hundred bucks less than one of the previously mentioned overpriced over-hyped wallet rapers, this phone strikes a sweet spot for those of us that need performance without paying Ferrari prices for a dang phone.

Hi everyone, this is my first review EVER on Amazon but I figured it is worth the time. I recently purchased the Huawei Mate SE - first of all, it arrived earlier than expected so that was great. Once I received it, I noticed that the phone is just a tiny bit bigger than what I am usually used to but this is no biggy - you get used to it pretty fast. I ordered it in gold and I am loving it so far - the camera is very nice and takes great, crisp pictures. I honestly bought it because I wanted a phone with a larger memory, good camera and bokeh effect (lol). This is the first time I am purchasing a Huawei phone but the reviews on here and other websites really convinced me and so far, no regrets. I do have friends that own iPhones so I can say portrait mode isn't as perfect or fast as on iPhones but the pictures do turn out pretty nice once you get the hang of it. Let's bear in mind that this is a $220 phone vs a $900-$1,000 phone. Oh and BIG PLUS! The battery life really is AMAZING, it charges super fast, and not just because it is a brand new phone. The Huawei boasts its long-lasting battery charge in its latest phones, and I can definitely confirm :)

I hope this helps you make your decision - If I had had more budget, I would have gone with the Huawei Mate 9 or 10 Pro (with Leica cam and so forth) but I am so pleased with my purchase so far.

Taking nasty ugly photos. If you are camera lover. Don't buy this. My friend have Huawei ascend xt2, it takes beautiful photos and videos. He bought as a deal of 40 dollars in Thanksgiving. After seeing his Huawei ascend xt2, I thought higher end of Huawei mate se will be pretty good for camera, also by seeing reviews in Amazon. Those who gave good reviews must be for the slim and sleek shiny look of the phone, but definitely not for the camera. Worst phone for camera I have ever seen and also screen brightness is not good. Huawei ascend xt2 is much much worth than this phone.

There are dozens upon dozens of reviews singing the praises of this phone, and I don't disagree with most of them nor will I repeat those accolades. But there are issues.

Bluetooth, generally:
I connected this phone via bluetooth on three devices: two car radios (factory Toyota, Pioneer AVH-270BT, Bose Soundsport headphones). It runs into two issues with all three devices:
1. The range is terrible. Get any further than a few feet from the paired device (e.g., putting the phone on the seat of the car, or leaving the phone on a desk and walking a few feet away) and the signal drops out.
2. It stops working after two days. It will connect, but you can't hear anything nor can anyone hear you (if you're attempting to make a phone call). Rebooting the phone fixes that issue.
(These issues also plagued my Huawei Honor 5x).

Bluetooth, in video messaging apps:
It doesn't work for Facebook messenger or Whatsapp. You can hear the dialing tone through the headset, but that's it. They can't hear you, you can't hear them. I have to disable/disconnect the bluetooth device to use video chat. Uninstalling / reinstalling the apps, factory resetting the phone - none of those things resolves that issue.

Bluetooth and Wifi:
You've read about this ad nauseum. I have issues with streaming music and web browsing - it (at least for me) prioritized the bluetooth stream over loading the webpage (which, I guess if I had to make a choice, I'd make that one).

Camera:
Terrible. It is perfectly serviceable if you have no intent to look at photos on anything other than on the phone itself. Printing photos or viewing them on higher resolution devices isn't advisable. You can make a pinhole camera that takes better photos.

Speaker:
Think of it as an earpiece on the bottom of the phone. Don't expect it to be a serviceable speakerphone anywhere except in a quiet room.

Screen:
Perfectly fine if the image or text is static. It has ghosting issues when you scroll or watch fast moving videos (e.g., football / basketball / hockey highlights). Brightness and colors are fine, though.

Included jelly case:
This case makes the phone more slippery than a wet bar of soap. I think Huawei intended for you to drop the phone repeatedly and upgrade to the Mate View 10. Sneaky, Huawei, very sneaky.

Okay, those are the negatives. Positives:

Android OS, EMUI: Oreo runs beautifully. It was actually a joy to use the device on a daily basis (outside of the above issues).

Headphone jack: 1. It exists. 2. It sounds fine for earbuds.

GPS: Surprisingly excellent. I've had no issues in the city or suburbs. Google Maps with the PIP works very well.

Fingerprint reader: surpasses everyone, including LG and Samsung.

Space: 64GB with a MicroSD slot? Good lord.

Battery: It can go nearly two days easily.

Device: classic iPhone style, copied by Huawei perfectly. Improves upon the iPhone design with the inclusion of a headphone jack. It looks like a premium device, and feels solid in your hand.

Call quality: Great. I used it on AT&T's network. No issues getting LTE coverage everywhere I normally received LTE coverage. Calls sounded good over BT (when it worked) and over the headset.

Even cell phone pros were impressed. I had my reservations, I have had quite a few smartphones over the years, and have only owned the Nexus 6p from Huawei. They had improved significantly from the 6p. Buttons have good feel, phone is snappy, software is decent. Camera quality is pretty good, but slightly overexposed in my short time with it.

Bought for my mother in law, and there was no sense in getting a $1,000 phone that will mostly be used for calling. For what it is, I could genuinely see using this phone as a daily driver if I were short on cash. Obviously I prefer my Pixel 2 XL, but I can tell you this is one darn decent phone. Battery is above my expectations as well. Screen is bright, and big. Easier on older eyes with the Android software letter increase size.

If you're looking for something "good enough", this phone is a hit. Politically, I don't care what Uncle Sam says about the espionage potential of Huawei. If you are worried about that, avoid smartphones in general. Could snag up a big roll o tin foil too....

Update 2/13/19:
My mother in law is still using this phone daily on TMobile. This phone has exceeded my expectations in every capacity. Battery life is superb for the light user. Camera quality is good, albeit far from modern quality like Pixel 2/3 or iPhone. For someone who won't be super picky, or needs an affordable replacement, this phone is one viable way to go.

the bad first...Lag, choppy graphics and freezes up for a few up to 30 seconds at a time when playing SOME games. and if you try to use a screen recorder when playing one of those games its 5x as bad and makes some games unplayable, on games that do not support the wider screen ratio that this has there is a black bar across the side of the screen right next to your game controls, and that would be fine except if you touch this black bar and when your hitting the touch screen game control's you are definitely going to hit this black bar and if you touch it, it will restart the game and put it into full screen mode which you cant play the game that game in anyways whoever though this was a good idea should be fired, for games that support the wide ratio you dont have this issue. When holding the phone sideways to play games or take video your fingers will often cover the microphone and speakers which is also a terrible design and you hear horrible sounds just from hour hand moving around near it when you play back the recording... i tried out the FM radio and not one, and i do mean not one station came in good, they all cut in and out and full of static.. i have a moto G4 which is not said to be a very good phone and it does have some issues butt its does not have any of these problems but it will disconnect from wifi occasionally causing issues for me on most all games i try to play if i am on wifi.. if it was not for that issue i would say the G4 is awesome... All these reviews are saying the mate SE is just as good as flag ship phones, i guess they are right and they are wrong, now the good stuff

The Good
for most games its good to very good, the phone is very quick and snappy in general use, it has lots of nice features you can turn on the phone like it counts my steps when i walk and it did that right out of the box and some other cool stuff i found in the settings and what not, seems to work great for calling people and texting, super long battery life (if not gaming allot) charges pretty fast for not supporting fast charging, plenty of storage, the camera is the best in low light i have seen in a phone so far and takes good photos, i have a DSLR and a bunch of lenses, it cant compare to that but if i need to get some photos in a pinch this is nice and does a pretty good job so far. your average person would probably love this thing. for the price i guess you cant complain too much.

now this thing is not as good as my old motoX pure edition phone, in some ways its not as good as my moto G4 and in other ways its way better than my G4, if it had a front facing speaker and mic and played all games equally well and did not have the weird side bar you do not want to touch when playing a game but its in a spot where your almost guaranteed to touch it (if the game does not support the wide aspect ratio) i would really love this phone i think

I've had this phone several weeks and I love it. My battery lasts in to the second day. I surf the internet quickly and effortlessly, the camera is better then adequate, the response time is lightning quick, gaming (though I don't do much) has no lag time, and as a phone and texter absolutely no complaints. Is it as good as a flagship phone? No. There is a reason they cost three and four times as much. The thing is I don't need whatever those reasons are. And that's what you should be asking yourself. Is it ego, or do I really need that flagship phone? Because if you don't then buy this one. It's a great performer, with a fabulous display and a build that should last a very long time.

I am giving this phone a one star because although I like the phone, this is my second one. Amazon send me a replacement phone but I'm still having the same problem and it's really rediculous. I don't have no mobile data on the phone. No, it's not my SIM card either. I've tried putting my SIM card in another phone in it works just fine. This phone makes you update the phone when you first get it. After doing so, all of a sudden the mobile data doesn't work anymore. Mind you I'm still paying for data. I'm so disappointed you have no idea. Has anyone else had this problem?

Ok so I'm terribly rough on phones. A decent ones last me a year hopefully. This one has been great so far. Only complaint is Android auto doesn't seem to work. Tried two different cables and keep getting a no connection error. The thing that sold me to buy another::;
I crushed this phone with a pressure tank to the shape a mild c. I was pretty upset after having it only two weeks. Picked it up and the screen was not cracked. In fact I bent it back to almost normal shape and it is amazingly working as normal still. No glitches screen cracks or anything. This is almost as bullet proof a phone as any I've seen. Super glad I'm not replacing it already. Specs seem good and all loads and downloads seem fast and equivalent to an upper end smart phone. Bottom line is I will need to buy one for when I inevitably kill this one but for now, a 400 lb pressure tank didn't kill it so I'm pretty happy.

I bought this phone because it has a legit specs under $250 price tag and it didn't disappoint indeed. The phone is impressive compare to samsung's pricy android phones. I've been a Samsung user for years and i would choose this phone over it. The reason I give this phone 4 stars out of 5 is, it doesn't support NFC, a tool for android pay which the latest Samsung phones have. Aside from that, I don't see any advantage the pricy Samsung Galaxy phones have over this great budget phone. Lastly, with regard about the spying allegations on it's makers, I think it's ridiculous! For sure the pricy competetors out there has a real reason to get nervous about how good this company from China make their phone with a budget price tag. Samsung's phone for example is 4x more expensive. Established company phone makers here in the US doesn't want this product getting noticed I think. Spying concerns? Come on! We all know they've been doing it for years already. It's about $ concerns in my opinion. Peace!

The phone is fast. Pros: decent camera, nice UI (flashlight available with 1 swipe), fast enough with 8 cores (comparable to 630). Cons: It gets warm when using Skype, fonts might get too small to read.

I am not crazy about 18:9 aspect ratio. With that being said, other than the top part of phone getting warm during Skype, I have no issues. Netflix, Amazon Video all are ok. I have not tried any games so no idea how hot this thing can get or what it can do if you are into games. The Wifi does not come with 5Ghz.

Overall, it's a pretty decent phone, wish Huawei releases Android Oreo soon.

Negatives, I ordered the phone when it was 249.99 and now it is on sale for 229.99. I have asked if I could get a 20$ credit and the customer rep snickered and laughed. This is actually quite common which i do it at Costco. At that point, I have realized how little I meant, for a retail giant like Amazon. I'd suggest buying this phone from a merchant with a local presence so you are not stuck paying UPS shipping cost if you need to return it.

I bought this phone on May. I was very confortable with the choice because except for the camera wich is no good at all ( i was not excpecting something great for the price) , it was running fast and battery would last for a whole day and even to next morning.
Well, the battery suddenly started to perform really bad and it doesn't last for more than 10 hours with regular used.
As for the signal problemas i got to say it's true. I don't Know why but when i leave a place where i've been using wifi ,phone usually has some issues to get 4g data.
So, it's a good phone for the price but it has some issues that i find really unconfortable.

For the Price this is not a bad budget mid range phone. VOLTE works on Mint Mobile (mvno of T-Mobile). This phone does not support WIFI calling. It does have T-Mobile bands 2,4,12 - but is missing 66 and 71 for other main bands used. With that said I have not had a connection issue in my location. Out of the Box this phone updated to Oreo 8.0.0.341(C567). With Huawei budget phones though I am not sure how long they will support updates though. Unfortunately Huewei does not allow unlocked bootloaders as of this spring so keeping the phone up to date in the long run with Community Builds is not an option. Overall the phone does have 64 gb storage for a 2018 budget phone and does work well when paired with T-Mobile and it's MVNO's with the correct APN settings.

Other Notes: The Phone only has 2.4 Ghz Wifi, which does work well - would be nice to have 5Ghz. The Bluetooth paired with both of my cars - however it is choppy compared to my Oneplus 3T. Also the GPS is not a real strong suit for this phone. I was able to succusfully use GPS Status & Toolbok to help calibrate the GPS to within error of 4.9m which is pretty good. Micro USB is a dissapointment to have instead of USC C - not the end of the world. no NFC. Camera is very sub par in low light.

This is a pretty good phone. Does almost everything I need a smartphone for. I use my phone moderately for texting (WhatsApp/Telegram/Slack), checking emails, news, listening to music, uber and few other standard apps and there has been no lag or hanging issues with this phone. It has been pretty reliable.

Pros:
When I bought this phone, I had one important need - Good audio quality. I listen to a lot of music and the iPhone 7 I had before sounded terrible. There is no bass and music sounds pretty flat on the iPhone. I didn't want to spend $500-$700 on an LG phone just for the audio because their update cycle is bad. This phone has pretty good music output. I wouldn't call it the best, but it definitely sounds better than the iPhone 7 (I use Bose QC25 headphones).

I don't click too many pictures on my phone and whenever I need it, it does the job. If I really need to click pictures in the dark with bokeh and all that jazz, I would use an actual camera for that purpose and not rely on a phone. Don't care about selfies, so even if there was no front camera, I wouldn't notice.

The battery is terrific for my usage. With my regular usage with maps, music, YouTube etc, I end the day with almost 40% remaining. I have pushed the phone for 2 days straight on a single charge. I get about 5.5 - 6.5 hours of screen time on an average.

The fingerprint sensor is fast! I barely brush it and the phone is unlocked. I don't have to look at the screen to do it.

Also, this phone doesn't have the ugly notch on top and that's a huge +. I can't wait for the world to move on from the notch abomination and until then, this phone is a winner for the price.

Cons:
The screen is a bit too big for my liking. One handed usage is a bit of a pain. But I installed Nova Launcher and found some workarounds (swiping down on the screen for notifications etc).
The auto-brightness isn't accurate. It's usually calibrated to lower than what I would've liked. I'm constantly increasing the brightness.
The screen itself isn't the most beautiful screen, but that's not a major concern.
Doesn't have USB-C but again, never bothered me. I just swapped the lightning cable to the micro-usb cable next to my bed and I forgot about it. As long as the phone charges and holds the charge well, I don't care if it uses usb a b or c.

Bottom line: If you are budget conscious, need a phone that does the job, this would be a great buy.

I was surprised and still get surprised every once in a while when I remember the fact that this phone is this price is insane to me. I use iphone and my 6s is breaking down, and instead of fixing my screen (which would cost as much as the phone) I decided to get a new phone. Problem is the new iphones are about to come out soon and I don't want a phone that's going to be outdated in 3 months. So instead I bought this phone as a temp phone and let me tell you, it is a quality phone. Maybe an upper-mid tier android. Some of the best money I ever spent.

Great phone for the money. This replaced an Axon 7 that I smashed in the door storage holder of a Ford Transit 250 when I closed the door I hear crunch! LOL, I have done it twice in two years. I hated the Axon 7 from day 1 - too many haunting stories about that thing - I am glad it broke in half. This Mate SE was a breeze to set up and I got an immediate upgrade to Android 8.0. Reused my Cricket SIM from the old phone and it fired right up without even calling Cricket. Google Play Apps installed quickly (45 of them), WiFi was self guided tutorial. Great pics, display. The only thing missing is dual front speakers but not a deal - sound is still good. Battery life is excellent the first four days of heavy usage. Also, for some reason, double tap screen to wake does not work on this model - again - no big deal for $$$.

I work in IT so my tech level is really high. This is an AMAZING phone! I mean granted I don't own the IphoneX or Note9 but I do have to say, the fingerprint reader is sooo fast. The facial recognition is sooo fast. Screen is sharp and VERY responsive. There were 2 or 3 updates I ran which brought the phone to EMUI 8 and Androind 8. It's just amazing. For so much speed and quality at such a cheap price I can't imagine any better. I know diminishing returns would occur for higher end phones. Don't get me wrong. I am sure flagships are better, faster, whatever. For me though, this is beyond expectations! people looked as asked of is that the new samsung? And I grin ear to ear! Nope, it was just over 200! and their faces are priceless! I am not at all worried about China tracking my movements. Nor should anyone else! That is a political mind game. The FBI, CIA, NSA, and Homeland security have been able to do that since 2000! If, by chance you are one who can not be tracked and MUST stay under the radar. I would suggest do not buy technology. The screen is bright, bright enough for me. There are many little nuances that make me really appreciate the phone. It's quick enough to charge. But, wow I really really like it.

I shopped around the only other thing I might have changed is the new "pocophone" might be better but was ~70 more and too new to get my hands on. In the future I might look at that line.

as soon as I opened it i put it side by side with my cheap $70 smart phone to compare browser speeds. not only did it not perform well, the wifi continuously cut on and off, forcing me to manually open the wifi settings and reconnected. also, the browser continuously crashed when loading pages. and on top of all of this, the person who packaged it must have been eating lunch while boxing it because there were greasy finger prints on the box. i assumed the phone would be brand new and factory fresh. returned it immediately.

I am give it a 2 stars because the phone keep deleting my WhatsApp application conversation. This doesn't make me happy. I am a businessman and converse with a lot of people through WhatsApp. This is important for me to be able to retain my conversation history. This remind me what a customer and I discussed about in the past. I bought the HONOR 5x I changed it after 2 says just because of that. Now I realize the HUAWEI SE is doing the same thing.... Deleting all my saved contacts and conversations. I am very disappointed with this phone. I has a galaxy phone and other phone never had to endure that problem.

I've had this phone for a few months now and it's great. Previously had a Nexus 6p which I loved but it finally got the dreaded bootloop. So I decided on this Huawei phone for a reasonable alternative to a $500+ phone and I'm very happy with it. It's on par with my old Nexus as far as performance and speed goes. Screen quality is great and nice and bright, it's got some nice features my Nexus didn't have. The operating system is a kind of a mix beetween Android and ios which is nice. The only complaint about this phone is there are some apps you cannot delete off the phones home screens which is kinda annoying but not a deal breaker at all, you get used to it. The other is that the photo quality isn't perfect usually, you have to really mess with the camera setting to get some real good pictures. Camera works great, I'm just very picky lol. But overall this phone was well worth the money spent and I would invest in the brand again without a doubt.

I got say this phone far exceeds what I expected. If you're looking for a good priced phone this is it. They're some drawbacks no NFC but I can live with that. Its going to get oreo so im excited about that. camera is good, yes is not Samsung note 8, but it takes pretty good pictures. I am happy with it.

I have had all types of phones. I have owned both Android and iPhone. I decided to buy a device and have money left over. This is the perfect device. This phone is fast, has a great screen and the battery life is the best that I've had.
I've owned the device for almost a month and I am completely satisfied. The size of the screen is awesome and the phone can be easily held in the hand. I love that it also comes with a case. Just pop your sim card in and go! I'd like to think that Im into media consumption and this is the best device. If you want a great device and don't want to spend $1000, this is the device for you!

If you need a new smartphone and have a GSM carrier (AT&T or T-Mobile), this is a great phone for the money. 4GB of RAM means plenty of room for all your applications (unlike my 2GB Moto G4 that kept force-closing apps if I opened more than one at a time) and activation was a snap: just remove the SIM card from your old phone and put in this one. Porting everything over was a breeze thanks to Huawei's app that copies over all your apps, pictures, etc. I find the OS to be snappy and responsive. The built-in launcher (EMUI) isn't the greatest, but a quick installation of Nova Prime solved that. All in all, this phone is highly recommended!

Well I've had this unit for about a month now and after getting used to the emui platform I'm happy to say that it has lived up to my expectations and above. Was a little quirky at first but seemed to adjust (me and the phone) after a week or so. The only problem I have with this phone is the audio. It just doesn't excel in the sound department. Not loud enough for my taste. The operating system is solid, and very fluid and pretty damn fast. I play several games and have not had any problems whatsoever. Face recognition works fairly well and as others have pointed out, the fingerprint scanner is awesomely accurate and fast. Battery lasts me about a day and a half with moderate usage. Pairs easily with all my Bluetooth devices. I'll tell you that I was sooo happy I bought a Spigen case for it, as I dropped it and it survived beautifully. This phone seems like it was built just for me. Looks classy, tall and lean but solid and sturdy and packs quite a punch (like me.) I am absolutely delighted with this device. I am coming from the moto g5 plus which is a good phone in its own right but the SE blows it away. The screen is vivid and colorful to me (and I am a pressman so I am chromatic by nature ). Perhaps an I phone or Samsung is better but $$$ is worth more to me than a better camera or OLED screen. By the way, the day and a half battery life is with brightness at max all the time. I'm sure you have read all the techie reviews and seen most all the you tube reviews as I did first, so my opinion is about overall value. This phone fits me like a glove. I turned my friend onto the moto g 5 plus and now he wants this phone. Research payed off multiple dividends on this purchase. Woway is my newest best friend.

Huawei has made such incredible strides by leaps and bounds and at a blistering pace that they were technically run out of the US. Ridiculous shame. Here you have a phone, as with all their phones, that has excellent battery life, a really nice screen, acceptable sound, and everything on it works pretty much flawlessly. And all of this for just under 250 bucks. I still have my Galaxy Note 8, and about 5 minutes off the charger at around the same screen brightness of the Mate, the battery begins to deplete. At 100 percent battery, it can be well over 30 minutes before the Mate begins to deplete. They can put a 5000+ mah battery in the high end phones (like Samsung), and the incredible quality of their screens is still going to race right through that battery. Why does anyone need a supposed high end, super bright phone? And frankly, how many people use the seemingly 75,000 tricks and this and that on these so-called flagship phones?? Most of the stuff on them that supposedly consumers want, but honestly you will rarely if at all use, is simply useless. At 250 bucks I am hard pressed to see any kind of real difference that a 1000 plus dollar phone. It takes calls flawlessly (my note 8 has issues with calls, especially on Bluetooth), it works well searching on the net, screen is plenty bright at just over 50%, sound is more than acceptable (I am not looking to use it as my stereo), and I don't game so I could care less for that. Build on it is solid. The added case is more than acceptable. I don't understand how it is people are constantly dropping their phones! It comes with all you need out of the box, minus headphones. Great unit for 250 bucks - period.

So far so good. This is by far the highest quality mid grade phone I've ever seen at this price point. 4gb ram and 64gb with a surprisingly decent camera. I'm using it with metro PCS and it's flawless so far.

Operating system:
Upgraded to Android 8.0 Oreo.. it's buttery.
Smooth transitions from app to app and very little lag, if any at all.

Display: absolutely stunning at this price point. I'm used to the Galaxy AMOLED screens and the screen on this phone is the closest I've seen to AMOLED at this price point.

Battery life:
So far it's pretty standard. Don't love it, don't hate it.

OVERALL: I certainly feel that I've gotten my moneys worth. The phone isn't plastic either, it feels and looks like a $800+ flagship phone. This phone is sort of like an Android and an iPhone had a baby. Blown away and very happy with my purchase. Even came with a clear phone case.

I will update this review in a few months and let you know if the phone is worth 8t in the long run.

1 month after purchase:

Phone is still working perfectly without any major issues. I have to say, I'm blown away by the battery life on this phone. I'm the guy with his nose in his phone 24/7 and I rarely go below 50% battery life.

Only thing I can say that I've experienced that isn't so fun is the response time of the touch screen. Scrolling isn't as fluid as my old Samsung and sometimes I have to tap something more than once to get it to go.

I have this phone for about a week. I could not have been more pleased. I had bought a Moto G6 and was not pleased with it. I figured I would try this one.
My criteria were 1) Less than $250, 2)3GB RAM and 3) 64GB or disk space, and of course an overnight charge that can last a day. This phone more than met those. Actually had 4GB of RAM (better than the G6), was less than $250 and I charge it once every 2 or 3 days. The picture quality is amazing. The speed is blazing fast.
I am not the kind of paying 1K for a fancy phone, yet I do consider this phone as quite fancy. I doubt these fancy phones have bells and whistles that can justify the price differences. The only thing I can't really speak about is the camera. I don't use my phone for pictures. If this is something big for you, then I would research this a bit more. For me a phone is a phone, not a camera. Still it does make excellent pics and nice movies. I use my phone a lot, and it does wonderfully well in every aspect.
The only thing that bothered me when I was looking for a phone is that it come with Android 7. As soon as I turned it on, it updated to android 8. So nothing to be bothered about anymore.
Highly, highly recommend.

Drawback: I can't see the screen while wearing sunglasses. Other than that PERFECT. When I needed a phone, I always bought the latest Samsung from the factory. Out right, no payments and completely free of any company owned soft/bugware. Recently my car was broken into and my phone and backup phone were stolen. This time I decided to see what was outdere other than Samsung and I found this. Let me tell you, it's FAST, I'm a super user, not social media but actual work programs running all day and it doesn't skip a beat. It's beautiful, and if you had told me that it was a Samsung I would have believed you! Thanks Samsung for all those wonderful years we spent together but this is goodbye for me, I'm with someone who loves me just as much but doesn't cost a fortune, I'm with Huawei.

I have this phone for about a month now and I can easily recommend you to get one. In fact, I liked so much that I bought the gold version for my younger brother. So far I haven't experienced any major lags or slowdowns. There will be some minor lags, but not so much that you'll really notice or get bothered by it. There are three things that you should consider when buying this phone which is the speaker, the ear speaker and there aren't that many good screen protectors and cases. The speaker is not that loud, but for $250 I can't complain. When making a call you might want to be in a quiet place. I found myself having trouble hearing the person, but the audio is clear. I've bought a few screen protectors and most of them don't fit or causes the rainbow edge effect. My advice is to not purchase any temper glass screen protectors for this phone.There are many cases but the quality isn't that great. Right now, I'm using this case https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0794ZYN4D/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 and although it doesn't have the best grip I like it a lot. It is a bit bulky but I like my phone to be a bit bulky so consider this when purchasing this case. Besides these three issues, this phone is fantastic and a major go. The screen is huge, the camera is decent but I don't use it that often, the phone is fast with no feelings of slowness, and the fingerprint sensor is usually accurate and really fast. So far $250 I think this is an absolute buy and a great deal. It is also said that it will be updated to Android 8.0 but don't quote me on this.

Arrived on 12/31/2018 to replace my old phone which had broken.
Things I like:
1) Very simple setup once you enter Google credentials. It even copies over your application data
2) Beautiful phone, thin and sleek-looking. Huawei logo below the screen is understated and does not detract from the appearance
3) Comes with cheap, clear plastic case
4) Fast performance
5) Screen brightness and resolution are fine
6) The price (presently $219.99) seemed to give this unit the best value compared to other options considering all of the features (4GB RAM, 64GB storage), recent version of Android

Things I don't like:
1) With its 5.93" screen, this is a large phone. It fits a pocket easily due to being thin, but the feel in the hand is not ideal. Unfortunately no one is making a quality phone with these specifications and a 5.2" screen. Popsocket actually helps.
2) The Huawei company has been a subject of national security concern over the last year or so. Huawei has a Phone Clone application that you are encouraged to download to ease the setup of the device by copying data from your old phone. This works great, *but* you have to wonder if Huawei is keeping a copy of your data, hacking your password info, etc. based on the government issuing official statements that we should not buy Huawei phones. If I end up being hacked in the near future and they drain my bank account, I will be sure to update this review.

I don't play a lot of games on my phone-just a couple of word games, don't stream movies, don't download big data, and don't take many pictures.
I do all of my banking, all of my reading-books, newspapers-everything on my phone
I text, message, and talk on my phone and use it for GPS maps.
I love, love, love this phone. It's light, sleek, good size, nice display, great speedy charging, and is very reliable. Never had it stuck, paused, or shut down during use.
I can't imagine a phone that would better meet my needs, not even for the $800-$1200 some people pay.
Doesn't get better than this.
And that nonsense about Chinese using these phones to steal from US
I checked on that at the reliable tech sources. None of them had any facts to back up that fear-mongering rhetoric.
So try one of these out.

I buy alot of smartphones. Typically, just flagship devices. This is my first budget/mid-range buy in years. I purchased because my old S6 Edge Plus would last about 2 hours SOT before dying. Where I work I need a reliable battery so after some research and not wanting to spend much money, this and the essential phone were the options.

What I can say is this.. The phone performs as good or better than my $1200 galaxy S6, except in sound and camera. The camera will definitely bum you out if you're used to having the higher end Google, Sansung or Apple devices. But, in good lighting it's not half bad for HDR shots. In low light or in video though you'll start seeing where it falls short. The sound.. pretty bad. Kind of loud but "tin can" sounding and actually hurts at full volume (high pitch, zero low end sound)

For the good.. This thing is quick, quicker than expected. After a week of use Ive had zero crashes or lagg at all. It works very fluid. And the battery is the best part! Ive had the screen on for over an hour and I am at 91%.. I'm not used to that. Sure, the Essential phone would have had a better processor and camera (maybe) but with 4 gigs of ram, and a killer SOC and Battery, I'm very glad I went this route.

It is slippery, and though they do provide a case (pretty cool Huawei!) it's just about as slippery. I'd really recommend getting the Poetic or Spigin case on Amazon when you order.

I definitely recomend this phone! And service on t-mobile in norther california is great. My old Galaxy wouldnt get phone calls in my house, this one does. So it even has better radio/antennas then a phone that costs 4x as much. Huawei wanted to get a cheap device in america almost at cost, to get people more into them, and it's working. This thing is a powerhouse and could have easily cost 400+ is it had "Samsung" stamped on it somewhere and people would buy it.

One last note.. if you're into the iPhone's look but not the software, this phone is the one for you. Almost identical to a 7+, with excellent build quality just like Apple.

Hoe this helps! If anyone needs help just send a message and I'm happy to answer any questions.

I bought this 5 months ago and loved this phone until a couple of days ago the SIM card reader failed and now it cannot send or receive calls or texts. The screen is beautiful, the phone is solid and the right size, the finger reader is superb and super fast, the camera is above average in quality, and the Android OS is quick and the phone has been a delight to use, until now. I have emailed Huaweii to see what response or support they will offer, but this phone should NOT have failed in less than 6 months. I have kept in in a protective case with a tempered glass protective screen cover, and have babied it, never dropped it. If it weren't for the SIM card reader failure, it would be a 5 star item. I have never had a phone that failed before this one.

Excellent quality and workmanship, Greatest cell phone with powerful processor and has all the functionality of much more expensive cell phone. Works great with ATT as the carrier. I absolutely love the phone and recommend it highly AAA+++. The only negative aspects are the the fact that the built in Wi Fi is only 2.4 ghz and not 5 ghz making it impossible to connect with my home Wi Fi. If they make the phone with 5 ghz 802.11a Wi Fi, they would double their sales, second draw back is camera quality is mediocre and the charging cable that comes with the phone is only three feet, way to short could not not even reach my bed night table. I bought a six feet cable and problem resolved. It is absolutely the best cell phone for the price. I highly recommend it, Buy it now and you too will Love it !!!

After losing my 4th iPhone to water damage (my own fault), I just couldn't justify purchasing another $700-$1000 phone. Apple makes great products,but their premium tech comes at a premium price. This forced me to look towards android. I saw this phone on amazon with exceptional ratings and I decided to take the leap.

After a week of use, All I can say is Wow! What an amazing phone, especially considering the price tag. It feels like a device that's two to three times more expensive and comes loaded with a crazy amount of tech. As a longtime apple fan, I've gotta say that this is pretty amazing. The screen is beautiful, the processor is faster than my iPhone 6, the 64 gigs is more than substantial (I installed a 64g micro SD (another benefit over apple) so memory is effectively 128g), and the fingerprint sensor is faster and more effective than any sensor I've used before. It's thin, lightweight, feels good in the hand and the nav buttons are intuitive and easy to use. Perhaps my favorite feature is the battery. Even as I write this review I've been using the device pretty heavily today (at least 7 hours of moderate to heavy use) and I'm still sitting at 82% battery. That's phenomenal.

The front camera is great, mostly when using the pro mode, although it's easy to wash out pics especially in high sun without adjusting the settings. The selfie camera does leave a bit to be desired (image quality seems lower than the 8mp they advertise, sometimes appearing grainy) but that's not a huge deal for me. My final caveat is the speaker. It's fine for browsing videoes and that sort of thing but don't expect it to get loud. I almost struggled to hear calls while on speaker phone with minimal-moderate background noise. It's not a huge deal since I just switched it over to the ear piece and the call quality was clear and loud.

Bottom line, this is the best phone I've ever owned considering the amount of tech vs the price tag. It easily feels like a $500-$600 device. I'm a fan.

PS the Chinese government has yet to contact me and my credit card accounts remain secure. I think we can stand on the huawei tech threat.

So, all of you have likely read a lot of pros and cons about the phone. I did likewise and thought-Wow...finally a very good (not excellent, but thats not necessary) for a very reasonable price. So I got it. Initially really liked it...big display, fairly quick, etc... Eventually did not work out. Here is why (1) Processor speed-I use the gps a lot. I found that too many times, I was just passing the street when it told me to turn...that never happened with my Galaxy. (2) related to this, GPS was more inaccurate than any other phone I had bought in recent years. I heard some other reviews say this, but ignored. I live in Boston and need high accuracy. (3) phone quality-I also changed cell phone carriers so not sure to blame the phone or the carrier, but got terrible reception at my house and other locations. (4) minor compared to the rest, but the sound quality of the speaker was a big step down. Eventually, I ended up biting the bullet and getting a new Galaxy...I am not in deep love with it either, but wow, the processor is amazing...so fast!!! I just noticed that Amazon dropped the price again of the S9, so not as cost prohibitive...might want to at least consider that or another phone.

Without question this is the best phone I have ever owned. I was a little worried about purchasing a product by a company I have never heard of before. Once I got the phone I was immediately impressed. It came in a very nice package and set-up was rather easy. Later finding out that Huawei is the largest tele- communication company in the world it even made me feel better. Before ordering this phone I read a lot of the reviews and most were very favorable to the product. The ones that weren't favorable were mostly about the pictures. I found the pictures to be very nice. You can even adjust the settings like on a regular 35mm camera to get the best picture possible. This phone even came with a clear case which is made of clear rubber and helps a great deal to hold on to the phone. I would highly recommend this phone to anybody wanting to buy a new Android phone. The battery last all day as well. This phone would be a great buy at twice the price but at $230.00 it's a steal.

OK - yes this is a 'cheap Chinese phone', but it is fast, has a good feel, and plenty of battery life for the way I use it.
It also cam with a minimal amount of blot ware, which is a huge plus! Yes, it probably has spyware installed, many phones do, but I am not stupid enough to have private information on my phone. Duh!
The 4 GB of RAM, and the built-in 64 GB of storage is more than I'm likely to need, but if I do need more then the 128 GB micro SD card I installed has that covered.
With my previous phone (BLU), if I tried to listen to music on my BT headset with the phone in my pocket, it would drop in and out frequently. With this phone I have a solid connection all the time, including up to 20 feet away from the phone. Sweet!
The camera takes sharp, clear pictures. No it does not have image stabilization - darn it (grin) but I am satisfied with what it does. Give them 2 years and I bet they will have that covered as well.
The screen is sharp and clear and I can comfortably watch movies or read for hours without fatigue. A real plus!

I popped in my Tracfone SIM card, there you go, 4G LTE! I had troubles with other international stocks, not this one. Excellent build quality, blazing fast 2.4 GHz processor, ample storage space, smooth sound, user friendly and beautiful EMUI 5.0..... most impressive of all, the camera! See the snow scenes I took. I say the camera itself worthy the $229 I paid for! I LOVE IT! I can not believe a flagship phone costs this low! The casing feels lighter than the Mate 10 Pro, which costs much more. That is perfect for me. I strongly recommend the phone, to those can not bear infinite OS upgrades, just to welcome more bugs, and cheap tricks that slow down their devices. Good job, Huawei!

Update a year later: this phone works as perfect as the day it arrived one year ago. I can not help bought a second one. I am now awaiting for the Huawei Mate X Fordable as soon as it is available for sale!

Fantastic little phone. Huawei has set a great standard for what a budget phone should be. Extremely high build quality with a clean UI. What else could you ask for? More than adequate performance and outstanding battery life. I have purchased three Huawei phones in the last 3 months (one for each of my two kids) for less than the cost of a high-end flagship. I'm a very discriminating shopper and I can confidently say that I'm extremely pleased with the value and performance of these phones. Well done.

Amazing phone for the money

I was a little skeptical about buying this phone but it is great. I had a top brand phone that cost 600 two years ago. You still cant buy that phone for less and this phone and it has more storage and processing power and a bigger screen plus its unlocked so you can take it to any GSM cell company. I chose Consumer cellular which has at&t and t--mobile service for half the price.

After a huge amount of time looking for a new phonebi decided on the Huawei Mate SE and was excited.
Received the phone and setup was easy and everything was going great and then I started noticing the problems.
1. Pictures are good at best. They are not amazing just good.
2. The bottom speaker sucks. I spend most of the time with the volume all the way up.
3. And this was the worst part. The reason I will be returning this phone. It will not pair via Bluetooth with most of my devices. Won't pair with my fitbit or Garmin and won't pair with my portable speaker. And this isn't because of anything other then those companies won't support this phone on their products

I really wanted to like this phone bit for the 219 dollars I spent on it I could buy something different.

I will start out by saying that the phone itself is a great phone with many features for a budget phone. The downfall is that the phone wasn't unlocked as promised. When I tried to activate the phone with my current carrier they informed me that the phone was not unlocked. So something that should have taken only about 15 or at the most 30 minutes took 2 hours to complete in the store and then an additional hour to program. To say the least it was an very long day and I had plenty of time to work on patience.

Initial Review: (1 star) Battery Failure (effectively bricked)
OK, I don't hate it, it it a GREAT phone when it was working, just like my Honor 8. It would run logged into Google & FB on Wifi for 4 days and still have 60% battery remaining! But after a few charges, the phone went dead. Does not respond to the supplied charger or any other charger or cable. Since I did not want to do battery surgery on such a beautifully packaged/fit device & it is a gift, I opted to return it and since I did not see any similar battery failure complaints I will try a 2nd one and update the review.

UPDATE: (4 star) - So far so good with replacement unit. I set it up and gifted to good old Mom and she loves it over her old tier 1 Samsung cheapo trial phone. It's fast, long life and a great camera compared to what she was used to, and MUCH easier to see the big screen for her.

I have had this for about a month now, and I love it! Battery lasts a long time, got the Oreo upgrade, works great! Easy to use, etc... No wifi calling, no 5G, but I don't miss it. Also, switching phones from an old Samsung was so easy! Does not come with a bunch of bloatware like my old phone. My wife bought an Iphone 7 at the same time, and I like this much better, and half the price!

Having owned several iPhones since their launch, I got to the point where every next generation was more disappointing. I decided to save $800 and try the Huawei, a brand I was familiar with in Europe where they've had a presence for many years. Is it as good as an iPhone? Probably not. Is it an excellent phone? Absolutely. I've had it now about 3 weeks, have gotten used to android, and couldn't be happier. If I only keep it a year I'm good. If it drops and breaks it's cheap to replace. It does everything I need it to do. The speakers are not great, but adequate. The photos are not excellent, but good. Screen is great. Finger print work well. Functions are as they should be. I paid $225 odd for this, and that's a bargain. Good battery life, quick charging, and I just bought a memory card to boost this thing... You won't go wrong, unless fashions, brands, and bragging rights are your weakness.

Former iphone user for many years. I was initially drawn to iphones when smartphones first came on the market and integrated phone, media, and data, and when my employer used to pay for my phone :) Now that my employer does not pay for my phone, and I have to use my own money, I did a ton of research to get the best phone I could in the $200-$250 price point and pair it with a super cheap data provider (ie. went with H20 wireless.. check it out to save more!). The hardest part about switching from an iphone to my Huawei was converting my pre-2009 music downloaded from itunes to a "universal" format that could work on my Huawei. I took the easy route, bought a $25 one-year subscription to itunes match to remove all the DRM protection, converted my music, copied it to my Huawei, and I will be cancelling my itunes match subscription soon. (There are other cheaper ways to recover your pre-2009 itunes music, but that's the route I choose since the $25 seemed worth my time. If you have post-2009 music you can simply copy your music without any conversion) I also proved to wife that I could do EVERY SINGLE THING that I formerly could do with my iphone and more, including adding all the extra memory I want with a simple cheap micro card, although I haven't needed one yet given it came with a generous 64GB memory! We have 2 Huawei Mate SEs in the family now, and when my son and daughter eventually need one, I will be pushing to save money and buy these again. Great, great deal!!! Wish I could give it 6 stars.

Screen is good quality, battery last a very long time. I don't think and 1 hour to 1.5 is not too bad for a full charge. It updated to Oreo in about 5 mins. It takes great pictures for the price point. The audio is plenty loud both ear and speaker. And it has headphone jack, sadly no type c but that was not a deal breaker for me. Front camera is good as well as rear. It will do split screen. There is NO lag on anything I tired with it. Has awesome signal and the hotspot work's!!! Running it on cricket works perfectly. The phone spying is hogwash... These people make a good quality lasting phone. I'm still using my 2 year old mate 9 and I've not had one issue with it and it still getting updates. Got this model to replace wife's honor 6x phone. All she said was wow this is way better than the old one and really digs the display vs old phone
I will say this they had a super cool phone clone app with each phone it could not have been more easy to swap out the handsets. Scan app from one one to other bingo 30 mins later everything transferred including app data. She literally picked it up and did not have to go through the whole silly process of resetting apps password or relogin in. It even transferred all the text message which surprised me as we both use Textra . No issue. For the money why go buy a 1000 phone when in my opinion this can hang with it. Plus it's dual SIM which give you more storage space for a SD card.

Install Flash Player
...Yeah I know I said that about the Kata M4
But I think the Huawei Mate SE stole that title.
FYI this phone is known by other names.
Honor 7X and Nova 2 Lite.
Pros.
The battery life.
I can see why tech reviewers on YouTube have waxed poetic about it. Don't believe me? Please see my screen shot.

Build quality.
It's solid and clean. Nice metal back with a smooth glass screen. The camera lenses is glass too.

The OS.
I normally like stock Android better but Hauwei's EMUI has won me over.
It's super easy to customize without rooting/jailbreaking.
It's fast and intuitive.

It has Micro SD card support.
This makes me happy because I keep most of my music, pics and videos on a micro SD card.

It has OTG support.
OTG means On The Go. I can connect a USB thumb drive, keyboard or a mouse.
See my screen shot.

WiFi
It can be used as Mobile hotspot or a router bridge/extender. Best of all, it's done natively, no need to download an app.
VPN is also natively supported.
Doing stuff like web browsing, shopping or email is fast.

Processing Power and RAM.
It's got 8 core processors and four gigs of RAM. It handles multi tasking like a champ.
So far I haven't noticed much lag.

Temperature management.
Pretty solid in my book.
I keep my phone in a case.
So far I haven't noticed the phone getting hot while charging, using and being in the case at the same time. The charger doesn't even get warn.

It has a regular radio. No need for a subscription or internet connection.

GPS. No complaints. I tested it by looking up my job's location.

OK Google ( AI assistant.)
It works well enough for me. I tested it by asking "Who played the Goblin King in Jim Henson's Labyrinth?"
Not only did it understand me, it gave the correct answer! David Bowie
(If you have a speech issue or a thick accent then you may be better off typing your inquiry.)

The finger print scanner.
This is another thing that YouTube tech reviewers have waxed poetic about.
It's very erganimicaly placed at the back.
It doesn't get in the way of the camera.
More importantly it's fast and accurate.

It has a gyroscope.
It can accurately track your steps. Even if you put the phone in a purse Very handy if you're trying to get fit.
Works well with Pokemon GO too.

Time.
The clock is accurate. Heck I've used the timer function for baking. It rang when it was supposed to and my blueberry muffins didn't burn.

Multi tasking.
Remember Picture in Picture by Magnavox?
Lol this phone can do that too.
App Twin .You can be logged into two Facebook or two Twitter accounts at the same time! You know businesses in the front, party in the back! You'll need to turn this on in the settings.

Display.
Nice and sharp! I keep my brightness level around 40% and have the auto brightness adjusting turned on. I also have the eye comfort option turned on. My eyes say thank you Huawei!
Videos, art photos and text look good to me.

Accessories.
This phone came with a case. Do iPhones come with a case?
If you don't like the one that came with it then there are other options. If you can't find one for the Mate SE, just get the Honor 7X/Nova 2 Lite cases. Like I said before, same phone just different names.

And since it has a headphone jack, any headphone, earbuds or wired speaker will work with this phone.

Headphone jack!
A thin $230 phone has a headphone jack, imagine that!

The microphone.
I tested it by making an audio note and calling a friend for a ride. My buddy said he heard me just fine.

Accessibility.
Fingerprint to scroll.
Smile or use victory/peace sign to take pics.
Flip over to mute calls, notifications, alrms
ect.
Love it!

Predictive text.
OMG. I'm terrible at typing. If it wasn't for this option, you wouldn't be able to read this review.

Built in emojis!
Lots of cute ones to choose from like cherry blossoms, cats, and fruits.
If you like texting with emojis then this is the phone for you!

Now for the meh. Meaning not good but not bad.

This phone does come with a bit of bloatware. But I actually do use some of them.
It has one speaker on the bottom right corner.
Sound quality can get a little tiny on high volume. If you are holding your phone in landscape mode then you might accidentally cover the speaker. But look on the bright side, at least it's not at the back

Camera. The rear one has an LED flash but the front doesn't. If you want to take a good selfie you'll have to use the rear camera or find a location with good lighting.
There is no image stabilization on either camera. But you can compensate for that by using a tripod or selfie stick with a gimbal. Or just lean on something. Or just edit any blurrness and shaking in post production.
I took a few sample shots.

Charging.
It's not super fast but not too slow either.
The way the OS manages battery consumption makes up for this in my opinion. It takes about 2 hours to go from 0 to 100.
No wireless charging due to the metal back.
The charger port is not type C. This may bother some but not me. I'm fine with that because I can still use my OTG dongles.

Bluetooth connection can be a little spotty at times but it maybe the fact that my other phone is broken. I'll update this part later.

The phone supports dual SIM cards.
SIM card slot one supports 2G,3G and 4G speeds but slot two only works on 2G.
And you can not be using both at the same time.
If you were planning on using this phone for business and personal calls, you might want to look elsewhere. Anyway I bet most folks would rather use the second slot for the Micro SD card.

Cons.
NO NFC or Hot Knot support. Just a little FYI. That means no Google Pay or transferring files by touching screens together.

Pre installed apps can not be deleted or moved to the SD card unless you root/jailbreak.

Battery is not removable, unless you have the tools and skills.

Final thoughts
Please give this phone and Huawei a chance.
This phone looks and feels luxurious. One lady on YouTube even thought this was a $1,500 phone? LMAO.

Don't believe everything that the government is spewing. They say the Chinese government is using this phone to spy on us.
Not sure how dust and water resistant this thing is. OR drop damage ressistant. I'm too chicken to test that. If I ever do drop it down some stairs or in the sink, I'll let you know.

I have purchased a few of these...they are excellent phones that run Oreo with Huawei skin. The build quality, display, and battery life are very, very good. I don't care about NFC, so this phone does everything I need it to do. It is very responsive and the battery does not get hot (like my old iPhone). I have dropped mine twice...once very hard...and it was fine. The Huawei skin is a little Apple like, but not in a bad way. Paying $230 makes a lot more sense then $700-$1200 for an iPhone. I use Cricket and it seems to play very well with ATT/Cricket.

This review will focus on one of the major complaints that I read here in Amazon reviews both before and after I purchased my Huwai Mate SE. No need to rehash all the stuff that is good about this phone, plenty of other reviews for that but I was having problems with some Apps. But I found the solution so now everything works.

90%-95% of Apps work right out of the box
Over 90% of my Apps worked from the get go, when I set up the phone and imported all the settings from the old phone I was good to go for most of them but there were primarily 2 that did not work right.
1. Mileage tracking App (in my case it was Hurdlr)
2. Call screening/blocking App (My fave didn't work and I downloaded 4 other ones and none of them worked)

The reason these Apps failed is because of Huawei's built in "feature" called Protected Apps. You will find it in Settings in the Battery section. You have to make a change in how your phone manages the battery with respect to certain Apps.
In Settings>>Battery there is tab called Launch. Under the heading "Manage all automatically" you must turn off the slider for App, which will place the App in the group "Manage batch manually". When you go there you will find check boxes now next to your App that you can turn on or off:
Auto Launch
Secondary Launch
Run in background
For my Apps that weren't working before I have all 3 boxes checked and they are working fine now!

I already liked my phone from the appearance, the size how it's large enough yet fits easily in any pocket, how it receives calls all over the house in places where my previous phones could not. But fixing this last issue, certain Apps not doing what they should, takes it over the top and it's clearly a 5 star now especially considering the price.

Update: some common defects people have reported
1. Bluetooth and/or WiFi: I have not had any issue with this at all. My calls are crystal clear in my car. No WiFi problems on 2.4 Ghz.
2. GPS: No issues, I use Waze and Google Maps, both have worked as well or better than on any other phone I have used in the past. My previous phones often had a tendency to get very hot while navigating, the Huawei Mate does not!
3. Camera Quality: Ok,my Sony Xperia had a better camera but it also cost nearly double the price. I don't expect to get a top notch camera at this price point. However, it is more than adequate for my needs. If I need more I will take a camera with me.
4. Battery Life: some have complained about this but my phone lasts for 2 days easily with normal use. If I play with it a lot or do a lot of navigating without it being on charge then it might only go 1.5 days.
5. Reception: the radio on this phone works better than on any other phone I have ever owned. I receive calls in areas of my house where I often wouldn't and I'm experiencing very few call drops even while driving.

Edit #2 (02/07/19) I bought a second phone so I could have one while I sent my first phone in for warranty. The old one had white spots on the screen and the wifi would cut in and out and became extremely unreliable. This new phone I have had for a couple months and I am already noticing dead pixels in the display. Sadly I am going to have to stop reccomending this device because of these issues that have arose. I will have to knock off a couple stars due to these issues.

Edit #1 (11/6/18) 6 months in and this phone is still going STRONG! The thing is still as fast as the day I pulled it out of the box and has aged very well. I've had it in a case with a glass screen protector since day one and the phone still looks brand new. I've recommended this budget phone to everyone I possibly can. It's well worth the money.

Phone has what matters where it matters. The biggest things it lacks is USB-C and NFC. Other than that it's a SOLID phone. It has a great processor and plenty of memory. It feels great in the hand and doesn't feel cheap. Flagship phones last 2-3 years. With this pricing I can buy a budget phone every year and throw the old one away and it will still be cheaper than buying a flagship phone every 2-3 years.

After using Apple for several year, then switching to Samsung, the bottom line is that I was getting tired of paying over $800 for a cell phone. This is a great phone for the money, but if you use Bluetooth often, you might want to consider something else. I use this Bluetooth with headphones and 3 different cars. The main problems are in the cars. Apps such as Audible regularly skip, slow down, speed up, or just stop. Podcasts do the same thing. I can't even get it to recognize my home stereo to pair it. Even with the WIFI turned off, the Bluetooth is spotty.

The pictures appear good, but are pretty bad in high contrast shots. I took a picture of my daughter's soccer team on a bright sunny day (the best conditions in terms of camera light) and the pictures look like a painting when you zoom in at all.
