compared to iphone 6s, just a tiny bit slower. Face and fingerprint recognition are lightning fast. Very light and thin. Picture quality is excellent. sound and speaker mode for calls are nice and crisp. I use it with a tracfone micro sd card. no issue to report.

I've had this for at least a month. I really like it. Since so many parts of phones, etc. are made in China I thought I'd take a chance. It has a lot of things that you can customize as well as features other Android phones didn't have.

Facial recognition works well too. Battery life is amazing. I can go all day constantly browsing Facebook and whatever and when I get home in the evening it still has 70+% battery life left.

So far love this phone. Fast, smooth and feels great. Glad I got it.

Thank you amazon finally i got my choice and good quality phone. This item works every thing great fast super smart i love HAUWAI mate.

I purchase this phone . Because this phone is beyond any expectations I had for a smartphone and available for an incredible price .This phone has everything I needed .Dual sim card or micro sd card allows two phone number or unlimited storage , massive screen larger than 1080 HD ,decent camera good loud speaker fast fingerprint ID.One thing is this phone only support 2.4 GHZ wifi not 5 GHZ wifi . but overall this phone is good.

It is just ok. Looks great. Fingerprint reader is lightning fast (much, much faster than Moto G4 Plus) - didn't realize my G4 was slow until trying this. Unfortunately fingerprint reader is on the back (I know this is the trend, but don't like hunting for something I can't see. Bothered me more than I thought it would)

However, response time for starting and switching apps is no faster than my Moto G4 Plus (about the same) and the wifi speed is significantly slower (about 20%) than my Moto G4 Plus (side to side comparision with speedtest). Touch sensitivity is also worse - typing always results in missing characters. The worst thing about this phone is the sound quality. It is absolutely terrible from the internal speaker and also over headsets. I would guess maybe the internal speaker's poor quality is the price for the slim design. Was also inconsistent on Android Auto - sound quality was really, really bad on Android Auto until I found a tip online that said to turn off the 'special effects' from the sound settings (this fixed the problem). Also, not a big fan of EMUI (the customized version of Android), prefer the closer to stock Android experience of the Moto phones.

I returned it. Will wait for Moto G6.

So far so good with this budget smartphone. A lot of people call this the King of the Budget Smartphones...I must agree.

I'm nitpicking, but here are a few suggestions that would make this phone perfect and probably $50-$75 more expensive, but I would still buy it.
1. Type C USB for charging
2. Dual Band Wifi (AC). Lacking this is a real bummer when a $40 Moto e4 at Walmart at least has dual band wifi
3. This phone only has LTE and would be better with LTE-A
4. fast/turbo charging
5. any type of water resistant rating
6. Optical Image Stabilization (OIS) But Google Photos (the android app version) does a pretty good job of fixing the shaky videos (after you shoot your shaky video)

Overall the phone is Really good and very well priced. And the battery lasts a Long Time! I am coming from a Moto X Pure (2015) edition and the Mate SE battery is 1000x better than my older Moto.

I also purchased the Honor View 10 to compare to the Huawei Mate SE. I know the View 10 has a better processor, more gigs of RAM (6 compared to 4) and double the internal storage, plus other features too...but when comparing them side to side, I don't notice a difference (i.e. speed or lagging) when using daily apps. When I use the Mate SE as a hotspot for my laptop, it is usually as fast as the View 10. I actually now prefer the fingerprint sensor on the back of the Mate SE better than the front of the Honor View 10. Using the sensor on the back seems easier and more comfortable than I ever thought it would.

So I don't think the View 10 is worth 2x the price of the Mate SE.

The Huawei Mate SE is a great budget phone that I am using as my daily phone now. I'm surprised at how much I like it, I did not think that would be the case. And it is not too expensive that I won't be upset replacing it within a year to 18 months with another newer budget phone. It will be interesting to see if Mate SE will still be as fast as it is now in 12 months.
Upgrade from honor 5. Simple data transfer. Fast fast phone!! Polital govt. Hysterics on Chinese ties seems absurd given that nearly all our phones are made there.

Bought this phone to give to my wife so she could give her sister her old (but solid) Honor 6x. Where on day to and not much complaint from her except I noticed it got a bit hot the other day. Will update if I notice this to be a patter or something else show undesirable.

This device is very fast and very smooth. Easily the best experience I've had on an Android device. This phone birngs you flagship level specs without breaking the bank. Don't let the price throw you off. There is no lag. Cameras are absolutely gorgeous. Fingerprint scanner is instant. And that 3340 mAh battery keeps you charged all day, even under decently heavy use. That Kirin 659 Octa-Core CPU can handle everything you throw at it with incredible speed and realibility. The onboard EMUI is very responsive with no lag. Currently Android 7.0 out of the box with 8.0 on the way. Do not hesitate another second. But this phone. You will NOT be disappointed!!

I really like this phone way faster than the Galaxy for sure , the signal still sucks but that's because AT&T just sucks, but the phone is really good, screen has a good size and good resolution 4Gb in ram and 64Gb in memory it makes it even better , totally recommend this phone

This one great phone. In this price you cannot get any smart phone with this high performance. I really recommend that to everyone. I got 2 more when get this one thanks I donât have buy iPhone or similar price phones anymore

Iâve had this phone for close to a month now and Iâm very happy with it. My previous 2 devices were Moto Gs, with the most recent being the G4. The G4 was a great phone that was only hampered by my dumb decision not to get the model with more RAM and Storage. I assumed I would get the G6 when it was released, but the announced specs were disappointing, (this will be the first G6 to not have a 6XX series snapdragon processor), and the price is higher than previous iterations. To be honest, the Moto E5 Plus is more attractive as a true budget phone.
The Huwaei Mate SE had solid reviews and great specs for the price, so I decided to buy it. I also considered waiting for the Nokia 6.1, but again, the specs (3GB RAM and 32GB on base model) donât campare to the Huwaei.
Pros:
Screen - I really like the 18X9 screen. The quality is great, with no color hues.
Fingerprint Scanner - I never understood the big deal about these things, but now I canât imagine living without it. It is lightning fast.
Memory & Storage - I think that anything with less than 4GB of RAM will not last more than a year without starting to significantly lag. With 4GB of RAM and 64GB of storage this phone should perform well for a while.
UI - The custom UI is actually pretty decent, and close to stock Android. This was actually the only thing made me consider not purchasing the phone, as Iâve enjoyed the stock android on my Motos, and know that the Samsung UI is really annoying. This one is pretty straight forward.
OS - The Android 8.0 update came through today and resolved some issues. The touch sensitivity on the screen was an issue, but seems to be resolved now. Also, I had issues with pairing with my car that are now fixed. Nice!!
Camera - Iâm not a great judge of picture quality, and Iâm not going to say that it takes better pictures than my wifeâs iphone 7. It doesnât. It does, however, take much better photos than my G4 ever did. Thatâs all I really need. The camera could load faster, but oh well.
Processor - Plenty fast for my needs. In the ballpark of a 6XX series snapdragon, but it does underperform in nearly all benchmark tests. I donât play many games, but I downloaded PubG, just to see how it did, and it played nicely with no lag.
Case - Just want to point out that it comes with a pretty decent clear case. I didnât realize it when I ordered it. Consider that when you purchase the phone.
Cons:
OS - I miss the gesture controls for the camera and flashlight that I had on the Motos.
Network - GSM Only. Not necessarily a negative, but you should be aware of it. I bought a 12 month card for RedPocket and the service is pretty great.
No NFC - Iâve never had this, but I imagine itâs like the FP Scanner. Once you have it, you probably donât want to go without it.
No Type C or turbo charging - For me, this is the only true negative. Fortunately, after nearly a decade of android ownership I have amassed roughly 3 million micro-USB cables, so Iâm never more than a few feet away from a convenient, albeit slow, charging solution.
Thatâs all the negatives I can think of right now. All in all, a fantastic phone for $250 (price when I bought it, $229 now). If youâre a casual user like myself (no intense games, rarely watch videos), thereâs no reason to buy anything more expensive than this range of phone.

Great for the price. The picture quality is ok. Not as good as my old Huawei phone which is also twice as expensive as this one. If you are particular about picture quality you may want to buy a more extensive phone. This is a basic inexpensive phone.

I like everything about the phone, the camera, battery, memory, size, I almost give up and no buy the phone because I had read a comment that someone made, saying that the battery take to long to charge but it is looks like it was not true because my phone battery get charge very fast, this phone is amazing, kudos to the Huawei company, they are making the best phones in the market right now.
Great budget phone, great battery and performance
I spent days researching for a replacement phone for my dying Note 4. But it needed to be affordable and unlockable. And this phone met all my needs. All I can say is I love it.
Huawei has a lot of features at an exceptional price.....

Very nice phone for the price. Has a lot of high end functions that you would not expect from a 200 dollar phone. Why pay 1000 dollars when you can get the same quality and functions in this very well built phone.

I bought one of my kids the Honor 7x and one the Huawei Mate SE. Both are great, low cost and beautiful phones. From the outside, the only difference I can see is the color and the camera housing being a single piece on the Mate SE. You can definitely tell the Mate is a little more responsive with the extra RAM. If you weren't already aware, there are some big limitations to these phones. You can only connect to 2.4Ghz wireless and Bluetooth shares an antenna with wifi, which means you get slower performance on wifi when using blootooth. You also don't get fast charging or USB type C, which really isn't a huge deal to me. It seems to charge fast enough. The body is a great size and it really does look very pretty overall. For kids who want something that looks good, but you won't be too concerned about losing or breaking, this is a great option and one I would recommend. At the current price of $230, the extra 30 dollars is worth it over the 7x for the extra memory/storage.

It's a great phone with plenty of storage for me and it's super fast but my only issue is once you get the update added to the phone my messages will stop showing on messenger unless I restart the phone

I really wanted to like this phone and initially I did. Everything about it is great except the reception. I live in a somewhat rural area and in the past I'll have to go outside to make phone calls once in a while. With this phone, even if I go outside, people always complain that I am breaking up or they can't hear me. It will show two bars but have terrible reception. When I'm in other areas I don't seem to have this problem, but it's annoying that my wife can use her phone inside our house just fine and I cannot make a call anywhere on our property when we have the same carrier.

Update:
Phone went swimming in a water bowl for a split second and screen stopped working. Given the opportunity to buy this same phone again (I already had a case and I liked that the micro USB is very popular among other devices) I opted for a different phone in the same price range and just bought a new case and a bunch of new USB c cables. I didn't want to take the risk of having a phone with poor reception issues again, so I went back to Motorola which has never let me down in that area. (Also, my new phone is waterproof, which should prevent another accident like that from happening)

The cloning operation was spectacular... suddenly the new phone had EVERYTHING from our old phones, apps, contacts, pictures, videos, music, files... and then much better because faster and great full HD screen. Odd how it can have virtually the same outside dimensions, but the screen pictures are a half inch bigger! Great photos and videos, everything!

I do not have a single complaint or reservation about this phone yet, compared to any phone I've ever owned, and I've had some flagships. Easy operation, quick learning curve from the 6X, the cases we bought fit perfectly and securely.

I purchased Huawei Mate SE with really big expectations after I read a lot of reviews online. But now I am returning it back to Amazon before one month is over.

I am not going to talk about the good stuff about the phone because the phone is really nice. I can say it's really a great phone with really spectacular features. It is really very much customizable, I can say it's much better than any other Android phones out there on the market as to customization perspective. But the phone has lots of downsides and I would like to inform you about these.

The most important problem I have experienced is that the phone's performance declined significantly within a month. The phone slowed down significantly. Sometimes it is responding like 1 to 2 seconds later and this is the most important problem to me. Especially when downloading something or running a few different apps it gets really sluggish. This is very annoying and the phone with these specs and strong processor should not easily be worn out like this. Warning: the processor is made by a Chinese processor company (Kirin), unlike most smartphones this phone does not have Qualcomm brand processor which could be the reason.

I also don't like the display which is not bright enough. The screen brightness is not good at all, it may be okay for the inside environments but when you're out there especially on a sunny day under the sunlight it's it's really not user-friendly even though you max the screen brightness...

Another downside of the phone is the data transfer. The reason I like Android phones because it's easy to transfer data just like plug-and-play or plug your phone into your computer and you can easily transfer data but on this machine you need to download Huawei application to your computer so that you will be able to transfer your data I have experienced that the phone keeps disconnecting during the data transfer. I lost data just because of that and I lost time...

Another reason I bought this phone was to use with my Cricket line and its hot spot but even though the phone is unlocked the hotspot service is not working with Cricket when I checked with Cricket customer service they said that they will get in touch with the manufacturer so the manufacturer will allow hotspot tethering which really sucks. This may depend on the carrier and I would highly suggest being precautious if you intend to use hotspot with this device.

I would like to throw a few words for the battery as well. I am a heavy data user and I can say Huawei Mate SE has a decent battery life. In my case, I was able to get at least 8 hours of battery life with lots of streaming and social media activities.

So like I said, I really like this phone but I'm going to return it back because it has a lot of downsides that really impacts my daily usage...

I am replacing my old Samsung Note 3 which has well outlived its usefulness. This Huawei mate SE seemed somewhat of a compromise of speed and price so I decided to go with this phone. I did not realiize that it is so quick, responsive and easy to use. The screen is super responsive. The display is bright and clear. I would not be able to tell this from a top of the line phone and the price is amazing. Granted, my comparison is with a phone that has not been sold in years and barely works. But as a casual user this phone does everything one needs. There is no reason to spend more than three time the money on something that is equally outdated in just 12 months from now. Great phone with a huge display, thin profile an very good battery life. All the value and less fluff. Also the phone is not tied to the provider. Little bloatware..
Update: I have it now for a few weeks and use it every day off course. The phone is fantastic. The photos it takes are actually great. I like the fact that I can select the point of focus and the point to take the brightness of the picture. I can take decent interior real estate photos with it. Not 100 % as good as my DSLR with indirect flash but quite close. The lens is a good medium wide angle at around 28 mm (equivalent) focus length so you can cram a lot in it. But it takes pictures that don't look like they come from a phone. The bokeh function where the background becomes blurred and the subject is sharp works good and yield nice results. I did not expect the camera part to be so decent. I bought it with the thought in mind that I am settling for a bargain phone with a not so good camera. However, it allows me to do quite a bit more than with the old one. My camera bag stays at home quite a bit more. As a Realtor I can use this in a pinch and get great looking results that I can actually use without being embarrassed. (I hate when my colleagues use haphazard pictures that are done with a phone held upright where you can not see anything of the house) Compared to all the phones I had before, this is lightning fast and very responsive. I still love it. I completely love the price. Get this phone.
Update: I now have used it for about a week and love it even more. The battery life is incredible. When in a location with connected wifi the phone can last for about 3 days without a recharge. I presume the use of wireless data will cut down on the battery time a bit. But it is still plenty of time on the phone. This phone is incredible considering the really low price tag. Considering traveling abroad? It can take a second sim card and work both at the same time. Or have your work phone number and personal phone number routing to one device. I would not buy one of the flagship phones. There is truly no need since the Mate SE does everything one asks for an more. It even has a vault functions where you can protect your data and apps from unauthorized access. Good feature if you carry sensitive data or customer files on your phone. Also the ability to add storage with a sd card gives you affordable storage expansion. They even give you a cover with the phone so you don't need to get one right away. The thing I personally love it still has a headphone jack. Who ever complained about the presence of a headphone jack in a phone? Why are they gone in the most expensive phones? It does not make sense to not have one and deal with unreliable Bluetooth or cumbersome adapters. This phone makes sense in every way. There is no reason not to buy it. Did I mention that I love this phone? Best purchase I made in a long time.

When I started working with computers in the 1980s, I never expected to walk around with 8 CPU cores, 64 GB of storage, and 4 MB of RAM in my pocket!

The price/performance ratio of this device is phenomenal, and it's a joy to use. The sound with Bluetooth and headphones is excellent (there is a headphone jack). There are few bloatware apps, and most can be removed.

The version of Android is not stock, but isn't annoying either. Huawei says the device will get Oreo in the future.

I am using this phone with T-Mobile in the USA and the call quality is good.

The phone can either take 2 SIMs, or 1 SIM and 1 microsd card. I installed my 128 GB microsd, so I have all of my music (ripped CDs) on the device.

I like that you can set up the phone to turn on with two taps to the screen. There is a step counter that displays on the lock screen which is useful to me.

Battery life seems to be pretty good. After fully charging the phone last night, and spending a lot of time installing software and configuring the phone, the next morning it's still at 60%. I even used the hotspot feature when my ISP had a brief outage, and I'm sure that uses a significant amount of power.

After charging to 100%, in the morning it was still at 97%.

The camera is quite good, but I still use a dedicated camera for photos that require a decent zoom.

May 13 Update:

I just received the OTR update for Android 8.0 (Oreo). The installation worked without a hitch, and Android 8.0 is running well.

First impression, this is a thin and light phone. Screen is bright, performance is fast, not much junk loaded from the factory image. The setup gives you a way to move data and apps from another Android phone to your new phone.

Camera is good, phone has a fingerprint sensor. The OS image is not too far from a stock android version. The Sim is a nano site, and the tray for the Sim can hold either a second Sim or a micro SD card to expand the storage. This phone is both carrier unlocked, and comes with a US warranty.

Few negatives, does not have a knock code capability. Screen icons look pretty crappy in landscape orientation. Battery is sealed in and not replaceable similar to some other phones.

(Update) after using the phone for a few weeks: Battery life is great, my LG would be at 25% after a day of running around and moderate usage, the Mate SE is still at about 65% battery.

Other issues noted: The PIN code on the lock screen does not have a scramble option, which would be good to have again. A couple of little issues noted: 1) one time turning on the phone with the power button, the digital clock display did not show up. 2) In my email app, the screen started showing a blue color tinge. I restarted the phone and the issues have not reoccurred at this time.

Overall my impression is still that this is a very good phone for the price.

Let me start by saying that I am not a phone snob. I am not trying to impress anyone. This phone has almost everything I want and provides me with all the functionality I need. It is essentially an Honor7X with upgraded RAM and storage making it equal to the Honor7X released in the rest of the world outside of the US. It has a decent camera, Android 7, 64GB storage, and duo SIM and unlocked for travel. The fingerprint sensor is nicely placed on the back and I don't have to struggle to find it. The battery lasts me for 2 to 3 days depending on my usage (I am not a heavy user). I use it a lot for Spotify in the car and for my home audio system and it works well. It is lightning fast at boot up and loading apps. I find it to be great value. My cost was $229 US. I had considered the new Samsung A8 (2018) but it only had 32GB memory and I felt that it was overpriced at $429 US with the only advantage that I could see for the Samsung product was being IP68 water resistant and protected against dust ingress. Could have done without the bloatware. Some people will dislike the lack of a headphone jack but I only use Bluetooth so it is not an issue for me. Support for NFC would have been a plus. Essentially a great phone and aÂ Huawei Mate SE Factory Unlocked 5.93" - 4GB/64GB Octa-core Processor| 16MP + 2MP Dual Camera| Grey (US Warranty)great bargain.

I was originally considering the Honor 7X, then I saw this device with twice the RAM and an extra GB of RAM. After a week of use this device has been amazing. The screen is beautiful and responsive, all the apps I want to use work well. Let's make this quick.
Pros- The phone is very snappy. Responsive and just a joy to use.
- Screen is great for the price. Feels soft for typing. Decent for videos and zoom is nice for widescreen.
- Allows you to use MOST of the stock Android apps with full support.
- Battery is quite awesome. Processor is fast and efficient.
- Mostly a stock experience after changing a few settings.

Cons- CAMERAS are excessively bad. I can't stress enough that you should buy a different phone if you want a good front and back camera. These are so poor in performance it's kinda sad. Oversaturated, poor auto focus, horrible white balance and exposure settings for auto. Even after trying to install 3rd party apps as well as Google's own camera. I came to the conclusion that the sensor is just grainy and dissapointing. My 3 year old Nexus 6p worth 4 less megapixels takes better photos just cause it uses Google's image processing.
- Huawei's ROM is pretending to be Android iOS it's pretty lame but easily fixed.

End: Glad I bought it totally going to buy one for my dad later in the year.

I am a US T-Mobile customer and my last 2 phones were:

- Oneplus 1 for 2yrs
- Oneplus 3 for almost another 2yrs.

Both were purchased directly from the Oneplus website, not Amazon. I loved them both. After recently breaking my OP3 I was was devastated to find out that my insurance was not able to provide a replacement phone only a refund, which sounded ok at first (I would just find one here on Amazon). Since I could not afford the price of the new OP6 (just released), I re-purchased a new OP3 from a seller here on Amazon. To my dismay it was an international version and could only receive 2G speeds from my carrier due to the Band range. So after returning it, I found this gem for $150 less than my OP3.

For the last 4 years I have enjoyed the use of phones that were on the pricier side and manufactured by a startup company based out of China. I did my research and Huawei appears to be making phones with great parts for low prices. The total price I paid for this phone was almost $270 total with tax. That is a lot of money to spend when bigger companies like LG and Samsung have nice phones for $200, but their quality is not quite as good Overall (Screen resolution, camera quality, internal storage and RAM that the Mate SE has for $250).

I would recommend this phone for US GSM customers that are comfortable with paying $250 for a $400 phone. With all that said, this phone has a solid build, great specs, and a happy customer.

It does everything that I wanted my Galaxy Note 4 to do, but faster with double the storage and a nicer screen. I'm already impressed with the battery life but I'm sure that will degrade over time. Still getting used to this version of Android and GUI but it looks neat.

This is a beautiful phone. There is no need to pay the outrageous prices for the tier one phones. The Huawei Mate SE Is a great phone for most of us. I like this phone a lot. I've had it for less than one week. My previous phone was a google / motorola nexus 6.

Good:
Screen is very nice and bright
Battery life is incredible. will last me two days when my old phone needed charging during each day
Camera is amazing. Front camera is as good as my old phone's back camera
Comes with a nice clear case

Bad:
Touch sensor is not great and sometimes registers a tap as a swipe. I wonder if this is a software or hardware problem
Form factor -- 2:1 aspect ratio is weird and unusual for android. There's a special button to tell the system to stretch the screen for each app. It has worked in every app I've pressed it, but it seems weird. It's also hard for me to reach the whole screen with one hand.
Spyware is factory installed.

I usually like to mod my phone and get root and install custom roms. This phone I haven't even rooted yet, but I still leave that open as a possibility. The built in ROM is quite nice it supports themes including dark mode. I've been using DNS66 to block ads. It works ok, but some sites still show ads. This phone doesn't have a section in XDA yet but the previous model (Honor 7x) does and the development is progressing slowly. This phone is bootloader unlock able and root able using the same procedure as the 7x. Today Huawei released Oreo beta for honor 7x in US and I assume that will come to this phone too.

Overall I'm quite happy with this device and I think that it's pretty good. I hope that Huawei / Hi Silicon release information about the CPU and camera allowing custom kernel and ROM development.

This Huawei Mate SE is much nicer and more sophisticated than the Honor 5X. The problem I have for both phone is the operating system taking too much space. The Mate SE Firmware used 12 Gigabyte plus 3 GB for other when it was just shipped. After the 1st software update, it still used 8 GB plus. My Honor 5x is the same way. It has 16 GB and the Firmware used almost 6 GB plus 2 GB for other. I keep having clean up files and delete photo in order to keep my honor 5X running. I am having doubt about how the operating system used up that much space (8 GB plus 3 GB for other?). I am not sure if other brand are the same way.

Edit: This is legitimately the worst purchase I have ever made in my life. 3 months after arrival the phone is completely unusable, as it fails to recognize sim cards. It is completely irrelevant how good the warranty is, how the company treats customers, and everything else. If your product is completely nonfunctional in 3 months you need to do the world a service and get out of the market..

Beware. Even in protective cases expect this phone to last a month before the screen breaks. I dropped it 10" while in the case to have the screen shatter. After sending it to Square trade, and having it come back as good as new, it immediately went back into the case, and has developed a new crack in the screen, without being dropped at all. This in the month since it was returned to me. All in all a beer average device by performance, but Jesus it's more fragile than a soap bubble.

I bought this phone and I had used it for a few days now. I Will name some of the Pro's and Con's based on my opinion:

Pro's
*Excellent battery, I finish my day with 20%
*Fingerprint sensor is super fast
*No laggy OS

Con's
*Really not the best camera. Do not buy if you like to take lots of pics. Also, videos are really bad.
*Screen colors are Pale and I totally dislike that because I had a LG G4 and the screen was better. If you had an Amoled phone before, then don't buy it.

I will add more while I continue to use this phone.

Huawei phones are totally under the radar. I upgraded from an Honor 6x I've had for 18 months - I loved that phone. Battery life on Huawei phones is incredible. The Mate SE looks and feels premium, hits the 80/20 rule right in the sweet spot. Screen resolution is not as high as a phone like the LG V20 I also bought for comparison, but the Mate SE is lighter, sleeker, and has much, much longer battery life. EMUI is a good overlay - fairly iPhone-like without losing the Android experience.

I was trying to replace my 2 year old OnePlus X with Huawei Mate SE. Mate SE packaging was cheap, but when opened the phone, it looked gorgeous. It really makes impression of expensive device. However, there are few things that I didn't like, so I had to return it:

1. Performance. Comparing to my old OnePlus X, Mate SE is slow. When I used it for a day, it was kind of OK. The next day, it was so slow, so it took 1-3 seconds to respond to my tap. I had to restart the device and then it become tolerable but still not fast enough comparing to OnePlus.
2. Size. The devise is bulky and heavy.
3. Screen glare.
4. Speaker and sound quality. It sounds very cheap.
I would recommend this phone to people who transition from cheaper phones. People who have more expensive devices will not like this phone.

This phone is amazing in so many ways. The only reason I gave it 4 stars is because the notification light in the upper right corner is so tiny you can barely see it. The other thing I don't like is that you must use the same notification tone for emails and texts. I've never had a phone where you can't have different sounds for the two. Pix are amazing, storage is good. Works just fine for me.

I'm loving this phone. One nice thing is that it did not come with a lot of bloatware already installed. The other reviews cover all the technical details. I just want to say it is a very easy phone to use and is much cheaper than other large format smart phones.

I dont really used the phone, cause I was unable to connect to my home wifi.
I found its is known problem of other models of this company, so I return it.

The phone seemed pretty nice at first but now when I try to make a call I get a popup saying I need to enable VoLTE to make calls. There is no option to do that so now I have an essentially worthless phone. I can't find any tech support regarding this issue.
Good overall phone with one giant negative. This phone will not connect to Wi-Fi 5g. This is a big deal as the 2.4 band is loaded and makes your internet slow and will not stream without buffering.

I went from a note 3 to this and felt like it was a downgrade.
Pros:
Price
Touch sensor

Cons:
touch screen does not seem as responsive as my note 3.
Camera only shoots great under perfect lighting.
Speaker is sub par
After about two weeks of having my phone the speaker is very muffled and full of static can barely hear anything when on loud speaker or when playing videos etc.

Phone works fine. I enjoyed using it for gaming and daily usage although, screen is not bright enough. Speaker was loud but at high volume it explodes. However, after 2 weeks of usage the speaker started having problems such as: staticky, and when put on high volume it explodes and after observing it the speaker started weakening and i couldn't barely cant hear anything. I called Huawei support team/warranty department and it was hard communicating with them since they are based in china. They told to me to factory reset my phone every time the speaker stops working. After factory resetting it worked but who would buy a phone that needs to be factory reseted every time something goes wrong with it? . Don't get me wrong the phone is nice and performance is fine. Speaker problems though is a big "NO, NO".

It's affordable, it's fast, it has a great camera for the price, and the screen is big and easy to read. I've had zero problems with this phone, and only a couple of small caveats that led to not quite making that fifth star. One is a lack of support for 5ghz wifi (a major oversight for a device released in 2018), and the other is that Huawei has discontinued their bootloader unlocking service. They didn't just discontinue it, they lied about when they were ending the service, having announced an end date.. the week after they took down the site. So, if you were hoping to play with custom roms, this is not the phone for you.
Beyond that, it's performed like a champ, and still manages to make it through a day with decent charge, and in my use case, with the murderously battery-draining apps I need to keep loaded on it for my job, that is really saying something. My previous phone, a Blu R1 HD, was at 20% by 6pm, this baby is reporting in with 55% at 10pm.. There's also no dreaded sudden yet silent loss of connectivity requiring a reboot on a daily basis that's so common with chinese phones, either. It's perfectly reasonable to expect 10 days or more of rock solid up time.
I've used several budget phones. This one was a disappointment. It was slow, logging, poor camera, issue with convertering photos to MMS massage etc.

This thing is absolutely nuts for the money. Fast no lag and everything I use runs fine on it. The HiSuite software that you can download for it allows you to text from the PC while it is connected. You can also easily backup all your stuff using the software even import export your texts etc. I can't get over how much you get for the money. This thing even runs super cool even with the bulkiest case available for it. I used this thing all day without a charger and only used 9% battery too and that included watching some videos on youtube and everything. This is one smokin phone and definitely holds it's own against current flagship models out there.

Great design, remarkable battery life, nice screen, friendly OS, also came with a transparent cover.

Have a manual mode in order to take the manual control over the pics, but really, who have time to set all that taking a casual pic? Others phones do this job with great results instead this one.

Initial Review: Huawei Mate SE looks, feels and performs very good. I like it very much. It is worth more than the price I paid for it. I will chose it anytime over the other expensive phones.

This phone is great. A lot better than most Samsung or Apple phones that cost 400+ dollars. It runs very smoothly. The camera quality is amazing. Although it does take a long time for it to fully charge (it takes about 2-3 hours for it to fully charge from 10 percent), the battery lasts very long.
Love this phone have to return it because my bluetooth wasn't connecting

Just received this phone last week b/c my other Honor phone had issues and now I can't believe I'm saying this but my phone just blew up sitting here at my desk at work. SHOCKED is beyond what I'm feeling. I have faith in this company and love the Huawei phones but idk... I'm a little hesitant now.

Powerful phone, fast. The OS takes a whopping 14 gigs of space, leaving only 50 gigs free of the 64. The claim of 5.93 inch screen is only true if one includes the control panel. Actual viewable screen size (according to screen measuring software) is only 5.6". The screen does not have the look or feel of a true 6" screen. Does come with a case, which is a nice touch.

A shame it doesn't have induction charging. That would have been nice on a phone of this quality.

Was advertised as Android 7.0. When I turned it on almost first thing it did was update to a solid Android 8.0. Hurrah!

Annoying factor: despite the fact it has very accurate fingerprint-login recognition, every 3 days it requires entering the pin number. This can't be changed, it's not an option, it's hard-wired into the system. BAD HUNWEI. I suspect someone in design department trying to earn his wage with "new idea"... and missed the mark. It doesn't imrprove security, is an annoyance every 3 days, and NO CUSTOMER WANTS THIS, right? On that point alone I knock this down an entire star.

Watermark issue: the CAMERA app may come in default mode to stamp a Huawei logo blurb on every photo it takes. To fix this, go to settings and un-check the "Watermark" option. (Personally, I can't imagine why Huawei would believe any customer would want their company logo on our photos. What were they thinking?)

Major drawback: A customer reports turning on Wifi and Bluetooth at same time causes a major bottleneck. Something to be aware of if you regularly use a Bluetooth headset. Another star knockdown.

I am very impressed with its wifi speed. I wasn't aware until recently that different Android devices can have higher or lower wifi download speeds. This phone significantly out-performs every other Android device I've used in sheer speed of wifi downloads-- including my high-cost Android tablet.

Overall I'm quite pleased with this phone, with a couple of annoying exceptions. Yes, recommended.

The one really disappointing thing for me is the battery life. I cannot get through a full day with even moderate use. I have put it on battery saver mode, made sure no apps are running in the background and made whatever other setting adjustments I could, but the battery life is still poor. I recharge once during the day for a while, and it is OK. However, I don't think I should have to do that. I am not sure if the battery is a general situation, or if I have just received a bad one.

Update 4/2/18: company emailed me about ways to increase battery life. It worked. The battery is now great, and so is this phone, probably the best I have ever owned! Dual sim is awesome. I live in Costa Rica, and need both Movistar and Kolbi for complete coverage.

After having this phone for a few days now, I can say I'm very pleased with it. I owned a Moto X Pure which was a Motorola flagship phone and the Huawei Mate SE is lightening fast in comparison. I was a little nervous about the form factor being 8:9 but the phone size fits comfortably my hand. Also, After owning the Moto X Pure and having great sound quality with the two front facing speakers, I was afraid the Huawei Mate SE would pale in comparison. Well, I was surprised that the one speaker has pretty good sound.

The only con is that the phone has very few choices for cases and screen protectors. Even it's sister phone (Honor 7X) doesn't have a quality two piece case available. I did end up getting a Skinomi screen protector and a Spigen case. They are adequate for now.

UPDATE: Huawei support says Oreo (Android 8) available first of May, 2018 for Huawei Mate SE.

If you are hesitant to buy this phone, DON'T BE! I think you will be very pleased with your purchase.

The best phone you can buy for $200 bucks! It performs like my s7.

Been using it about a week. I will update my review if anything changes.
UPDATE 4/14/18: So something else I don't like is the brightness problem. Regardless of whether you turn on/off the auto brightness, certain apps will dim when used. So my home background and google search or some other apps are all bright but when I open my chrome browser, it gets very dimmed. Only way is to up the brightness to full but that also means everytime I come back to other apps or home background, its so bright. After using EMUI for about a week right now, I find more errors than more convenience. This dimming problem and not getting gmail notification are really starting to get on my nerves. So I had to take one more star away.

I definitely recommend it if you are looking for a good phone under the budget. Everything runs smoothly and camera is actually better than I expected and overall, I can't really complain much because of its great price. However, as someone who has to stay on top of my emails and such for my work, it gets frustrating because getting a notification for my gmails is hit or miss. I also don't get notifications from certain apps but I don't care as much as I care for my emails. I tried looking for battery optimization setting and trying to see if I can excempt it from battery saving etc but no option such as protected apps on this system. Notification is a big, big problem for me and probably lot of people who depend on their phone for work. Other than that, I don't have anything that I dislike about this phone as of yet.
This is the best phone for the price that I've ever had. It seems like flagship quality, for $230.

I have owned this phone a little over a week and can't say anything but good about it. Runs smooth like a champ. All apps are quick and snappy, including games and social media. 64 gb storage and the extra money for 1 extra gig of ram and double the storage was worth it to me. 4 gig ram also allows apps to run quick and even when multiple are running its quite fast. 4g lte is also a great bonus, although it's expected in most smartphones these days.
Battery life is also very good with its close to 3400 mAh battery. I can be on it all day and still have about 30% by the end of the day, given I would run it for 8 to 10 hours straight. The phone is larger than other phones I have owned and some may feel that the screen ratio is strange. I however don't mind it being a bit taller and slender. Some people are worried that because it's not a flagship phone that it won't perform and that is not the case. Fingerprint scanner is very fast and responsive. The camera is mediocre to say the least but what can you expect from a phone that doesn't break the bank at only $229 dollars. Also, for those who are worried about "spying", Huawei is just a company trying to make money like any other. I highly recommend this phone to any who were on the edge about purchasing in the beginning as I was. It is a fantastic product.

Do not buy this phone if you need the dual SIM functionality - it doesn't work. With two SIM cards in the slots, only one SIM can be active at any time. The other SIM will be inactive (no signal) and cannot receive calls or messages. I spent an hour talking to Huawei tech support and they confirmed this is the case. You will need to manually go to settings to select the SIM card that you want to make active. This makes the dual sim feature practically useless. Very misleading advertising.

I bought this phone out of curiosity and good reviews from Amazon. I was excited when I opened the box. I liked the hardware design of the product. But the SW is not there. Here are a couple of examples of bad bugs or design features that are troublesome for me.

1. The data transfer from my old Nexus to this phone needed to go through the cellular/hotspot data path instead of WiFi or other low cost means. This was the first surprise. Fortunately, I only picked up a couple of small items to transfer. Otherwise, I would have exhausted my data plan for the month without completing a 3rd of the transfer.

2. the icons in the app groups is way too small to see.

3. way too many meaningless settings for me to play with to get the phone to a point that I like it to be.

4. the camera is not able to zoom in in viewfinder mode (being referred to as "portrait mode" in the pop-up message when I tried to zoom).

5. There are a couple of Huawei related things such as "Huawei share" that I don't even want to try.

6. when I viewed pictures from my Google drive folder today, the pictures darkened themselves to a point that I can hardly see what's in the pictures. I found no way to change that behavior.

The item 6 above is the last straw that made me decide to return this product. I am not sure of what other surprises I will run into down the road. Enough and no more Huawei products. I am going back to Moto.

Beautiful phone and you'll think you have the best hardware/software for the price. THERE IS A REASON FOR THE LOW PRICE. This phone is defective and has very serious signal problems. I understand it uses the same antenna for both Bluetooth and Wi-Fi. You can use only one at a time, you won't know it but you will realize it because of the miserable speed when using Bluetooth. It will not connect to Wi-Fi 5G!!!! Mostly no problems with calls and messages, but video will degrade constantly and images will become completely blurred. This is above ground! I am in NYC and am used to the intermittent signal service in the Subway, as it is only available at the train stations. All my prior phones, including my last Huawei HONOR 5X, worked fine. They would pick up the signal as we approached the station, go full signal at the station and would start losing strength as you move away from the station, but you will be able to connect! This phone is really, really bad at it (horrible really!). You may be at the station already, it would show full signal and 4GTE but it will not connect, it will be frozen, it will not open any pages. Sometimes I go through four or five station before I have a response from the phone. I thought the phone was malfunctioning and got it replaced. Same issue with replacement. I sent the second back to Huawei, I don't know what they did, but phone still the same and never heard from Huawei again. If you only use this above ground for calls and messages, you will like this phone. If you need to use it for the internet or streaming, this is not what you want, and in situations similar to mine, like the subway system, this one really sucks and in case of an emergency underground, you don't want to be caught with this one. DON'T BUY THIS PHONE, IT APPEARS TO BE FACTORY DEFECTIVE.

This is it, this is the phone you want to buy if your budget is less than $500. At half of that cost too. I always bought flagships, from Samsungs to HTC to Apple. I am switching to this phone from an iPhone X mainly because I wanted to sell it off before the next batch of iPhones were released, and also just because I missed Android. This phone is not a flagship and while you must keep in mind that this costs 4x less than most flagships, it does so well and I have little experience with budget phones that I can't help but compare it to them. I'm a week in and am so blown away by this phone that I figured it deserved a review. I do a lot of navigation for work, play Pokemon Go, and just normal social media from my phone.
Battery life - While it is not a two day battery life like some people claim, it is better than anything else I have used besides the Samsung Note devices. Normally I plug in when using Google Maps but decided against it just to test. After a full day at 50% brightness, waking up early and going to bed around 11, I was left with 10%. I had done around 3 hours of screen on navigation, around two hours of Pokemon Go, and around two hours of social media throughout the day. Very impressed. Should be noted that when I used the dual sim feature, the battery seemed to die a lot quicker and I was needing to charge by around 7.
Software - Running Huaweis own UI was the biggest concern of mine. I had almost went with a Nokia 6.1 because of the stock Android. It performed better than I could've imagined and I experience no slowdown at all, everything feels very snappy and I've only seen a couple lags on apps that seem to lag no matter the phone. Upgrade-able to Android 8.0 out of the box, time will tell if we get any more updates.
Design - Definitely nice feeling in the hand, I used the included case out of the box. Looks to be inspired my iPhone and while it is a good looking phone, I don't appreciate the branding on both the front and back. Although it is helpful as I had to check about 7 times to remember how to spell Huawei.
Display - A much nicer display then I thought would be possible on a device of this cost. Besides the blacks, I really can't tell a difference in this display and any from Apple or Samsung, definitely can't tell which is sharper but that may just be me. It does not get as bright as other phones, but I never use full brightness anyway.
Connectivity - Amazingly this was faster than both my iPhone X and my Galaxy S7. I am on the T-Mobile network and get around 50 mbps speed compared to the 37 on S7 and abysmal 13-20 on iPhone. GPS never has problems finding where I am and it reconnects very quickly. I don't use enough bluetooth to make a fair opinion but I will point out that some other reviews are correct. While on WiFi if you connect to a bluetooth device, my connection dropped by about 15 mbps. Not a big deal when it's 55 down to 40 in my case because it's still plenty fast but beware if you have a slower connection and use both a lot. I only use bluetooth in the car so it doesn't affect me. Oh this is a phone right? Call quality is decent. Nothing mind blowingly clear or really any difference from other decent phones. It also does not support 5ghz WiFi which is disappointing but not a deal breaker.
Camera - The part where most budget phones cut their corners. The camera is good. Better than most budget phones but not even close to any flagships. Low light isn't very good and it takes awhile to focus sometimes. Usually it gets the job done but this is probably the weakest point in the phone. Pictures can still look great provided you have proper lighting though. Front camera also gets the job done but a little washed out. I don't take selfies so again, not a deal breaker.
Value - Just buy it. I guarantee this phone will make you question why there are $1000+ smartphones. If you need a nicer camera on a phone I doubt you will find it on anything less than $600 though. It's a $230 phone that does 95% of everything phones 2,3,4x its cost will do. Plus you get a headphone jack, micro sd card or dual sim, there's also a case in the box. No headphones though. Extremely happy with this purchase and will update if anything changes.

UPDATE 07-23-18: So it's taken a little bit, but I ran across a setting on the phone that I've not seen on other Android devices that could help a lot of folks out there especially when it comes to battery management. If you've done any sort of deep dive into this or other Huawei phones, you've undoubtedly come across their great battery life but also the fact that some apps don't behave as well or give out weird notifications. Let's keep this simple: Android operating systems let apps run after you open them until you make them stop running (by selecting all previously open apps and clearing them). EMUI skips all that nonsense by pretty much shutting everything down once you finish with it (or sometime soon thereafter). Great for battery, but bad for things like say something that relies on geofencing (yes Arlo, I'm talking about you). But there is a very simple workaround.

To get an app working and to have it continue to work (like the caller ID app HiYa) here's what you do. Go to Settings and then to Apps and Notifications. Select Apps. AT THE BOTTOM OF THE APP PAGE you'll see ANOTHER Settings icon. Click on it. Now select Special Access and then Exempt from Battery Optimization. Your final step: click were it says Allowed and select All Apps. Once that is done, find the app you want to exclude from battery optimization, select it, and then select Allow (may drain your battery more quickly).

Selecting a few of these shouldn't have an adverse affect on you battery, just don't go crazy and select everything. Good ones to have selected besides HiYa: Visual Voicemail, Dropbox, and Wear OS. Hope this helps!

UPDATE 05-18-18: About a week ago I started to get this error when checking on one of my apps: Google Play Services Are Updating. From what I've read, the problem seems to be confined to Huawei and Honor handsets (and one has to wonder if it's because of the recent update to EMUI 8.0 and Oreo 8.0). The fix is easy - navigate to Settings and then to Apps & Notifications, Apps again and then find Google Play Services. Once you tap on the app, go to Storage and then hit "Clear Cache". Once that is done, finish it off by going to "Manage Space" and then "Clear All Data." If you were getting the Google Play Services Are Updating error, it should be cleared. My error was coming through the Arlo app- others reported they were having problems with Google Maps and Uber (or any app that relies on Google Maps for location).

UPDATE 05-17-18: Phone recently received Oreo 8.0 and EMUI 8.0 update about a week ago. Phone seems a little faster and still pretty bulletproof. I mentioned Arlo app problems- turned out Arlo was having a little Android/server meltdown a few weeks back (that has straightened itself out). One tip: make sure under geo-fencing you have your home address typed into the address box (the app decided my phone wanted to be in Madagascar - if only...). Wireless adapter still works but will still do the annoying reset ping over and over randomly. Full screen problem seems to have disappeared with the update (or maybe I just finally set all of the apps to fs every time they asked). Still liking the phone and recommending it to anyone in the market for a new handset.

ORIGINAL POSTING: :If youâre in the market for a new Android smartphone you have a multitude of choices. I recently started having problems with my Galaxy Note Edge (a one-time Samsung flagship) but given that the phone lasted way past its two-year mark, Iâd say I got my moneyâs worth.

The biggest factor in my decision making for getting the Huawei Mate Special Edition (SE) was price. Itâs hard to swallow paying upwards of $800 to $1,000 for a smartphone thatâs one drop away from becoming the worst thing to happen to you all week/month/year. On the other hand, after experimenting with lower-end budget phones (ZTE Maven and Moto G4), I learned that at least with Android, you do get what you pay for.

Iâm going to start with something a little different from most other reviews: apps I had to replace. Specifically, there were three stock apps that were tripping me up on the Huawei, because they wouldnât do certain things. I found free replacements for them on the Play Store and Iâve had no problems since the switchovers.

â¢ First the browser: Chrome on the Mate SE is slow and full of ads. I ditched it for (of all things) Samsungâs Internet browser coupled with two extensions for ad blocking (Adblock Fast and Disconnect for Samsung Internet). Much faster and you have the advantage of a home screen of web shortcuts you can create inside the app.

â¢ Next, the music player. For some odd reason, Huaweiâs music player doesnât read pre-made m3u files (these are files for playlists). You can make one on the phone, but if you have ones that were made on a computer, the phone wonât recognize them. Solve it by installing another music player (I used Pi Music Player and it works just fine).

â¢ As for the camera, the dual back facing cameras are pretty capable right out of the box (you will want to play with the photo and video settings to get high quality pictures). But there is one software/app problem that doesnât affect everyone but will affect some: in video mode, the camera wonât recognize an external microphone. Most smartphones can handle a TRRS microphone (4 âpolesâ and three black rings) ; the stock camera app on this phone can't. Solution: download a different camera app. I used Open Camera; to get it to work, in video settings, set the microphone to use external mic when present and you should be good to go.

Now the good stuff.

Is the Huawei Mate SE a good substitute for a Galaxy Note Edge? Yes. Is it as perfect as the Note Edge was in its hey-day? Nope. Am I much happier with a new Huawei than a three-year old Samsung? Definitely.

So letâs start with whatâs missing.

Thereâs no NFC, no 5G wi-fi, no removable battery and of course, no S-Pen. The Mate SE also has a bottom firing speaker that while loud, is kind of weird the first few times you listen to it. Screen resolution on the Mate SE is not as bright and crisp as the Note Edgeâs Super AMOLED display (but after a few days youâll get used to it).

What will you NOT get with the Mate SE that youâll get on other smartphones (some priced the same, some more expensive)?

â¢ No USB-C- Not a deal breaker for me b/c I have a ton of Micro USB chargers and cables lying around (so itâs actually a plus right now).

â¢ No Android 8.0 Oreo- The Mate SE ships with Android 7.0 (Nougat) but since the Mate SEâs sister phone the Honor 7x is now going through beta testing with 8.0, Oreo is probably in the Mateâs very near future.

So what is there to like?

â¢ Battery life. I run the same exact apps (plus the three substitutes I mentioned) on my Huawei as I did on the Galaxy Note Edge. At the end of the day, the Edge was at about 15% but the Mate SE is at about 50%. The Mate SE has a 3340mAh battery; the Note Edge a 3000mAh battery. Size-wise, itâs not a big difference, but the phone, the processor, and the 7.0 OS versus the 6.0 OS on the Note is obviously much more efficient. Advantage Huawei.

â¢ The fingerprint sensor. THIS THING WILL BLOW YOUR MIND. Iâve used a fingerprint sensor before, but I found it finicky and slow. Not so here: the Mate SEâs sensor is super, super, SUPER fast. Touch it, and youâre in.

â¢ Landscape mode: This is odd- on my Samsung Galaxy Note Edge I could never get the phone to do a decent landscape mode on the home pages. Inside an app, no problem, but on the home screens, it never worked. This phone does landscape on all pages. Itâs a little thing, but after missing it for so long, itâs kind of cool.

Cool Stuff Iâve not seen before since my last new smartphone three years ago:

â¢ IP67 dust or water resistance (originally I didn't think it had it, but apparently it's on the spec sheet).

â¢ Screenshot scroll. Youâve probably done a screenshot before, but what happens when you want to get an entire page as a screenshot that is longer than what you can see on the screen? Screenshot scroll takes care of that: itâs built-in software that will copy an entire page not just what is displayed on the phone (find it in drop down navigation menu). A regular screenshot is just a tap on the navigation button as well (instead of remembering a combo of volume up and power keys).

â¢ Speaking of the drop down navigation menu, Huawei gives you the ability to add a fourth button for that navigation menu at the bottom of your display. You can program the fingerprint sensor to perform a task by sliding your finger across the sensor (like say opening the camera), blocked numbers can be based on keywords and contacts, and Huawei has a virus scanner baked into the phone under the phone manager app.

â¢ Other goodies: you can encrypt photos and videos as well as lock certain apps so that you (and your fingerprint and nobody else) can use the app. Finally, thereâs App Twin- the ability to log into the same app using two different accounts at the same time. two different logins on the same app at the same time.

My last comments: troubleshooting some apps and things.

â¢ If you happen to use Waze with Android Auto, youâre going to have problems with the Mate SE the first time you try it. The fix: go to settings, go to apps, select Android Auto, delete all data including the cache, start Android Auto BEFORE you connect it to the car and go through the permissions. Once done, connect it to the car and you should be good to go. Donât ask, all I know is it worked for me.

â¢ I still havenât properly figured out why the phone and Wear OS (for smartwatches) isnât perfect (I had to reboot and start over several times to get watch faces to download.

â¢ If you miss wireless Qi charging from your old phone (or you want to add it to this one), buy a wireless adapter. I modified my old Note Edge to do wireless charging using an internal wirless pad; I did the same with the Mate SE using one that plugs into the bottom of the phone (search for a "narrow side up" Nillkin Magic Tag Qi Wireless Charger). It's about 12 bucks- worth the investment. The only drawback with mine: the Huawei Mate SE "cycles" through a bunch of charges. What I mean by cycle is it will charge, the screen will light up, and the phone will beep. That's normal when you start to charge, but it kept doing this over and over again about every 30 seconds or up to 2 minutes or so between cycles. Strangely sometimes it does it, sometimes it doesn't. I finally just loaded an old schedule setter app that turns the ringtone to zero each night and back to 100 in the AM in place of Do Not Disturb.

Iâll finish with this: the dumbest thing about this phone (and the nicest!) is the 18x9 display. On most apps it works perfectly fine. On some, a dialogue box pops up asking if you want to go âfull screen.â My answer is always yes and when I hit it, it makes you sometimes start all over again. Huawei- please fix this! Itâs the one annoying aspect of your phone that there doesnât seem to be a quick fix for.

Conclusion: if you need a new phone, buy this one. It comes with lots of memory (64GB built in) and lots of operating RAM (4GB). You can pop in a big SD Card (I have a 128GB) or another SIM if you want to go dual-SIM. Is it going to be as good as a flagship phone? No. But are you getting $600-$700 more âumphâ in a Note 8, S9, iPhone 8 or iPhone X than you would in a Mate SE? Thatâs for you to decide.

# # #

I purchased this phone due to the price . it replaced a great Samsung phone , that the dawgs knocked out of my hand and cracked the screen. The new Samsung phones are way too much money , and to repair a phone is expensive so i got this phone . i used ATT with a SIM card out of my old phone . when i got this phone i read the instructions on how to put the SIM card in . they provide a wire pin to push into a hole on the side of the phone and a tray pops out , then you place the SIM card and memory card on this plastic tray and side it back into the phone . the tray appears to be very fragile , and the instructions were not clear on exactly how to put both cards onto the tray . it is kind of scary because then you have to side the tray in and if it gets stuck you cannot get it back out . the procedure is easy when you know how , i don't want to over dramatize it . but you do need to be careful .it took me about 5 mins to totally figure it out

i took the SIM card out of my ATT Samsung phone put it on the tray slide it into the phone , turned on the phone , and it worked perfectly . then i used the pin provided , got the tray out and got my memory card from my old phone and put it into the tray , The tray has slots in it that has guides that shows you the orientation to use . the phone read the card , and i had all my old photos MP3's documents etc working just perfectly when i put it in .

Thus to move the cards is very painless , you just need to learn a different way from Samsung to do it .

this phone has a stand alone FM radio in it , that uses the ear phones as its antenna . This is something that should have been with the first smart phones . the radio will play through the head phones or through the speakers . thus with Samsung when I wanted to listen to the radio i had to use WiFi or my data plan to listen to the radio . the FM radio is a good one too .

The internet speed seemed to have a problem , but this seems for some reason to normalize .. what i mean that the speed test would not be as fast when tested it against my other computers or smart phones . after a week this has seemed to have worked it self out , and now it will register as the same speed as my other computers . so just be aware of this

another issue it that when i would send e mail , with a photo attached it would take a long time to send . for some reason this has work itself out and sends at the same speed and my other electronic . kind of weird , just be aware of it .
other wise i could not be more please with this phone . it works as it is suppose to . and as a computer it is perfect . i can talk on the phone , minimize the phone icon and use the completer to look stuff up , use the calculator etc while i m talking on the phone . i was not able to do this with the Samsung . maybe you could , but i was never able to do it .

SO IF YOU WAnt A GREAT PHONE that is not expensive that work as a smart phone is suppose to , and does it very well , this is it . i am very happy with my purchase

good price, but I like liter color, later I found and only $220 (same model), so you should put all color together, let me easy to choice.

Super phone, but battery seems to last litte.... it's new and less that 10 hrs and already need to recharge.
