Do not buy any more

This review is way overdue, however I wanted to give myself time to use the phone and get used to its features so I have good information regarding its good qualities and bad ones as well. Fist of oll i am coming from the flagship world of LG and OnePlus phones. I've had the OnePlus One, X, and OP2. Also from the LG Family i've had all of the G Series phones from the G2 all the way through the G6 as well as all V-series phones, V10 and V20, .except the V30. In actuality it was the Huawei Mate SE that Drew me away from the V30 Purchase that I was about to make.The Good/Excellent Qualities of this phone. Actually there is nothing good about this phone.... The things that you like about this phone, are GREAT!!!!
Battery Life: I will go through 1complete day of heavy use (heavy video 3hrs and audio 2hrs streaming) plus regular internet and app (instagram and email) use. no gaming, and still have 15 - 20% battery life by the time i'm going to bed. So Battery life for me is outstanding and it does come with a quick charge feature as long as you use a qualcomm or compatible quick charge device.
Screen Resolution_ Outstanding. Pictures are crisp and colorful and the the stock UI comes with enough options to adjust color and hue to your liking. Also direct sunlight viewing is outstanding with no visible loss in color or shading. Love it!
Processing Speed without a doubt is excellent. Just as fast as any Flagship phone i've ever used. I multi task quite a bit (also come s with a split screen mode which i use frequently to fact check or look up items that I watch on youtube or shopping) and this phone handles everything that I do and more.
WIFI and Bluetooth - comes with an outstanding wifi radio which gets excellent reception from wifi transmitters that you may have problems with on other devices. Also the Bluetooth radio is excellent as well. more of a typical experience but non problematic as most Bluetooth setups are.
Form Factor: its lightweight and thin. very similar to an iphone 7+ or maybe a samsung glaxy 8+
finger print reader: Outstanding. quicker than an LG phone by noticeable lengths. and very reliable.

the not so great or just good::
bluetooth connectivity. I was having difficulties connecting the bluetooth after 3 days of continuous use withouth shutting the phone off. Ive found that shutting the phone off every 2 days alleviates the problem. however now Ive set the phone sho shut off and turn back on at 545-550 in the morning and now i don't even have to touch the phone. my bluetooth now connects flawlessly evry time i enable it.
The camera is good. i can take good quality pics with this phone in normal to medium/low light levels. I take hundreds of photos weekly and i am not disappointed in its capabilities. i've had better but for what you get with this phone, it heavily outweighs the camera inabilities
Lack of USB C..... Okay, this was a big one for me. as all of my newer phones from OnePlus2 to my LG G6 and V20 have had USB type C. It was hard switching back to micro usb and i notice the micro chargers are more susceptible to the ends bending where USB type C are more rigid. But for 239 dollars, it was worth the trade off but to be honest its a livable condition considering the high quality of the phone and the price.

In closing this phone dwarfs the LG G6 and V20 in functionality (ie.UI, and performance) and comes with a dual sim Tray, one of which can be used for expandable memory up to 256GB. but with 4GB of RAM, 64GB of available memory, you probably won't need it.,

Thats it! Honestly, the phone is amazing overall and i Highly recommend buying the Mate SE over the 7X as the added memory and processing speed are worth the extra 30-40 dollars you'll spend.on the phone. As long as Huawei keeps making high quality phones in this price range, i don't ever think i'll buy another 500-1000 dollar phone every again!.
Only one day so far used this. Disappointed as there was no pin or headphone in the package. Will provide final review after 20 days.

I can't get to everything right now but I want to mention a few things until I can do a full-fledged (and edited-for-length) review. And maybe someone will read this and share how to fix Hangouts!

I think a lot of these reviews must be from before the Oreo update, or from people who mostly just use the phone to browse the internet and text people (with the terrible built-in app).

I am going to get rid of this phone as soon as I can. I am frustrated every time I interact with it.

The battery life is CRAZY good... because the phone kills EVERYTHING ALL THE TIME. The battery lasts forever because the phone doesn't function. Rotten trade-off. There are several different settings (each in a different section) that you have to change for each app that you don't want killed, and then it doesn't work most of the time anyway. Yesterday I watched an alarm be dismissed by the phone before it could notify me. A little bubble popped up saying "the app was blocked from using dropzone" (even though the app has permission to use dropzone). What is dropzone? They ain't gonna tell ya. You can spend several hours a day googling crap that the phone is screwing up. (No solutions for most of them.) BTW, you have to grant permission for each app to use dropzone (and write over other apps) or it won't pop up and alert you. If you grant permission it still won't alert you, but there we are.

You will probably have a hard time finding the various relevant settings because Huawei moves them with every update, doesn't explain them to users or devs, doesn't explain what icons on the screen mean, etc. So when you start googling during your daily Huawei troubleshooting session, you will find hundreds of outdated user guides that describe the previous operating systems. When you install an app that needs to be whitelisted, the app will likely launch a whitelist tutorial that sends you to a settings menu that doesn't function anymore (protected apps). Otherwise they'll send you to an obsolete page that tells you how to whitelist apps in the previous version of the OS. Most pages don't list all of the relevant settings anyway so you have to piece them together. It seems that I'm missing something too because my notifications aren't working properly even though I've gone through the 20-step process on each app. Why isn't there a single button for this?

If you want to try to whitelist an app to run in the background at all times, you have to:
* Go to "exempt from battery optimization" and make sure the app is exempt.
* Go to "launch" then "manually manage" the app, and make sure all 3 options are checked
* Open the app you want to whitelist, press the square multi-window navigation button to show recent apps, then click the lock image in the header of the app preview. It should be set to "locked." This is supposed to keep the app from being closed when you turn the screen off (who knows?)
* Go to the notification settings screen for your app. On every single notification category, set it to priority. This may take some time
* Go to the dropzone settings and grant permission to your app
* Per Oreo, all apps must have a notification showing that the app is running in the background, so if the app has a persistent notification option, you probably (?) have to activate it to keep the app alive. (I have 9+ persistent apps in my notification browser at all times now, looks great, A+, love visual clutter)
* If you use the power saving setting (which btw isn't available in the quick settings for some reason) you'll have to add apps to the unrestricted data access list as well, which causes problems but is mandatory in some cases
* Reboot your phone or it won't work
* Enjoy your significantly reduced battery life

I did all of this, in stages, for Hangouts, because I have a Google Voice phone number and can only use Voice or Hangouts to text with that number. No matter what I try, I can't get it to notify me of texts unless I manually open the app. I unwittingly ghosted several people for several days because of this garbage phone and garbage Oreo/emui. I think part of the problem is that Google is intentionally making Hangouts trash to drive users to their other products. And Oreo is bad. But the other part is that Huawei sucks at software and has prioritized battery life over basic phone functionality. I still have a few things to try but honestly I've spent most of my free time the past week trying to fix this piece of junk and I'm over it.

Oreo really did a number on notifications, and it looks like Huawei made it worse. Notification banners are constantly popping up when I'm typing, and whenever a banner pops up, the keyboard disappears, I accidentally tap the screen in a spot that makes something bad happen, and (from what I know about it) Huawei immediately dismisses the notification so I can't revoke the app's notification privileges because I don't know which app it was. This may be Huawei or common to all Oreo phones, but either way it makes the phone unpleasant to use.

The speaker-phone volume is almost as quiet as the regular headset volume. Sometimes I have to hold the speaker up to my ear to hear YouTube videos at full volume. I have very sensitive hearing so it's not just me. The Bluetooth volume control (?) is so whacked that even when the phone is connected to an extremely loud speaker, the volume is not significantly higher than that of the phone's speaker. It is a software issue. Some apps have adequate volume and some don't.

Their native apps suck. They made a cool shortcut feature on the lock screen that canopen several apps like calculator and clock without unlocking the phone, but the apps don't work for my purposes and don't have enough settings to be made useful. The timer makes a ticking sound that you can't turn off in settings (really representative of Huawei's design style) and has limited sound choices which are bad and not appropriate for my work setting. The alarm clock is stupid. The calculator has no history or any settings at all really. That lock screen shortcut feature was part of why I bought the phone. They could have made it customizable but that's really not how they operate. I like the flashlight a lot but I had a lock screen flashlight on my Lollipop phone five years ago.

Seriously the worst phone I've ever owned.

Original review:
Huawei uses a customized version of Android just like most phone manufacturers do. It's sort of a wreck. I use Amdroid alarm clock religiously because it has special features to make sure I can't ignore alarms. I spent a lot of time changing several battery settings so that the phone wouldn't kill the app, and it worked when I tested it, but this morning it didn't go off anyway. I'm so glad I had a backup alarm set. There's a Don't Kill My App page that shows you how to keep Huawei devices from killing your alarms, and they said that Huawei is a real PITA because they don't share information about how the OS works, so this kind of thing is a continuing problem. Without Amdroid alarm clock (and the other time/alarm/reminder apps that the phone kills) I have no use for this phone. Reminders and alarms are one of the main reasons I even have a smart phone.

It's so responsive and fast, and the battery lasts a really long time. The camera is sick. I'm really pleased with some of the features. But the app-killing is a dealbreaker. I think I can find a way around it but I've already spent a LOT of time working on making the phone work properly and it shouldn't be this freaking hard. (Even if you do sort out the battery settings for apps currently on your phone, you have to set them per app, which is an ordeal, and you have to set multiple settings perfectly each time you download a new app or it won't work. It might not work anyway. It is a painful process.)

Also, it's taller than a Note 4 but skinnier, so even though I have ridiculously long fingers, it's uncomfortable to reach search bars and things like that. (And the back/home/search bar is obnoxious.) It's a two-handed phone. YouTube videos look tiny because they're limited by the width of the screen. It's a tiny video on top, then the screen below is mostly filled with comments. If you tap "fill screen" then there are huge black bars on the sides. You have to hit "zoom" to fill the screen which crops out parts of the video (I haven't seen it on this phone yet but cropping like that usually cuts off captions). Most apps aren't optimized to work with this stupid aspect ratio so the OS displays an alert on the bottom ("tap to expand to fill screen, this may cause errors" or whatever) that fills up part of the screen. Basically the additional length isn't useful, and apps don't fill it, but makes the phone uncomfortable to hold. If you have a 5.93" phone that is shorter and wider, videos, images, etc., will be way bigger and the phone will probably be easier to navigate.

The speaker is on the bottom right, so if you hold it by the bottom edge in your right hand, the speaker will be covered.

It's a budget phone but I don't think it's cheaper to make a phone skinny with the speaker in a bad position, and set it up to kill apps constantly. Those were design choices. I'm pretty bummed.

I ordered my phone as an Amazon warehouse deal and I regret it. It arrived in a box that had been retaped twice. So I'm concluding that someone bought it and realized the right edge of the screen isn't touch-responsive, then they sent it back. It was "inspected" and taped back up. Someone else bought it and sent it back, it was inspected and taped again. I bought it and am sending it back. Don't be the fourth person, lol. It isn't that much cheaper and i have to set up a new phone all over again.

This is my second Huawei phone in a year as I upgraded from an Honor 6x purchased this time last year. That phone was still going strong but I wanted more RAM, storage and solid unibody design. I was so impressed with the 6x after some consideration I decided Huawei ticked all the right boxes once more.

That said this is much the same phone as the 6x but with a different form factor, somewhat stronger processor, and more RAM. Improvements include build quality, more vivid display with higher contrast ratio, smoother HD video streaming, and better audio through the headphone jack. It also has face unlock. However you need to wake the phone to it's lock screen to use the feature. The finger print sensor is faster to unlock the phone, but it's still a neat feature.

Phone has no quick charging capabilities or NFC. It also appears a bit drab in grey as the grey used is...drab. If you want the phone to appear expensive and upscale choose the white and gold varient. Oh, and the camera is good in this segment with lots of features.

For what it is and priced at $200 to $250 it's one of the best choices in smartphones one can make. Sleek, solid, reliable, and modern. I am good to go with Huawei for another year. This a great basic use phone.
Does not go good for services.

Very good value smartphone considering it's relatively low price point. My only complaints are that the camera quality is not as nice as my old MotoX, the external speakers leave a lot to be desired (volume is very low even when set on max, especially if you have a phone case), and the fingerprint sensor is a bit finicky sometimes. The phone also comes with a lot of bloatware apps, which I disabled upon setting up. The battery life is amazing compared to my old MotoX though. I can use it all day browsing the internet and it will still have plenty of power at the end of the day. I also snowboard in the winter and even in single digits temperatures the phone stays on and holds its charge. Just make sure you check with your phone carrier if this phone is compatible first. This model works perfectly on the AT&T network. However it is not fully compatible with T-Mobile - as per their tech Dept, the Mate SE is 100% compatible on the data network, but only 50% compatible on the calls/texts, so that is something you will want to keep in mind.
Second sim card will not work with at&t! Will only work with a 2g network

Great mid range smartphone with 64 gb of internal memory and 4 GB of RAM. The phone is well built, and has a solid feel to it. The camera, while not on par with the highest end Apple or Samsung Galaxy phones, is great in good light situations. I normally use the phone heavily, with streaming satellite radio at work while surfing the web and maybe playing a game. The ram in this thing means that everything runs smoothly. I have not had one problem with this phone. In fact, I bought a second one for my wife and she loves hers also. Two of these phones cost less than one of the even last generation Iphones or galaxies. Octa core processor, 64 GB of memory, 4 GB of ram, all at a great price.

I am using this on the metro pcs network. I am upgrading from the ZTE Zmax Pro and have to say this phone is a massive upgrade. There is nothing you can complain about here:

+Bright crisp display. 24bit, 1080p,5.93in,ips,18:9,gorilla glass. Awesome colors with deep inky blacks.
+Fast Processor: 2.3ghz octa-core processor
+Memory: Whopping 4gb Ram+64gb onboard storage! Micro sd expandable up to 256gb
+Camera: 8MP front camera combined with a dual 16MP rear. Takes quick very clean photos
+Software: Updated to Android Oreo. Stock phone has minimal bloatware. Useful preinstalled apps
+Unlocked: GSM network
Bottom line if this phone had Apple or Samsung pained on the front the price would be $499 minimum. I can't say enough how much value this phone offers. Fantastic phone!

Order arrived when promised and it's actually a really good phone. BUT just incase it is important (it is for me especially since Cricket only allows 8mbps download cap) That would be okay but that is only with LTE PHONES! This is a 4g phone and therefore it is only capable of spitting out 4 mbps downloads. It really sucks cuz other then that love this phone.

I've had the phone for approximately 6 months and I love it aside from the picture quality in low light. My big concern is that the US government has big issues with Huawei and it's alleged spying issues. There may be a time in the future where it will be difficult to get technical support or repair work done if Huawei offices are not in the USA.
You may wish to consider purchasing a different brand of phone. Which is a shame because the phone is really good.

Phone looks good. Its screen, view all are ok but if it is not sent from China. There are not any google services including play store too. So it suddenly looses its functionality. Chinese all over the place through the phone menus settings etc. Also there were problems related to screen sensors, i.e. the phone wasn't working properly as expected. I dont know how people place 5 to this seller, but it doesn't seem as an honest seller to me.

So I've owned iPhones and Galaxy's, and after paying a third of the price for this phone I truly believe Huawei is the best of both worlds! The camera is better than the iPhone, it has portrait if you're into that, also the Kirin processer is extremely smooth, almost "Apple smooth". This is the best Android I've owned, and I will never buy a Galaxy again. If you love the iPhone but want to try Android, you will absolutely love this device. The battery last forever and it's basically an iPhone trapped in an Android body. So before you buy a 800$ phone, consider this phone. Also if you are worried about Huawei spying, I'm just gonna put this out there, I have personally had 2 iPhone 7 phones hacked remotely And a Galaxy 7 hacked so...I don't trust any manufacturer anymore. And almost all phones are made in China, so if any of the other manufacturs wanted to spy they could, if they aren't already.

I have had this phone for a few weeks. I am extremely impressed. I got tired of having a samsung with at&t where they would release updates to slow it down. This phone does not have that and its well priced. I am very impressed. The battery life is amazing i used it all day 13+ hours and im still at 80% My usage includes social media connections to stock widgets and tickers. multiple long phone calls. connections to my home security system. The phone is fast and runs well. Only cons i have are that there are no available methods to root it or unlock the bootloader and how there isnt 5g on wifi. Other than that fantastic phone!

Got this phone in early 2018 because I had issues after only a year and a half with my Nexus 5X and didn't want to throw several hundred dollars at a phone. Excited based on the reviews to try this one. First few months were great. Somewhere around July 2018 a software update totally ruined this phone. The GPS accuracy went to crap and my navigation apps were basically unusable (Google Maps and Waze). It's now December and not fixed. Also, my Fitbit Alta HR can't sync with this phone anymore; it's not on Fitbit's compatible equipment list but it did work when I first got the phone.

Warning: President Trump has banned the purchase of this brand of Chinese phone by the military due to the fact that it was determined that China steals the data that is on the phone. So, if you do online banking via this phone, Chinese data collectors will have your password, etc., to drain your bank account. Secondarily, anything made in China is intentionally made not to last much less to any standards of quality. Avoid at all costs. Personally, any electronic device that contains personal identifiers and passwords that is made in China should not be purchased for safety's sake.

First I need 3.5 mm phone jack, finger-print, and 6 inches screen. Purchased the honor 7x AL10/TL10 version before but not support the T-Mobile LTE; Mate 10 pro doesn't have gold color; the L24 version of honor 7x has only 32GB/3GB; this phone (L34 version) has same spec as honor 7x with T-Mobile LTE bands and 4GB RAM. Only complaint is that 64GB is still not enough; would like to pay more for 128GB.

More thoughts: the second SIM card has 2G (phone call & message) only; if you have AT&T SIM (2G shutdown), got to set it to main SIM, otherwise no service; all calls and messages have a label of SIM 1 or 2; the clone function makes it very easy to transfer app and data from other phone within same WiFi network by scanning the QR code.

the camera was a joke! ive had lower megapixels that worked better... the dual camera was not really dual... if you covered one of them it did nothing just one of them was working. deff a deal breaker for a nearly $300 phone returned if the day I received it! maybe it was just defective but ill not try again on this brand.

I purchased this in June, 2018 with some hesitation because of security concerns. When new concerns began appearing in the media in mid-July, I returned the phone while it was still within the 30 return period. To the best of my understanding, the new concerns are that the manufacturing process used by Huawei leaves the phones vulnerable. Search terms Huawei security July 2018 to learn more about the new concerns.

I've had this phone for a few days now. Pros are as everyone else has mentioned. Typing is so fluid and switching between apps and overall processing speed of the phone is incomparable. I replaced a Galaxy Note 5 with this phone, so the improved battery life and increased fluidity is definitely recognizable.

Some issues I have are minor, but I think they're important to know because they are things I will be looking for in a future phone, due to the absence in this one.

1. No quick charging, but I knew this when I bought the phone, just didn't realize how much I valued it due to my high daily usage. To be honest it's not necessary due to this phone's long battery life, but still a nice feature to offer.

2. Lack of tempered glass screen protectors. You will get frustrated trying to find one because for some reason this model isn't popular enough. A lot of cases though.

3. Notifications not expandable on lockscreen. Some may feel this is hit or miss, but I really miss being able to quickly reply or check a full notification on my home screen. I messaged Huawei, they said this won't be capable on this phone at all.

4. No wifi calling, again I already knew this when I bought the phone but would be nice to have.

5. No NFC reading capability. Doesn't affect me but important to know.

I wouldn't buy this again at 250 because of these little nuances, but it truly is a good mid range phone and does last all day which is very valuable. I'd recommend just waiting till it goes on sale to get it, unless you need a phone right away.

About 3 years ago I switched from Android to iPhone, because I was so frustrated by the general low hardware quality of Android phones (including those expensive galaxy), the poor power management of the OS itself forcing me to charge more than once a day and develop a battery worry syndrome, I was happy for a couple of years.

Now 3 years into iPhone ownership, I am more and more pissed off by the control freaks in Apple, and the greediness of this company, so I started research Android phones again.

My past experience told me even as expensive as galaxy, they slow down to a crawl over a few weeks after I install a bunch of apps, so I am staying away from Samsung or any expensive option.

A friend recommended this phone, I was very suspicious how good can a 200 bucks phone can be, but this is cheap enough for me even if it became a toss away toy, but I was so happily surprised.

After a few weeks, I am fully moved off my iPhone 8+ to this device, and no way I will be shifting back. It is a huge loss to US consumer to not have this brand as easily available as most other brands, and I think I understand why after having one now. Apple will be completely dead in a matter of a year or two if US market opens up to Huawei. My recommendation is get yourself these devices before more nasty trade barrier is built, then you will have no option but get ripped by Apple or Samsung.

I purchased my Huawei mate se because I wanted something that had more memory
and ram. After ordering it it was delivered on time and there was nothing defective inside or outside of the shipping box. After setting the phone up it quickly updated to the most recent update Android 8. The phone is very quick has a picture quality that is just amazing. I tested it using Bluetooth, mirror share and wifi didn't have one problem with connection. I use at&t as does most my family and they received 3 bars of signal while my mate se is getting full 4G LTE signal
Awesome phone! I'll be purchasing another one for a back up without a doubt. For those of you that are wanting a really good phone get this one trust me at the price we're the ones benefitting.

It's a pretty buggy phone. Overall it's okay for the price but I wouldn't compare it to any flagship phones. I had HTC M8 before for a very long time and it served me well. In some ways it still beats this Huawei SE.

Things that stand out to me after a couple of months are: camera quality is lacking; vibrate mode is barely noticeable and I miss a lot of calls because I can't feel it buzzing; speakers are okay and it's not as loud as my old phone, sometimes it's hard to hear people even on max; no extra storage slot; bluetooth doesn't work with Apple products; Huawei suit is not available in Apple store so I don't even know how to transfer files at this point, useless; virtual keyboard could be better; tap to zoom works in a weird way, especially in games; some other things I can't think of right now.

It's an okay phone, like it's good but it's okay. It's a 3 star phone that is nothing special or mindblowing. It's buggy and while I am writing this review, the phone asked me to pair my Apple... when I turned off bluetooth on the phone and my Mac 5 minutes ago. It's the little things like that...

Been using this awesome phone now for a week. I will list the pro's and con's of the phone.
Pros:
64 GB of internal storage. That is a ton of space for apps you can put on the phone. Pictures and videos also if you don't have a microSD card. Love it.
MicroSD card slot. I put in my MicroSD card and for the first time a smart phone that didn't ask to reformat the card and lose all your pictures. That is pretty awesome.
Kirin 659 CPU is fast! Octa Core CPU running 4 cores at 2.36 GHZ and 4 Cores at 1.7 GHZ. Every app opens really fast.
4 GB of RAM. I have had up to 20+ apps open at the same time and still had 2 GB free of RAM. No slow down with many apps open with more RAM to spare to open up a bunch more apps.
Phone running Nougat 7 Android OS and I heard that Oreo 8 Android will be rolling out to the phone next month in May. That was a big selling point to me to get the latest Android. When I set up my phone it had a update for EMUI and also updated to the latest security updates released by Google Android.
Antivirus protection already on the phone out of the box. Avast security is running on the phone! Pretty good antivirus program and didn't have to pay for the antivirus program. Always a plus. I found this by looking through all the settings on the phone.
The one speaker sounds pretty good while on the speaker phone or listening to music. Wish it had 2 speakers.
I easily connected to my Bluetooth Headset and Bluetooth on my car stereo which sounds really good.
The Camera has alot of settings you can change and takes pretty good pictures.
For $229 this phone works great.
Cons:
The only con I find in this phone is wish the battery was bigger. At least a 4000 MAH battery. However I browse the web, check work and personal email, Facebook, google +, listen to Pandora internet radio all day, text, make phone calls, access other apps and still have some battery life at the end of the night before I go to bed. I have always felt that smartphone batteries could be better/bigger but this battery on this phone does its job.

I always try to buy phones that can be rooted easily. I am a developer. When I purchase a new phone, the previous phone is used for development. Why not? It's my phone. I paid for it.

This company was ending their program that allowed consumers to unlock the bootloader of their phone. Although I requested the unlock code many times before the deadline, the company chose to string me along with instructions that didn't work and directed me to irrelevant or non-existentent links.

While the phone is a decent phone for the price, the fact that it will end up in a landfill somewhere greatly reduces its value and the misleading/poor customer service reduces it further.

I will not be purchasing another Huawei phone.

I purchased this phone from Amazon. It's everything that the video reviewers and people say it is. I could find no fault in it. I ended up returning it though because for me coming from a Samsung Galaxy S4 I just found the phone to be to a bit too bit. It's more than 1/2 inch longer than the Galaxy S4 and it's also a bit wider. After just a few days, I found my hands a bit tired of holding the phone as it's also heavier and tired because of the slightly more reach in order to text with it quickly.

I want to emphasize this really is a great phone for the price. Best I have seen but keep in mind when you're purchasing a new phone than form factor is something you should also think about.

After having this phone, I have to say that Huawei makes a great product.

I rarely write product reviews, but in the case of this Huawei Mate SE, I felt compelled to tell other buyers like me that you will be pleased with this device provided you don't need to have NFC. Otherwise, I highly recommend this smartphone. I bought one at first to make sure that it measured up to reviews. After a short time and enjoying its performance, I bought another for my wife. She loves her's too.

Why spend $1000 on a phone when this $230 phone does most of what you need? The display is edge to edge (left to right), the body is unibody aluminum, the fit and finish is great, the fingerprint reader is amazingly fast, and the performance is really fast. They also give you a free clear case that fits well. I have the Huawei noise canceling earbuds, but they don't charge via the phone headphone jack, like it does on older Huawei phones. I am not a power user of a phone, but I am impressed with the Huawei quality/performance for the price. Setup is easy, you run a Huawei cloning app on your old phone, and it transfers data and apps to the new phone vis Bluetooth. Compared to aluminum iPhone, the antenna lines on the back look much nicer, and the blend into the case much better.

I've had the phone for several months and so far it has been great. I'm using a Samsung Fast charger which I feel has made the charging faster compared to the standard charger. The phone is a little larger than what I'd like but the screen real estate is fantastic! The screen is durable but I would recommend a screen protector.

This phone isn't like the flagship phones in which some features you are used to may not work as well on this phone, although they are being updated often. One thing is if you have more than 1 bluetooth device connected it cannot figure out which one to use. This is being fixed with Android Oreo which is being pushed in the next month.

If you're looking for accessories, look for Honor 7x instead of the Huawei Mate SE. This will make things much easier and at times cheaper too. They are the same phone just rebranded for the US markets for some reason.

I've refereed this phone to others and I will not be buying a $800 phone again.

I bought this phone to not only review on my channel since I'm a tech reviewer, but also because I needed a backup phone as my main Axon 7 phone is starting to display some iffy battery life. With that being said, this phone is quite the buy and for $250 dollars you are getting one of, if not the best budget smartphone of the year for now.

The Full HD plus screen is quite eye catching and visually pleasing and you can see this even more so with some nice wallpapers in the background. The colors look more cooler and arguably more naturally looking compared to the slight oversaturation of Quad HD AMOLED displays. I love the sleek and light form factor of the phone but the design doesn't give me much of a WOW factor as compared to some other Huawei phones I've seen. While I am slightly perplexed as to why this phone comes with a micro usb port, I appreciate that they still have the 3.5mm headphone jack.

The dual camera at the back shoots some nice pictures with good dynamic range, sharpness and clarity in good lighting conditions. Video recording at 1080p 30 frames is good but with no optical image stabilization, you will need a stabilizer or small tripod to get some stable footage. There are a respectable number of filters and camera modes such as slow motion, panorama, and one of my favorites, Light Painting. The front camera, which is 8 MP, unfortunately takes some slightly out of focus face shots and its beauty mode is more of a hit or miss and looks as though it is making my face more artificial. Even when you turn it off fully, I feel that the camera is still adding the beauty effect in some shape or form. AR Lens has some face animations but they are few and won't be replacing your Snapchat animations anytime soon.

The software is EMUI 5.1 with Android 7.0. I actually have no issues with the user interface and navigating it was fluid and seamless. I like the battery management systems and the pre-installed virus scanner which is powered by Avast. The fingerprint scanner is pretty fast and possibly one of the fastest on any phone in this price range. The performance is definitely good as playing games was pretty good. I did notice that more heavily graphic intensive games, such as Asphalt 8, may lag and drop frame rates a bit but that it not always the case. Switching between apps and using multi window is done fluently on this phone.

Two main red flags were found in my experience with the phone. There seems to be an overheating issue as the phone really heats up after a while of watching Youtube videos and playing games. The temperature rises to the point that I have to hold the phone a certain way so that my palms won't be affected as much. Secondly, the single speaker grill can easily be blocked when using the phone in landscape mode and the speaker lacks good bass and loudness, even on its highest volume.

Other than those two main gripes and the slight issue with the front camera, the phone is perhaps the best budget smartphone you can buy and is great for all daily tasks and even some light to moderate gaming. I am already considering to make this phone my daily driver but only time will tell.

The reason I give 4 stars is that nothing is ever perfect. However, I have few to no complaints with the phone I've had for over 2 years. The Huawei is a very good value for under $300. I'm thinking about upgrading with this offer simply because the value for the upgrade is reasonable. I'm usually very frugal and would avoid doing this, but the value is too tempting for the price. Verizon doesn't accept this phone. I've been with ATT. The phone and provider have provided reliable service in high desert, mountain regions, that are very rural.

I deleted my original review because this phone doesn't deserve any negative reviews. I had reviewed on my opinion after a quick open startup and shut down....without actually really putting any kind of use to base my opinion on because although it says 5.9" I was a little frustrated as it's actually smaller then my Note 4 and I bought this to replace my aging Samsung Note 4 and after I gave a mediocre review last night my Note gave out this morning just unresponsive. I had printed the return labels and I was sending this back.

Well to my surprise this phone turns out to be the best phone I have ever had, just amazing.
The display is so crisp, the audio is pretty solid, the CAMERA! The camera is out of this world, my wife who uses her S6 to take pictures of everything and anything just fell in love with it so we are buying another one for her. I uploaded a few pics of random things. It's running Android 7.0 flawless, I have TMobile and all I did was put my sim in and I have signal where I couldn't even get 2 cans and a string to work. As for the gov telling us to not buy this phone...... Yeah, I found no malware so far so I'm not worried.
Updating:
I want to add this in, screen is actually 5.7; I installed cpuz to get the true specs because although they advertise 5.9 something isn't feeling right so review the screen shot.

Here i am a yr later, the phone is still AMAZING me and i find new features each day it seems like. i recommend this phone. If your still on the fence which "budget phone" to get this is it. I havent had a screen protector on it and the screen is still solid and glossy still. I can say enough how much i still love this phone.

This is a good phone, a great one at the price point. However, you should know that this phone does not support Wi-Fi 5GHz. In most cases, this will not be a problem since most routers have support for both 2.4 and 5. I had my router set up on the 5GHz channel and it took me a while to figure out why I could not connect. More importantly, if you're left-handed and you want--need--right to left layout support, this does not have it. Not sure if this is applicable to the entire Huawei product line. I would have given this a 4.5-5 star rating, but the lack of right to left layout support is bothersome to my left-handed wife and there are probably others who feel similarly.

This phone was issued to me for work. And it's causing some interesting issues for me. Namely what in the heck am I spending all that money monthly for my S8? A curved screen (never doing that again)? Water resistance? QHD screen? Last year's flagship specs? A stupid heart rate monitor (has anyone actually used it more than once?)? I'm really stumped here. Sure it's not as fast, doesn't have quite as good or a screen or quite as good of a camera. All I know is, it's not a $500 difference.

I'd like it to have Qi charging and water resistance, but at this price it's excusable. It has micro USB (stop crying people), so what. I'm not the clown running around the office trying to find someone with a USB C or Lightening cable because I don't have a spare and forgot to bring mine. Open drawer and PICK ONE with spares to go around! Plus it really doesn't matter since the battery is really good for a phone twice this price. It has a headphone jack for those that care... Just pointing it out. Lack of GHz WiFi. Haven't noticed it being an issue. Lack of a few obscure random AT&T or T-Mobile bands... again haven't noticed any real world issues. The stock launcher is a bit "different" if you're coming from Samsung or some other Android skin. Give it a week and it's no big deal. If you're coming from an iPhone it'll be quicker.
Excellent device. One star since does not get timely firmware updates.

I experienced the same malfunction on two of these phones. The phone goes into "sleep" mode after 30 seconds - and you can not change the setting once it is randomly initiated. Clearly, there is a software glitch, and I had the misfortune of having two devices affected. It doesn't happen at first but a week then 3 in both cases. I done with this phone. I need a device I can at least read through an email before shutting down.
For the money it's a pretty decent phone however I feel you can spend an extra 75 bucks and get an essential phone and have a flagship device with much better build quality and just a snappier device

Great phone! My Nexus 6 wasn't holding a charge. After my husband replaced the battery and did a factory reset, I was still charging it 3 times a day with moderate use. I was waiting for the Moto 6 plus only to learn it would not be released in the US. My tech savvy son recommended the Mate SE. I was surprised by the specs given the price and decided to give it a go. So glad I did! I'm in my 60s and found it very easy to transfer my old phone. G-mail didn't work at first but once all the Google updates were complete, it was perfect. The display is bright, audio clear and the font size is customizable. Pictures are clear and crisp. Most of all, I love that the phone is so light and easy to hold. I usually have 30 percent battery left at the end of the day. I've always had an Android phone and this tops every one of them. Everything about this phone is fast and smooth. Highly recommend!

This phone was great overall for the first month I had it. One thing that is a continual issue is the bluetooth, it cuts in and out while driving which is an issue being in a "hands free" city. I received an update notice over the weekend and applied it. Now I can no longer text photos (which the camera quality is pretty good) or receive any. This is a problem since that is a lot of my texting. I have sent in help emails and hope to have this glitch resolved ASAP.

Hi quality full feature device for the price. Long lasting battery, no lag, solid build. Resembles the iPh0ne. Camera quality is lacking for a new device this day but is acceptable for quick snaps. I don't like the odd 18:9 ratio. No option for 3x2 size photos. My old Note 4 is superior camera quality over this. Not a deal breaker though. Again, for 250 bucks for an unlocked dual SIM phone with these specs, it's a steal.

Bought mine from B&H after seeing it in person. A+

This is a very good budget phone I was very impressed this was my first Huawei phone. This phone has definitely made me interested in a more expensive Huawei phone. The phone does not stick or give any problems the only negative is the picture quality is average. It's definitely a phone that can do a lot of tasks and I honestly did not miss my high-end phone except for the camera this phone also has excellent battery life. Do not hesitate to purchase.

Huawei makes such competitive products, but they just don't last. Before this phone, I owned another of their phones. Unfortunately, the camera stopped working just after the warranty expired. With this phone, I've experienced issues with the camera as well. Both times I've called the company, only to be told that they could not do anything for me, since I was out of warranty. As much as their phones outperform many of their competitors, they do not last long enough to justify buying from them.

Great phone, intuitive operating system, great battery, and vibrant colors. My only complaint is that the speakers aren't the best, but that is a very minor part of the experience. You would think that paying 4x the price of the Mate SE for an iphone x (or whatever absurdly priced phone that will be obsolete in a few months) would get you a phone that is 4x better, but this is far from the truth. Don't buy into the hype, you can get a great phone at a great price and avoid an unnecessary payment plan.

I am not a reviewer, by any means. I'm merely writing this to underline how fantastic of a product this phone is. The price point vs the performance, quality, EXTREMELY user friendly interface, and the numerous other exceptional features are simply incredible. To be honest, I buy a phone, I keep it until it it's final breath. My last two Samsung's each literally ended their individual lifespans with a deathrattle. Each one lasting for an excruciatingly long time, by most of today's smartphone consumers' standards. Picture Doc Holiday at the end of Tombstone. I have no doubt this little guy will last just as long, and at a mere fraction of the price I've paid for inferior specs and performance. I'm thrilled. I love it, and I actually look forward to upgrading. If for no other reason than to see what the other models have in store.

Pros- amazing battery life for someone who is constantly on her phone (I charge it once a day or every two days), looks beautiful and I like the feel of the phone. Very good deal , even though I had my doubts. Because of this phone, never again will I go back to Samsung.
Cons- currently have none.

This is a great phone for the price, with actual performance and features you would find in upper market phones. BUT YOU HAVE TO KNOW two major flaws this device has before buying it:

1. You can only use it EITHER double sim OR one sim + micro sd card. Yes, it is double sim and yes, it supports external memory, but you can only use it in the way I mentioned before because apparently Huawei engineers couldn't be bothered to provide one slot for sim cards
tray and one slot for the memory card, so the phone uses the only two-slot tray it has to accomodate the three cards, which it can't so you have to decide between double sim with no memory or one sim with memory.

2. The camera SUCKS.

If you are used to great camera phones such as Xperia (my case), Pixel, Nokia, etc, you will be very dissapointed with this phone's camera performance. It is as bad as it gets.

The rest of the features and performance, however, are only second to much more expensive phones.

Great phone. I bought it for my daughter, now I want one for myself. The camera is great. The only drawback is that it's not compatible with the Straight Talk service. I read where it's compatible with Straight Talk, and that's why I bought it, but it's not. . .so now I'll have to switch providers. . . Or return it. That's the only reason it got 4 stars. . It's not compatible with Straight Talk.
This phone was the worst ever. I lost everything because was not recognizing the password.

So glad I took the risk and ordered an unlocked phone and did some research online on the overall reviews of this phone. So far I love it. The clarity is pristine and the functionality is great. It was super easy to just put my SIM card from my Cricket Wireless carrier into this phone and it worked without any difficulty at all whatsoever. This also arrived super quick. Highly recommend.

The phone is fantastic, greate screen, excelent memory and speed. The only problem was that I didn't received the earphone, according to Huawei it must include in the box. My order was sent to a PO Box in Miami that forwards the product to Paraguay. When I made the claim to Amazon, they told me that the products sent to intermediaries have noguarantee. I received the box perfectly closed, with the factory seals unvoided.
It is a warning for those who buy through PO boxes, because even if the product comes incorrect or factory failed , we have no guarantee.

This is an amazing phone. After being a long time iphone user and recently buying a galaxy note 9 i got this phone for my son. Im really surprised by the quality and similiarity to any other flagship phone for 219.00.

Im seriously considering a future purchase of a hauwei phone over apple,samsung or lg.

Beware of this brand. After a year of use I began to get pulldown ads even though I use Adblock. What finally killed it for me was when clicking on Gmail they kept trying to switch to Huaeai Gmail which says they have they right to view my mail. Reluctantly I am going to abandon the brand.

I only care about the basic of things: Screen quality, picture quality, speed, and battery life. This phone meets all of those. I bought it at $240, but I see it went on sale right after I bought it. It has a good ppi, the camera on the back has been really good quality and the camera on the front is better than any camera on my past phones. It's fairly fast on it's own, but games are a breeze. I don't have it in power-saving mode and the battery lasts all day. The one con is it takes forever to charge, but I just plug it in before I go to sleep.

This phone is a viable option for those who've always been iPhone users but cannot afford the new phones. The only things I will say that are cons are that the phone's front camera isn't that great, scrolling through content is kind of choppy compared to the smooth new iPhones, and the charger isn't a USB C. Otherwise, I have absolutely no complaints. This phone is great for the money.

I had a Samsung..it was terrible..I had an LG which would get extremely hot ...this Huawei mate se is the best phone I have ever had so far..before I bought it I reviewed it over and over again..then I purchased it and I am a pappy camper...the battery life amazing..only thing I wish it rang louder but thatâs ok considering this phone mimics the iPhone in some ways with out the price...when I save up I will get an upgrade ..but if this phone keeps working as it is I will stick by it...love this phone...

This is one amazing phone! Even if it is just a budget tier phone it works amazingly well. Fast and fluid. Apps run very smooth. In the months I have had it, it has never reset or frozen up. I have this phone and also the honor 7x. I do like this mate se better with the extra power inside. Listen the bottom line is you can get a beautifullly crafted, efficient smartphone for around $ 200 bucks that works like a $400-500 dollar phone. I would recommend this phone to anyone!

Great battery life, nice build quality, excellent finger print sensor speed, and overall performance is much better than expected at this price point. This is the first non-flagship phone I've carried as a daily driver and I've been happily surprised.

I would rate this product no star if there were such option. The Huawei Mate SE is VERY difficult to be recognized by computers & forever loading/connecting, either at home or at work. Functions are usually unstable. Got frozen frequently. I had to restart the phone on a daily basis. 2nd SIM is 2G. Swollen-headed Huawei designs its own interface, unfortunately NOT user friendly, even NOT logical. Caveat Emptor!!!!
It feels so cheap, something about it is just off

Loved this phone..
Had it about 3 months before the GPS antenna broke inside the phone. It never knew where I was, which is a massive problem for someone who already doesn't know where they are half the time.
Premium feel and design.
But performance after a month or two of use definitely suffered and ultimately rendered this phone unusable.

After almost a year of regular usage, I dropped the phone in water. I wasn't worried because the huawei mate se is advertised as waterproof, but after a few minutes, the power button and figerprint scanner malfunctioned. Now my phone is stuck in a loop of constantly force restarting. Very disappointed.
I have been using a Mate 2 for almost four years and it has been the best phone. I ordered the Mate SE to replace it, and I am very happy with it. Hope it gives me four more years of excellent usage.

The specifications say sim slot 2 only supports 2G but I think the better description is that only 1 sim at a time will support 4G which isn't a problem for me and maybe others as well. As shown in the pictures i've uploaded, whichever sim you select as the default data sim will have 2G/3G/4G and the other will have 2G so if you want to use data from the other sim you can simply switch in settings instead of having to remove the tray and switch the cards

Update: I have switched from Google Project Fi to Mint Mobile. Now I can receive/send MMS with no problem. I guess it was because of the setting of Project Fi.

This phone overall is good. However I can't receive or send MMS. I am in Hawaii and use Google Project Fi service.
Did some research on Internet and tried the APNs reset, still doesn't work. Sad. :(

Problems with GPS/Bluetooth/WIFI due to its cheap antenna. No 5ghz... then super limited LTE bands on the device... No fast charging neither, very very slow. I bought this months ago and I was disappointed.

Now that I have Stylo 4, this is so much better in every aspects...

I wouldn't buy this product if I were you, and who knows when and how Huawei will declare that they will leave the US market due to sanctions, which makes this device pretty much obsolete when it comes to future support?
Don't buy these Huawei cell phones. Chinese piece of junk. The settings move on their own that I don't want. Now I can't even use yahoo email anymore on this crappy phone.
Works perfectly with ATT, recognize your fingerprint in no time so it links to many of your accounts and opens up in seconds. I got another for my wife, and she loves it.

Its an android system JUNK GARBAGE.. TRASH Ill stick with Apple, thanks, but no thanks for this garbage.
This is America , we deserve better. USA USA

This is our second Huawei phone. We loved the speed and quality of the first one and decided to upgrade a second phone from an ASUS model. The screen size on this Mate is great especially for my large thumbs when trying to text. The phone has a great bright screen which provides good visual experience even in bright sunlight. The camera is fantastic and takes great quality pictures. This being the use of 2 lenses to get the right setting. I would recommend to family.

This phone is not worth the trouble. If you want a budget smartphone, you are better off with a Motorola.

Good:
- The camera is decent.

Bad:
- Poor battery life
- EMUI is worse than expected (It is like the software team looked at Android and tried to find ways to ruin it)
- Does not work properly with pebble smartwatches
- Vibration is not strong enough to feel in a pocket and there is not a way to change vibration intensity

I owned the Huawei Mate 7 and had a love hate with it. Hardware exceptional. Great performance hindered by terrible software, I vowed I never would again. I owned a Note 5 and a Moto Z since then, but fate decided to smash my moto. After 2 fairly expensive phones I decided to go budget. The sub 250 market isn't that great nowadays, but this little gem popped out at me at best buy. One left in the whole of Chicago, managed to snag last one, and I'm super impressed. Battery life is all day and more, performance is way above 250 dollars worth but don't expect Galaxy levels. Screen is great, software is much much better, but still needs work. But I'm super satisfied for this price. And I can buy 2 more before I approach galaxy prices.

All in all definitely recommend this as a buy.
Doesn't work. screen is defective

Believe me when I say this is the worst phone in the USA. I DARE you to research this phone and you will agree. Besides that One small drop (with a case on it) and this phone is dust. Couldn't get my pics and other files off of it and I will never by a Huawei phone again.

Does not connect my Bluetooth speaker.
Selfie is not sharp face with beauty off.
Sound in not clear and no bass, worth than iPhone 5.

Great phone, I especially like the fingerprint reader for easy access and you can't beat the price for the tech. The only reason I can't give it 4 or 5 stars is that the black outlined text is jumbled and hard to read, (see attached photo). There is no space between the letters, it all just runs together, and is cheap looking. I downloaded a new font but it didn't change that particular text. If anyone knows how to change this particular font I'd appreciate the help. I asked in the questions section here and reached out to customer service but haven't heard back. Thanks.

Update, I decided to give it another star and keep the phone. I just hope I can change the font to make it more readable.
Bought in March of 2018, just went dead on me for no reason today, November 23 2018. Otherwise was a great phone but would never buy this brand again.

The Mate SE is built very, very, well - it definitely feels like a premium phone and is an incredible value. Sticking with industrial design, the weakest points of the Mate SE are the front-facing logo (seriously, why? put a logo on the rear if you must), and the screen. The screen has a slight bit of grain to it. The grain is most visible on white content, e.g. in Google Now or if you open a new tab in Chrome. Might not be an issue for some.

The WORST thing about the SE is the software. It only ships with android 7.0, and EMUI is *awful*. I installed Nova, and even tried out a few EMUI themes to try and get the quick settings & settings menu to be more like stock Android. Then I found that Huawei had also replaced Android's standard 'share' menu (e.g. when one shares a photo from Google Photos to WhatsApp) with their own inferior version.

Huawei: please join the 'android one' program, and ship stock Android on your phones. This will also make it easier for you to provide OS updates for your phones.

If the Mate SE had stock Android, it would be fantastic. I can't accept EMUI though, and have returned the phone as a consequence. I highly recommend that anyone considering this phone purchase the Xiaomi Mi A1 instead - that's what I did. The Mi A1's build quality is excellent, it has no front-facing logo, and it is part of the android one initiative, running stock Android 8.0 - it is incredible. (It does have larger top & bottom bezels than the Mate SE, but in all other aspects the Xiaomi Mi A1 is better, or at least as good.)

Do NOT buy the Mate SE - get the Xiaomi Mi A1!
https://www.amazon.com/Xiaomi-Android-Cameras-Unlocked-Warranty/dp/B076HQ6FSY/
The touch stopped responding after 43 days. I tried to recover or do a factory reset. But, it need some touch input. So I cannot use my phone now.
My screen froze up and could not be fixed. I may have just gotten a bad phone, but...returned
Have this phone for two weeks, so far works great.
Awesome phone!! It's good for how much it costs I was scared at first because I had never bought a Huawei phone before, but now I know I was totally worth it!

I bought the phone through Walmart. Have been using about a month. Quite decent display at this pricepoint. Very nice dimensions - big screen but lightweight and easy to hold. Fast and responsive. Fingerprint scanner is excellent! Doesn't heat up during long calls. Battery life is good. Sound is mediocre but can be boosted with volume booster app.
Two things I miss are fast or wireless charging and No NFC.

I have been using this phone for six months now. The build quality, battery, camera is good. But touch screen is horrible. I am having smartphone thumb symptoms (painful thumb injury because of touch screen stress) because of this phone. Won't recommend to anyone. Not worth it.

Best smartphone value for the price. It's smooth and powerful with a huge memory. Everything works perfectly! Great display! Camera has great software and features but I think my Moto g5 camera is a little bit better. All in all a Great deal.
I have poor reception in my area. I relay on wifi calling when I'm home. its not supported so I'm out of luck
Great phone, only problem is that no good screen protectors are sold for it.
Perfect budget smartphone!

Great battery life even playing with the game that uses high resources. Glass screen not the greatest stick with gorilla glass this phone screen cracks much easier. The other major issue is when you're at work can you multimedia So that you'll hear your phone ring if someone calls but not here getting notifications and other stuff. Everything comes through the phone profile so you're going to always hear your games notifications and other stuff. The only way to do fix that is to mute phone but then you'll never hear your phone ring if you really need to. This also only has one speaker so it's not stereo. I had contacted the company and they said that this is there practice on this phone that everything plays through the ringer volume. So you even if you're on the phone and a game or message comes through it will play as if that person has it on their phone in this playing it at that time. Don't get this phone if you keep your phone on at a job and keep the ringer on to hear if an emergency. Because everything plays through the ringer messages games everything
The best phone for its price range.

Huawei mate se is simply awesome. Ive had the samsung galaxy phones and iphone, but this by far is the best one Ive ever had. I absolutely love it! And I have walmart family mobile, so that's a plus as well.

I'm disappointed the battery discharging quick and takes for ever to charge full
Sometimes it's freeze or crash for the money $300.00 you can get much better phones... don't buy it the customer service is terrible and if it's get something defective they won't help you...!! You're are on your own...just get Samsung or Motorola
Great phone for $220. Using it since 6 months and never had any problem. Great battery back up. I get almost 2 days per charge easily(low usage). Great camera and picture edit options.
I am not for shure if I want this phone,it is not what I expected
This phone works as well or better than a Samsung 8 that was stolen. And all that at a quarter of the price

I got a Honor V10 directly from the HiHonor store and had been using it for 2 weeks. I tried to write a review for it but Amazon won't let me so I leave my review here. All I have to say is the picture does not do it justice and you really have to see it in person. The phone is fantastic and I agree with most other reviews on the internet it is best mid-range phone you can get for $500. Trust me, just get it. I heard Huawei is moving out of the American market, what a shame, damn those dirty politicians.

I ordered this phone for my mother. Everything was great with the setup except when we tried to connect to WiFi, we kept getting an error "WiFi - Denied Access to Network". We tried everything to include resetting the phone back to factory settings. Still no luck! Other phones connected to the house WiFi with no problems. I ordered a replacement phone. I'll update my review.....only if it works like its supposed to.

Update: I finally discovered a fix by accident. First...take the phone to a carrier store to have them set it up and connect it to their network. My mother is on T-mobile. Second...go to a public place like Starbucks and use their wi-fi to complete all the phone updates. Headsup...you will be there for a while so make sure you have plenty of power. Once finished you should be on latest Android version 7.1. You can now go home and connect to your personal network. The phone no longer has any issues nor receive that stupid error anymore. I took a star off because the software could be better. There should be no bloat on a phone with these specs, and unfortunately BLU insists on trying to install Facebook and other crappy apps on the phone.

If you want to make this phone faster you can do what I did:
1) Let phone run through its updates
2) Disable and uninstall unneeded apps
3) Under privacy settings, enable installing apps from unknown sources
4) Install F-Droid (google the link). F-Droid is an app that lets you install free and open-source software, much of it lighter than other non-free apps.
5) From F-Droid you can try: Lightning Browser (faster than Opera or Chrome), KISS Launcher (replaces built in launcher), Blokada (system wide ad blocker), and NewPipe (youtube replacement with no ads or fluff). If you insist on using Facebook, get FaceSlim replacement on F-Droid.

It took me a couple hours messing with the phone to do all these steps because the updates and disabling of apps takes awhile, but the phone has a lot more free space now and uses less RAM. It runs like it has twice the processor now.

I'm 88 years old, don't wear glasses, and don't text, but I wanted a smart phone just for pleasure. I've had two BLU phones. I will compare and contrast them, in the event you are shopping.
I had an Advance 5.2 for some weeks. It has an all-metal case that will not open. You need to put a tiny tool in a tiny hole in one side, and out will come a tiny tray that will hold only a small SD card, and a nano sim. That's it. The size is great, and it seems well-made. I was wanting something larger, so reading text would be easier, and I don't plan on using it as a phone that much, so I was looking at the Advance A6. I received it yesterday, and I am delighted. What's great is that the entire back comes off, and you can access two sim slots and an SD slot with the battery out or left in. My hands are large, so the size isn't an issue, but it might be awkward for petite ladies. I also had a Blackberry Leap, which wouldn't even look at sims I tried, so back it went. The A6 greedily accesses sims and memory cards with glee. If there is any down-side, it could be battery endurance, but I will not make a judgment on that until my experiments are concluded. You are advised to do a few cycles of full to empty, and I'm awaiting hitting empty for the first time. It doesn't seem to suck out much power on idle, so I guess I'll have to task it a bit to drain the sucker out. At this point, I couldn't be a happier camper. I sincerely hope this helps you.

The BLU A6 Phone exceeds expectations with a great screen, dual cameras, Dual Sims, and strong performance, as well as a very reasonable price. One caution - you will likely need to buy a "Bring Your Own Phone" Sim Card to get compatibility. I went to Walmart,, my cell plan provider & they had a package for that at $57, but told me I could order it online from them for $1 plus about $7 in shipping. They even helped me order it. Getting it activated was a bit more trouble, but once done works great. Amazon should offer the Sim with the Phone and save us the trouble and extra shipping. Add 2 SIMS as it does support dual SIM Cards.

This phone is great so far. Super easy to setup and get working on my phone plan thru my carrier. Sound is great on calls and seems to work perfectly for me.Has a one yr warranty which is is to set up first thing using you phone.Came with a screen protector, ear bud headset to both added an added plus as I see it. I have seen this phone in one of the big box store for 30 bucks more. I've haven't seen any down side so far with this phone. Need a new phone so this is it. I'm not one to use a phone for web or gaming I have far better devices for that it's a phone to me So it has all the bells and whistles I want plus more I'd believe there. I would recommend it to anyone needing good phone without breaking they bank to get one.

Phone works great. Very responsive, fast, and great picture. Only thing misleading is the second nano sim slot is the SD card slot. Cannot use both, is an either or. I only have one phone plan, so no big deal. I use the SD slot for my Amazon music. Swipe keyboard is great, predictive text works awesome. Only complaint is that there are almost no cases available. Does come with a clear flexible case.

I am pleasantly suprised. The software is great. The phone is not glitchy and has a pretty fast touch to react time. Overall this is a great phone for someone on a budget. Also as an added bonus it came with a screen protector and case.
Very nice. Impressed that it came with a case and screen protector for that price.

This is a nice phone and for the low price for a 6" phone, I knew the modest specs and didn't expect spectacular performance.
Good display - color and sharpness
Good mic for dictation in my email writing
Has OTG function which I formatted to FAT32
Nice feel and handling of phone.
Although ROM is 8 GB, it has about 4 GB for user; better than the big name phones with their unremovable bloat ware or those from the phone carriers (AT&T bloat ware even hogs the display).

The speaker volume is quite low even at max - not good for listening to lecture MP3 recordings
Most apps take a second or two to run, which is acceptable in view of low price.
When surfing and youtube watching, battery lasts between 3 - 4 hr inspite of estimates displayed as 6 hr.

What pushed me to return it was that every day when powering up, it would not recognize my micro SD card, and needs to be rebooted. I notice that even in a few Samsung reviews people complained of the same problem. Though not a common problem in phones, the hassle is not worth it. One time, the BLU just froze up, black screen, and refused to budge. So I plugged in the power, push the on-off button few times and it work. Strange because the battery was about 70% remaining.

If you are lucky in not encountering this non-recognizing SD problem, then it is a good phone for the low price. I have two other BLU phones for 3 years which perform well, even in the rough treatment when boarding planes and scanning the Boarding Pass on the BLU screen on many flights in Europe. My BLU phones work very well for phone calls in Europe and Asia using their local SIMs.

I was a little skeptical about this product at first. It started and did everything slow but I think it was just because it was still loading apps in the background and trying to keep up with my tasking. Now that the few apps that I will use are loaded it performs at an "ok" speed. Comparatively speaking, but for $69.00 phone, it performs at great speed. The few Apps eat up a lot of memory fairly quickly so adding a micro SD card is a must. I recommend starting with an SD card from the very beginning so that you can put the Apps on the SD rather than internal memory. This will help greatly. Moving apps from internal to external (SD) card is not as easy later. I had to delete some (not all) Apps and then reload to the SD card to free up space.
It is important to mention that the apps, once installed on the SD card perform just as fast as they do in my iPhone7. The only difference is that they OPEN a little slower on this phone as compared to my ($800) iphone7.
I bought this phone to replace my Garmin GPS on my motorcycle since I can use Pandora, Waze (and/or Google maps) and Bluetooth all at once for half the price of a decent GPS that can't play these apps.
The screen definition is very good, the map font is larger than a GPS (good for those with "tired" eyes like mine). I used the Rockform Universal phone mount to mount it to my T&T Fab batwing fairing mount.
Oh, and to the surprise of the AT&T rep. this phone DOES work in the AT&T network.

While I believe that this phone may work for some people, as with all cheap electronics, clearly quality control is very low. Mine started to freeze within 24 hours of receiving it, until it got to the point I could literally not even activate the reboot/shutdown options, and the screen largely stopped receiving input, which makes all the other ways of judging a phone irrelevant since it's completely unstable. It did work ok for a few hours, maybe 8, before the touch screen simply stopped working, or worked totally erratically.
I've bought cheap phones before, like the Posh, and had really good luck with them, so I thought I'd give this one a try. Basically understand that you are gambling on getting a phone that works for $59 (Advance 5.2), apparently this gamble works for some users, and if you read the reviews, many have similar experiences to mine. Not worth the headache of spending time returning it in my opinion.
Sad thing is, the case is pretty nice, the screen seemed fine, quality wise, but they just didn't spend the money they needed to on the rest of the hardware, maybe think about spending 20 to 30 more on the screen and internals and sell that for $80, that's about what Posh did, and it seemed to do the trick.

So, I write this to help others that I thinking about possibly purchasing this home. I think it is a great value for the cost. I read through all of it reviews and found some that were quite inaccurate. The phone works and functions just fine. Yes it might not be up to a premium iPhone or other Android as far as speed however there are things that you can do to minimize lag. I ran into similar issues as others have mentioned but with one simple fix it has seemed to alleviate all of the problems. The main source of memory consumption seems to have been the Google Assistant. "okay Google". After going into the settings and disabling this acrossed the entire platform my phone is three times as fast as it was initially prior to me making this adjustment. I highly advise anyone to disable this feature because it sits in the background wasting memory and causes other applications to lag and not function correctly. I hope this helps other people.

I use both this phone and iPhone. The iPhone cost more than ten times what this BLU did, and I think they work about the same. They both have all the same functionality and are about as easy to use. This is excellent technology that just works. It was the cheapest phone I could find. It works just as well as the most expensive. I am very happy customer. Long battery life. Fast charge times. Standard accessories. Easy set up.

I bought this as my first smart phone, so I feel that my opinion isn't clouded by having used a more expensive phone in the past. I really wanted to love this phone, but it just didn't happen. Maybe I got a bad one. What I liked about the phone was... Its compact size and how it fit in my pocket and hand. The phone came with a case and screen protector. The display was very crisp and bright. The wifi hotspot feature worked really well and had decent range. The problems I had with this phone were... The sound quality during phone calls was bad, I had trouble hearing even with the volume all the way up, also the other party had trouble hearing/understanding me. When connected to my desktop via usb cable the phone showed up as an empty folder that wouldn't even allow me to move files into it. I also tried connecting to the phone via bluetooth and the phone wouldn't pair with any other device. I tried using it with my Square credit card chip reader and it didn't work. However it did work with the older magstripe reader. The battery life was also bad, a 1 hour phone call would almost totally deplete a full charge. I returned this phone and purchased a Doogee X10, very happy with that phone.

I cracked my Galaxy S9+ screen, and sent it back to Samsung to get a factory repair. I bought this phone to use for the next week or two... Wow... Listen, it is not fast, it doesn't have an HD screen, but OMG, it does EVERYTHING my S9+ can do (a little slower) and it is 60 dollars!!!!

I had to buy a sim card adapter (3 bucks) to put my nano sim in the micro slot, but that's it... It runs on ATT 4G, youtube works, directv app works, messaging, whats app, it all works... It is unreal....

This is a decent, inexpensive phone . It has a very large screen, beautiful for watching YouTube,Amazon prime video etc. Functions well in use as a phone and video player. This does not have much RAM or storage room however so if you like a lot of apps, this phone probably isn't for you. It does work reasonably well for Facebook and Messenger. It quickly fills up when apps are updated and you get constant warnings that you are running out of space. It has a lot of preinstalled apps that not everyone uses and they take a lot of space. Japanese input keyboard is one such app that I have no use for and cannot remove. I was also annoyed that Blu has surreptitiously added more such useless apps into it's system update such as a Blu rewards app that is basically bombarding your phone with advertisements for which you can earn rewards for interacting with. Super annoying! You cannot remove this app once installed with the update . Again-super annoying as it takes up valuable limited space. This can thankfully at least be disabled. To be fair, this phone does say it will accept a large capacity memory card however I have not tried this yet and it may resolve some issues. I have noticed what I'm calling a bit of instability in the system as it sometimes seems to open random apps at it's own volition. So to sum up. ...it's a decent basic smartphone for the casual user. Great for on the go video entertainment, not so great for a multitude of apps. It does come beautifully packaged, comes with some decent earbuds and a plastic case for protection. Probably a great phone for elderly users do to large screen size or for youngsters wanting their first smartphone or as I've said before great for watching videos. I hope this review is helpful!

I liked that it was unlocked and was able to use Tmobil SIM card. The SIM card slot is a bit bigger for it to slide in than regular sized phones, but it works fine once the back is on.
