The buttons are large, the sound is great, the adjustments on the volume is A+ (some ring tones are louder than others) and the camera is even better than mine.

Buttons don't work easily. It more often than not takes several attempts to switch between menus or lists. I got it for my husband thinking that it should be the easiest phone for him to work, but even I have had trouble working it.
This upgraded flip phone is so much easier to use and the speaker is great. I am very satisfied with this model.
I'm not very happy with this phone. I purchased it for my aging husband's because he enjoys a good flip phone. When he answers it, it sounds ad though he's in the bottom of a ton can and garbled.
A very good phone for elderly.
If you want a phone just for calls it's fine. Texting seemed slow and the camera is fair
It is hard to get thru to set it up but it beats a regular cell phone for someone who just needs it for an emergency. The big button is cool.
They for get to tell you all the addition charges that you have to pay for to have the phone it self .

I can never say how much I love my Jitterbug. For me, a smart phone was a waste of time and money ! My Jitterbug is just what I need and the 5* button is icing on the cake I do recommend it to the older generation.
Did not get to use it as the monthly price was not as advertised nor did I know ahead of time there was an activation fee. Then I had to pay to ship it back. Very disappointed!!!!
Perfect for senior citizens.

Bought this as a gift for my aunt. The phone did not ring and after about 3 hours of calls to Great Call service, they decided the phone was defective and said they would send a replacement phone via 2-day mail. No new phone has arrived and the 30 day window for returns to Amazon is near, so I've returned the phone to Amazon. I'm incredibly disappointed because my aunt really wanted a simple phone with the option of an emergency contact button.
Great for an "unwired" senior like me!
Not happy w/Jitterbug! The phone was defective. I requested to return the phone & my experience w/this company, made the process very simple & easy. GreatCall gets a 5* for that process THOUGH!
Good option for elderly users. Simple and easy to read.

Gave this phone to my Mother this past week. So simple to get set up and it is easy for her to use. I did get the package with the urgent care notifications, and I an able to see where her and the phone are anytime. Also able to see if it needs charging so I can remind her to do that.
Basically I hope all its great services never have to be used. But so good knowing they are there for her. I am in New York City she is in
Florida with not many people in her community she can count on. She still is able to live independently.
So much better for seniors than a complicate iPhone

Big buttons for use with old stiff fingers....is a great basic phone for making and receiving calls without all that other APP and unwanted fancy confusing hype that I never used.....I shut down my fancy phone and cut my bill in half plus got a phone that is easy to use.....if you don't want all the latest phone baloney, this is the phone for you.
Would be great if unlocked.

Jitterbug uses the Verizon network which is unreliable from our location. We get good cell coverage from ATT, but this is not an option with Jitterbug.

The phone looks well suited for seniors, with easy to read keypad, menus and navigation.

I took off 3 stars because it took 45 minutes on the phone to request the service disconnection.They even suggested a $10 restocking fee unless we spoke to tech help. Then, they said the $10 fee applied only to phones purchased directly from Jitterbug.

The refund would be processed after the phone is received from Amazon.
Easy for my elderly mother to use, ringer could be louder. Reception isn't always the greatest.

So far a wonderful phone for my husband. Phone has large numbers for seeing.. It's easy to use with just YES and NO to deal with. Self explanatory by just using, but the information booklet is well written. This is being the best phone my husband has had and happy we got it..

It was easy, painless and fast to get it registered and fired-up to go.
I bought it from Amazon and initialized it online with GreatCall. I added the necessary contacts, changed the ringtone and charged the battery with no problems at all.

This is the first cell phone for my wife, who is 77, and she adapted well to it.
Only phone my mother has been able to dial by herself.
Crappy phone, parents could not hear
78 & 97 year old grandmother's approve. This model uses the camera as a magnifier "app"
Ordered to quickly replace a broken one. Fast delivery and works perfectly thus far. Will update if any probs. should arise. Highly recommend.

My 80 year old mother was so afraid of using it when we gave it to her for Christmas and she loves it! I love it because I can tell exactly where she is and have the comfort of knowing at anytime she needs medical assistance she can press the red "help' button. A few times she got lost getting off at the wrong bus stop and know we can pinpoint her exact location. Best buy ever!
Easy to use with the large numbers and the yes button. The charging station does not work good so have to charge without it so is a little harder for my older mother to plug in.

My 96 year old mother loves this phone. The large buttons are great for eyesight and shaking fingers. The speaker option is loud (she likes that) but can be adjusted if needed. Perfect for seniors who need a simple cell phone.

This just concerns the hardware, not the phone service. Wall wart transformer doesn't work. This is used to charge the phone. I'm using the wall wart that came with my Kindle and that seems to work ok, although it seems to charge slowly. This is my mom's phone so I'll need to give her the transformer and to find another way to charge up my Kindle. I wish they'd done some better quality control on this.
Excellent for my hubby who doesn't like the smartphones!

I her purchased the phone for my mother and she is 81 years old and not very versed in electronics,however she has mastered the Jitterbug phone with very little coaching and she loves it,The large font and numbers are great for her.
It worked great for 5 1/2 months. Then it just quit dialing. We can get calls just can't make them. Too bad because it's great for people who need bigger numbers.

We purchased the phone, set it up with the 5 star emergency service. My mother in law fell down, broke 3 bones including 2 vertebrae. She pushed the 5 star button and got no help. She called my wife And had her call 911

I am 71 years old and I don't like cell phones because I can't read the numbers or even answer the darn thing. I needed a phone with large numbers and just plain simplicity. This was the ticket. Absolute perfection for me. Service with Great Call is great and available on line and easy to navigate. Wonderful phone!
My 90yo Mom decided not to splurge on a cell. But Iâd recommend it for arthritic, hard of hearing and seniors needing simple instructions. It was beautiful and well made!

Very misleading advertisement. Supposedly works on the the Verizon network, yet three Verizon reps told me that this is not the case and that itâs not compatible with the networks they are and will be using.
Too hard to press numbers and letters when texting. Very tiring on arm and finger muscles. Also was unable to make corrections in texts without having to delete everything after the correction.
Purchased for husband who is not too tech savy. It is a great phone with great reception and the battery has a very long life compared to other types of phones.
works great and no hidden fees
This does not work on verizon system. I probably missed that in the fine print. It is a contract carrier. Looks like a great phone but not able to connect to my carrier.

Bought this for emergency purposes only--because I hated the complications of using the iPhone I had previously. But for a simple device, it's got some unfortunate fatal flaws.
1) You can't adjust volume up or down while on a phone call, which is exactly when you need to be able to do it. If you try, your conversation echoes and you can't talk. You have to hang up, adjust the volume offline, then recall. PLEASE!
2) "GreatCall," the only service provider for the Jitterbug, ballyhoos its live help desk, but to get to it you have to remember to dial "611." I suggest a direct "How-to" button at the bottom next to the 5-star button (which is its quasi-emergency service line with live people who can connect you to the help you need all the way up to an 9-1-1 call.)
3) There is a less than adequate low battery notification. Yes, it'll give you a "low" or "critical" message if you happen to be using the phone at the time, but if you're an infrequent caller like me, that doesn't help. The volume of the low battery beep unfortunately sounds at the same volume as you have set your call volume, so if it's too low, you WILL NOT HEAR the audio low battery signal. It is a constant annoyance to me to find the battery drained when I don't know it's happening
4) There's no reason these minor fixes can't be cheaply corrected while at the same time manufacturing another version of this phone 1" less tall to make it a much more popular size that younger people, kids, and even techies could embrace when they don't need or want Internet connectivity. Marketing it strictly to "old people" is a big mistake.

I purchased this for my grandmother. She is not very technical, so a smartphone would not be a good match for her.

Greatcall is the carrier, you will spend about 15 minutes on the website setting everything up [remember, this is for someone who is NOT technical, but it allows you to setup everything, including the phone book (call list) that is sent down to the phone]. If your transferring another phone number, the process is simple. Greatcall gives you a temp phone number to get the phone activated that minute. Then you have to call Greatcall on their 800 number and give them the information from the current carrier. We had to call T-mobile to get the PIN code setup for transfer, but that's really simple. We were able to transfer my grandmother's phone number from T-Mobile in a few hours. The people on the line at Greatcall were really nice and helpful.

One issue, which was resolved quickly by Greatcall on the phone, is after you setup the phone, we did not want text. If you do not select any plans that include text, Greatcall turns it on at $0.10 per message. We called, and they removed it so my grandmother cannot receive texts. She hates text messaging [her choice, I just wanted her to be happy]. Greatcall had no issue removing the text has very happy to do it.

The other thing about Greatcall, they let you add someone else to control the account. This way, my grandmother can tell me what she wants done, I can call Greatcall on her behalf, and take care of the issue for her. That is a very nice feature. Also, I had to call them twice, once for blocking text and getting information on transferring her phone number to calling back in to give them all the information on transferring the phone number. Both times, difference agents, they were very friendly and professional and did not sound like they were in another country.

Now more about the phone. She loves it. When you open it, you hear the dial tone just like the old landline POTS phones [how 1950s can you get]. I think my Grandmother said it best that this is a phone for old folks. It has a magnifier built in, and the characters and fonts are all very large. Very easy to see. The menus to move through the phone book are simple and easy to use. I can see if she was to use text, it would have been easy to use as well [but Grandmother gets what Grandmother wants].

Also, Grandma loves the red color. It's easy to see and find.

The only setback, and this is really the industries fault, I guess the spam callers figure out if your on Greatcall, your an senior. The spam calls have increased trying to sell Grandma all sorts of garbage. I do wish Greatcall would block more of these spam calls.

Overall, it's a great phone, light weight, easy to read and easy to use. Grandma is happy, and that makes me happy.

First, the phone is ok. The font on this picture is not the font on the phone, so my mom cannot see the number or name.
Second, the plan counts incoming calls as well as outgoing calls. So, in the case of my 93 year old mom, even if she makes 5 calls out per month, she received more than 700 calls in a month. So, the lowest plan of 200 calls per month is quickly overtaken. And guess what? The charges add up at a rate of 35 cents per call over the limit of 200. As a senior, if you need to figure that out, you're toast in no time.
Third, for seniors, even though it is a simple phone, there is a period of adjustment as learning new skills without the eyesight and dexterity of your youth is pretty difficult. However, it beats the touch screen 4h generation phones, the iphone, and all the other phones hands down.

I just got the phone. Set up was excellent. Just follow instructions. No complications at all. Love the phone size, the large print. The sound. you can take photos and send to facebook. They ask you if you want too. I have not tried the camera yet. Will today. If displeased, will update. I have not used it much but I know it's good quality and simple. I'm 59, and I'm not into smart phones, etc. Had them, hated them. Don't want to be contacted by every person on my facebook all the time with beeps, etc. Lol. I wanted a simple phone with a simple plan for emergency or necessary contacting only. I like the little stand and I get a free car phone they said which is coming. To purchase and start it all up with activation fee was over $100.00. That does not include minutes. I did not get text but I did get voicemail which is $3.00 extra a month plus tax I imagine. So I'm thinking with the 200 mins plus voicemail it will be close to $20 a month. Not great,not bad. Just is. They gave me time of course but in a few days I will be billed for that. They bill ahead they said. The good thing is I was told the minutes roll over. Love that, cause I don't use my cell hardly at all. So that means if I'm ever without my land phone at home say a power outage, which we are known for, I will have a phone with some time on it. If I change my mind on the phone as time goes by, I will update. But I think I won't. It's just what I wanted.

The phone was ordered for our mom. She loves the phone, the menu is easy to use, and the buttons are large. The drawback to this phone is the GreatCall team. Do not buy this phone if you are planning on paying for the calling plan from overseas - the website doesn't accept foreign billing addresses or telephone numbers. Do not try and call them to activate the phone, as they will confuse you, read off a script with no flexibility, and upsell you expensive options you do not need. They even hung up directly after mentioning a $4 monthly charge without saying what it was for. We had to call back and ask what it was, and then request they take it off the bill. With all the computer activation, phone activation, re-calling, etc., it took over half a day. It's a nice product, one that we need, but do not let your senior parents try to activate it at all - the customer experience is frustrating, confusing, expensive, time-consuming, and just plain awful.

So disappointing. Came up as unlocked but when tried to add to current carrier found out that great call was locked to phone. We get crummy reception, everyone says sounds like a fishbowls husband has terrible time with it and settings are so limited. Almost ready to go back to Smaller phone. HATE IT
love the phone but wish the ringer was a bit louder.
great phone-love it!!

It was a nightmare! Advertised wrong! Lost $ in shipping to me, & in sending it back, due to ad incorrect!! But jitterbug people VERY helpful once u got through to them. Quality phone, just not for me.

After owning many different models of Jitterbug phones by Samsung over the last 5 years, this new one by Alcatell is terrible. First the ringer is far too quiet for an older user. It's set at max ringer and the best you can do is lay the phone on it's face to hope to hear it when it rings. Doesn't matter the ring tone set. Second, and the worst part about this phone is that unless it's held just perfectly, noone can hear on the other end. It's muffled and inaudible. This is a serious flaw for an older person in my opinion. I was reluctant to buy this phone since a different manufacturer than the previous models but I gave it a try. Unfortunately there's some much needed improvements to be made on this one.
On another note not related to the phone. I've had to call Greatcall(Jitterbug) for various reasons over the years and it's always been a smooth, pleasant experience. With this phone I've had to call several times to try and relieve the issues I've had, and I've been met with the recording "we're experiencing unusually high call volume today, for faster service please call back another time". Now this has gone on every day for a week and the wait times are very long. 30 minutes so far. And the representatives are short and come off hurried. I'm getting the feeling these are starting to slide at Greatcall unfortunately.

There are a couple plus' I can give. This one is actually USB capable. I can transfer my photos from my phone to the PC which the other models I've owned cannot. Also the reading magnifier MIGHT come in handy, but I'm returning the phone before I could actually use it realistically.

The first two did not work after one day and the third (yes, I am slow learner) became so S L O W that I was not able to operate it. This was after
a week or so. I think the red ones are a bad batch or are at least with my experience. My husband has a jitterbug that works wonderfully so not sure why this group was so defective.

Hidden charges and unexpected fees (when signing up for monthly plans which the only advertised 14.99 plan doesn't initially disclose) once the phone is received. Everything seems to be an UPCHARGE! Works well but doesn't provide any internet access. For an 80 year old so returning the phone is more hassle than keeping it at this point. I expected a bit more considering the phone was a bit pricey to begin with.
Returned phone. Connection process too difficult for senior. Get a tech person to call for you.
Perfect phone for my Father.

I love this phone. Had a trac phone but everything was too small to read easily. Complicated instructions for use. But the Jitterbug is just the opposite! Big keys with big letters and words and numbers, so easy to learn to use immediately. Has a dial tone which I found adorable. Haven't learned how to text or use the camera yet, but haven't taken the time. Meanwhile it is so easy to use to make calls. I love it! If you are as technology impaired as I am, plus my aging eyes aren't that great, by all means this is a great phone.

Excellent delivery, product as advertised! My mom loves it. Set up relatively easy with customer support. Would have given it 5 stars except for it being a little heavy and you need a computer to save part of activation cost.

I bought two of the Jitterbug Flips for my parents. My mom has vision issues so the big screen is a huge help for her. My dad loves the fact that it is so easy to use. They aren't hard on their phones and my dad has already procured phone holders to protect them (local swap meet).

Instead of setting up an account online I placed a call to their customer service so that I could get both phones on one account (I didn't know if that would be an issue online). I almost fell off the couch when a real live person answered the phone! I am very impressed with GreatCall and their customer service. Their call centers are based in the US, with calls answered quickly by knowledgeable reps.

She walked me through the account process, answered all my questions and had every thing set up in about 15 minutes. I love the idea of the 5 star service (they can press a button and have emergency services called, or even a family member contacted) phones have gps and you can ping the phones location from their website. We'll see how the phones hold up, but the customer service is amazing and you can't put a price on that.

My Mom had this phone for 45 days and it quit working. I've never had a cell phone go bad and this is supposed to be the end all phone for seniors.

What a piece of Junk.
Second attempt to improve my elderly family members phone experience. Button controls not intuitive.could not guess at commands for actions

I bought this phone for my blind father and he likes how heavy the phone feels compared to his old ones. We thought by getting a phone that was geared towards the elderly that this phone would have functions to better serve him but it he doesn't think so.
Big keys & display makes it easy to see & use for mom.
Works most of time but problematic. Have to remove and reinsert battery rather frequently to get it to operate. When it works it's good enough.
Very nice phone , great idea, good price, & fast shipping!

Initially tried another flip phone option for my 94 year old dad, but the Jitterbug Flip was so much easier for him to learn. The user friendly menu and prompts are hassle free, nice large screen, easy to use buttons, and the 5star option is a great peace of mind.

the phone has started locking up randomly and this is very frustrating for my elderly father. I have to remove the battery to reset the phone. Also, the charging port doesn't make contact with the phone well, so we have to disconnect the port and use the cable directly to charge the phone.

The Jitterbug phone is a nice phone but it takes advantage of the elderly it cost more after you get it for example.

so be very careful when you purchase it.

This phone is the worst phone Ive ever owned. Ive been with great call for over 10 years. The Samsung flip phones were the best. This is the worst. Bought it for my elderly father. Set-up was far too difficult for him, and there is a charge for everything, including Voice Mail. The package deals offered don't really exist, as all they allow is phone calls; no voicemail, texting, etc. It costs 10 cents per picture to send or receive pictures. Entering phone numbers into the Phone Book is very clumsy, as is Voice Dial. The phone isn't loud enough for a senior who is hard of hearing. One has to request Voice Dial, as it isn't automatically included, even though it's free. The Voice Dial stopped working twice, and we had to get the phone replaced, going through the set-up all over again. Any senior smart enough to set up this phone is smart enough to use an iPhone, with far less aggravation. Buyer beware!

Many times it won't even ring or place calls because the signal is so poor. Perhaps GreatCall has a remedy. If conditions improve, I'll update this review.

The phone's feel, keypad, and easy reading are wonderful. The menu system and user interface is confusing rather than simple. It takes too many keystrokes to execute many functions such as "Delete Message", etc. The "Yes", "No" buttons are poorly named in many of the menu contexts. There appears to be no simple method for finding a name in the address book if you use a long list of addresses.
The HELP guide does not include instructions on how to search for and/or call a person who is listed in the address book. This is an oversight from which I form a negative impression of the user-friendliness of the product.

Reception at our home is bad. We are probably in a shadow of the network. It is mostly for this one reason that we are returning the phone.

Got this for my husband as it has big numbers and is suppose to be easy to work and hear. This is the second one that we are having a problem with as it is very slow to activate when you open to make a call. Also it is very hard to hear the ring and conversations are not clear or easy to hear.
I have contacted Great Call and after an hour on the phone they are telling me that if it continues to happen they will do a warranty on it. I am wondering if I just get a different phone that you can hear and will not have all these problems.

The main problem I have with this phone is that it navigates slowly through it's menus. For such a basic phone I would think it be a lot simpler to scroll through the menu but it has a noticeable lag.

Another annoyance is that Verizon does not carrie this as a service provider so I had to get service through Great Call (the makers of the phone) which runs off of Verizon cell towers.

Also this phone is not good for people with arthritis as it is designed in a very streamlined way which makes it difficult to open the flip phone.

Lastly, the ringer volume is not very impressive with it's ringtone selections. So if you are hard of hearing this might be difficult for you to use.

Was hoping this flip phone and its alleged increased volume boost would help my 87 year old mom. It didn't. Ringer volume is standard and earpiece volume average as well. Sound is better on her old Motorola. However the bigger problem was the phone didnt get a strong signal despite being in well populated areas that are fully serviced with cell towers everywhere. Signal always read POOR. More than 50 percent of the calls didnt go through at all. Lastly, I saw the 74.99 price on line but called Great Call to order. The slick salesman charged me $99 for the phone and when i corrected him to 74.99 he did the used car saleman line of "Oh well Im not sure. I will have to go see if my manager can find a way to grant that price". Oh really?? Spare me. After that dog and pony show the manager was "Kind" enough to charge the advertised price. Also be aware that even though plans start at enticing levels of 14.99 and up, you will get charged for all extras...like texting which is a separate monthly fee. Rather quickly your monthly bill adds up to numbers that are no longer great deals. Now that I am returning it Great call sends an email which warns "the phone must be like brand new" and only then will they determine if/whether a refund will be offered. The phone isnt even a week old. Id say that is brand new. Not happy with the phone or the customer service reps. I would not recommend. One star because negative stars arent an option.

Had the Jitterbug about 7 months. I'm only on the 200 minutes per month plan so the phone gets very little use. I have always suspected it is not new. Maybe one someone else had and returned.

This review is in 3 parts:

BEGINNING: Worked fine for about two months.

MIDDLE: Problems started. 1. Phone would not ring. Found ring was delayed. Phone rang 5 or 6 times on callers end before my phone finally started to ring so, if I didn't answer fast they had already hung up. 2. Phone would not come on. It's supposed to come when opened but it didn't. Pressed the Off/On button but still didn't come on. Finally comes on but then the Up/Down buttons for the menu don't do anything. They finally start working. 3. I wasn't signed up for text messages. Still, I got 3 or 4 texts a month from people I didn't know and a charge for each call was added to my bill. I called Greatcall to get text message capability taken off the phone. They made it a pain in the patoot to remove something I said I didn't want in the first place. Obviously, just a way for them to add a few cents to the bill each month. 4. Started noticing phone wouldn't hang up. Closing phone should cause it to hang up but the last couple weeks I noticed I would close it and still hear sounds coming from it so would have to open and close again to get it to hang up. 5. I charged phone yesterday. This morning I tried to use phone but it is completely dead. So, I put it back on charger which makes the display screen come on to tell me phone is charging. Display screen is blank. No sign of life. It's just a flat rock.

END: Today I Will Happily Call GreatCall and Tell Them I No Longer Want Their Hunk of Junk Phone.

Although I did not purchase the phone through Amazon, doing so would have helped me deal with one problem: dealing with Great Call. Unfortunately, there are so many incredible problems with Great Call, not dealing with them for one issue is not nearly helpful enough. Needless to say if my grandma could use another phone easily, we'd have already switched, we're in the process of a change for her safety because this company continually leaves her unsafe. As it is, they've put her in danger, leaving her without service for days with a fully paid bill; sent her a new phone in an empty box-no chargers, info booklets, nothing; repeatedly sent the wrong devices or sent the devices to the wrong address (me in AZ rather than her in TX); repeat rote answers about being helpful when it's the last thing this company is; worse, they have a monopoly on this type of service where the core base are seniors and they do not care, at all, about these customers as human beings- our loved ones. Repeatedly- wrong services, wrong devices, cutting off service on the current phone BEFORE the new one arrives and is set up (leaving my grandma in her 90's without service for FIVE days); zero communication or problem solving skills by the reps or the supervisors who only read from rote answers in front of them; hours that are not helpful (supervisors do not work weekends and are difficult to reach); and the option to "press the 5 star button if this is an emergency" when we called after hours did NOTHING- no one ever answered. I'm not only a family member, I'm a registered nurse. They would call her on a daily basis telling her to do and eat things against medical advice. This company does not have these seniors as a priority and unless you have back up plans, your loved one could be in danger if relying on this phone and their services.

bought the jitterbug phone about a year ago (late 2017) and signed up with GreatCall as the provider for my service. Just recently (August 2018) I terminated the service when I bought a new phone of a different brand and changed service provider. A very short time later, I called GreatCall to assess what my final charges would be for ending the service. I was informed that I would have to pay the "full amount" of monthly service billing, even though I only used approx. 7 to 8 days of that term period. I asked . . . "Do you (GreatCall) not make any adjustments on the last billing when someone chooses to terminate the service?" They said "No". I feel this is robbery. I in good faith call them up, wanted to make my final payment for service that I used, but they said I still had to pay the full amount. Even if you used only one day of the service out of the term billing - you have to pay the full amount charges! This is crazy! I just had to express this review to YOU, the reader, if you are a potential buyer of GreatCall Jitterbug what you should expect when you wish to terminate service with this provider. Again, if GreatCall is reading this - - this is wrong! I will spread the word that You Are A Money Rip Off!

I bought this phone for my husband last year. Since the first day we had trouble getting phone calls. It would signal a missed call, but wouldn't ring or we couldn't call out because it wouldn't turn on when opened (flip style). I called CS the second time and they said it must be a battery problem and sent a new battery. When that didn't change anything they said they had been having trouble with the batteries and asked us to just take the battery out and reinstall it anytime it would not work. (That turned out to be most of the time.) They said they were working on the problem and that we would get an email when the problem was resolved. That was about 9 months or so ago. We are so fed up with this phone and totally frustrated! (I know, I know, why did it take so long to complain and get rid of it!) Both busyness and laziness involved in waiting so long. We are getting rid of it now and we would never think about getting another jitterbug phone! Too bad, because the idea is GREAT but it is not worth it! I am finding there are other phones that are compatible for electronically challenged seniors. ANYTHING else has to be better than this phone!!

I am not sure that I can convey just what a horrible experience this phone has been - a disaster from word go! Getting two phones set up for my parents required 10+ calls to the customer service lines - and that is with trying to use the on-line set up process! It took more than a week to have the phone numbers from the previous company switch over to the Great Call phone - and that was all on Great Call; I had the transfer verification numbers from AT&T. Then, when it came through, it wiped out the already set-up on line account,and that in turn wiped out the phone directory that I had typed in (there is no way to electronically transfer from your previous phone), meaning doing it all over again.

All the customer service people that I have dealt with are perfectly nice, and most seem to want to help, but the problems are systemic. The phones themselves are not all that intuitive - but the buttons are large, clearly marked, and the type face is clear and large on the screen. It is the only reason I did not go back to AT&T or Verizon. My advice is to see if there is any way to make a phone from one of the big carriers work for you - and then DO IT. Do not use this carrier if you have any choice at all.

I bought this Flip Phone phone through GreatCall over a year ago for my fairly deaf father who is 96.

Upsides:
1. the numbers are large.
2. The speaker is loud, when you use it instead of the handset.
3. The menu navigation is pretty straightforward for old people without a lot of confusion, but there are still seniors who will get confused using it. Answer the questions yes or no and the phone does what you want it to do. "Do you want to call this number? >YES." That kind of menu.

Downsides:
1. You can't block numbers on this flip phone. Old people are a big target for phone scams. My dad gets bogus telemarketing calls all the time and I can't block the numbers to prevent repeat calls. Thankfully, my next comment comes into play so he never answers the phone ...
2. Why? The ringer isn't very loud. My dad can't hear it even when it's in his pocket, and it's set as loud as it will go. On top of that, you can't set the ringer to loud AND vibrate, which would be very helpful. The ringer is either on some volume OR off with vibrate only.
3. For my father, even with hearing aids, the handset is not loud enough. Hence, we use the speaker a lot.
4. The charging dock bit the dust in less than one year.

This phone made by Alcatel is junk compared to the older Samsung flip. We upgraded when our battery went dead and were unable to replace so we thought it would be better to upgrade the phone. What a mistake. First we had all kinds of trouble because the phone would not activate even though we had to go by a window, then go to the front yard then the backyard. Hours with customer service with no help, we had to mail it in and have them activate it then send it back, more hassles and no phone. Finally we got the phone back and found that it would go dead for no reason at all. Again went through customer service, she had me take the back off and remove the battery then replace it. This is the only way we can make the phone work. If you need it in an emergency you are stuck out of luck until you remove the battery again. We were told not to do that but to return the phone for a replacement, for what another junky Alcatel. Not again. We are going to look at other carriers that have a reliable phone.

Jitterbug Flip phone has Large Keys and SIMPLE operation. It is just great for seniors or non-techie persons. Price is most reasonable. Texting is available IF the user wants it. With Large clear menus , it's EASY to operate with YES and NO buttons! Voice dial service is free!

Great Calls doesn't tell people the truth when they activate this phone. They advertise affordable monthly plans, but don't tell you that they charge you for INCOMING calls as well as OUTGOING. My 89 year old mother only has the phone for emergency calls and talking with family members. Her first bill came (on a $33 a month plan) and it was $250! They charged her for every INCOMING and OUTGOING call!!! This also means that any solicitation calls she got, Great Calls charged her for!!!!!. When I called to tried to find out why the bill was so high, they told me my mother would have to go on-line and print out her call usage and identify every phone number on there....all 276 calls!!! We cancelled the next day.

My 77 year old mother has this phone and has nothing but problems. The buttons on the sides of the phone are right where your hand/fingers would go to hold the phone up to your ear when talking to someone. The ringer mysteriously gets turned off all the time. The menu keys are so slow to respond it reminds me of when the internet was dial-up. It could be my mother not knowing how to use it, by both I and my sister have tried to turn on the "jingle" as they call the ringer, and it just goes off again. Is it my mom's thumb grasping the phone as she holds it?

I don't know, but it's no good. I do not recommend. I love the idea of the large letters but it still has too many un-needed features like background color, etc. Seniors don't want that option...do they? Time for another company to re-invent the wheel here. A wheel for seniors.

I bought this phone a year ago directly from âJitterbugâ/GreatCall for $99 plus a $30 activation fee. My mom is in her 70s and I just needed her to have something for emergencies. The cheapest plan they have is something like $25 per month with fees but it was worth my piece of mind. She has had flip phones in the past so I figured this one would be no problem. I even programmed her friendsâ numbers into it. SHE HATED IT. I paid for the service for a year before finally giving up. She couldnât get it to turn on, it never worked right and it wouldnât hold a charge. Honestly, I heard nothing but complaints from her for the entire time she had this phone.

For Christmas I gave her my old iPhone 7 Plus. She looooves it. I honestly didnât think she could figure out a smart phone, which is why I gave her the Jitterbug Flip. What a waste of time, energy and money.

She used the Jitterbug MAYBE a total of 30 minutes for the ENTIRE YEAR!!!

The worst part of this is that when I called to cancel the service today the rep was like âToo bad your service month just renewed January 10th. I can cancel your service but youâre still paying for it through February 9thâ!!!!

WHY IS IT THAT EVERY OTHER COMPANY IN THE WORLD CAN FIGURE OUT HOW TO PRO-RATE A CANCELLATION?!!â Good job getting an extra $20 out of me, GreatCall. Maybe youâd like to step into the 21st century with the rest of us?

I got a great price for the phone I bought here on Amazon..I made the choice considering the easy use of the phone and idea of a $14.99 monthly charge with no contract..Sounded great!!! But....when I got the phone and called for the activation, I learned the company adds a "service fee" on top of the monthly charge which came to roughly $31.40 a month. Additionally the phone has camera and texting capabilities..Great!!!! But...every time you text, it costs $0.10 for each text you send and receive. Furthermore, for every picture/selfie you take, it will also cost you an additional $0.10 for each photo..I was not pleased about the additional fees,especially the "service fee" which doubles the monthly basic fee. This explains the two star rating. However, I did keep the phone and activated it..These additional fees need to be considered when purchasing this phone,especially for those on a limited budget..

I wanted to believe the good reviews because my mom wouldn't stop bugging me to purchase this red flip phone for her. She has bad eyesight and like many older seniors needs to have a cell phone that will work without all the fuss of the internet on the phone. My sister broke down and got it for her and it has been a head ache for the last 6 months. Just imagine that you don't live near the person who needs it and the phone stops working. Then you spend HOURS contacting every neighbor of hers and then more time contacting the seller to send a new chip. Many times it would just ring and she wouldn't hear it. Long story short - Before this red phone I had a walmart smartphone set up with a software that always showed big easy buttons. Then I used bluetooth to transfer her existing contacts. On this red phone all the contacts and numbers will need to be entered manually. The marketing for this phone is great because everyone who hasn't had one thinks it is a great idea. I thought it was. Currently she has no cell and waiting again for a new chip. I'm across the country so not sure if it is a signal related issue or just that the phone breaks easy. I just want to save someone else this headache and worry. Read all the negative reviews before you buy this.

Back to the drawing board!

I purchased this phone for my friend who has limited vision due to macular degeneration. Activation Fee was High: $37+ . This is Day#1 with the phone, and it seems like it won't work out.

1. Poor Audio: Although we set up Voice Dial to automatically activate upon opening the phone, the automated attendant voice that says, "Say the name" is very tinny and difficult to understand". The phone seems to vibrate with a weird buzzing sound when I press the keys on the keypad to enter New Contacts. This leads me to believe that Audio is going to be a problem.

2. Entering Contacts: Contacts will not let you enter duplicate phone numbers with different descriptions: I wanted to add both the doctor's name themselves and the name of the doctor's office in the event that my friend "said the name" in either form. Also, there is a limited amount of characters that you can use for contacts. For example, Livingston Catholic Charities was too many characters for the phone, and we could not enter it into Contacts. I wanted to enter a Contact called "Call 911", but it stated Invalid Number, and would not let me put it in.

3. Phone is Slippery Material & Easy to Drop: A rubberized coating and a more "bean", hand-shape would be easier to hold and less likely to be dropped. They don't offer any sort of protective case.

4. Voice Dialing: You can't turn the phone off without calling Customer Service to reset the automatic Voice Dial feature. Also, twice in the first two days of use, this phone has said, "Say the Name"; however, the beep is missing. So, I have to shut the phone off and reboot it. It was a risk that the Voice Dial wouldn't come back automatically, but it did. I don't like that you have to wait for a Beep before saying a Contact name. The Senior user either "jumps the gun" and starts to say her contact name too early or waits a few seconds too long and the phone doesn't recognize anything. It just sits there dormant. You have to close the phone and re-open it to activate the Voice Dial again. I also don't like that you can't simply tell the phone a phone number to call. For example, say you have to call somebody not on your Contact List. For a blind person, this is a fault in the Voice Dial feature. You need to be able to say, "000-000-0000". The system should call whatever number is spoken.

5. Quality of keys: Should be separate, rubberized / textured keys for visually impaired users. The keys remind me of the plastic used on microwave oven keypads. It doesn't seem very durable over time. Plus, they are not responsive. They don't spring back when you depress them. This blind user had difficulty telling which key she is using and if it has actually been depressed because she can't see the screen.

DOESN'T WORK ON ANY NETWORK OTHER THAN JITTERBUG. they won't unlock phone to use on ANY other network.

It does NOT say that clearly. If your an AT&T, or other network customer just DO NOT BUY!!!

A definite abuse of SENIORS.

Do not buy the Alcatel Red Flip Phone. My mother has dementia and is 89 years old. She has been a GreatCall customer for 4 years. She recently upgraded to new flip phone and the time continues to change through out the day. Sometimes it is correct and sometimes it is an hour off. Imagine how difficult this is for a person with dementia. No wonder why she keeps telling me the time recently changed and changes all the clocks in her home. Upon calling customer service for my mom, I am told that it is an isolated problem identified over a year ago with no solution. They would not send out a new phone to see if the problem would be rectified with new hardware. Not a phone for seniors or ANYONE for that matter. Customer service told me that having the wrong time on the phone was not a cause for sending out a new phone. Well for a senior, which is the GreatCall customer segment they are marketing to, having the wrong time is not acceptable.

I owned one of the first Original Jitterbug phones at a time when I was not considered Senior. I liked the look of the Original Jitterbug, the relatively cheap plans and the large dial pad. At the time I needed a cell phone when traveling a long commute to and from work. I had a landline at home and didn't want to give that up. I've since upgraded to a different cell phone and service because my kids are grown and I have grandchildren now and needed more talk time. Jitterbug/GreatCall has changed a lot since then and I wanted to find out if I would like their service now better than my current service. I am very close to being considered a Senior now but there are still problems with Jitterbug/Great Call that I don't like.

First the coverage map shows that I am in the Verizon network-I did check before ordering. I was also in the Verizon network 6 years ago with my first Jitterbug. The Original Jitterbug didn't work very well at my previous address. This Jitterbug doesn't work at all at my current address. So if cell phones don't work at your home or you have spotty coverage at your home, this phone is not likely to work for you and that means the 5Star Urgent Response Emergency Service will not work either. I have medical conditions that will eventually leave me unable to live alone. I had hoped the 5Star would work so that I would feel more confident as I age.

Setup-I opted to go to GreatCall's website to activate the phone. If I can do it myself I will, but that's just me. After activating and following instructions I turned the phone on to allow it to program and update. After beginning the process I received an error code with the message to call customer service. Still not wanting to deal with customer service (I'm like that) I turned the phone off, back on and it again began programming and gave me a different error code and again the message to call customer service. I restarted one additional time and the phone programmed completely. So if you're a do it yourself person and this happens to you keep turning the phone off and on-maybe this will work for you too.

The thing I hate about this phone is the VERY SHORT battery life. I've conducted the same test several times. I put the phone on the charger when I come home. By the time I'm ready to retire it's fully charged and I put it in my purse (so I won't forget it-that age thing) and when I get up the following morning I've lost 25% of the battery with absolutely no use. I carry the phone with me to the office, did not use it at all, and when I come home in the evening the battery life is down to less than 50%. If I fail to put it on the charger that night, it's dead before noon of the second day. My current cell phone will stay charged up for 5 days with little to no use.

Bluetooth-This phone is blue-tooth enabled. My vehicle is blue-tooth enabled and I had this phone connected in a matter of minutes.
The camera works as well as any cell phone I've owned and used, honestly no better/no worse.
When I have service the call is clear without any background noise. So far I've had no dropped calls when I'm in a service area.

I likely will stick with my current cell phone and not continue service with GreatCall. I really wanted this phone for the 5Star helpline and it doesn't work where I need it.

My Mom and Dad have a Jitterbug and they love it. It also works at their home. I include that to tell you It's a great phone for Seniors and people with serious health problems if you have service where you need it. I guess what I'm trying to say is the phone didn't work for me. It may work for you or your circumstances and the only way to find out is to try it. For me it's not a good fit.

This Jitterbug phone does remind me of a Motorola Razr phone from 10 years ago. It's a flip phone that has extra large buttons and a simplified system so itâs easier for people who have never used a smartphone. I have a 90+ year old aunt who uses a hearing aid, and has poor vision in only one eye, and so she needs a phone that is really loud so she can use it even if she is not using her hearing aid as she doesnât like to use it.

This jitterbug is made by Alcatel and has some good features, but some negatives:
- Large buttons that she can see, and large on-screen fonts that she can read
- Simpler navigation with Yes/No buttons rather than symbols. However, she still presses the wrong buttons sometimes. If âYesâ was colored green and âNoâ colored red, it may make it simpler for someone with poorer vision.
- The Speaker and On/Off power button are also a bit confusing. These could be symbols I think.
- If the phone is not held up properly, the sound can be muddled and distant sounding. This is a bit of challenge with an older relative.
- The ringtones can be set up to ring differently for people so she knows who is calling without having to look. However, the ringer can be a little too quiet for my aunt sometimes, who does not hear it. I wish there was an extra loud feature.
- The phone plan can ONLY be purchased from GreatCall, they have many plans available from $14.99 that are no-contract. It piggy backs on the Verizon network, and has pretty good coverage everywhere.
- It comes with a 5 Star urgent response button for emergency, recent news suggests that the operators can also call a Lyft ride for the seniors.
- It can also take pictures as it has a camera, but this feature is not used by my aunt.
- Itâs got a location GPS function, but as another reviewer points out, it does NOT update automatically after 20 minutes, and the update can take 1- 5 minutes, or may get stuck, which can be terrible in an emergency. So itâs a feature, but not very reliable.
- The screen brightness cannot be changed, itâs bright enough but there is no way to change it. There is also no way to tell the battery power without going into Phone Info. I wish it glowed a different color if battery was low. That would provide a better visual cue to a senior.
- There is also no voice dial. For someone with vision disability that would have been a great feature.
- My world does not allow browsing or email but does give weather at the current location.
- There is also a reading magnifier which works with the LED light to magnify and light up menus in restaurants, or read finer print more easily.
- It comes with a wall charger, a docking stand, a USB cable for connecting to computer.
- This phone will also work during international travel, itâs a CDMA phone so it will work with the Verizon partners internationally
- There are some add on services available like Urgent Care (24/7 access to registered nurses and doctors), MedCoach (reminders to pick up prescriptions and take medication), and Check-in Call (an automated phone call up to six times a day to check up on the senior). Each of these services costs extra though, and can add up.

From other reviews I can see that the customer service from Great Call is variable, so far I havenât called them myself. It seems that they try to fix the problem but if this phone is to be given to a much older person someone else will have to call to have problems fixed. Also donât buy this phone to use with another provider as itâs locked to Great Call. It cannot be used with Verizon directly from what Iâve learned. So overall a good and simple phone for seniors, but not perfect.

One of the things that I have always hated about new cell phones is that the keys require you to be with perfect vision, nimble fingers, and a sense that really small letters are the things you should see. Well...this phone dispels all of those myths! You do not need perfect vision...it is lit up so that the keys stand out, the letters are large and back lit, and in case you do not remember the way to access the phone book you can talk to it!

Yes, this phone has all the bells and whistles! A single button in red can dispatch a call for emergency help and if you feel that you are in a quandary about whether you might make a mistake with it while you are on a call, you can turn it off for a spell while you chat with your friends.

The website which connects to the phone and you is very versatile so you can enter your phone numbers easily using your computer rather than having to use two thumbs or fingers. Type as you normally do and all gets entered in the website and your phone at the same time.

There are several ways to charge your phone and keep it operating well. One is plugging into the wall, another is connecting to your lap top or desk top computers. When I found that keeping the phone handy so that I could us the USB connection, well I was really impressed.

Some of the things which you can do with the phone are fully discussed in the well written guide book which, incidentally is in larger than normal type! Yes, you can use it without getting the magnifier out which incidentally is in the phone with a 1 to 5 magnification setting.

You can set up some text messages which will be sent if you so desire using the same words and this can be done on the website.

There is a very bright light which operates when you open the phone and press the button. There is a warning in the manual, pay heed to it. Do not stare into the light when you turn it on, it is VERY bright!

The camera takes decent pictures, but is not the same as some of the high quality you will find in a camera or other type of phone. One thing which I would have done is set it up so that you could shoot a short movie like 30 seconds to capture a memorable moment. You also can upload to your Facebook page the photos you take.

This is a small, compact, and easily handled phone with a speaker ability which is easily accessed by the touch of a button you can very easily see.

The monthly service charge is reasonable if you want to use this phone for only emergencies or speaking on occasion. If you decide to use the health lines the cost is .99 per call. You might want to use this Ala Carte menu unless you feel you need to be in the loop many times per month. There are two other health related calls you can make as well for advice on medical care.

The Jitterbug Flip is an effective and easy to use phone for use with the 5Star Urgent Response service. This is the primary factor for having this phone in my home. For a person with dementia most phones are too difficult to use for emergency contacts. The single button contact with this phone makes it ideal for this purpose. The 5Star agents are courteous and efficient.

If the Jitterbug Flip could incorporate single button dialing for calling "favorites" this would improve its usability for use by persons with dementia or limitations in manual dexterity.

The phone appears to be constructed in a very sturdy format and should stand up to daily use, including being dropped, as is often the case with senior citizens.

If ones primary use for this phone is to serve as a regular cell phone, there are limitations. The lack of "voice to text" capability significantly limits its use for text messaging. The camera function is also limited and does not permit picture editing, etc. without downloading the photo to a computer.

Was given to a senior relative. She likes it because she can make a call by just pushing a programmed button and she does not need to remember how to get an outside line from her facility. Down side is that she cannot easily call people that are not programmed into her phone without us giving her direction over the Jitterbug so she can dial her land line. The REAL downside is the horrendous sound quality. It is nearly impossible to understand her when she speaks on this phone. If we get a call or message we cannot understand, we know it's her and we just call her back on her landline, where she is very easy to understand. For the price of the phone, and the price of the service I'd have expected better quality. I honestly think this company just scams seniors with their phones and service. We'd love to get her on a better plan with a better phone but because she is used to this phone she refuses to change.

Mom got this to replace the medical alert system I had bought her as she didn't care for wearing the pendant. It arrived late. Now she did buy this from the company directly not through Amazon. The phone went on sale the next day, and the company rep never mentioned that. BUT they did credit her the difference. Problem was, they credited it for a period BEFORE she owned the phone. Another shining example of customer service. They finally straightened that out, but it makes you wonder how relaible the 5 star might be if the rest of the service is this messed up.

Pros: Big keys and easy to see. One button dialing for help. Dial tone just by flipping open the phone.

Cons: Customer service needs way more training. A $45 activation fee. In this age when almost all cell phone companies don't do this anymore. Get charged for an incoming call, even from Great Call. Hardly anyone does that either anymore. Decide you don't like it and return it, forfeit the activation fee AND pay $10 for restocking. A load of garbage there.

Pros: Bigger than previous version, 5-Star button has been moved to bottom so you don't easily hit it when you don't mean to. So, some small pluses over previous Jitterbug Flips.
BUT---
Cons: IT DOESN'T ALWAYS RING FOR INCOMING CALLS. This is a big one for me. I've missed two important medical calls in the last week. Was sitting right by the phone waiting for the calls both times, but the phone went straight to "Missed Call" notice without ringing.
Also--hard to open, hard to hold during a call so that you aren't constantly touching the buttons that turn volume up or down. Obnoxiously loud dial tone.

UPDATE. A very nice CSR from GreatCall reprogramed my phone, so we hope it will now ring when it's supposed to. Only thing is, now the phone doesn't have a dial tone at all. Hey, ho.
SECOND UPDATE: A week later, it's back to not ringing consistently.
Gift

I really like the phone. HOWEVER, I have been constant harassed by IRS scammers and robo calls!!!!!! I am on the do not call list. BUT SINCE we can NOT BLOCK calls this is VERY annoying!!!!!! I get calls in the middle of the night and early am....I filled FCC consumer complaint but these (*(*&* scammers just get different phone numbers, The phone service provider Verizon does NOTHING to stop this...Do these robo scammers calls earn a lot of money for the major phone companies, and that is why nothing gets done to protect the consumer?

Love the phone hate the scammers calling on my phone and eating my minutes

Pros:
Clear display, bright flashlight

Cons:
Flimsy charging base that tips over easily
Phone can be set to Ring or Vibrate, but not both
No real battery gauge, just a display that will come up when it needs charging
Phone book (contacts) cannot be sorted; it is always in the order that you entered your contacts
Phone book only holds names and phone numbers, no other information
No real keyboard for text messages, you must hit number keys multiple times to enter letters
Photos cannot be sorted; they are always in the order taken

Good things about 5Star Service:
Urgent Care; access to nurses and doctors
MedCoach as a reminder to take medicines
Check in call that notifies family/friend if there is a problem

Just tried to set this up for my grandmother, what a nightmare. Website consistently had errors, I had to input the same information over and over again while site tried to figure out what it was doing. The order never confirmed the phone plan, cost, taxes or fees. Ultimately an hour in, and the phone its self won't connect(error 09) to the network and suggests I call customer service. So much for and easy to use device.

The Jitterbug Flip is the answer for those not too tech savy. Its easy to follow instructions get you started in just a few minutes. Extra large keyboard makes it wonderful for the sight challenged. The Five Star feature is excellent . When I tested it , I was talking with a response operator within 15 seconds! The phone itself is pretty much automatically operating, just open it up and you are ready to either dial your number or you can tell the phone who you want to call using the voice call. The phone comes complete with an easy to use charging stand and the battery seems to last for several days on a single charge. If you are looking for a phone for a loved one who needs special care and ease of operation , I would highly recommend this phone!

I bought this from the seller, GreatCall. I just wanted a backup because my smartphone stopped working once.
EVery week I have to contact customer service: phone wont turn on or wont accept charge. First time I called was because I could not get a signal. Tech told me to stand near a window. What kind of help is that?
I faithfully charge it every day.
Tonight phone is stuck at 6:52 pm while the real time now is midnight. Customer service wont be available until morning.Phone wont turn off or on and I cant figure out how to open battery case to reset.
The best thing about this phone, a Jitterbug, is the 5 star emergency service.That is an unexpected bonus. At least that part is working even if the rest is not.So maybe I will get another flip phone from a different provider and get emergency medical service from somebody else too.

Not-so smart Jitterbug Operatorâs Manual

When selecting a cell phone it would have helped me if someone had written an Operatorâs Manual for the Jitterbug Alcatel OneTouch. So I will do that for you.

Setting the phone up is easy if you buy it from Great Call. Simply turn it on. The rest is automatic.

If you want to put names and phone numbers into your âPhone Bookâ the easiest way is to log in to your Great Call account. Not only can you use your regular keyboard, but you can alphabetize.

Now, to use your phone, flip it open, press the âOnâ button, and hold it for the count of five. If you donât hold that button, youâll be disappointed to find your phone off when you want to use it.

After the count of five there will be a row of lights across the bottom of the display that run, and run, and run â Iâd guess for at least a minute. If you close your phone before those lights stop running you may find that your phone is not on when you want to use it.

Now, when you want to use it, flip it open. If it does not light up, donât press the On/Off button again to turn it on, because you will turn it Off.

After you open it, press a button and wait. If it eventually lights up that means that it is on, and ready to use. If it does not light up, itâs still off, in spite of your best previous efforts to turn it on.

Now, letâs say someone calls you. You look at the outside window to see who is calling, and donât see anything. So you open it to see who it is, and discover that you have taken the call, whether you wanted to or not.

Now letâs say that it is someone you want to talk to, so you say âHello.â âHello.â âHello.â This time you need to press a button to answer your phone.

So now you get a call that you want to take, so you open your phone, and not knowing if you need to press a button to receive the call you ask, âAre you there?â The caller answers, âOf course Iâm here. Why else would I be calling you?â

Want to know if your phone needs charging? There is no indicator on the screen. Flip your phone open, coax it to light up, press the down arrow eight times (it wonât scroll if you hold the down arrow down), then press âYesâ for Phone Info. If you forget to do this regularly youâll find that you canât use your phone when you need it.

Now, if you want to call someone in your Phone Book, whoâs last name starts with Z, and you have alphabetized by last name, go to your Phone Book, and press the down arrow. Then press it again. And then again. And again. And again, again, again. You need to move through your entire phone book, one name at a time, to get to the Zâs. Did you buy a smart phone? Then you canât expect to just hold the down arrow down and expect it to keep scrolling through unwanted names until it gets to the name you want.

7-20-18 I finally gave up on the Jitterbug and bought a smart phone. I cancelled GreatCall service on June 28. I received a bill dated June 26. Great Call charged me for 28 days that I did not use their service. Had I been aware that the previous month's service ended on June 26 I could have cancelled two days earlier. So be cautious about giving Great Call your credit card number.

I find the Jitterbug Flip phone to be very easy to use, even when you are not proficient with technology. It has large yes and no buttons and arrows up and down for the different functions. It also has large buttons and display, is bright and clear to see everything and has volume controls for those who have difficulty hearing. I have never completely understood how to do everything on a cell phone until I started using the Jitterbug. Now I can do everything from making calls, sending texts, taking and sending photos, checking messages and more. It also is a safety device with a button to push in case of emergency to be instantly connected to a professional who can help you. I like the additional features of flashlight and magnifier. I highly recommend it, especially for seniors like myself who have trouble seeing or hearing well and are easily confused.

I had a smart phone, most of which I had no idea how to use, being born prior to the technology era. I had to charge it all of the time. My apps were using power when I didn't even use them. Now, I have a Jitterbug Flip. It's easy for my arthritic hands to hold. The buttons are large and well lit. It has an easy to use menu. I can send pictures in minutes or save them for later. The phone book puts my friends, family and emergency numbers at my fingertips. With 5 star, emergency help is just a push of a button away. If you're a senior citizen, it is the easiest, most convenient communication device you can own.

Jitterbug Flip was recommended to me ...I ordered it and the surprises began...first, the customer service rep was knowledgeable, courteous and efficient....Apparently, the features were all activated for me...friends immediately sent me photos..and lo and behold!... there they were!!!...another friend informed me that she texted me...and it just magically appeared!!! Then...I took my own photos with the very easy to use camera and sent them out...miracles of miracles!!!
"Easy to use" does not begin to describe my introduction to the Flip...it holds your hand and walks you through all the features...
As a matter of fact, at 87, the Flip has given me so much confidence and joy...I am seriously contemplating moving up to a Jitterbug Smartphone in the foreseeable future!!!

I really liked the large buttons. They were easy to use despite having arthritic and tremulous hands. The 5 Star button was a nice feature, but unnessary if one has an emergency alert system. Mine is free with my home alarm system, and I never leave home alone. I did not like it for calls. II entered a number and instructed the phone to call. I got a message that it was dialing then nothing. The recipients never got the call. "Of all of the calls that I attempted, only one went through. I also found that I kept hitting the volume button when holding the phone.

If you are looking for an easy to use flip phone, this is a perfect choice. The Jitterbug Flip has many of the features of more expensive phones, but at a lower cost. Most of the phone's functions are done by simply using the YES and NO buttons.

You will find a phone book, camera, photo storage, text capabilities, voice mail, and even an object magnifier at your fingertips when you open the phone. All are easy to find and use.

The camera is easy to use...the photos are adequate but not great.You also have the ability to share your photos on Facebook. You can download photos to your computer by using a cord. You cannot, however, send photos to an email address...only to the phone number of a contact.

I found the phone to be large and a bit heavy for my hand, but otherwise more than adequate based on how easy it was to use and its cost.

After receiving my Jitterbug Flip, I was very impressed with the appearance and features of the phone. First of all, it is a flip phone with features that I would never have imagined on a flip phone.
The color is crisp and shiny, the screen is bigger (one of my favorite features), the buttons are bigger, which makes them easy to see, and the volume and speaker phone is louder(which is great for Seniors). Not until I received my Jitterbug Flip did I realize there were so many differences in flip phones. This one is amazing!
All the amenities such as the 5Star service, which connects me to a highly trained agent to help with emergencies, Urgent Care which gives me unlimited access to RN's and Doctors 24-7, and prescription refill reminders, for me makes this the best flip phone I ever had!!

I got this for my husband who refuses to use a cell phone. He didn't like the little throw-away phones because the buttons are too small and they're just too hard to read. Basically, they weren't intuitive enough for him.

The Jitterbug Flip was easy to set up. My husband likes the large display (he has eye disease) and the large number pad. He also likes that he can leave it on and just drop it into the charging dock, which is a sturdy and steady station that doesn't tip over (What a concept!). Then drop into his pocket when he leaves the house. Drop back into the charger. Easy peasy. The emergency button is a terrific feature too! The camera allows for some basic shots. While not for making art-pics, it will certainly would be handy if a quick photo is needed. The sound/voice is good on the phone too!

I'll update this as we continue to use this phone.

First, let's start with the pluses. The screen has a clear boldface font that is easy to read. The volume is good. Even though it does not have computer access, it can transfer photos to a computer. The keys are large enough to be easy to tap without overlapping into the next key and mistyping. Dialing by voice is helpful. Because it is a flip, no chance of a butt dial. Some (especially the children of older seniors) will love the 5-star option for emergencies and other services.

Now for the negatives. The screen is still tiny, only about 1"x2" for the text in a text message. And this is in a phone that is just barely lighter than my existing phone, which is closer to 2"x3" for texts. I love the idea of the magnifier but found it difficult to position so I could read what I thought I had it aimed at. The keys have multiple characters per key so it is onerous to type anything and it cannot send texts by voice. Some might like the simple scroll down menus for options but I have grown accustomed to a touch screen with icons and prefer that; however, if I channel and older friend who never really got the hang of her phone, I expect she would have found scrolling easier. Photos appear rather grainy.

Coverage has been a mixed bag. A call to someone whose voice has a tendency to cut off while using my existing phone was quite clear on the Jitterbug. She, on the other hand, said she could hear my ok said my voice sounded "mushy." Also, a voicemail I left myself was not at all good quality. Other calls have generally been ok on both sides. The phone itself described as anywhere from "fair" to "strong" the reception for the areas from which I typically call.

As to improvements, number one would be the ability to text by voice. Second would be an actual full keypad. (If there were voice texting, that would not be as important.) Some of these issues do appear to be resolved by Jitterbug's higher-end phone.

I purchased my Jitterbug Flip phone about a month ago. I am happy with it because it is simple and easy to use. There are a limited number of buttons to choose from, which makes it very easy. The numbers on the number pad are large and backlit, so are very easy to see. I don't consider myself very old--I'm 73--or handicapped; I know computers, and have always considered myself an intelligent person. However, on two occasions I was given a "free" smartphone, and I found it confusing, frustrating, and very hard to use. I didn't want the long list of "apps" on the phone; I only wanted to be able to make or receive calls. I don't like a phone that has a "mind of its own" and does things I don't want it to do. For example, "Ask Google" kept coming up on the screen whenever I tried to make a call, even though I didn't want it to.
I am paying $31 a month for the service, including voicemail and up to 300 text messages. I was able to cancel my landline phone; I didn't like the taxes and fees I had to pay for the landline service.
I don't have the 5star emergency service, as it costs about an extra $9.99 a month, and I don't think that I need it--maybe I might in the future. It is easy to re-charge. One small drawback is that when I use the "phonebook," I have to keep pressing the down arrow until I get to the phone number that I want; this is slightly inconvenient. It takes a little time to do text messages, but it's worth it sometimes, when you don't want to actually make a call but just want to send a brief message.

Since you HAVE TO go work GreatCall, so yes my activation experience is relevant. Calling GreatCall to order the red Jitterbug flip was a good experience, although on top of $60 they charged me $35 activation and $10 shipping, and refuse to waive those, but threw in a leather pouch as goodwill...

The real nightmare cane when the phone arrived and we try to port in a Verizon prepaid number. So GreatCall submit the port request and tell you it might take up 3 days to convert. This phone is for out of town elderly relative I can't stay there keep testing for him for , so I waited an hour and called GreatCall, only to find port request was rejected (Verizon account number didn't match). If the port request is rejected right away, LET ME KNOW RIGHT AWAY INSTEAD OF MAKING US WAIT FOOLISHLY FOR 3 DAYS FOR NOTHING! It took a week and many phone calls to finally port in the Verizon number, and some reps were very helpful and some just want to brush you off.

The phone being easy to use does have drawback. The Bluetooth would not pair to any of my phones or PC to let me transfer phone book or photos. Do the final solution was to text the photos to the phone, and login online to enter the phone book (and then the contacts automatically pops up on the phone. The phone works fine, but interface is very limited so not much you can tweak or personalize. Oh well the user asked for a simple phone, so you get a simple phone.

I wanted a cell phone to replace the one I had that you purchase cards for. I wanted a plain phone with a emergency contact button. Being a heart patient with a defibrillator and pacer the 5 star ( emergency ) button was very appealing. The voice mail , camera , light and large numbers is also nice plus the low monthly rate.
All in all the Jitterbug is a nice package for a person who wants security and some extras without all of the rest bells and whistles. Personally I can not see where a person could go wrong with the Jitterbug , I really like mine. . .

This is exactly the kind of phone you get for relatives who are getting just a little too old. They have trouble seeing numbers and their fingers aren't so good at pressing tiny buttons. What they need is an easy to use cell phone and forget about all the other stuff like internet access. Actually this is also the kind of phone that I could live with too - 99% of the time I do not use smartphone features (in part because I am scared of triggering high data charges and in part because I am rarely far away from my laptop). We have purchased similar phones before for my mother in law and basically there was not much chance she could do much more than use speed dial of preentered numbers. This phone delivers nicely as a basic easy to read phone with big keys. This version is tied to Verizon's network and Verizon's charges are IMHO maybe 50% higher than the $10/month spot where I think basic voice phones should be priced. You do get a camera, a charger, Bluetooth and a USB cable.

Phone is quite usable. It seems to be louder than other phones, which I appreciate. On/off is simple--just push the button. I very much like the fact that it includes a medical alert button, although I have not yet had occasion to use said button. I also like the additional services offered--for example, check-in calls daily or several times a day if I want them. The phone is of a size to slip conveniently into my pocket, so I have the medical alert when I am out and about.

A couple of things kind of bug me. One is the fact that the phone periodically resets the time an hour early--which is a bit of a nuisance. Customer service tells me that GreatCall is working on that problem, but for now, if I turn the phone off and then on again, that should solve the problem. It does that.

And when I want to send a text, the phone offers me a choice of a "library" of prepared texts and a second selection where I can customize the text. Since I seldom, if ever would want to use the "library" of texts, it is rather a nuisance to have to switch to "customize" before I can send the text I want. I would prefer that the "customize" option were offered first.

I purchased this phone for my 88 year old mother who is still mobile and independent to an extent. She has some memory issues and learning to use the phone was a challenge but it is getting easier. I love the 5star button. I love the fact that I can use the app and keep track of her. She only goes a few places a week but it's nice to know when she gets home safely. Setting up the phone and adding contacts and personal information is easy. Customer service is usually very busy but both times I have called I have been treated very nice and not hurried. I actually spoke to a person that I could understand as well which was a welcome change! Both times my questions were answered and both reps went above and beyond to explain some things to me that I was unaware of. The app was a little challenging to set up. It took a while to get it connected but I am so thankful for it because I don't have to call her every few minutes to see if she is at home. Overall we are very pleased.
