My mother loves the red phone because it is easy for her to locate. She loves the big buttons and the screen showing larger numbers. The best thing is she can hear on it! The speaker is loud enough that she can hear really well.

This review should be for two separate things: the phone and the service.

The phone is great, big buttons and very loud. I ordered it so my dad would actually hear his incoming calls. We tried to activate the service several times and were never able to get the phone to work. My dad already used Verizon so it wasn't that the service wasn't available, it just kept saying the service had already been activated by somebody else (not us).

The point of this phone was that a non-internet savvy person should have been able to use it. This definitely isn't the case. He wasn't interested in the trouble he faced in activating this phone and just bought another 30-day card for his old phone.

Good phone, bewildering activation.

My old flip phone from Greatcall worked fine. When I held the ON button down, I had dial tone in about 4 seconds. Then they offered an update to an "improved" version of the phone. I bought it. This one takes between 58 to 60 seconds (I timed it several times) to get a dial tone after the screen first lights up. Since this is supposed to be an emergency phone, and 60 seconds could be a lifetime in an emergency, this is unacceptable. Customer service says "it is supposed to be that way," and then "we no longer support your old phone" when I said I wanted to go back to it. Really? Would the older phone have suddenly stopped working because I hadn't bought the newer one?

One of the improvements is supposed to be voice dialing (select a name by voice), and is described in the manual. The phone didn't have it. Customer service told me that It had to be turned on by them, and they would do so. That was several days ago....

Update 10/11/18. Well, there is still no voice dialing. This is not the first time a GreatCall representative has lied to me.

Another annoyance: This no version has almost NO configurable settings. For example, pressing keys to enter a phone number causes a very loud beep with each press. There is no way to turn off or reduce volume for this.

I have been using cell phones since the late 1980's and this is absolutely the worst one I have ever owned. The earlier flip phone model that Great Call offered was really nice but they stopped carrying it and replaced it with this piece of garbage. I had to send the first one back and the second one works slightly better but not much. You flip it open and sometimes the screen lights up and sometimes it doesn't for quite awhile. You press a key and sometimes it works and sometimes it doesn't. Pretty much the same with every feature on the phone. If there was a "minus" Star in the rating I would have used it.

This Jitterbug Flip phone by GreatCall, was tested by both myself and my mother. My mother is elderly and not a technical person. She could never use one of those phones that you have to use your finger on, however, after not too much time, she was capable in using this phone. I like the design of it, the buttons are big and the numbers typed in are displayed big. It has a good speaker on it too, so people who may be slightly deaf, should still be able to use this phone effectively.

The interface is simple too. Basically, "yes" and "no" responses are used. When you press a button it asks if you want that feature and you answer "yes" or "no." Then of course there is the main event, the 5Star Urgent response button, which immediately connects to a, "trained Urgent response agent who can help in any situation and emergency."

One thing that threw me off a bit was when I dialed 411 for information, expecting a regular telephone operator and was connected to a Jitterbug operator, who gave me the number I needed. So I like this phone. I personally like the flip phone design better than the flat screen design anyway, but I could see that my mother also responded well with the phone and used it correctly.

This Jitterbug phone could be very useful in an emergency, even more so than flat screen versions. My neighbor who is in her eighties had a similar flat screened phone, and she couldn't figure it out. So I recommend this Jitterbug flip phone to people who are not technically savvy, but might need it.

Just activated this phone today for my grandmother. So too soon to rate battery life or durability of phone. But so far we are happy with the size and the functionality. My grandmothers old phone was the LG Revere 3 and it just wasn't big enough for her. She found in difficult to dial. You can see the comparison in the photos. The bit bigger numbers make it alot easier. I am impressed that the jitterbug has a dial tone before you dial. The activation was easy enough online through greatcall.com there was a $25 activation fee and $4 activation fee I believe for the free car charger they are mailing us. The 200 minute plan is $14.99 before taxes and fees. Texts aren't included. We didnt add on voicemail or anything thing additional. The 5star button when pressed without the 5star service plan will still ask you on the screen if you want to dial 911. Which I think is great. All in all so far so good. Hopefully everything will be smooth sailing and the phone will keep working well. I'll update if not!

This was a great phone. Not used very often, but fairly easy for my low vision, memory impaired 86 yr old mother. Now it doesn't work at all. Have had it 2 yrs, used it several times/mo and now several keys have stopped working. The "yes" key doesn't work at all. Also it doesn't end call when closed. The volume resets to low for no known reason. So I'm shopping for new and will not again use Jitterbug. This is the second Jitterbug phone I've had to replace.... Fool me once shame on you, fool me twice, shame on me.

Although, admittedly, I don't use my Flip often (I mostly keep it in the glove box of my car for emergencies) when I do use it I'm really happy that I purchased it. Yes, I'm a senior citizen and a bit technologically challenged, but I make no apologies for loving the big buttons, large screen, and intuitive user interface. Since I don't use it often, I also love the way the battery stays charged for long periods. Thanks, Jitterbug, for coming to the rescue of those of us who just don't want or need all of the features of the over-hyped smartphones.

This started out as a five-star review.

While Iâm no senior citizen, I feel Iâm the perfect consumer for this product. I am 54 years old and have never had a cell phone. I donât like the small buttons, complicated user instructions and all the bells-and-whistles going on with the most up-to-date phones. Personally, I have no use for the majority of the functions. I have no interest in texting, surfing the internet or taking selfies while Iâm out and about. Plus, call me old fashioned, but when I talk to someone on the phone, I prefer to have something actually in front of my mouth when Iâm speaking.

So this was just what the doctor ordered. Firstly, itâs super simple to set up. Literally, I just turned it on and the number was pre-programmed and ready to go. The keypad numbers are extra large and all the functions are pretty much 100% self-explanatory. If you want to call someone, merely punch the number buttons (which appears in large type on the screen) and when youâre done, there is a bar across the bottom of the screen that asks if you want to call and you hit âYES.â I never cracked open the user guide and was still able to record my voicemail message, access voicemail, take a couple of photos, set my ringtone and talk on the speaker with no problems.

I live in CT and took it on a long weekend to Chicago to test these various functions. I took a couple of photographs - albeit very grainy ones but hey, if you need to catch that subway perv in the act, it will certainly do the trick. I used the speaker phone on a call to my mother and all three parties on the conversation could hear one another splendidly. There are a handful of pretty standard ringtones on offer and some pre-set emergency medical numbers (although I suspect these are fee based services associated with the phone manufacturer).

So yeah, everything was going great until I got to OâHare for my return trip to CT. Turned on the phone to call my husband and - pffft â it was gone. Nothing. Nada. Completely black screen. I attempted to charge it up when I arrived home (even though I kind of knew this wasnât the problem) and still nothing.

This is a really cool functional item that was super-intuitive and easy to use. I hate to admit it, but after just a week of use, I actually missed having a phone. Perhaps I just got a lemon. I donât know. Since my experience is probably not typical, I would suggest reading other reviews and weighing everything together before you make the choice whether to buy the Jitterbug or look elsewhere.

The new Flip Phone is a step backward, the Jitterbug 5 had the perfect size and user friendly functions, dialing could be easily done with one hand AND the speaker stayed off until you told it to turn on. The Flip has the annoying feature of having the speaker on for frequently used functions, including the annoying dial tone when you open it up. Even more annoying are the "beeps" you get when sending text messages, there's no way of turning that off except dialing the volume all the way down, an extra unnecessary step. After that you have to remember to turn the volume back up so that you can hear calls. What you are doing can clearly be seen on the screen so why are the beeps necessary? Here's a radical idea: Engineer the phone so that you only have the speaker on when you want it on.
Fixing the beeps and dial tone issues would make the phone better, but one would still be stuck with an unnecessarily big bulky phone. My fantasy is that a Jitterbug 5 type phone would make a comeback with new features like more symbol choices such as $, &, %, " and be able to send a text message with a phone number that you have in hand and not have to go online and enter it into your phone book list to send.

This is a nice "Star Trek" (flip) phone, and I like it a lot.

First the plus side:
*I love having my phone number so prominent on the opening screen.
*The text library is INGENIOUS! Such common texts as "Yes," "No," "How are you?", etc. are saved and are easily available to pick and send--minimal fuss and bother.
*The earpiece speaker is loud, and the handset microphone is quite good. Old Dad, who is 80 and who is missing a lot of his hearing, can hear me better when I use this phone.
*The customer service at GreatCall is U.S.-based and is terrific. Second level customer service took a fair amount of time, but she was able to fix the problem right up once I got her, and she stayed on the phone with me until the Jitterbug was completely on the system.
*The keypad and the words are easily tactual--a bit sandpapery. This is NOT Braille--it is that the print can be felt. This is superb for low light or low vision.
*The call waiting, which seems to be NON-standard on this unit, is so easy--"yes" to switch and "no" to end. Frankly, this is the first time I've ever been able to use that feature with a phone.
*The "dock" (drop-in charger) is something I've never had with a phone, and it's a GREAT idea! The phone can be plugged in as well.
*It's NOT black or charcoal gray! It's silver, and it's SO much easier to find! A bright little blinkie even comes on on the front of the unit when there's a text or a call.

On the more negative side:
*There doesn't seem to be a way to add a battery indicator to an easily visible spot, and it's a good bit of a battery pig.
*I haven't found a simple way to add callers, texters, etc. to the address book, and I've really tried. I've only been able to do it directly--write the number on paper, then add it to the address book.
*It's taken some getting used to because it's not all that intuitive, at least to me.
*I didn't care for the built-in games.

Mixed:
*The phone is fairly big (6.6 inches by 2.4 inches) and is on the heavy side at 4.64 ounces. Size is both a plus and a minus--big screen is nice sometimes, but it's pretty big in a pocket. The weight easily pulls it out of my pocket, and I think I'll start using a small camera case to hold it. It just fits in one. It does seem to be able to handle a fall, though, and mine bounces once a week or so.
*The magnifier (uses the camera to show something on the screen) isn't all that useful, if you ask me.

So...I call this one most highly recommended, IF you're looking for a simpler phone. If you want a "smart" one, you won't be happy at all.

Trying to look at the phone was very difficult.
The company that sells the jitterbug phone (Great call) does not let stores like best buy open the phone box so you can see the phone. We had to buy the jitterbug phone just to look at the phone. The phone did not work for my friend. The flip phone has a smooth surface that was to hard to get a grip on. She could not open the flip phone. She returned the phone that day. But what a pain for an already handicapped person!

Only GreatCall phone service works with jitterbug phones
GreatCall makes jitterbug phones and controlls the phone plans. Unlimited talk and text is $49.99 per month plus admin fees. Then add in the special services and you have a big bill!

Activation was a pain. The Great Call support person said I should be in an area where there are at least three bars or the activation would be difficult. This forced me to leave my home, get in the car and park where there was a good signal (using a different person's cell phone) just to activate this one (which took several attempts by the way).

The charging cradle was sloppy. You had to play with the phone's position and tip toe away hoping it would stay in the "charging" mode (very frustrating).

When you wanted to use the phone, once flipped open the display sometimes would appear, sometimes not. Usually when the display would appear, there was a delay first. When you were lucky enough to get the menu to display, there was a noticeable delay from when you pressed the up/down button to when the item on the screen would change.

Powering it off/on, removing/replacing the battery and calling Great Call were of no help. The symptoms persisted.

I can't comment on battery life or call quality since I returned it to the local pharmacy store where I bought it out of frustration.

I should've known with the poor design of the charging cradle, more frustration with the phone was inevitable.

Months later I called Great Call asking if they worked the bugs out. They admitted there were some phones out there "with those issues" but they have corrected the problem. As of this review (April 4, 2017) I still see negative reviews out there for the same issues I experienced several months prior. Since my Jitterbug5 died and they no longer activate those models anymore, I'll wait for the Jitterbug Flip to be discontinued and will consider its replacement.

Since there seems to be lots of people who are happy with their Jitterbug Flip, the only advice I can offer is if you get the phone and don't have these symptoms, CONGRATULATIONS! If not, make sure you return it before your return period expires because it won't get any better.

I, for one, don't have the patience to keep buying/returning it until I find a "good one". Great Call should've recalled those they know to be defective, or at the very least offer a decent alternative which isn't a smart phone.

I bought this phone for my 85 year old grandmother, per her request. It has great features like big buttons and...A DIAL TONE! This is essential for our seasoned citizens, who are just getting used to having a little more access to technology. The interface is very easy to use overall, and you can navigate easily by using the large YES? and NO? buttons. Both times we contacted customer service, they were excellent and extremely helpful. We were even able to port her existing phone number over to the new device in about two days. She's a happy camper, and so am I!

I purchased this item for my self, I find that it works very well. I can call or receive calls and they are very clear. I got the flip phone as I do not need (or want) the smart phone, with all of it's features. I wanted it for basic communication, mostly on trips and do not require any of the other features on the smart phone. My phone will text, but I do not wish to ! I would recommend this phone to anyone who requires communication. This item is also available in a smart phone version, if that is what you need. I never had any trouble getting or receiving a signal and it was always crystal clear !

Seniors seem to fall into one of 2 categories...either they are pretty tech savvy and lean heavily on their smartphones and tablets to help them or they are extremely tech-phobic. This Jitterbug is obviously geared toward the latter group. It is cleverly designed with some features that make it easy for seniors to use for calls and a valid and surprisingly convenient "safety" device, too. Our experience of it is mixed as there are definite pros and cons.

Pros:
- Solid feel compared to the typical flip phones of yesteryear
- Large Font and bright, easy to read screen
- Large BACKLIT Keys on the Keypad
- Default Text Messages saved for easy sending
- Camera is decent for a flip phone!
- Red "5" button offers great service
- Games to stimulate brain (more available, too)

Cons
- Charging stand is AWFUL
- Yes/No commands are sometimes confusing
- Navigating the menus is not all easy or intuitive
- Volume is completely inadequate for anyone hard of hearing

Overall, it is a great simple phone for calls for seniors, especially if they do not have any hearing issues. If they do, a typical phone call may be difficult as the volume never got loud enough for the lady for whom I do caregiving. She didn't have the patience to try to stamp out text messages of her own design either, but she could use the static ones already saved in the phone. Since it is a flip phone with a standard numeric keypad, you need to press each key multiple times to get to certain letters or characters (remember when texting first came out?).

We have an 8 yr old who has medical issues and, between her tremors and lack of dexterity, she can't reliably use a touchscreen. She often has medical needs that arise when she is in bed and we thought we would give her this phone to try instead of having to communicate via the baby monitor (she shares a room and doesn't want to wake her sisters). She was able to easily update us on her needs through the old-school text method on the Jitterbug and she really grew to love it!

The menu system on the phone leaves much to be desired and, while it may have been clever to label the Send/End buttons as "Yes" and "No," the prompt questions don't always fit those responses, which created a lot of confusion for the lady I take care of. She has all of her faculties, but found the Jitterbug rather confusing, except for making or receiving calls and sending the stored messages. Our daughter, though, has less fear about pushing the wrong buttons, (a benefit of being 8) and although she thought the prompts were confusing, she didn't mind the trial and error method. The elderly lady, however (like many older people who are technophobes) was afraid she would destroy the phone with the press of a wrong button, so it was more challenging for her. She did really like the larger buttons and the crisp, easy to read numbers on the screen, though!

The 5 star button (center bottom of the phone) is a really cool feature, though everyone here agreed that it should say something else on it...because 5* doesn't mean anything to anyone except Great Call. It should say HELP or something like that, especially if a senior has any memory issues...they wouldn't know what the heck "5*" means. The 5 star service itself is awesome, though! If a senior falls or has a medical crisis and presses that button, they are instantly connected to the service team. Our experience with them was fantastic! They operate as a triage team of sorts. They can dispatch medical or police as needed, or simply notify a couple of pre-determined individuals on a contact list about whatever the situation may be. It can even be used to see if symptoms warrant immediate attention or not. For us, we could have our daughter keep this at school with her in case she has a seizure between classes or in the restroom and needs help. We could set it up so they could notify her school office and me, for example when she presses that button. If you press the 5* button and don't answer, they call the phone and you can leave specific directives with the team as to what to do if they don't get an answer. This customizable help feature is definitely the SHOW-stealer of this phone and is critical for vulnerable people, whether they live alone or not!

The serious downfall of this phone is the charging base. At first, we thought it was wonderful...you set the phone in it and it starts charging...which is what a senior citizen or someone with compromised dexterity (like our daughter) would need. Unfortunately, however, we found that MANY times, it actually wasn't charging! It would say it was...and we would go back a couple of hours later to get it and the battery would be completely dead. Soon we realized that it takes a delicate balancing act to get the phone to actually take a charge. The charging station has 2 little prongs in it (see the photos) and they have to essentially slip inside little openings on the phone. But much of the time, they don't stay there! The base itself is powered by a micro USB cable, which I appreciate, since it isn't a proprietary connection to the actual base itself. But, the phone needs to truly be easy to charge. Maybe it is just ours? With as innefective as our charger is, it would be nice to have the option of a traditional charging port, even though that requires dexterity.

Bought this for my 9 year old mother who is hard of hearing. Itâs hard for me to hear. We tried all ring tones & volume high. It cuts out a lot. Great Call is not great at all to work with. We no longer use it so there is no satisfaction to this red lemon. Would advise anyone it to purchase.

I had the previous jitterbug, it worked fine for years. Died. And I bought the Easy-to-Use brand-new from a friend who got it but had a stroke. This one simply does not work. Takes about 3 seconds for every command. Texting, it hangs on each letter. I called technical support, they have reprogrammed it. Still doesn't work. I took it to a cell phone tech and they confirmed everything that I have observed, he could not send a text on it. Now I am searching for some other phone that is elderly-friendly. I notice other comparable reviews.

I bought the jitterbug flip for my Grandmother 4 years ago and it still works like a charm. She is 96 years old and I asked her if she wanted me to purchase her an updated jitterbug. She said this one works just fine and she loves it. She sleeps with it under her pillow at night so she always has it close by. Of course she has hearing issues, she is 96 but she rarely has to ask me twice what I said during our conversations. My brother calls her every morning and I call her every afternoon for the last 4 years on the same jitterbug. Had an issue one time, customer service was great and it turned out that when I entered a phone number for her online I entered the wrong number. Thank so much to Great Call!! I will be calling soon to get a smart phone for myself!!

The Jitterbug flip phone is finally a phone my 88 yr old Dad can use with very few problems. The buttons are larger and easier to read and the text on the screen provides a larger font to see contacts in the address book. I can update, or add contact for him from home on my computer through the website. It has been a God send for our entire family but especially my Dad. I recommend this phone for anyone who is visually or hearing impaired or both. A wonderful asset and I'm so thankful I took him off my son's cell plan and signed up to Great Calls!!! I did purchase the Jitterbug at a Bestbuy as I wanted to talk to someone who knew something about them as opposed to ordering one online. I would now have no issues ordering one online now though.

Overall the phone has been good. My mother in-law likes the large buttons, the overall size, and finds the red color easy to find if she forgets were she put it. Outside of two issues, it works as well as any other phone our family has. The first issue is that the ringer will stop working about once a week. If the phone is restarted, the ringer comes back. Odd. I'm actually not positive she isn't doing something. The second issue is more concerning. Twice over the six moths she has had it, it locked up and we had to do a hard reset to get it working. If she was in trouble and it locked up, bad news. Thank said, she was having a lot of trouble using her other phone due to it's size and she refused to use a smart phone. Not getting daily calls because she messed her phone up has been a big stress relief.

I bought it for our 91 y/o mother in a nursing home. She was always complaining about the size of her previous cell phoneâs numbers so I though this would be a major improvement.

So far the phone has been a pain in the butt. The interface is relatively simple and straightforward and yet annoying to use. I use electronic devices on a regular basis and this phone has a number of counter intuitive features.

On a number of occasions the unit has gotten squirrely (functions didnât function, callers kept hanging up because they couldnât hear mom when she answered).

After calling Great Call and waiting on hold for 20 plus minutes (after ignoring the recorded advice to call back due to high call volume) it was more than a little annoying to discover the Great Call operator hung up because he couldnât hear me.

Desperate, I turned the phone off and then back on and it worked. When I told my brother, he told me heâd done the same thing to clear up a different quirk with the phone. So the question is, how often does the phone have to be turned on and off?

Speaking of Great Call operators, when my sister called to set up the service an annoying rep (obviously a saleswoman) wasted an inordinate amount of time agressively trying to upsell services mom didnât need and wouldnât use. Itâs absurd to have to argue, justify, and explain to a salesperson about basic service being more than enough just to initiate service.

A while back, when mom had trouble with her Medical Alert unit (from the same company) she let the phone rep know how annoyed she was. I was astonished to be notified the service was turned off. (If my name wasnât on the account it would have remained off indefinitely.)

When I called the company, a supervisor was honest enough to admit heâd listened to the phone conversation involving my mother and the rep. It turned out she she didnât request termination. What happened was the creep was so annoyed at mom, he retaliated by turning off her service.

The supervisor was very apologetic BUT I was shocked to think some thin skinned phone rep would be spiteful enough to risk my mother's life by turning off a device designed to save lives.

They changed the manufacturer from Samsung to Alcatel. Alcatel is below acceptable for this phone. I have a Alcatel smartphone and wish everyday I would have chose another brand. And there is not a holder that goes around the neck. If you try using any holder, it is usually to big to fit in the holder and the holder covers the ringer which muffles the ring and no senior including myself cannot hear the phone ring at maximum. So my mom is stuck holding the phone and constantly losing it. You would think there would be a place to hang a lanyard so a senior could wear it around their neck.

If all you need is a basic phone with reasonable minutes at a great price AND your area has Verizon service, you're set. If you text a great deal, get their smartphone. I don't, I just need a phone to make emergency calls and to have during power outages (frequent in my area). I also want on handy in case of road emergencies. I don't want to surf the net or text or play games, just call and for me it's PERFECT. I have high-speed internet at home so I'm set. Porting my number went quickly. I just periodically turned the phone on after speaking to my old and new carries and it was done in hours. Price is great and call clarity excellent.

My parents have resisted the smartphone, and even learning much about the cell phone. When my nearly 90 year old mother tried Great Call's Flip phone, she instantly appreciated that the earpiece and ringer sounds were louder and crisper. When I answered her call, I appreciated her clearer voice, made possible by Flipâs clearer microphone.

Flipâs speaker-phone is also loud and crisp, and its cameraâs lens doubles as a bright small flashlight and as a magnifying glass. A big red button to call for emergencies. Larger screen and phone buttons. Cell phones menus baffled my parents. Flip simplified this-- nearly all instructions are in large, plainly-written text, and need only simple yes or no responses. Very well designed for seniors.

Flip utilizes a phone-emergency-assistant service, which appears to be same as my prior reviewed Great Call's emergency telephony button, as seen here: https://www.amazon.com/review/R2E5UC1L37RSZG/ref=cm_cr_dp_cmt?ie=UTF8&ASIN=B00KCWEEPS&channel=detail-glance&nodeID=2335752011&store=wireless#wasThisHelpful . Lengthy URL! This button review, titled "Very good emergency resources management service, July 14, 2014" includes comparisons of competitive services. Notice also in the buttonâs review that the service has fail-safe features that correct errors seniors make with technology products. I believe Flip has comparable features.

I like Flip, and believe my parents will love this. About as much technology as my elderly parents can handle. Very well designedâsize of buttons, clarity and volume of speakers and microphone, very easy navigation, etc.

I have had this service for my dad for several years and am beyond thrilled with it. He lives in a small town and is in his upper 70s. He still works so he uses this phone throughout the day to converse with me, clients, his secretary, etc. Being in such a rural area I thought he might have trouble with his coverage, but that is rare. And he much prefers this phone to even his house phone. He has trouble hearing and wears hearing aids in both ears and says he can just hear best on this phone.

You can go in online and setup your contact list and enter your emergency contact numbers as well as pertinent medical information. This new phone unit is different than the older model in that the 5Star button is located directly on the front as a one button connection rather than having to dial it. Whenever I have had to use customer service, they have been very helpful and are also very careful. They are acutely aware of people trying to scam seniors so they manage well that fine line of being helpful but also protecting against fraud for their customers.

We really like that this is a no nonsense unit. The numbers are easy to dial and it is easy to answer. It directs you where you need to go for what you want to do on the phone, be it speakerphone or voicemail. The screen is easy to see and easy to read and having the flip phone makes carrying and using it simple and intuitive. You can even set up a specific ring for the contact who is calling. I will say I don't think the camera and the magnifier on here work that great, but that is not why we have this phone and they won't be used that often. They are adequate for our needs.

We had tried other carriers and their units - we have asked for the very best for hearing impaired and the easiest to use. None of those are as good as the Jitterbug. We actually kept our other for a while before completely going to the Jitterbug to make sure we chose that which we like best. The Jitterbug is the clear winner and I'm glad we have this updated model with the emergency button on the front - it gives us peace of mind.

It worked just the opposite from what I thought. Flip closed didn't turn it off. My $14 subscription ended up around $24 after taxes and stuff! This senior found it hard to understand. I am keeping my TracFone flip phone, it works and is much cheaper.

She was recently hospitalized and had difficulty using the cell phone she's had for years. So I ordered her a smart phone, disabled the WiFi and data, but she couldn't even swipe. I did my research and found Jitterbug and I can't emphasize enough how wonderful it is. You only pay for what you want -- in this case, just phone calls, no texts or voicemail because she can't work either of them. The phone is a great size when you open it. The color makes it easy to find it in her purse. The ring is adorable. The cell phone problem after she got out of the hospital was virtually a crisis. Problem solved. So glad I went with the Jitterbug. And the price is better on Amazon. Love love love.

We are in our 60's and hubby has gone without a phone since he retired 10 years ago. Was not interested in a phone since most of his career he carried two phones. A situation came up this pass summer and he had to drive across the desert in the middle of summer with no phone. I told him "that is it" you are getting a phone to help relieve the stress you put me under when you are out and about. So he received an early Christmas present and got a phone,. He does not want to tex, or have access to anything. Just to make calls and take a couple of pictures here and there. The flip phone does text but he is not interested in that - just make calls. I did a lot of research on phones since I am somewhat of a tech person and decided on this phone. Its great and everything he wanted......THANK GOD!!!!

I bought the Jitterbug for its 5Star button, but I am fed up seeing "charging critical" because it needs charging regularly (like every few days) and as I don't have any other use for the phone to remind me that it needs charging so often, I think the Jitterbug is a waste of money. In other words, the 5Star emergency button is only as good as the battery and I am going to ask for my money back.

I just discontinued service after 3 years. Reason: Had to call several times due to problems with phone. The customer service was not very good. Finally, the speaker would not work and I had to call several times on that. The check-in call was not reliable. Some days would not get check-in call or it was late. Then I found out that the check-in call really doesn't mean anything. I thought if they couldn't reach you, they would call 911 or your contacts. Not so!! The only time they will call your contacts is if you push the 5 Star button. If you faint or have a stroke, and cannot push the 5 Star button, you are out of luck. I have the old shell flip phone and I understand the new Jitterbug flip is hard to open.

Unfortunately we have had problem after problem with this phone. They rolled out a new phone without adequate testing, and the seniors who depend on having a working phone are the ones who pay. There is a software bug that causes the phone to remain off when you open it. They have a patch, but it doesn't always work. We have been through three phones, all with issues. They send a "warranty" replacement, which is just another phone with problems. Sometimes the phone remains on indefinitely when closing the phone.

Another issue is the outgoing sound. It can be extremely muffled, so the person using the Flip cannot be easily understood. The person must use their other hand to bring the phone closer to their mouth in order to be heard. Great Call is stuck with selling this awful phone, and they will continue to claim it's "new" and they're still working out the issues. It's a shame we've spent so much time just trying to get a working phone.

My husband is 72 and has a significant hearing loss as well as challenges with technology. He had 2 other flip phones which he couldn't hear ring and eventually lost. He has done well with the Jitterbug. He can hear it ring, hear the speaker, understand the directions on how to use it, and has managed to keep track of it. My only complaint was in activating the phone. The directions said to "Press the on/off button" to turn it on. Nothing was happening when I did that. I finally figured out that I needed to "Press and HOLD the on/off button" to get the phone to initially turn on. Hopefully Jitterbug will fix this wording issue.

Bought several of these for my 90+ YO mother. We have had 4 Jitterbugs in last 2 years. They are not designed for the elderly!!! Volume very low on highest setting in the ear piece. Hard to work buttons. Too complicated for elderly to figure out. Horrible option. She cannot hear it ring on loudest setting. Stops working after a few months hence 4 different non working phones...Not under warranty.

Donât waste your money. My wife bought this phone and immediately returned it after her first bill from Great Call. Cheaply made and Great Call ainât so great either. Had to pay a restocking fee to Great Call even though it was purchased from Amazon.

My mom's previous Jitterbug was starting to lose battery longevity, so I decided to take advantage of Great Call's offer for a free upgrade to this latest model. Right from the get-go, it has had very disappointing battery life. Despite my mom living just outside Baltimore and having a "strong" signal, it won't hold a charge for 24hrs even if it isn't used. Not sure why this is happening, but I'm frustrated and will be reaching out to Great Call to see if they have any answers. We've had very good luck with the previous phone and customer service in the past.

The phone is ok. My mother in law had a hard time using it though.
But the real problem is getting yourself out of the contract. You have to call them and I am now on about 40 minutes on hold. They try to make it so hard to get out you'll forget about it.
There is apparently nowhere on the website to cancel service. They make you go through the phone lines.
Creepy. Like dealing leeches that won't let go.
Finally after many years and many phones, we found a phone my 81 y/o mom can and enthusiastically uses. She only does the basics, so this phone is perfect for her. The customer support is great.

Have had phone for several months without a glitch. Suddenly, I was unable to either forward or receive photos . The screen shows "photo successfully sent'" but it never arrives to its destination, just vanishes. I attempted sending one to my own number and it shows on the screen that "you have a new TEXT message". Contacted customer service, was on the phone for close to an hour with unsuccessful attempts at rebooting, software updates and finally a puzzled rep telling me that it may be the phone. No kidding. So I'm stuck with a piece of garbage that can send and receive texts but is incapable of handling photos. Save your money, your blood pressure will thank you.

Would not do business with GreatCalls. Flooded my cell phone with repeated telemarketing calls from call center. ,12 in a single afternoon. I called them back demanding they stop calling me. Person said they couldn't remove my number from call list. Transfered me. Next person said they couldn't do it but would get supervisor. Same person came back,said they had a number for me to call to get my number off the list.. I said they needed to remove my number, not me and where is your supervisor? Put me on hold a long time. Same person came back, said supervisor only takes calls from customers.. Gave me a number saying, again, I had to call it to have my number removed. Number they gave me is Federal No Call list. My phone has been registered on it since the beginning and registration regularly updated. GreatCalls is flagrantly breaking the law.

Cheap cell phone plans through Great Call which is what my mom needed. About $15 a month for 200 minutes or so. So That's awesome. Has a cool little stand charger that my mom found easier then the plug. That was good.
My mom had trouble with the phone but she has dementia so might not be the norm.
Bad thing about phone for her was when she missed a call in would give her an audible notification every 5 minutes which she didnt understand how to make it stop. There is no way to turn that audible notification off so that sucks.
Then... Phone just stopped working after about 3 weeks to a month. Don't understand why just doesn't work any longer. So I will need to contact them to get a new one.

This phone is easy to use and perfect for seniors with it's large keypad and loud speaker. It's an entry level phone that's difficult to text on and doesn't connect to the internet. It comes with a few games loaded but they're kind of cheesy. There are lots of services available with this phone - for instance, you can have someone call to remind you to take your medicine - but they all come with a price and adding all of those extra features would be expensive.

I did have some questions at set up and called customer service. They were very friendly but couldn't help me. They promised to have a supervisor call back between 3 and 4 that day but they never did. I emailed the next day and was able to get the issue resolved.

Bought it for my 98-year-old mother on recommendation of an assisted living center. Operation is not at all transparent: very confusing. What's more, during the time my mother was trying to use it there was a usage/transmission problem which the company would acknowledge IF you asked the question "why isn't my phone working?" We thought it was our mother's cognitive problem so didn't report it - and when we discontinued service with Great Call they gave us no credit for that period. By the way, Great Call seems to be the service provider - and it is WAY too expensive for basic service. Their rationale for high service cost is the medical alerts included - but it a person is in a facility already it has its own medical alert system. STAY AWAY FROM THIS PRODUCT! My sister can't even figure it out, and she's pretty young!

Bought the new Jitterbug Flip Phone for my sister three weeks ago, with the Text and Talk only plan, but she doesn't use Text. So far, we're both very pleased with her new phone, because it's so SIMPLE and EASY to use. My sister's older Jitterbug version and plan only provided 50 minutes a month (for $19.95), but she likes the phone so much, she has begun using her Jitterbug exclusively, so it seemed fun to upgrade her to the new RED flip phone and a plan that provides 600 monthly minutes for about the same cost as the old plan.

I don't even want to give it one star. First, if you're typing a text and get a phone call or another text it wipes the text you were working on. Second, after several months we noticed the clock on the phone was an hour off. After several calls it still isn't right. Also, after some updates the microphone on the phone stopped working intermittently and sometimes would work if you rebooted the phone. But this really concerned me when we tried to call 911 for an auto accident (not us, thank God) and the dispatcher couldn't hear us. If this was an emergency we could have been in real trouble. I will say their help desk people are real friendly and as helpful as they can be, but if they can't fix their problems then I'll find another phone, which is what I did.

I really like my Jitterbug Flip phone as it is easy to use, I am able to store numbers I call often in the phone book. It also includes 5-Star , the emergency program that I used to have in separate item before & then I also had a cell phone so I had 2 items that I had to carry. I keep it charged in the desktop charger that came with it. Mine is silver colored and flip also comes in red. I can accept text messages on the flip, this I can't do on my land line so I am very happy that I invested in the flip ;last Sept.2017.

Terrible experience. Got this product for my husband. One hardware problem after another. Phone had to be replaced, then the charging cradle was defective, multiple service calls. Finally just cancelled the contract and tossed the phone and charger after a last maddening conversation with a tech specialist. Got an ATT flip phone for my husband and everything works just fine. Jitterbug Great Call seems like a scam for seniors. I use an iPhone.

Not dependable for the elderly. When a software upgrade is required the phone shuts down and requires a removal of the battery then reinstall then turn back on procedure to reactivate service. Over the past year I have had to go to my moms house and perform this operation 4 times because the phone was deactivated.

Great phone for my aging mother. Big buttons and screen is fairly large. Simple menu and Yes/No buttons make it easy for her to use. I love that I am able to manage her account online, including her Phone Book so I can add contacts for her at any time. We're not using the 5 star button feature yet, but I'm glad to have that option available and will likely be adding that service in the near future. I love that you can decide which services you need and only pay for what you need. There's nothing else out there for senior cell phones -- I've looked! Jitterbug / GreatCall is awesome.

It's like having your own body guard ! It helps to know there is a trained agent to speak with 24-7 should you need help ! My phone helps me to feel secure and safe and the best thing that, I ever did for myself !!! I highly recommend this great call cell phone ! I can talk anywhere and never loose communication unlike other cell l phones! and this is a great feature that anyone should be looking at when purchasing a cell phone !! As an older person, I wouldn't think twice about buying it again !!!!

This Jitterbug Flip Easy-to-Use Cell Phone for Seniors is a practical solution for those that don't want or need the advanced features found on most modern cell phones.

The phone comes with a charger and was very easy to set up and get working. We really did not want the games or other built in apps and are only using this for phone calls. The buttons are large and most screen prompts use the "Yes" or "No" buttons for selection. I like that "Dial Tone" can be heard when the phone is flipped open since this is a sound most Seniors are very comfortable hearing and know what to do when it starts.

We have fairly good coverage in our area and the phone conversations are decent quality on both ends of the call, but I suspect results will vary based on physical location.

Highly Recommended!

CFH

The Jitterbug Flip is super comfortable to use. The large, well-labelled keys, and yes/no prompts make it a breeze to adapt to. The 5Star function provides priceless peace of mind for me. It means a lot to know I just have to press a button and help is at hand. Also found the magnifier and super bright flashlight very handy. I love the attractive design and shape.Even a 20-something co-worker admired the way it looked. Wherever I go, the Jitterbug makes my life easier.

I'm happy with the Text and Talk functions but not the camera. I have not been able to get my photos out of the camera using a USB Cable, nor have I been able to register my Facebook account at GreatCall.com to send photos to Facebook, as they promised. I did send a photo to a friend's smart phone who emailed it to my email account and I was able to retrieve the photo on my computer that way. It's a very low resolution camera and the photo was very grainy.

Very good phone for seniors & others who may have vision problems or other disabilities.
I wish this was available when my mom was alive because it would have been so easy for her.
It's very simple to use and figure out even without the instruction book.

I set mine up in the bedroom, very easy, my only negative is that the picture in the instruction book does not show which way to set the phone in the cradle & I can see some people being confused by that but it's easy to figure out.

My favorite thing about the phone is the ease of overall use. It has simple yes/no buttons, you really don't have to remember any commands. Easy to take & send pictures as well.It's much simpler than other phones I have used.

It also has a one touch emergency button that I think is also very good for seniors & others.

The only drawback I see is that it's a bit too simple for me as I like to text & I don't see any way to use any punctuation or emoji, but again texting is simple to do even in places where it is hard to see.

Tried this service with this flip phone. Stopped working the first week.
Had to stay on the line with company for hours troubleshooting the problem, before they
Finally agreed to take the phone back. Next phone lasted about three weeks. Again had to troubleshoot the problem for several hours. Sent phone back. Third phone lasted about 6 weeks. My advice......donât buy this flip phone. They are all defective.
The amount of time spent âtroubleshootingâ was ridiculous. Waste of my time.

1. I did NOT order from Amazon - I ordered directly from GreatCall after a horrendous experience with Consumer Cellular.
2. This is an EXCELLENT basic flip phone for those seeking a simple phone or not wanting a smartphone.
3. I purchased this phone for a senior relative who began having challenges with her basic touchscreen smartphone.
4. The phone covers all the basics with built in flashlight, 2 megapixel camera, speakerphone, easy to read menus and address book. It also has Bluetooth, but I haven't used that feature.
5. Reception, call clarity and speaker phone are fantastic.
6. Customer service is AMAZING. Very helpful, understanding AND in the U.S.
7. I absolutely LOVE that I could create an online account and manage the address book online. Makes it so much easier than the other person having to program phone numbers.

I traded a smaller 5 year old Jitterbug for the newer, larger Jitterbug mainly for my husband, who has hearing aids in both ears. He was having trouble hearing calls from our children and grandchildren. The new Jitterbug has improved his hearing their message, but it still isn't perfect. Several relatives have come to check on us because they had called and we hadn't answered. When we checked the incoming messages, theirs were not recorded. So we may be missing some calls. All together I think the new Jitterbug is probably an improvement, but I am thankful we didn't pay an enormous charge to make the change from a 5 year old one.

I`ve been using Jitterbug phones now for several years and am very pleased with the phones and the service when I have had a problem.What problems I have had were taken care of by customer service who in my experience have been very friendly and willing to help.I used the Jitterbug plus for several years and just recently went to the Jitterbug flip which I am loving so far.These phones work well for me as I like the ease of them as they are not complicated.They have everything I need and not a bunch of things I don`t.The plans are very reasonable in cost and you can have what you want on your phone.My brother got me my first Jitterbug a few years ago as he is the older one but did not want to carry a cell phone so I got one so we would have a phone with us to call if we needed help of some kind.As I said I just recently got my Jitterbug flip and am very happy with it so far.The only thingthat I can say otherwise is that the company made a small mistake when they mailed me my phone as I had actually ordered a red one but got a gray one instead.This is okay as I `m not worried about color just a phone that works and gives good service.I`ve gotten that from the Jitterbug.

After paying for the phone and various fees it was considerably higher than quoted. Then after dropping to the most basic of the plans I calculated I was paying over $250 annually for a phone hardly ever used! I am calling to cancel the service today when their Pacific time office opens!

I purchased this phone for my 89 year old father who recently moved into assisted living. He has never used a cell phone before (despite my getting him one many years ago) because he's technology phobic and insists he can't figure them out. This phone is very simple to use and while he still struggles with remembering how to use it, he often can figure it out without too much difficulty. It's loud, which is good since he's hard of hearing, and the numbers are big. You flip it open to answer it and close it to end a call. The Yes and No buttons are used to place calls to numbers already in the phone book. Using the phone book may be the biggest challenge because of needing to remember to scroll through it to find the number you want to call. For someone not use to using a directory of this sort, it's hard to remember to do that.

One thing that makes this phone different from others is the âyesâ or ânoâ feature. For example if you want to take a picture......while scrolling down the menu, when the word âcameraâ is highlighted, you push the âyesâ button, and the camera feature appears, ready for picture taking. If you push ânoâ, the phone scrolls down to the next feature. If you donât want to use the yes/no feature, you can use the arrow keys to scroll, then push âyesâ to select the desired item.
All number buttons, as well as the menu items are large and easy to read. Also the speaker volume and ring tone can be adjusted very loud.
The 5 Star feature is the most unique and important feature. Just push the red button and an operator will answer to help in any situation. This eliminates the need to wear a call button around your neck. Some people find a neck button awkward, and this combines 2 services into one, with only 1 bill to pay.
Finally, the red cover is beautiful and easy to find, and the size of the phone is perfect!

Jitterbug has made life easier for my husband. The phone is thicker than AT&T flip phone and fits better in his larger hands. The buttons are large enough that he does not hit two or more buttons at a time. The emergency red button make me know that he can receive help when I am not right at his side. I had a jitterbug phone for my Mom. There was no question about getting one for my husband as he has aged. The red color makes it easy for him to find.

BUYER BEWARE!!! this phone's carrier does not work in all areas. I was going to buy it for my 91 year old dad and found out that is does not work in my zip code. Make sure you check your area before buying this.

It doesn't hold it's charge... I have to keep it off to hold a charge for any length of time. It grunts when it wants charged, and I use it only for calling my husband. They say they have plans for as little as $14.99, but I haven't seen that low price since I bought this phone some years ago... now I pay $26 for it and I use it about five times a week. I left it on by accident today, and when it grunted that it was critical battery, it was HOT! I'm going to get a trac phone... paying $26 a month for about 20 calls is ridiculous! And don't fall for the big numbers and good screen... the flip is so small, nothing is is BIG! Do I sound angry... I am, because I only want a flip phone for emergencies and short calls, and it is costing me $26 for that.

I LOVE this phone. So easy to use. I have had other phones with so much on them that was useless to me. and the service was more expensive. This is exactly what I was looking for. I can call, text, take pictures, send and receive pictures and get phone messages. I don't need anything else! I can also get games, but don't want to. The price for the service is great. The only thing I was unaware of was that I would have to pay 10 cents to send or receive pictures; however the service is cheap enough that I don't mind - don't use it that much anyway. Love the *5 button.

The Jitterbug flip phone may make younger folks laugh, but who cares. This cell phone is all I need and it always works. I bought one for my wife and me primarily to take with us when we're driving around town taking care of business and running errands. We're not one of these people who has a cell phone constantly glued to one ear, nor do we text all day or while we're driving. This Jitterbug phone is great for calling someone for assistance or just checking in with my wife when I'm out and about running around town. It has a telephone directory to call people I need, a camera, and the ability to text. One great feature is the extended battery life. I've had the battery registering 32%, and the phone functioned as well as it did when it was charged at 97%. Finally, the customer service at Great Call is simply outstanding. Regardless of the situation, no customer service rep at Great Call makes you feel stupid for asking for help with a techno question or problem. They walk you through the issue while providing instructional information how they will correct the problem. It's a great product.

Ringtone is too low even at maximum volume. Call quality is terrible; static. Calls drop constantly; I had to call back my dad 3 times during a 5 minute call. When someone calls, sometimes it rings, sometimes it doesn't. We've only had this phone for 2 weeks. Frankly, I think we got a defective phone.

Bought it for my 88 year old father who has macular degeneration and is hard of hearing. The numbers on the key pad and screen are easy to see. The menu is easy to navigate. Volume, sound quality and flashlight are good. Magnifier isn't the greatest. He doesn't have the 5Star service but we like that it can be added on if needed. And no contract is nice. All in all, it's easier for him to use than his last basic phone and he's happy with it.

I have a cell phone primarily for possible emergency situations and don't use it often. Simplicity of use is very important to me. The Jitterbug has all the features I need. The screen contains simple instructions on use, and those instructions are available every time I use it. In fact I use it a little more because I don't have refer to a users manual every time I want to make a call. I'm very pleased with this purchase.

Bought this phone for my 87 year old Mom and she loves it. It is easy to use and has nice large buttons. The customer support at GreatCall was awesome and walked me through setting up the phone and features. When Mom accidently pushed the 5* alert button, the operator was very kind, understanding and reassured her that they would always be there for her if she needed them. Great product and customer service!!
I bought it for outdoor furniture cover, followed directions and didn't hold, could be the type of material.I was trying to fix. NOT sure

I got the Jitterbug Flip for my elderly mother after a fiasco with a Samsung Smart phone. It has been an absolute GODSEND. Unbelievably easy to set up and use; it's as if senior citizens got together to design a phone and input all the things they want/need. I input all first & last names of contacts and then initiated voice-dialing for my mother. The Flip phone voce had difficulty recognizing the last names of contacts so I deleted all last names (online). Problem solved! Not having to remember a password for voice-mail? Brilliant! Ease of taking pictures and looking at the photo album? Simple! Every operator we've talked to has been extremely easy to talk to and seems to know to explain things in non-techno-speak and one or two syllable words.

Complaints? Mom doesn't like that the 'On/Off' switch is right above the 'NO' button and wishes the volume rocker-button was not on the side of the phone. When a senior answers the (Flip) phone, they grab it tightly and can sometimes press the rocker which can turn the volume all the way down. She would also like something like a lanyard to hang it around her neck. I got her a passport cross-body pouch and that solved the problem.

Bought this for my 81 year old Mother who is visually impaired & has been struggling with standard phones for a while. When she saw this phone she was so happy that everything was big & bold & she could see what she was doing. She doesn't really need to use it much but she wants it with her for that comfort feeling. She has the 5Star option too so it makes me feel happy that help is not far away if she needs it.
Definitely would recommend for the elderly.

I read somewhere that you can stick a pin into the power outlet. It works. After getting text messages that I am not signed up for and the phone beeping over and over and over again which woke me up, I started looking online for answers. I found a pin and inserted it into the power plug in of the phone. I moved the pin back and forth and finally I was able to turn it off.

My father purchased this from Greatcall. As a phone it is ok. But I thought it would be fun for my father to stay in touch with grandchildren via text. We started looking at it. The texting system is Ancient! I mean back in the 1990s. There are so many steps in the Jitterbug texting when it should be straight forward. Why has the texting system not been brought up to date? Yes many older folks arenât interested but at least make it easily accessible to those that would like to!

I bought this phone for my Dad for the ease of use. He really loved it -until 4 months later it literally fried on the inside while it was charging. This left my elderly father without a phone for over a week while getting a replacement. I was worried. He lives alone -in the boonies. I bought him the phone for safety reasons and not only did the thing get super hot and melt inside - but my elderly Dad was without a phone for a few days! " GreatCall"'s customer service acknowledged the overheating/melting problem and said they'd since corrected it and the newer models were fixed. Not true. The exact same thing happened again to his replacement phone. My Dad gave up and got an Iphone. I cancelled "GreatCall" and they did NOT refund my money for the phone - even though it was a manufacturing defect and even though the warranty was renewed with the replacement phone.
Bottom line: If you want to keep your seniors safe - Do NOT get them the Jitterbug Flip. Not only is it a potential fire hazard - but it could leave your loved one without a phone for a while.

My husband and I are 70 years old and never had a cell phone before. Due to a health problem, I needed one for him. He knows zilch about technology, and I have bad eyesight. The Jitterbug is the best phone out there for folks like us - simple, easy to use, large buttons and large DARK print. It works for what we want it to do, and at a much better price than most other companies.

I purchased this for my elderly mother who wears hearing aids and has a difficult time seeing small print. She needed something very easy and this was it. She loves the large buttons and easy YES - NO questions. The only thing I dont like is that you get a dial tone every time you open it. My mom took her first ever picture with a cell phone today, it's that easy! I'm happy with the purchase.

I was given a prepaid c ell phone that could do everthing this thing could for severasl hundred dollars less.I don't feel safe walking to my car?????? REALLY....I am lost??/ This phone service is ridiculous and having a phone that is more durable less expensice by many hundreds of dollars is simply better,unless you're completely over come by alzheimers in which case you shouldn't be friving or walking alone anyway.

My husband has Alzheimer Disease and is in a Memory Care facility. I have the phone set up so all he has to do is flip it open, press 'yes', and it will automatically call me. We talk twice a day and it give him a feeling of security to know that he can reach me. I love having the date and time displayed and highlighted on the phone when it is shut and in its stand. He can then cross off the date on the monthly calendar of events as the day ends so he always knows what activities to take part in the next day. One bit of advice: I bought the phone at Best Buy and paid 90% more than if I had ordered the phone from Amazon. It is a perfect phone for someone with Dementia.

The Jitterbug Flip phone is extremely easy to use right out of the box. The screen is easy to read, the functions menu is easy to navigate. There is a one-touch button called 5Star that connects to agents who can help you if you have an emergency. I have traveled with this phone and it has worked great in every state I traveled to. The phone receives texts well, you can reply quickly using standard phrases that are stored in the phone's memory, or use the keypad to send a specific text. Overall I would recommend this phone for someone who does not
find texting important, but just primarily needs a phone for making phone calls.

Got this for my 95 year old mother, she loves it. Smart phones were too complicated and regular flip phones were too small. She likes the sound quality, the large buttons and the easy navigation. I like the excellent customer service and the price is very reasonable. I also like that it's on the Verizon network.

I bought this for my now 91 yr. old Father for his BDay in 2015? It needs to be rebooted DAILY, which he CANNOT understand. The location feature works...80% of the time, which is nice, except for the other 20%.
The hardware/phone itself CANNOT be locked on full volume, you CANNOT BLOCK ANY NUMBERS...
For the price, I would NOT recommend. I am buying a LARGE BUTTON cell phone, that he can operate, and hear. Maybe the other models are better? But the Jitterbug Flip/Red one, leaves a LOT to be desired!

Jitterbug is a perfect name, as we all did that in our time, lol. I DO NOT text, so it's perfect for my arthritic fingers. It has a library with a few phrases for you to send those pesky texters who insist on texting to us. All you do is hit the button for the phrase you choose, and away your message goes. Letters are big. Buttons are big. Volume is great. I LOVE IT!

Called the number from the Ad in the AARP magazine. They explained everything and in three days (no xtra charges) got my phone, all set up and even with my top 4 phone numbers input. I love the large buttons, the simple yes/no choices. I like everything about it and about saving $20 a month on my cell phone bill.

Bought this for my wife after trying several other brands with many bells and whistles, she is not tech savy at all ,this one she can use. That what this is ====a phone, you want bell and whistles===look elsewhere but with the extras available== it can't be beat

I have not bought this phone but I have done days of research and want to share what I've learned. I am blown away at all the negative reviews for every single aspect of this phone and Great Call. While overall it gets better reviews than other senior-targeted options, I am actually discouraged that this company has more hidden fees than any of the others. A fee to send a photo, a fee to setup ($35) when you are doing them a favor by adding to their revenue. While they claim they target seniors they obviously do not consider seniors on a fixed income, again catering to those who have higher income and can easily afford all the costs associated with this phone and a plan that gets as many negative reviews for customer service, etc and the cheapest other options. If I'm going to pay $150 for the newest model I want much higher consistency in quality of the phone as well as customer service. Go to several other web sites and research for yourself before considering the highest priced senior targeted phone and service out there.

Be careful, elderly people can easily be mislead by the large $14.99 price advertised on the box. There are also connection fees only listed in tiny print on the bottom of the box. The customer service is variable so please know your total fees plus taxes before you buy! Very unhappy with the way this is presented to Seniors.

I tried several other phones and the jitterbug is by far the easiest phone there is for someone who has poor eyesight and just wants the basics to communicate. I am finally happy and feel safe when i leave my home that I am able to use this phone with no issues. I am tempted to try the smartphone but maybe I should just leave well enough alone.

We've had this phone for about 3 months now and love it. It was easy to activate and is so easy to use. The ability to set up your directory on-line is a big plus. Love the big numbers the intuitive yes/no method of finding the function you want. We live in Florida where it is easy to find service everywhere and we just returned from a trip to the west coast where it worked flawlessly. The only reason I didn't rate 5-stars is that it takes an exceptionally long time to boot up when first turned on.

For 30 years I had two telephones on my office desk at Oxford University. When I retired I vowed to forsake telephones altogether, but discovered I did need to be able to phone out (plumber, electrician, emergency services, etc.) even if I did not want incoming calls. My main line of communications is e-mail - not telephone. But I am impressed by my Jitterbug Flip, which sounds like a drink one might order in a bar, but is an entirely user-friendly device which I am happy to have.

I really like my Jitterbug Flip Phone. I don't need to take care of the world with a phone and the Jitterbug fills my needs perfectly. Easy to use, easy to see the screen. However, I would like it better if the names in the address book would automatically come up alphabetically.

The Jitterbug Flip Phone is the perfect cell phone for me. I am not technical and am "scared to death" of Smartphones. This phone does what I need it to do -- it is easy to use to make calls when I am out of the house or out of town. I love the large number buttons, which make it simple to make phone calls. My only complaint so far is that my saved phone numbers are not in alphabetical order, but that does me no great harm. I hope we never need the special emergency service, but it's good to know that's also there.

The first thing to know about the Jitterbug mobile phone is that it is a two-in-one device,
namely the marriage of a mobile phone with a medical alert system. This phone kills two birds with one stone and makes the "I've fallen and can't get up" beeper worn around the neck unnecessary. Press the red 5-Star button and an emergency operator will respond. A notable health and safety feature is the ability to message the smart phones of family and friends if there is no response to a programed daily check-in call. Other cool features are 24/7 access to doctors and nurses and daily reminders to take medications.

This phone was built for the elderly. Large fonts and intuitive navigation make the phone easy to use. The built-in magnification and light feature comes in handy.

In my home the phone's signal strength was reported as Poor. However, there was no
problem hearing and being heard. The signal strength went from poor to fair to good as I walked a few yards from my home.

The phone charged to 98% with a few hours. Three days later with minimal use the charge was at 61%, estimating a charge could last approximately one week with limited usage. I cannot at this time report how long the charge would last with greater use.

The only problem incurred was the charging stand did not work. For me, not an issue since I prefer plugging the cord directly into the phone.

In summary, anyone looking for a simple, easy to use mobile phone with the added benefits of medical alert system the Jitterbug fills the bill quite well.

Locked down to Great Cell with no way of using a different SIM. The 3G version of this phone was great and wasn't locked like this. I had high hopes for this new version, 4g LTE etc.. But now I will have to return it. Also, this phone really isn't that intuitive for seniors -- ie, it has a 'Yes' and 'No' button rather than hangup and dial buttons -- that's not intuitive.

My 'Jitterbug' cell phone is a 'Great Gift' to my life; at 86 years of age, I have Hearing Loss and Texting makes sure I did NOT hear correctly on my Land Line. Also I have the Joy of taking Photos, with my Camera INSIDE my little phone, I can Add and Delete Ph. #s, Text and , Voice messages. AND I KEEP MY CELL WITH ME ALL THE TIME FOR GOOD REASONS AND ONE OF THE BEST IS MY RED 5 * ...I appreciate the large letters and all the conveniences for Vision inconveniences ! WITH GREAT JOY, I SAY "THANK YOU FROM MY HEART' GREAT CALL ! "
Sally Nave, Mesa, AZ

My stepdad loves flip-phones because he can drop it in his pocket. When my Mom passed away, every time I was around him he told me how much he hated the flip-phone he had. He claimed it was too hard to see the tiny buttons and he couldn't hear it ring and that it was even difficult to talk on. My sister was constantly having to "fix" his phone for him. I got him a Jitterbug Flip-Phone and he loves it! All he wants it for is making and receiving phone calls. It's perfect for him.

Purchased this last month for a family member with vision and mobility issues. He is quite pleased with its ease of use, as well as the peace of mind it provides. Prior experiences with power failures and loss of land-line service were distressing. These problems are now a thing of the past. Very satisfied with our purchase.

I'm pleased with the technical performance of the phone. If you buy it directly from Great Calls AND have it pre-activated you should be OK. Administrative performance is less certain. We had ordered a flip phone and a Smart Phone at the same time. When we went to set up owner accounts confusion prevailed as to which account belonged to which phone. This took a while to iron out but was ultimately resolved., The owner's manual is clear and comprehensive and the rates pleasant compared with the competition

My 91-year old father struggles with his Android for the duration of the contract. Hard to read texts even harder to get to the texts! Kept saying it was smarter than him but the real reason is because it was difficult to handle with his 91-year old hands. As soon as the contract ended I got him the Jitterbug Flip based on the glowing reports I got from a friend with MS. Easy to use, easy to navigate and best of all easy to see! Ordering from Great Call was the second best thing. Their customer service is awesome and porting over the old cell number to his Jitterbug was easy. No need for him to figure out who to contact to tell them to update their phone lists! Best phone & service for someone like my dad!

I had trouble with the complexities of my smart phone. The Jitterbug does everything I need to do, and it is so easy to understand and to use. The numbers and letters are large, it's so simple to scroll up or down and to simply indicate yes or no for a function. Calling and answering a call couldn't be easier, and that's all I really need it for, but it also has a camera, which is a bonus as far as I am concerned. I love it.

My MIL loves this phone, although we had a little trouble setting it up to work with service. The big numbers are just what her tired eyes need. Heck, I could use some big numbers on my phone and I'm not anywhere near as old as she is! For a phone for elders with the few critical features they need, this is perfect.

I love my new flip phone. It is so simple and easy to use. I only pay for what I want, no contracts. The volume is great. I can't here the phone well. I like the size, fits well in my pocket or purse. I down graded from an iPhone. The iPhone was too big and my plan was very expensive. I didn't need most of the stuff on it. Jitter bug was a great buy, I recommend it.

This new phone is very easy to use. Being 75 now and having MS, my gate is on the losing side. After falling several time and stumbling a lot these days, my wife feels confident that as I am out by myself I have something to rely on. I was never one to carry my former cell, which was very good, but easily going off as I bumped into things. Hence, just very disturbing to the point of not wanting to take the phone with me. Now, with the Jitterbug flip, all those former distractions are now gone.

There is no phone that will solve all the Senior problems, but this is MUCH better than the LG Flip phone thru the local phone company.
One request: Lanyard hook, so could be a necklace.
Support excellent. I think USA, as no accent.
This is a CDMA phone, so is on Verizon, so good coverage.

Bought one in April 2018. Now in July it no longer can send photos to Facebook. The help people said it is a software problem in all of the Flips now. They said to send my pictures to my email address but I can't find any info on how where the @ icon is or how to switch back and forth from numbers to letters to put my email in my phone book. As a phone it is okay. Another thing is that when I bought it they didn't tell me they were at the end of their billing period so I got 2 bills with in days of each other.
I think I will look for another brand that takes pictures.

WARNING! DONT BUY A PHONE FROM THIS COMPANY!!!! VERY CHEAPLY MADE!! Worst phone and service! After a couple of weeks the buttons were not working well, and the battery was not charging well. After it got worse, I called the company and just missed the 30 day return policy. However, they did send a new phone after much complaining. After a month or so this new phone has the same problems. Bad sound, buttons dont work, and doesnt charge well. I am just going to throw it away and eat the money.

Used by my 93 year old father.
Love it. He has it connected with Great star, He fell and was able to call for help. They GPS'd him, found him and got him the help he needed

Answering a call is as easy as opening the phone and disconnecting is just as easy, close the phone. My father doesn't text and if that were important, I would not purchase this phone. Does not have reminders from phone but you can call Greatcall and set up what you need. Otherwise, phone is great.

Great easy to use phone. Keys are easy to read and the 5 star feature is good knowing that help is just a button push away. Setup was easy even to someone not familiar with cell phones. Loved the magnifying feature!

Big numbers are good. Phone: Heavy. Clunky. Game feature worthless. Camera quality marginal. Magnifier of limited value.
Verizon has dead-spot in my area. That Jitterbug is on Verizon Network should have been clearly stated. Vibrate or Ring Tones cannot be used simultaneously.Volume button on side phone is easy to hit inadvertently. Wish I had purchased earlier, simpler Jitterbug.

I have no dislikes at all. I am 69 yrs old for someone like me it has just what i need for my lifestyle, no bells or whistles but just good reliability, loudness, big numbers,easy to use, small size flip phone, it has been the best phone i have had and i have had several.

I bought this Jitterbug after looking at other simple flip phones because I thought that it was the best for me.I had a smart phone for over 3 years and didn't use it enough to warrant the cost.This phone is just what I need so my family can get a hold of me when needed and I can get in touch with medical help when I need it ( the red button ) since I am having some heart problems.
