I feel much safer since I got this phone and carry it with me all the time. I have already talked to other people my age who are also interested in this phone and recomended it to them.
Sometimes it works, often not. Not a very reliable phone for elders who live alone. Bought two and neither is dependable. Don't throw away your money.

I like that it is only a cell phone and not a smart phone with all the apps. It is light weight, which I like not heavy like a smart phone is. I use it when I go out, so that my husband can call me, if he thinks of something else for me to buy.

Efficient easy to read phone design is overshadowed by its delayed response when pressing keys. The delay is so great the product is being returned and the Great Call Network will be replaced because it is not such a great network for calls.

I bought this phone for my elderly father in law. He could no longer hear with his other cell phone. I ordered this from Greatcall. They were easy to deal with and friendly. The phone works fine and he likes it. He can hear his phone calls again.

Great customer service and the phone works well for elderly technophobes. Offers many optional services that seem like they will be useful in the future as my parents get older and become less independent.

Horrible phone, not good for seniors especially! Not very loud at all, ringer or speaker for phone use. Not user friendly at all. Don't waste your money, a normal cell phone is easier. The only pro is bigger icons on the screen, which you can switch to on a regular cell phone, so not really a pro.

This phone has all the essential features for people who want and need the basics. There instructions are easy to understand. It is easy to navigate through the screens and locate the features that you want or need at the moment. Also, there are many options for plan choice and additional services that can be added a-la-carte.

I use the speaker as I can barely hear a phone without it. I like the phone. I am still learning how to use it. I have had a smart phone for a long time. So the learning is slower plus I am getting older. I love the phone. I would recommend it to anyone who needed a phone that was economical.

This phone is good for the user but the person getting the call cannot understand a thing being said to them on the other end. The WORSE RECEPTIUON SOUND QUALITY I have EVER WITNESSED. Very frustrating for both ends when you can't understand each other. This phone was returned and we are going back to Consumer Cellular (recommended by AARP) and getting their flip phone!

this phone may be ok but you can not return phone through great call without the biggest hassle. Had my 92 year old mom in tears. .do not buy this for your mom or elderly father, have to wait so long on hold, so upset great call is so

Easy but not that easy for a 95 year old. Doesn't always ring which I can't understand. Like this morning we are both sitting at the table and we got a message that we had a missed call but there was no phone ringing. This has happened before. I can't blame him because I am sitting right there too. It took a long time to train him and sometimes he bumps the red button accidentally and someone has always answered so that is good.

I absolutely love my Great Call flip Phone. I am 85 and find it very easy to use and I especially like the 5 star feature in an emergency . It is rechargeable and you can decide the monthly cost , by buying how many minutes a month you need.

We bought this for our former neighbor who is 89. She has never used anything like this before. So far she has been able to understand and use the calling feature and use the few contacts she has. She just wants to do the very basics. We wanted it for her safety,

I ordered this phone for my husband that hates technology. After I set it up for him, he has not had any problem in using this phone and carries it with him whenever he goes out. It was extremely easy to set up, however I do recommend going online to add contacts. The menus are simple and it is very easy to use. The big buttons and screen are a plus. Saw their ad in AARP magazine and it is everything they say it is.

I ordered this phone for my 93 year old Father who is still very active and it has been wonderful.The reception and clarity of all phone calls has been a real lifesaver in helping me keep track of him while he is outside the house.I would highly recommend this phone from the purchasing through the phone setup process it was very easy and stress free.

The phone is first rate, but I have trouble getting on line to view my account. I believe I gave a valid password but it seems not to be accepted. If i continue to have trouble I'd prefer to get statements on paper. Also, it appears that I'm on a 400 minute monthly use. I expressly ordered a 200 minute per month use, which is adequate for my needs. Alan Walker Acct. no. 3179436

I find the Jitterbug and the Great Call service reps topnotch. I have no need for a so called "smart phone", so the Jitterbug is perfect for me. Large numbers and an easy to use "yes or no" decision to make. Love the camera and the ability to load my phone numbers on my Great Call account page.

Just activated the flip phone for my 87 year old mother. She loves the large numbers and easy notification of missed voicemail and/or call. The only feature she uses is the phone book, but it is easy for her to find the person's name, and is now getting used to the "speed dial" number for the people she calls everyday. At any time, you can open the flip phone, push the one/two digit number and hit YES and it places the call. Very easy.

The phone is easy to use, big buttons, and it asks you at each step and mode what you want to do and you answer yes or no to the questions. The 5Star button, if you have that service, is easy to push accidentally. Otherwise, it seems to be a very good phone and phone service.

purchased for my 94 year old father. number 1 best feature: Largest display i could find.
Father struggles with any technology. not sure the menu's could be any simpler. Works as good as any device he has used with his hearing aids.

You are unable to transfer information, contacts etc from your old phone! You must type in all contacts. You also have to scroll the entire contact list to get to what number you are looking for, my husband hates this phone and I don't blame him. Sorry

Purchased this phone for my elderly mother. She did NOT want a cell phone/plan and did not like the touch screen smart phones or tiny buttons on other phones. Too hard to read and use. Did not need all the "bells and whistles." Found the Jitterbug advertised in a magazine and I bought it for her for her birthday. Easy to use, big buttons, and keeps her connected should her home land line go down.
Excellent purchase and the company really seems to stand behind their product.

UPDATE 10/21/2016:
The 1st phone started to intermittently function like it was muted. No sound from the Jitterbug but the person on the other end could be heard. I called Great Call and they have not heard of this problem.They sent another phone and in less than a week, it is having the same problem. I see that 2 other reviewers have had this problem and one was told to turn the phone off and back on which solved his problem until it happened again.
The phone should have a lanyard or case, an option to block/disable text messages, less expensive minutes.
I am subtracting 1 star because a phone for seniors should be simple which it is but also reliable which it is not.

I purchased this directly from Great Call to replace a Jitterbug 5 that had stopped working after 1 year. Even with help from Great Call (escalated to 2nd lever of support) it took a long time to get the phone activated. All contacts and minutes carried over successfully.
One of the things liked about the former phone was the optional lanyard.This option is no longer available on the Jitterbug Flip and per the company there are no current plans for adding such. I have spent hours looking for a lanyard or a case to which I could attach a lanyard. This is an important feature for seniors or anyone with motor issues. I finally found a YouTube video that explained how to use the speaker holes on the case back of a different phone. The speaker holes of the Jitterbug Flip are tiny and will not accept a lanyard but will accommodate nylon thread to make a loop for attaching a lanyard.. I don't believe this will void the warranty. Don't know if it affects the sound quality
I have to get this resolved before it goes to the person who will ultimately use it. I would appreciate any other ideas for lanyards or cases for this phone.

Nice size to the screen and numbers are so easy to see and the large buttons work better for a person with large or shaky fingers. I have been using an android and miss the one tap to write but I will get used to this. I have had flip phones before and do appreciate the ability to close the unit and protect myself from ending up with weird things happening. The older I get the more simple I like things in my life.

My quest was to get some semblance of a smart phone focused toward geriatrics whereby the GreatCall Jitterbug flip phone more than fit the bill. It's comfortable to hold, very easy to use, and in affect has texting, photo and voice-call activation capability. I opted to include the one-button 5Star emergency call function for obvious reasons. Overall, I'm very pleased with the device and GreatCall's exemplary customer service.
My 81 year old husband loves this cell phone. He says phones are to used to talk not write! lol

What a piece of junk. I called tech support on numerous occasions because one thing or another stopped working. They even replaced one. I got this for my mom and at first thought it was because she couldn't use it properly. But it actually didn't work most of the time.

I like my Jitterbug very much. It is the right size and the screen is wonderful. Going from a smart phone it took some time for me to adjust to the simplicity of it. I no longer needed all the bells and whistles of a smart phone and needed to save some money. Mission accomplished on both counts.

On the down side, sometimes the buttons are hard to press and need pressing twice.

Best cell phone ever had..extremely user friendly..and the one button concierge feature worth its
weight in gold..forget that smart phone nonsense which is a big con to make money off you by advertising
sales and selling you apps and etc..
Thanks Jitterbug my red flip I will never give up !!!!

Can someone enlighten me on how this phone can be so highly rated when I am thru only a few pages of reviews and I have 4 likes and 25 dislikes? I was contemplating this phone for my husband because of how highly rated it is in several cites for cell phones for seniors. The only way I could submit this was I had to give it a rating.

My mother is 91 and for a year now has been ok with phone...Only downside is I wish the volume was louder. Half the time she never hears the phone. Also there is no BLOCK number. My mom gets calls all the time. It scares me...
It is my first cellphone and it works well for an older person. I am 80 and cannot see well. It has done all I had hoped it would do. I would buy another. I would like to have a way to block numbers.

I needed a phone for my elderly mother with big buttons, solid construction, and most importantly, an easy to use UI, because she is very technophobic. The UI is very simple and very elegant and she has even figured out how to use some features on her own. The owner's manual and quick start guide (especially) have nice, large, clear print for her to read. I also like that the buttons are very, very big, because manual dexterity is an issue for her hands and the simple keyboard & large buttons are easy for her to use. In addition to the easy and elegant UI, the screen has a minimum of information on it and what it does is clear and in large print. I am extremely pleased with this phone.

I appreciate the simplicity of this type of fun. As a prisoner to the iPhone, its refreshing to eliminate the distractions and just have a phone with very basic texting ability. I love not having access to the internet, its healthy to get away from all of that stuff instead of drag around in your pocket where-ever you go. The Jitterbug is a great flip phone, if you remember that's what it is, a basic flip phone.

I love it, it is the best and easiest phone to program and find what you want.can't say much for picture quality but giving up for ease of use would have liked a red one but Best BUY only had grey. one more time i love it ,loud ring had a dial tone just like a land line..
This phone was purchased for my 92 year old father and he finally has a phone that he can use. It's easy to use and the larger buttons and onscreen assistance is readable and simple.

After struggling with a touch screen she couldnât use properly and poor connection problems from a cheap carrier, my mother has a phone she can use. And the call stays connected. The whole family is so happy because itâs now so easy to call her and receive her calls. Definitely a great service for those tech challenged seniors.

PURCHASED FOR OUR MOTHER WHO IS 90 YEARS OLD AND NEEDED A PHONE THAT WAS EASY TO OPERATE, AND THIS IS THE ONE, HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS PHONE TO OTHERS!! SO FAR IT WORKS AS GOOD AS THE PREVIOUS PHONE AND IS MUCH EASIER TO OPERATE FOR HER.

We've only been using this phone for two weeks. It is for out 95 year old father. We wanted something simple and clear. Although the learning curve is greater for older people, generally, he seems to be learning how to use it. We have not introduced him to the voice command yet. ...baby steps...
Wanted a bright color (red) so it would be easier for him to find it if lost or misplaced. I and I hope he, likes the dial tone that you hear upon opening the flip phone. This is like an old house phone. We'll see how he's doing with this phone in a few weeks or months.

Easy to use with large buttons and easy to program with the yes and no and up and down arrow navigation buttons. Calls out and in had clear sound quality and I especially enjoy the built in games and the bright flashlight when you flip open the phone and press the button on the side. The 5* button make it easy to get help if you need it by hitting just that button. They know automatically your location and can call 911 for you or get you an ambulance. Nice phone for the price.

The Jitterbug Flip phone ads are directed towards older phone users, but I think it is a great phone for any age. Out of the box, the Jitterbug Flip phone is easy to set up. Using the "Yes" and "No" buttons on the Jitterbug makes the menu very easy to navigate, making the process of each feature easy to complete. I was pleasantly surprised at the quality of the photos I took with the Jitterbug Flip phone in comparison to a Verizon flip phone I had a few years ago. The Jitterbug Flip phone produced crisp, clear photos with its easy to operate camera. If you are looking for an easy to understand, simple to operate phone, you'll love the Jitterbug Flip phone, as much as I do.

Good phone for this senior. Easy to read and hear and even I could figure out all the different things it can do. Texting is not something I like to do (arthritis causes stiff fingers) and this phone is not as simple to text as the more costly smart phones. I can text when I must, call & receive calls and take and send pictures. I don't need more than that and this phone is priced right and the monthly cost is minimal compared to other phones. I like it.

So far I like it. It is easy to read, to navigate and the yes and no is simple. Only use the phone when traveling or going to town so is not on 24/7. So far most of my issues have been solved and the waiting time is reasonable. We will see in another 6 months.

This is a simple no frills phone. I bought it directly from Great call and it arrived ready to set up. Very easy. I send some texts, and it is much slower without a keypad, but it works. I rarely used my iPhone and got tired of the cost. This is so much cheaper, no contract, good customer service so far. If you want a fancy phone this is not it. But, for safety and basic phone needs, this works well.

I picked this up for my father to use who broke his cell phone on his last trip to Washington DC this summer. He only uses it for emergencies, like when he travels to see me or to have in his car in the winter (he's in Minnesota) in case of a bad snow fall or car accident. This means he doesn't need a phone to surf the web, check email, or the like. He uses a cell phone like it's 2005 and that's fine because that's all he needs. Which is what made the Jitterbug so great for his particular needs. He's a bit anachronistic when it comes to technology, so having a simply flip phone with easy to read numbers is just what he needed. Push buttons instead of a touch screen was also right up his alley. The plans for the Jitterbug are cheap and so we're not paying fifty dollars a month for minutes he will never use. We haven't had to use the emergency button but it's good to have. One button to reach emergency services is better than having to press three. It's a simple easy to use phone for seniors who just want something in case of an emergency or their land line goes out.
To me the phone has been direct and simple to use. I have had no problems with it since I purchased about 4 months ago. Batter life has been very good.

perfect phone -easy to use-not complicated! 5 star is great in case of need. working in hospital- all shifts- feel secure! easy to use! meets all my needs! get it! you will not be sorry! (various packages to choice from)

This is a phone intended to provide basic functionality with an easy to use interface, large buttons, and large screen. It's aimed at those who just want a phone with one or two extras, not a hand held computer.

It comes ready to go out of the box, already charged. Just make sure it's compatible with the network in your area, and it should be fine.

After reading most reviews I decided the best course of action is to go.with a proven winner, that being Tracphone.
Thanks to all reviewers, you do make a difference and most companies pay attention.

The buttons are large and everything is very simple either yes you want to or no you don't want to. The cradle is great because it doesn't wear out a usb charging port on the phone. I was surprised to learn I had to go online or call to update and delete phone numbers. My husband doesn't go online, so that could be an issue for someone. The voice quality isn't the best, but it's understandable.
I purchased this phone for my mother for its simplicity and large numbers and words. Also after getting this phone, she was able to cancel her landline and be free of that expense.
Has given me much needed independence. I have macular degeneration and was unable to make calls when I was by myself. The voice dial feature gave me back my independence.

phone is nice and load buttons are big and I would have given it a 5 star if it was not for the location of the volume buttons. All phone put the buttons on the side of the phone and when one pulls the phone out of the case it's in you can't help the fact you are pushing on the buttons and then lowering the volume which is the main reason for buying the phone. Volume buttons should be under the cover and no buttons should be on the outside.
Super simple for my 70 year old Mother, now if I can just get her to continue to use it steady. Excellent customer service, they definitely know their customer base.
Easy to set up and easy to use- especially for people not used to technology

Amazing customer service. Tech support arranged for 3-way conference call to help my 99 year old mother when the phone failed,They then sent her a replacement, and transferred all 75 of her contacts to the new phone. The set up for the new phone was so easy she did it herself. Support has been available promptly even on Sunday. Being able to edit the phone book on line has been a plus for me as I live 300 miles away.

I have only had the phone for a short time . I like the size of the screens and number pad. Also the easy way to make calls and use the other parts of the phone. As I am a senior citizen it works great for me I am very satisfied at this time.

I purchased this phone for my 92-yr-old mother about a year ago, when her previous flip phone, from t-mobile, stopped working well. I used the phone myself for about a week and found it to be an decent basic flip phone. My mother learned how to use it easily, but she has also been able to learn how to use other inexpensive flip phones easily in the past. There are really 3 problems with the phone: (1) Sound quality is just okay, and the loudness, even at the highest setting, is not particularly loud. (It's okay for me, but not for an average senior.) This is really not a "special phone for seniors" as far as sound quality goes. Also the speakerphone feature is quite poor (again, the sound quality). (2) The call loudness is easy for my mother to change inadvertently during the call. (It starts at high, then shifts to medium and she can't hear me.) In other words, the location of the volume buttons is really a poor design for seniors. (3) The sound quality has gotten worse over the course of the yearâ¦ imagine that, a phone for the elderly that doesnât age well. ;)

In my experience, the Jitterbug is an avg-to low quality flip phone with a slightly dumbed down user interface and big keys on the keyboard. There is nothing else special about it as a phone for seniors, unless you use the emergency alert services. A disappointment overall.

I purchased the phone because I wanted a phone basically just to make and receive calls. My husband suffered a stroke and cannot "work" anything very complicated. This works well for just a basic phone. One neat thing I had it programmed by my audiologist so I can answer the phone through the hearing aids remote hanging around my neck. Very easy to use jitterbug and sound quality very good. I can use it without my hearing aids on.

Very pleasantly surprised to learn I can use Lyft ride service without needing a smart phone. a BIG bonus. do not understand why unit will tell me i have 1 new text message when in fact I do not. was never going to get another cell phone but when my late wife became terminal, it became necessary. this flip phone completely fills the bill.

This is a great, simple phone for seniors. I got it for my 95-year old mother, who has severe macular degeneration, to use in emergency situations. She is able to see the large buttons with relative ease compared to her previous phone. The red 5-star button that she can push to get help gives me peace of mind.

I PURCHASED MY JITTERBUG DIRECT FROM GREAT CALL.. I CAN ONLY RATE MY JITTERBUG WITH A TRIPLE 5 STAR RATING.
ASOLUTELY THE BEST CELL PHONE I EVER OWNED.. THE PHONE DID TELL ME IT DID NOT WORK WITH A USB CABLE TO UP LOAD
PHOTOS TO MY COMPUTER**BUT IT DOES*** I HAVE UP LOADED SEVERAL PHOTOS TO MY COMPUTER
AGAIN I COULD NOT BE MORE HAPPY WITH MY JITTERBUG****GREAT PHONE***
BILL TARRANT, ALTON, IL

This phone has been wonderful for my mother. She suffered a stroke and has weakness on the left side, unable to open a regular flip phone easily or fast enough, and not quite able to grasp learning a touch screen smart phone! I highly recommend this phone for elderly people... simple YES and NO buttons make it easy for my mom to understand. Thank you jitterbug!!!!

I like this phone very much. It would not charge on the cradle and the charge plug in went out a mouth later. These things happen. The customer service people are excellent and they are sending me a new charge cable.
I purchased two of these phones for my dad and my uncle. They both love the sound quality, the bigger, easy to see buttons and the easy navigation through the menu options.
The Jitterbug Flip phone gives me just what I need. It's very easy to use, help is just a phone call away, I take it with me each time I leave home and it gives me confidence in case of an emergency.

I purchased the Jitterbug for my mom. She loves it!! The red color is easy to find in her purse. It is extremely easy to use with the large buttons and simple screen. Best of all the personal service. They helped us set everything up.
Not a better phone anywhere for those with poor vision and hearing. Easy to use also. Only thing I wish I had is the ability to load a feew APPS.

I had a smartphone which was complicated but in 2 yrs, I learned it but when I saw the Jitterbug for seniors; and really love the big buttons it's big text; It takes way less time, I do all the rest on tablet or laptop. it's size makes it possible to carry it and charge card in my pocket. No need for a big heavy purse.
Easy yes or no choices with the topic highlighted makes this phone extremely easy to use.

The phone is everything I expected, and is just what I wanted. I tried the Jitterbug smart phone and soon discovered that it was smarter than I was. Didn't like the thing. Great Call was very helpful in exchanging it for the flip phone. I now am a happy customer.

My wife's cell phone was getting pretty old and not always dependable. I did some research and determined that the Jitterbug Flip was the right choice. Obviously, it operates differently from her previous phone, but she is getting more comfortable with it every day. the large viewing screen, numbers, and buttons has been a real find. Was a little disappointed that AT&T does not provide a network for this phone.

I purchased this as an update for the previous version for my 95 yr old Mom. The biggest drawback is the placement of the volume buttons. Silver buttons on silver not good for visually impaired, and on the side where anyone wants to grab the phone causes problems we didn't have before. The added camera, magnifier, flashlight are all good...but hard for Mom to remember how to use. Even the ability to use Voice dialing is hard because you have to go to the phonebook first. I think all these new features are wonderful if your elder can see relatively well. Great Call' s Customer service is top notch 24/7 365. Also the one thinv I love is the 5star button. Once activated, as soln ad the phone is opened the GPS is on. If Mom has a problem ANYWHERE she presses that red button and Grsat Call knows where she is to notify local 911. Peace of mind...worth it!

We bought this for my mother-in-law for Christmas. She has had a terrible time with it. Now the phone doesn't even take a charge or won't turn on. This would be a terrific phone for her if it worked. Please give us suggestions what we can do with this phone for her.

I bought the jitterbug smartphone for my 83yr old mother who has dementia. She could not use this phone even though it is a very user friendly phone. I sent it back and got the flip phone and she has been using it without a problem. Great easy to use phone.
for emergency, meeting people, when away from home. It is normally not turned on. I prefer email or land line.

Having this phone for my husband had been a big worry off my mind. I now know that no matter where he is, he isn't far from help. It is a very good price for not only having the phone for communication, but the safety factor alone is worth the price. We owned system earlier, but one had to be within a certain area or it didn't not work; several times it didn't work or notified emergency personnel without needing.

I enjoyed using this phone because it was light and fit in my hand. the number on pad were very large which was nice because you did not have to squint to see them. The features were easy and user friendly. I could easily go from one to the next without any issues or problems
I had Jitterbug phone before and liked it...no complaint. A friend talked me into a Smart phone,... and I re-instated my Jitterbug. It is all that I need and I recommend it to everyone I can
This jitterbug flip phone has big numbers, easy to use, highly recommended for seniors.
I'm glad I got my Great Calls Phone, it's come in real handy, with no problems yet.

My wife's cell phone was getting pretty old and not always dependable. I did some research and determined that the Jitterbug Flip was the right choice. Obviously, it operates differently from her previous phone, but she is getting more comfortable with it every day. the large viewing screen, numbers, and buttons has been a real find. Was a little disappointed that AT&T does not provide a network for this phone.

I purchased this as an update for the previous version for my 95 yr old Mom. The biggest drawback is the placement of the volume buttons. Silver buttons on silver not good for visually impaired, and on the side where anyone wants to grab the phone causes problems we didn't have before. The added camera, magnifier, flashlight are all good...but hard for Mom to remember how to use. Even the ability to use Voice dialing is hard because you have to go to the phonebook first. I think all these new features are wonderful if your elder can see relatively well. Great Call' s Customer service is top notch 24/7 365. Also the one thinv I love is the 5star button. Once activated, as soln ad the phone is opened the GPS is on. If Mom has a problem ANYWHERE she presses that red button and Grsat Call knows where she is to notify local 911. Peace of mind...worth it!

We bought this for my mother-in-law for Christmas. She has had a terrible time with it. Now the phone doesn't even take a charge or won't turn on. This would be a terrific phone for her if it worked. Please give us suggestions what we can do with this phone for her.

I bought the jitterbug smartphone for my 83yr old mother who has dementia. She could not use this phone even though it is a very user friendly phone. I sent it back and got the flip phone and she has been using it without a problem. Great easy to use phone.
for emergency, meeting people, when away from home. It is normally not turned on. I prefer email or land line.

Having this phone for my husband had been a big worry off my mind. I now know that no matter where he is, he isn't far from help. It is a very good price for not only having the phone for communication, but the safety factor alone is worth the price. We owned system earlier, but one had to be within a certain area or it didn't not work; several times it didn't work or notified emergency personnel without needing.

I enjoyed using this phone because it was light and fit in my hand. the number on pad were very large which was nice because you did not have to squint to see them. The features were easy and user friendly. I could easily go from one to the next without any issues or problems
I had Jitterbug phone before and liked it...no complaint. A friend talked me into a Smart phone,... and I re-instated my Jitterbug. It is all that I need and I recommend it to everyone I can
This jitterbug flip phone has big numbers, easy to use, highly recommended for seniors.
I'm glad I got my Great Calls Phone, it's come in real handy, with no problems yet.

I bought this Flip Phone phone through GreatCall over a year ago for my fairly deaf father who is 96.

Upsides:
1. the numbers are large.
2. The speaker is loud, when you use it instead of the handset.
3. The menu navigation is pretty straightforward for old people without a lot of confusion, but there are still seniors who will get confused using it. Answer the questions yes or no and the phone does what you want it to do. "Do you want to call this number? >YES." That kind of menu.

Downsides:
1. You can't block numbers on this flip phone. Old people are a big target for phone scams. My dad gets bogus telemarketing calls all the time and I can't block the numbers to prevent repeat calls. Thankfully, my next comment comes into play so he never answers the phone ...
2. Why? The ringer isn't very loud. My dad can't hear it even when it's in his pocket, and it's set as loud as it will go. On top of that, you can't set the ringer to loud AND vibrate, which would be very helpful. The ringer is either on some volume OR off with vibrate only.
3. For my father, even with hearing aids, the handset is not loud enough. Hence, we use the speaker a lot.
4. The charging dock bit the dust in less than one year.

This phone made by Alcatel is junk compared to the older Samsung flip. We upgraded when our battery went dead and were unable to replace so we thought it would be better to upgrade the phone. What a mistake. First we had all kinds of trouble because the phone would not activate even though we had to go by a window, then go to the front yard then the backyard. Hours with customer service with no help, we had to mail it in and have them activate it then send it back, more hassles and no phone. Finally we got the phone back and found that it would go dead for no reason at all. Again went through customer service, she had me take the back off and remove the battery then replace it. This is the only way we can make the phone work. If you need it in an emergency you are stuck out of luck until you remove the battery again. We were told not to do that but to return the phone for a replacement, for what another junky Alcatel. Not again. We are going to look at other carriers that have a reliable phone.

Jitterbug Flip phone has Large Keys and SIMPLE operation. It is just great for seniors or non-techie persons. Price is most reasonable. Texting is available IF the user wants it. With Large clear menus , it's EASY to operate with YES and NO buttons! Voice dial service is free!

Great Calls doesn't tell people the truth when they activate this phone. They advertise affordable monthly plans, but don't tell you that they charge you for INCOMING calls as well as OUTGOING. My 89 year old mother only has the phone for emergency calls and talking with family members. Her first bill came (on a $33 a month plan) and it was $250! They charged her for every INCOMING and OUTGOING call!!! This also means that any solicitation calls she got, Great Calls charged her for!!!!!. When I called to tried to find out why the bill was so high, they told me my mother would have to go on-line and print out her call usage and identify every phone number on there....all 276 calls!!! We cancelled the next day.

My 77 year old mother has this phone and has nothing but problems. The buttons on the sides of the phone are right where your hand/fingers would go to hold the phone up to your ear when talking to someone. The ringer mysteriously gets turned off all the time. The menu keys are so slow to respond it reminds me of when the internet was dial-up. It could be my mother not knowing how to use it, by both I and my sister have tried to turn on the "jingle" as they call the ringer, and it just goes off again. Is it my mom's thumb grasping the phone as she holds it?

I don't know, but it's no good. I do not recommend. I love the idea of the large letters but it still has too many un-needed features like background color, etc. Seniors don't want that option...do they? Time for another company to re-invent the wheel here. A wheel for seniors.

I bought this phone a year ago directly from âJitterbugâ/GreatCall for $99 plus a $30 activation fee. My mom is in her 70s and I just needed her to have something for emergencies. The cheapest plan they have is something like $25 per month with fees but it was worth my piece of mind. She has had flip phones in the past so I figured this one would be no problem. I even programmed her friendsâ numbers into it. SHE HATED IT. I paid for the service for a year before finally giving up. She couldnât get it to turn on, it never worked right and it wouldnât hold a charge. Honestly, I heard nothing but complaints from her for the entire time she had this phone.

For Christmas I gave her my old iPhone 7 Plus. She looooves it. I honestly didnât think she could figure out a smart phone, which is why I gave her the Jitterbug Flip. What a waste of time, energy and money.

She used the Jitterbug MAYBE a total of 30 minutes for the ENTIRE YEAR!!!

The worst part of this is that when I called to cancel the service today the rep was like âToo bad your service month just renewed January 10th. I can cancel your service but youâre still paying for it through February 9thâ!!!!

WHY IS IT THAT EVERY OTHER COMPANY IN THE WORLD CAN FIGURE OUT HOW TO PRO-RATE A CANCELLATION?!!â Good job getting an extra $20 out of me, GreatCall. Maybe youâd like to step into the 21st century with the rest of us?

I got a great price for the phone I bought here on Amazon..I made the choice considering the easy use of the phone and idea of a $14.99 monthly charge with no contract..Sounded great!!! But....when I got the phone and called for the activation, I learned the company adds a "service fee" on top of the monthly charge which came to roughly $31.40 a month. Additionally the phone has camera and texting capabilities..Great!!!! But...every time you text, it costs $0.10 for each text you send and receive. Furthermore, for every picture/selfie you take, it will also cost you an additional $0.10 for each photo..I was not pleased about the additional fees,especially the "service fee" which doubles the monthly basic fee. This explains the two star rating. However, I did keep the phone and activated it..These additional fees need to be considered when purchasing this phone,especially for those on a limited budget..

I wanted to believe the good reviews because my mom wouldn't stop bugging me to purchase this red flip phone for her. She has bad eyesight and like many older seniors needs to have a cell phone that will work without all the fuss of the internet on the phone. My sister broke down and got it for her and it has been a head ache for the last 6 months. Just imagine that you don't live near the person who needs it and the phone stops working. Then you spend HOURS contacting every neighbor of hers and then more time contacting the seller to send a new chip. Many times it would just ring and she wouldn't hear it. Long story short - Before this red phone I had a walmart smartphone set up with a software that always showed big easy buttons. Then I used bluetooth to transfer her existing contacts. On this red phone all the contacts and numbers will need to be entered manually. The marketing for this phone is great because everyone who hasn't had one thinks it is a great idea. I thought it was. Currently she has no cell and waiting again for a new chip. I'm across the country so not sure if it is a signal related issue or just that the phone breaks easy. I just want to save someone else this headache and worry. Read all the negative reviews before you buy this.

I am an retired letter carrier and I love my Jitterbug flip phone by Great Call but the only I had was as an hard of hearing, I could not hear the phone rings and missing some phone calls. Sometime next year, I am planning to Great Call Smartphone.
Had it less than 6 months and it's not working.

Love the big screen and numbers. Super easy to use - no "swiping". Great reception in areas old phone had none. Typing in the phone numbers list on the computer was great! Easy to download pictures taken with jitterbug to computer. Can't say enough positive things about this phone! BUY IT!
Still learning how to use. So far, so good....
Bought it for my 90 year mom,she seems to have no problems with it so far.
Worst costumer service ever product is not user friendly go to Walmart and by a track phone

Love my phone. I do not have time to devote to learning a computer system, which is what the new phones amount to, so this phone is perfect for me - a very busy person, who has a lot more to do than sit on my phone all day.

I first bought a consumer cellular Envoy and the buttons and numbers were to small as well as the screen, I had a hard time finding anything on the phone. I sent the Envoy back and called Great Calls for the Jitterbug and I am very happy now.
We love everything about the phone. When the trac fone quits, I will be purchasing another jitterbug phone. Keep up the good work.

I bought my Jitterbug phone primarily for safety - to have a way to communicate if something happens while I'm away from my apartment. I'm 77.

I've used it, some, mostly to call family members when I'm "back home" visiting. and have had no problems..

Fortunately, I haven't had an emergency while away from my apartment, but, it's comforting to know I have it "just in case!".

WHAT SENIOR CITIZENS NEED IS LOUDER

Not sure if I'm qualified to write a review on a "tech" item or not. Up to now, I've used a flip phone and this is the first smart phone I've used. Keep in mind that I'm not a tech saavy senior and my concerns might not coincide with the general public's (younger, more informed people).

I like the fact that this phone has some heft. To me, the weight of it attests to its quality and makes me believe it is a solid product. It feels good in the hand during use and, even with a Ringke case, it's not too bulky to be comfortable.

The display is clear to me. From what I understand, this phone, as an economy model, has a lower pixel count that competing models. Even so, I think the clarity values are more than sufficient for the average user. If you have no activities you engage in on your phone that require extra high resolution, this phone is a good choice. The 4.3" screen is adequate for easy viewing.

Sound quality is excellent. I have never had a problem understanding or being understood by anyone I have talked to. The small speaker actually sounds surprisingly good playing music (from your music library or FM radio) and doesn't even distort at max volume.

Design is fine, with rounded corners it fits comfortably in the hand. I particularly like the inverted "dimple" on the back. A finger of one hand fits well there while texting; ensuring a better grip on it and lessening the possibility of slippage.

Even though this phone is 3G and supposedly out of date by todays standards, response time has been incredibly fast. I'm more than satisfied.

The only complaint that I have is that this phone only has 4GB of built-in storage. Upon receipt, the phone has almost half of that in use so, the amount of apps you can install is limited. For most of us seniors, it is still adequate. Unless you want to install a dozen game apps to your phone, the amount of space will be sufficient. You do have the ability to install an SD card (up to 32GB) for extra storage. Unfortunately, many of the applications cannot be moved there to free up internal storage. You can however, store your music library and photos on the SD card.

The camera, while only 5MP, produces fine photos. There is no flash however and, if you're addicted to selfies, you'll be disappointed as there is only a rear facing camera lens. Battery life, I feel, has been exceptional. I'm only charging this thing up every other day.

Wifi has been flawless; I have absolutely no issues with this feature. Since I purchased this, I've gotten a portable Bluetooth speaker and this phone paired easily with it for great sound and the ability to use the speaker for conference calls.

For the most part, the switch to this smart phone has been intuitive for me, even though I am not technologically minded. There is lots of info on the web for any function you have questions about. If you are a senior like me, and know how to use a desktop computer, you probably have enough expertise to successfully make the switch to this entry level, economical phone. While TracFone is not known for selling high usage plans economically, the triple minute feature makes them more competitive. For approximately $25 a month (if you buy a 90 day plan) you get 450 min of talk time, 450MB of data (this is used to browse the web when you are away from your Wifi router) and 450 texts per month. While this won't be sufficient for a 16 year old Junior in high school it will be more than enough for a senior citizen who doesn't engage in 2 hour talk fests. Leftover time on the plan does carry over if the plan is kept current. If you're an "age challenged" person like myself, don't let the phrase "smart phone" scare you off. If you can operate a computer without having the Grandkids over every other day to unfreeze it, you can utilize and learn from this phone. Thanks for taking the time to read this lengthy review.

Update - 4-9-2016: I just purchased my first quarterly refill of "pay as you go" minutes and felt I should correct what was a misstatement in my original review. The plan I mentioned was $79.99 for a 90 day period. I just noted that there are some additional charges above and beyond that price. Most notably, for me, is just the sales tax (here in Texas it is 8.25%). Depending upon the state you reside in, you may pay more or less. While I'm still satisfied with my phone cost, in the interest of correctness, after the monthly breakdown I pay much closer to $30 per month than the stated $25 a month.

I have had the Moto E for over a week now. I have been a Tracfone customer for many years. The last phone I had was the ZTE valet. The Moto E came with a wall charger that has a micro USB on the other end. You will need a separate USB to micro USB to plug into your computer if needed. I have never had any issues with transferring service from one phone to the next. I logged in to my Tracfone account, and my phone # and minutes were transferred within 5 minutes. I used Motorola Migrate to transfer all my pics, music, etc. from my ZTE to the Moto E. Transferring my contacts via Bluetooth also worked flawlessly. I noticed my Android version on the Moto E is at 4.4.4, which I believe is an update from 4.4.2. Under settings the phone has a system update, which checks to see if you have the latest updates installed. I am hoping to get android 5.0 update when available. I installed a 4 gigabyte Sandisk micro SD card to store my music and photos. Their is one opening on the back to install the micro SD card. I believe 32 gigabytes is max. Wifi is excellent, I am able to pick up wifi as well as an IPad, whereas my ZTE was horrible. The screen is amazing, responding perfectly to the touch. I have had no lag whatsoever in opening any app or game. Web surfing is lightning fast. The FM radio works great. Your headphone cord acts as the antenna. The speaker sound is also excellent. The speaker is located on the front, where it should be. I have been able to play YouTube, Netflix, Facebook, etc.etc. flawlessly. I have taken a few pictures, and compared to the ZTE, they look great, even with no flash. The camera seems to let a lot of light in for a great picture. I like that you can tap the screen anywhere to take the photo. I will still use my digital camera for my important pictures.There are two buttons on the right side of the phone. One turns on the phone, the other adjusts the volume.There is a light on the front that flashes notifying you of a text, email, or missed call. This is the first phone I am not going to install a screen protector or cover. You can purchase different colored back covers from Motorola. GPS works perfect. YouTube and Netflix play full screen, and look amazing. Battery life is great. The Tracfone logo is on the inside of the back of the phone. When you snap the back cover on, the Tracfone logo is hidden. Moto Assist is handy to silence the phone during meetings, or overnight. The Moto E is CDMA and uses the Verizon network. The Moto E is 5 inches long, 2 1/2 inches wide, and 7/16 thick. In a nutshell, I love this phone. Compared to the ZTE, the performance is simply amazing in every way. I find myself using the IPad much less,since the Moto E works so well. Super responsive, looks very classy, FM radio, excellent WiFi connection, sound, etc.etc. I am not sure how the Moto E compares to the LG Ultimate 2, or the Alcatel Icon Pop, as I was unable to find a comparison as of 12/18/14. The only features I would like to have are a flash and autofocus for the camera.

**UPDATE 12/30/14** The Moto E is working perfectly. I have had no freezing or lag whatsoever. The WI-FI reception has been exceptional. I did not install a screen protector or cover, and the Moto E screen and case still look like brand new. The battery life is great. With a full day of normal use, web surfing, texting, calls, email, etc. etc. I am around 65 to 75% by the end of the day. I normally charge the phone daily anyway. Overnight, the phone will use 5 to 10% of the battery life, which is with Wi-Fi always left on. I replaced my wife's ZTE Valet with the Moto E also. If you are debating on upgrading from the ZTE Valet, you will not be disappointed. I still have not been able to find a comparison between the LG Ultimate 2, Alcatel Icon Pop, and the Moto E as of 12/30/14.

I have been a loyal TracFone customer since 2005. My first phone was a Nokia 1100 with a monochrome display and I have upgraded many times over the years. Today I can no longer recommend the company to anyone due to their abysmal warranty policy, which I now -- for the first time in over a decade -- need to use.

I bought a brand new Moto E from an authorized TracFone reseller on Amazon in September 2015. Everything was great with the phone at first except the fixed focus camera with no flash, but I could live with that. Then media sounds stopped playing out of the speaker. I could no longer hear movies, music, games, etc. Throughout the day at work the phone would out of no where speak in a female voice that I had a headset attached. I tried blowing out the headphone jack, factory resetting, etc. Nothing worked. Luckily basic calls still worked. Phone had been carefully handled this whole time -- never dropped, never submerged in water.

I called TracFone and the rep told me they would send me a replacement phone, and in the same box would be a prepaid return label and envelope for my defective one. TracFone's web site stated the same (see image). Rep also stated that because I had the phone longer than a month, I would be receiving a refurb even though I bought mine brand new. Also stated the refurb would not have a new warranty, but would continue on the original phone's 1-year warranty. All of this was less than optimal, but I had no choice.

I received the box a few days later and it felt suspiciously light. Opened it and it was empty except for the return label and envelope. I called TracFone back and was told I had to send my defective phone in first before receiving a replacement, despite what the first rep and the TracFone web site stated. Like many TracFone customers, this is my only phone and I cannot be without my cell phone for work and emergencies. Not to mention there was no guarantee I would receive a working replacement with my data and airtime intact. I told them this was not an option and even offered to let them put a hold on my credit card if they were worried about not receiving the defective phone back. Went through several call center and live chat reps, posted multiple times on their Facebook page. TracFone would do nothing.

So ends my 11-year relationship with TracFone. Buyer beware: if you are going to do business with TracFone, bring your own phone/buy only their cheap phones so you're not out much when they break, and above all, expect ZERO customer service.

The Motorola E is one of Tracfone's first "real" Androids in the market. It's generous 4.3" qHD display makes it look the part of an upper level Android, but doesn't have the costs like one. And while it's internal specs aren't anything to gloat, it'll get the job done.

Being a Tracfone user all of my life, I already knew what to expect from it, but first time Android users beware, as the minutes are counted differently. Instead of call time, texts, and data all coming from one bucket, they are divided up into their own separate buckets. Personally, I love how Tracfone has done this. Some months I might be using more texts than phone minutes, so I'll start calling people. Or optionally if I were to run out of texts, I could use Google Hangouts and message over data. It creates more ways to stretch your dollar.

Setup does take awhile to happen. Once you've typed everything into the Tracfone's website, you patiently have to wait, one hour personally, for Tracfone to deactivate your old phone, and transfer it to your new one. Once transferred you have to call a certain number and it "programs" your phone, with all of the Tracfone settings. It's not too long or tedious, but it is painful to wait for Tracfone to transfer your information as you wait to use your new phone.

One of the best things about this phone is the version of Android that is used. My Moto E runs off of Android 4.4.4, which is one of the newer versions. But this isn't the best part. After seeing my friend use their LG Fuel, their version of Android was modified. The options menus were different, not all of the base Android widgets came with it, and some base Android apps didn't work too well. This isn't the case with the Moto E. The options menus are almost exactly the same as my base Android, Nexus 7. I have all of the widgets. All of my base apps work perfectly. I have a feeling that this is because Motorola is owned by Google, so they closely working together, while LG can more freely do it's own thing. But nevertheless, this is why the Moto E wins me over.

While the internal specs aren't anything to brag about, they'll get the job done, especially for $99.99. The dual-core Qualcomm Snapdragon 200 boasts battery life and speed for entry level phones, and delivers. I use my phone an average amount for a smartphone user everyday, and it usually gets down around to 50%-60% before I charge it back up every night. The 1GB of ram isn't huge, but I haven't experienced many app crashes. But this can also be contributed to the limited internal storage on the phone. Tracfone and Motorola claim 4GB internal room, but the OS and base apps are included in this. The "total space" listed in the settings says 2.17GB, which I can believe is the accessible space. Even though all music, photos, and videos can be moved to the SD card, (apps say they can, but it doesn't really work very well, and I've never actually gotten it to work) there just isn't much room for a lot of apps.

The screen is actually surprising clear and good-looking for such a budget phone. It boasts a 540 x 940 screen resolution, and is often advertised with qHD - quarter HD, 1/4th of 1080p resolution. You can rarely pick out single pixels like some budget phones, and it's ~256 ppi is pretty well done. The Corning Gorilla Glass 3 is the same as most phones today, and I have yet to get any scratches. But with how nice the screen looks, the 5MP camera doesn't do it justice. The fixed focus really hurts the value of the camera, as it sometimes struggles to do simple tasks such as scan QR codes. It can record up to 480p videos, but unless the lighting is above good, it'll look choppy. The lack of a front facing camera does take away from the full Android experience a tad, but it isn't the most expensive phone on the block, so it'll get the job done in a pinch.

The chassis of the phone is built pretty well. It's slim enough that it doesn't leave a huge bulge in your pocket. Near the top, next to the speaker, there is a light that will blink if there's a notification. It's very helpful in case I didn't catch the buzz or ringtone, but can sometimes get annoying because I'll have a game request that I want to save for later, but the light won't stop blinking until I dismiss the notification. The main speaker on the phone is on the bottom of the front, just below the screen. I actually really liked that they put it there, because it sends the sound straight towards me while I'm listening. The speaker is a pretty generous noise producer, and is louder than my Nexus 7's speaker.

Overall the Moto E for Tracfone is a great phone. It's the first true "Android" for Tracfone in my eyes, and is the first Android I would recommend out of Tracfone's long list. It may be a budget smartphone in comparison to some, but it will hold it's own against the big dogs, with just a few markdowns from the top-of-the-line phones. The Moto E is not a deal to be missed.

Update 7/28/16
This phone now doesn't have enough internal storage because the updates of preinstalled apps has taken it. You MUST disable some of the preinstalled apps AND uninstall their updates to regain some valuable internal storage.To do this go to Settings>Apps and touch the apps you don't use. Clear the Data first then disable the app and uninstall updates.
This phone requires at least 300 mb of free internal storage to update apps and to work properly.
Get a micro SD card to put music, photos and apps that you install on. To do this go to Settings>Apps and On SD Card and put a check mark in the ones that you want to move.
-------

First off i really like the Moto E. It stands head and shoulders over the first wave of Tracfone offerings. It only took Tracfone a year to start offering some decent phones.

Now i know how bad the ZTE Valet that i used for over a year really was. Though at the time i considered it ok and i guess it was. It was painfully slow at running some apps like the yahoo mail app in particular. A few apps would crash because of the lack of processing power. (I had two weather apps running which showed the temperature in the notification area and that was about all the ZTE valet could handle.)

The Moto E is quite fast and runs android 4.4.4. (1.2 Ghz dual core processor and 1 gig of RAM.) I tend to use one app at a time rather than multitask and there is no lag what so ever. I think it could probably handle several apps running at once as well. When i first connected to my router and signed into my Google account it proceeded to install all the Google Play apps that i had on my previous phone automatically as well as my contacts. The speed in which it performed this was amazing. It left out a couple of apps which i later installed but got most of them about 20. I also installed 11 apps from Amazon App Store whose names were stored in the cloud under my account. Five of the largest apps i moved to the micro SD card and still had half of the internal storage available (2.21 gb of internal storage available to user total initially).

The camera is 5 MP and is fixed focus only. This was the only slight disappointment of this phone. I was expecting an auto focus camera. I've taken a few photos in good light and they are sharp and clear with great natural color. The phone by default stores photos in internal memory and you can move them to the SD card by going to Settings->Storage->Move Media. When the camera is open swipe right to
show the camera settings and one of them makes the camera store the photos directly onto the micro SD card. The camera has HDR setting which allows greater detail in light or dark areas of the photo. The more photos i take the more impressed i am with color balance and clarity. 9/23/15 The camera now has an exposure control so it may be able to photo checks for deposit with banking app. Open the camera and swipe to the right to access settings. The second from the top (the hand touching inside a square) touch to turn it on.

The screen is crisp and clear (960x540 resolution) and at 4.3 inches is a very comfortable size. I find 5.1 inch screens a little too large for putting in your front pants pocket.

The speaker i found a little tinny and with too much treble at first but there is a built in equalizer (Settings->Sound->Audio Effects) which i set to Extreme Bass and it seems to help or possibly i've adjusted to the sound. The speaker is on the front which i like.

The Power Control widget placed on one of your home screens makes it easy to control what features are turned on or off though it lacks the Data setting.

I had considered buying the next higher Motorola model the Moto G and bringing it to Tracfone in their BYOP program but several people said it couldn't be done with a new Verizon Prepaid phone. There is now one review that claims he activated a new Moto G on Tracfone as of December 15th. The Moto E Tracfone was the safe route to go and i am very pleased with it.

Update 1/9/15 I bought a 32gb micro SD card class 10 and put 13gb of music on it from my PC. (I also moved the files from my previous card using the PC.) I now think the speaker sounds great after listening to some of the music. This is the first phone i've had where you could listen to music on the built in speaker and enjoy it. Also moving the files to the new card with an adapter in the PC was the easiest way.

First I want to say that I purchased the Motorola Moto E as a birthday present for my mother who formerly had a QWERTY messaging phone on Tracfone. I chose the Moto E because I own the Moto G (Verizon) and thought that it was a great budget smartphone that fits my needs perfectly. My mom loves having a smartphone and being able to check her email on the go and play game apps. She picked up Android KitKat right away. That is one of the great things about this phone on Tracfone--it has KitKat and not some older Android OS like Gingerbread or Ice Cream Sandwich. Even though Motorola has said all their devices will be getting Lollipop, I doubt this Moto E will be since it is on Tracfone and they almost never seem to update their device's OS.
The Moto E is a little bit of a step down in almost every way than the Moto G. The screen's colors are not as vivid, the camera's photos are a little less crisp (although both don't take the greatest pictures), the physical buttons are squisher, and loading of webpages, ect is all just a tad slower which a dual core instead of a quad core processor. This aside, for an entry level smartphone user, that still wants a very user friendly and good experience with KitKat the Moto E is a great choice.
Like the Moto G, the Moto E has great call quality on both ends, the speakers are clear and crisp and loud when turned up a bit. The best part for Tracfone users is that (like the Moto G) the Moto E has an FM radio that does not use data. This is great when going for jogs, ect because of how limited most Tracfone user's data allotments are.
How does Tracfone do data? It's actually a perk of getting a Tracfone Android device. You buy a card, let's say 100 min (units) that that gets put in three seperate pots-- you will end up with 300 min 300 text and 300 MB of data from that one 100 min card. The only downside is that you can't use promo cards.
We were able to transfer my mother old number from her basic Tracfone to her Tracfone Moto E. It took a little over a day and about 45 min on the phone with Tracfone (their customer service leaves a lot to be desired) and then a second 25 min call to Tracfone to help with activation when the number was finally ported. Thankfully, she was able to keep her same account (her mins and service days from her old phone) and her number.
I paid $79.99 for the Moto E and in the box came the Moto E phone with stock black back (you can buy different colored/grip backs from Motorola), the irremovable battery already instead and 48% charged, white micro USB charger cord, and a 4GB micro SD card. That's the one better thing about the Moto E than the Moto G--it has a micro SD card slot to help with its only 4GB of storage space (Moto G has 8GB/16GB of storage space on device).
Overall this is a solid little device with Corning Gorilla Glass and a water resistant coating. I would recommend this phone for someone who uses Tracfone and wants the benefits of a smartphone or wants to upgrade a lower end Tracfone smartphone. However, if you are used to flagship devices with one of the big four (Verizon, AT&T, Sprint, or T-Mobile) this phone and Tracfone are not for you.

I have owned the Moto E for a month now, upgrading from a ZTE valet. I finally feel like i have a truly usable Tracfone, and wife is equally happy with hers. Itâs rather easy to use, sounds great, looks good, good screen, decent battery life, and for us cheap to use. We are a light user of the âphoneâ feature, mostly texting each other, and then usually in a wifi location. We keep building up tons of minutes, texts, and data, even when only purchasing 60 minute cards (3x everything remember). That brings our monthly out of pocket cost to about $6.67 a month. $6.67 a month! Good grief, a couple of coffees to go for the road costs more.

For the cost of the phone and monthly costs I truly cannot think of a worthwhile negative, and Iâm really good at that. Oh, maybe the camera. Fixed focus meh. Still gets the job done. For the rest of the features you should evaluate your particular needs, like FM radio. Really? Your mileage may vary. Apps run fairly snappy but Iâm sure someone can find one that wonât. Some people can break a steel ball.

Hey, itâs a good phone and I donât hesitate to recommend it. I find I can make it play nice with my Apple computers as well.

I recommend activating your new phone at the trackfone web site, make yourself an account first too. That makes activating, checking minutes, and buying airtime very easy. I had two swapped over in about 30 minutes on the computer. If you have to call use a land line or a different phone if you need to swap out another cell phone.

Here are some spots I found useful;
