I don't know if the phone comes from the factory this way or what, but every ringtone I chose, sounded nice and loud while testing, however when making a call to the phone the ring starts out barely audible then the second ring goes louder, then it goes back to barely audible. This won't work! By the time he could hear it and get it out of his pocket to answer, it goes to VM.
Who ever heard of a phone that, even though the ringer volume is set to high, starts so low it can barely be heard.

There is almost nothing good about this phone. I had it for a very short time and hated almost everything about it. Luckily, I broke the digitizer and replaced it with a garbage Alcatel droid.

Some good parts. The CPU is very fast and the screen is very good. Sound quality is good when it actually works (which is almost never). Bad parts? Basically everything else.

It's one of these phones that uses an emulated SD card, so programs that don't let you manage storage (such as Gospel Library) will be a huge problem. The phone itself only has 2GB, so good luck getting much of anything on this phone if you can't put it on the SD slot. Good thing that happens to be most programs. Did I mention you can't root this phone? You can't root this phone.

Like 99% of capacitive touch screens, the touch typing is horrid. Get a keyboard immediately. And I hope you've got money to burn on a bluetooth handset (or love hands free) because in my experience, almost all of my calls ended as a result of my face hitting the screen and it hanging up. Thanks, garbage touch screen. But at least the picture looks really good.

And back to the topic of bluetooth gluing stuff to the phone, the sound situation is a disaster. For whatever reason, only speaker phone is reliable. You seriously need to get some method of actually making calls with this thing, even if you just carry a bluetooth receiver around with you.

Battery life is poor doing anything except nothing. That's not entirely true. It does ok in programs with a mostly black screen. Still, power bank or wall socket recommended.

For the first 4 months I was extremely happy with the Motorola Moto E Android prepaid phone. Worked perfectly without any glitches that I was aware of. Then I took a trip to Alaska and discovered that my phone was totally useless - absolutely no outgoing or incoming of ANY kind. This phone uses Verizon towers which Alaska has. My husband has an older LG tracfone which worked fine even in the middle of the ocean! I called Tracfone and they assured me that as long as I was in the US my phone should work - NOT!!!! Now, my audio constantly fails for no reason. There is no sound for alarm clock, incoming texts & phone calls & notifications, or video. I've done everything advisable except remove the well-protected battery. Because I've no idea if anyone is calling or texting, or if my alarm will ever ring, this phone has become unreliable. I did discover this is 1 of 7 common issues with this phone that people complain most often about. I would not recommend purchasing this phone as you will have frustrating issues with it in a few months. Since these issues are common to this phone, it would be senseless to accept a replacement of the same phone.

I'm gonna be honest - this is a good phone. But there's a few major issues.

First off, this phone is sold by Tracfone. This wouldn't be a problem, if it weren't for the fact that compared to other carriers, for most people Tracfone is more expensive, when they only have customers because of their 'bargains'. Not to mention, with Tracfone, you'll have storage issues. If you buy this phone as an unlocked phone, and then do the Bring Your Own Phone program (AKA the only confusing part of Tracfone), you'll have 8-16 GB of storage, but with Tracfone you'll get 2.75 GB of storage resulting in only about 950 MB of free storage, so you can only have one or two games. Also, I just want to mention that you should not buy this phone off the Tracfone website, for it's 80 bucks more there.

Then we have the camera. First off, let's talk about the front camera - Oh wait! There isn't one! This is a major issue for many smartphone buyers because for whatever reason people love to take 'selfies'. Not to mention video chat will be awful with this phone. And then there's the rear camera. This camera is a 5 MP and it's on the center, which isn't bad, but with this packaging, most of the time the camera is cracked, which you won't notice until you try to take a picture. I don't think I need to say any more about the camera.

Other than these issues, this overall is a good phone. There's a few minor issues like many Tracfone apps and the battery being unremovable, but I'd say it's not bad, in fact the only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is because it's not the right phone for me, and Tracfone is not the right carrier for me. Overall, if you don't take pictures often and don't play many games or do too much social media, and if you just want a quick phone to go online, call, and text, this phone is perfect for you. But just not for me.

Tracfone's Android offerings continue to get better each year. This Moto E, at less than fifty dollars, really provides some great bang for your buck, while allowing the user to control their bill via Tracfone. The Moto E has some nice heft to it and is made of solid materials including its Gorilla Glass screen. The screen is bright, the call quality clear, and the wifi range is decent. The Moto E runs Kit Kat out of the box and feels pretty snappy for a phone of this price-point. Its also worth mentioning that this phone, and every Android Trac, gets triple values in each bucket. So when you add a 200 "unit" card, you get 600 minutes of call time, 600 texts, and 600 megs of data. And, if you find yourself burning data faster than calling and texting, you can buy data-only cards, though those do not triple.

I also like the fact that you can add a micro SD card to expand your memory for pictures, music, and to shift many apps from the phone's meager memory space. I picked up a 16 gig card here at Amazon, but the phone will accommodate up to 32gb.

Downsides include the somewhat mushy power button and volume rocker, plus the complete lack of any kind of front facing camera. Selfie and Skype addicts, beware. The primary camera is also not the greatest, but its serviceable and does just fine in well lit, outdoor scenarios. The first gen Moto E may not a cutting edge offering, but there's a lot to like in this entry level Android.

My Tracfone Moto E (Motorola XT830C) came with Android 4.4.4 preinstalled, and it is a huge step up from my 3-year-old LG800g. When I researched phones, I simply wanted a phone that:
-- is small enough for my jeans pocket and fairly light to hold,
-- has great call quality,
-- has a camera for emergency use,
-- has a responsive, easy-to-use, easy-to-read touchscreen,
-- has GPS and bluetooth,
-- can use my home wifi for downloading maps,
-- can use my Google Contacts, Google Calendar and Evernote,
-- is inexpensive but well-built,
-- uses Android, and
-- will work with my existing Tracfone (CDMA) plan, which I have had for nearly 10 years.

Moto E met my criteria. My only surprise has been that Tracfone changed my service provider from AT&T to Verizon, which meant I had to re-enroll for several banking alerts. Other than that, it has been great! It is so nice to get Google Calendar and Google Contacts on my phone.

I used Tracfone's 800 number to transfer my number to my new phone, instead of the Internet. Then, while I waited for the Tracfone service to forward from my old phone, I connected the Moto E to my home wifi and logged into my gmail account. Soon, all my apps were downloaded and ready to use. There was way less bloatware than the Samsung tablets have had. I popped the back cover off and installed a 16GB micro SD card (14.78 usable space). Unfortunately, Android 4.4.4 does not let apps write much to an SD card, so it will only be good for photos, music, books and maps.

The power and volume buttons seemed hard to push, but I have learned to press harder. The phone is not as light (5.0 oz) as I would have liked, but it is one of the smallest smartphones and it works with Tracfone. On my home wifi, it is as responsive as my desktop and Samsung Galaxy S 8.4 tablet. I have not tried the mobile data yet because I have it turned off. The phone paired easily with my two cars, two tablets, keyboard and headset.

The screen is remarkably easy to read, and the touchscreen is delightful to use. In fact, I won't add a screen protector because I don't want to change the responsiveness.

Be sure to look for a QR reader app that will work without autofocus. And download the Tracfone app, so you can see your remaining balances and expiration date!

This is a gift for a loved one and replaces an older feature phone (LG840G) from Tracfone. The experience I've had trying to transfer the number from the old phone from the new one is the reason I am giving this Tracfone 4 instead of 5 stars. The problem is that transferring the number from the old phone, which used ATT for service, to the new phone, which uses Verizon, has taken over 2 days thus far. Calls to Tracfone customer service, routed to a non-US location, have been frustrating and useless. I do understand that it must take some time for this to happen. I don't understand why it is taking THIS long. The process has resulted in my loved one (and me) being frustrated rather than excited about the new phone and, given that I'll be leaving in a few hours, they will be left to have to deal with ensuring the phone is eventually activated.. Not a huge deal, but frustrating nonetheless. However, the phone itself truly is impressive, particularly for the cost, and I assume the service will be great if the phone ever is activated.. I'll update to let you know how long it takes.

It does not come with any minutes at all. I guess it's technically true that triple of zero minutes is still zero, but it's still misleading and pretty shady.

Also be advised that battery is not easily replaceable unless you have the phone serviced-cost less to buy a new phone which I'm sure is what they want. Bought an unlocked BLU instead with replaceable battery, 2 sim slots PC connection and better value. Since sim cards are so cheap these days, an unlocked phone is a far better value if you use pay as you go plans like Tracfone.

Moving up the Tracfone phone food chain this is where we are today. Phone #3 or so. The first real smart phone. We have had this phone (two of them) for a year and a half at least. I have never understood how folks were so willing to spend all that money for a big name cell phone, except for a toy.

Since we have had one for so long I'm confident to tell you that if you don't demand the best toys, and highest talk charges this thing is for you. Especially using it in conjunction with WhatsApp, a hundred bucks a year on top of this $19.95 phone gets you plenty of uptime.

Now. Here's the deal. As you know a smartphone is basically a handheld computer with a phone app. The Moto E phone app works as well as any you'll get on the most expensive phones. Sometimes better. It really pulls in the signal. The phone software has all the geegaws you demand to soup up your experience as much as you like. Standard Android stuff.

As a computer. Well, I'm sure the big boy phones work better. The Moto E is not blessed with a whole lot of onboard memory, and the stuff that comes with it, Google, etc. can't be moved to the SD card you'll purchase separately. This means you can only put your very favorite apps on there. You can't junk it up. Still..I have quite a several programs that I like. For normal people, you will have space.

I have never had a problem surfing. For that... it is fine. Fine as rain. And the display is great. GREAT display.

But...I have had crashes with some other programs. This phone is *almost* powerful enough to go mainline big time. It also gets kinda warm with intense computing and the battery goes down pretty quick. So, if it's a computer you favor most, I'd recommend the higher end Tracfone or one of those other companies where you pay 10X to get to play Asteroids and Apesnargles. The phone does work pretty well for a map app, btw, but you'll have to keep it plugged into the charger.

The camera: My last brain dead phone camera took better photos, I think. The photos are OK..but probably not as good as some other phones might give you. If you don't have much of a picture connoisseur about you, don't worry about it. It's good enough. Since it has only a rear facing camera, you'll have to video chat using a mirror. If you haven't used the newer photo tools available with this thing you'll have all the fun.

My assessment is that for the price you could spend five times more and get the same or less. This thing is the king of the cheap phones. You'll be spending 10X-20X more to get significantly better performance.

So, if you need a good phone that will do everything the big boys will do...and one you'll be proud to show your friends...this is it. Unless your pals are geeks they won't know the difference. Get it and be proud. Save a thousand bucks a year.

PS: I'm going to try to add a recent snap for you to see. Note that the trees are just a little indistinct. Just a tad. With such a tiny camera to work with I don't know how much better the big boy phones will do. So, you be the judge. The video function works fine. Hey. I like it.
had problems with phone.

Does not come pre loaded with minutes. You have to buy a plan which defeats the purpose of a go phone. Also there's no customer service support. The number you call is electronic support and it is worthless.
could not get access where i live so they would not activate it si i sent it back
I had to return defective phone

I bought this phone through Tracfone two weeks ago for $129 and it's $89 here.

It's a pretty good phone and IMHO, the best one Tracfone is offering. I previously had a Samsung Galaxy Centura through Tracfone and it has a mind of its own. It starts programs on its own and actually started sequentially-dialing my "contacts" when it was in my pocket.

The Motorola e seems to be a very stable phone due to its more-current Operating System (Android "Kit Kat"). The camera is a little goofy. To take a picture, you touch any place on the image screen vs. a "button" . The camera doesn't have a flash or zoom options although all phone cameras are "digital zoom" which can be done with a photo editor anyway.

It does not have a replaceable battery like many phones do. The battery is encased in the plastic shell. It may be accessible if you're a "hardware type" by removing several small screws although the phone runs risk of being damaged in doing so. I also believe it may be difficult to find the battery. However, for $89.00, one could buy another phone but I suspect by time the battery goes, one would want a newer/more-current phone anyway.

Make sure to get a micro SD card when you purchase it (I got a 32 GB one).

Motorola has an excellent migration software tool called "Motorola Migrate". You load it on your old phone from Google Play and it downloads all of your contacts, WiFi configurations, videos and pictures over wireless WiFi. It also initiates an automatic download of Apps that are on your "old phone" with some exceptions. I found that it skipped a few apps (Waze and my weather app) and I had to manually load them via Play Store.

I love the phone. It's reasonable, reliable and with Tracfone, you get 3X talk, data and texts for the life of the phone. Also note that Tracfone uses Verizon's network for CDMA phones (like this one) so you'll get a reliable network with it.

Doesn't Even SAY It's a Tracfone!
No goofy TF logo or TF sound, but all the benefits of user controlled minutes and data at very reasonable prices, especially for those who use 200 minute/month or less. Kids must love it cause their friends don't know it's a TracFone. I love it because it is easy to use, does tons of things, and hasn't cost any more than the initial $109 I paid for it and the 400-minute/text/MB data card, which tripled to 1200. I've now had it for 5 months and couldn't be happier for all the reasons that many others have already mentioned. It replaced a maddeningly UNsmart ZTE Valet. The camera is just so-so, but OK for snapshots. The screen is quite clear and easy to read-except in sunshine. Sorry that a few folks have had problems, but that seems to happen in all brands.
won't let you use mms without a wifi connection.sucks!was going to get one for the wife,no way...

This phone worked fine given its limitatons for six months. Then suddenly it went into AIRPORT MODE {No, I didn't accidentally
hit Airplane Mode} and it got stuck in that option. That locks out all use of the Internet. I took it to a phone tech and we tried everything to take it out of Airplane Mode.
Apparently this is a common failing of this phone (and others?). Last resort we tried wiping the phone but all that did was wipe
the text but not shift the Airplane Mode. I gave up on it, bit the bullet and bought a Galaxy SkyJ3 TracFone. More money but it
also has a removable battery and SIM card in back. The Moto E has a metal plate preventing you from removing the battery and SIM card which I wanted to do as an attempt to get it out of Airplane Mode.

So, if you buy this MotoE, or have one, do NOT ever put it into Airplane Mode. You may not get out. Keep in mind that I did not put it into Airplane Mode. It slipped into it all on its own. :-(

I've upgraded from the ZTE Valet, and I can easily say that the Moto E is FAR better! Where the Valet had all the capabilities of a smartphone, it was just a constant pain to use. If you're on the fence about this, yeah, get the Moto E. My only complaint is the low storage (4 GB). So I would definitely recommend getting an SD Card. Also, I got a killer deal from shopcelldeals on eBay. I got the Moto E and a year of service (w/1200 minutes) for $100. (You may have to hunt around for a good deal from them because they change them a lot and they have multiple offers for the same phone.) The switchover from the Valet to the Moto E was really easy on Tracfone.

Later-> I ran out of space! I put about 1.5 GB of music and some apps on the phone and that's it. I have a 16 GB SD Card on the way, though. But 4 GBs on the phone??? I suppose Motorola wants the Moto E to be seen as an entry-level phone and steer people towards a more expensive one.

I'm still very impressed with the phone (despite the small storage). It even works as a good eBook reader. And I actually want to use it (in contrast to the ZTE Valet, where I only used it when really needed).

The phone's cable also will not break into a cable for connecting to a computer (another cheap move by Motorola). It is only for recharging the battery. You can buy a separate MicroUSB-to-USB cable, however. Or use a wireless app (such as AirDroid) to move files from a PC to the phone.

I am relatively new to tracfone - so I bought this as a replacement for the LG dynamic (which is an "OK" starter phone - just not a lot of memory and an old android version...) I LOVE this phone. I bought this because I wanted more space to download apps and wanted a phone with a bigger screen. It feels nice in your hand - good weight, sturdy build... this is not a cheap looking or feeling phone. Good sound quality, reception and wifi signal. I love that it has an FM radio in it! I am also impressed by the camera - takes pretty nice pictures. It probably isn't as fancy as some other phones out there, but for tracfone, this has to be one of the better phones to get if on a budget. Price was excellent too! Bought this on sale for $39.99 and I am not regretting it. Transferring my old phone literally was instant. Impressed all the way around.

I've been using Tracfone and its phones for many years. I'm always in search of a better phone. If they offered and iPhone id pony up and pay for the thing but they don't. Prior to purchasing this phone i had the ZTE Valet which at the time was one of the best if you want to call it a smart phone phone they offered. Thats all i can say it in comparison to the Moto E is a dumb slow rendition of a smart phone. The only thing this phone is missing is a forward facing camera which i'd been willing to pay extra for if they offered it. This phone is the perfect size. It's blazing fast and for the money i don't think it can be beat. Gorilla glass is what every touch phone should have on it. I'll keep looking for a higher performance phone but right now this is in my opinion the best Tracfone phone they have to offer. I mean it comes from Motorola which is like the king of wireless information devices.

The phone itself is worth 5 stars. Amazing for the price, especially if you buy with 1200 minutes package, which makes the phone basically free. But: It is a Tracfone. Simply transferring number from old Tracfone to this took a day and a couple of call to support to work out issues. Also, Tracfone Promo codes don't apply to Android devices. I also read if you are a heavy texter non-Android Tracfone's get you more texts for the buck.
In spite of the drawbacks it's worth it for people who don't want an expensive cell plan but want a full featured Android phone (including GPS). I have a Moto G and this is as good in most respects, but the lack of front camera and rear camera flash may be show stoppers for some. The screen is bright and clear. An inexpensive 32G micro SD card will allow the installation of all the apps, music, podcasts and photos that most could ever want. I bought one for my wife and she loves it so far. Maybe not the best choice for low tech folks (they may find moving apps, music and photos the to micro SD card challenging) but if you are familiar at all with Android OS you should be fine with it.

Tracfone has THE WORST customer service. We were trying to add on new air time minutes using a recently purchased 200 minute card with a previous pre-paid phone. I called the customer service line on the back of the phone, reactivated the phone as instructed and entered in the Airtime PIN. The phone was still not working, so I called again, this time to speak with customer service directly. I ended up getting the most obnoxious and rude customer service rep I have ever run across. The Moto E is one of worst smartphones that we have ever owned, out of the 6 smartphones that we've owned. My wife bought this phone less than a year ago, and the entire experience has been very frustrating.

Phone crashes frequently. Only has enough internal memory to hold 1-3 apps. Default apps like Gmail and Google Plus are constantly growing in size, which means you need to uninstall an app or two just to receive updates to system apps. Nearly all internal memory is consumed by the OS, leaving almost nothing for 3rd party apps.

While the phone supports an external SD card, very few apps will allow themselves to be installed on the SD card and the SD card is mostly unused.

As far as I'm concerned the MOST VALUABLE user review rating is from the one who's had the phone for the longest time, and that'll be me, right here, right now, as I make this review. After all.... everyone can say a phone is great, right out of the box, right? It's NEW, so it should be great. BUT....how about over time?? How about as time marches on??

Well, I've now owned this Motorola Moto E phone for 1 year. Here's what I can tell the reader about it:

âºâº The 3 NEGATIVES you NEED to know about:

#1.) The EAR volume, (held up to the ear), while NOT on speaker phone, is too soft & too low, even on the highest setting. In noisy airports, or with the TV going at home, I can't hear the person on the other line, with the phone right up to my ear.

#2.) As for the volume on the speaker phone, I have had it CUT-OUT and short circuit from time to time, to the point where it just does not function at all, like a loose short in it. I have to keep tapping it and tapping it in different spots and hope the speaker volume comes back to life & turns ON again. I've been able to revive it, each time. This has happened several times to me, over 10-12 times during the past 1 year.

#3.) And this negative, is a HUGE blow to those who are wanting to run all kinds of APPS. There is NOT enough internal memory storage space on this phone. Only 4 GB is a horribly low number in today's modern times, in the year 2017 as I write this. All kinds of APPS want to download updates, and new apps require NEW storage space, and there just isn't enough resources all the way around to install all these updates & apps to function.

âºâº The POSITIVES:

I've been able to store and load my own custom ring tones and my own custom notifications sounds on to this phone. Additionally, I can load up all my MP3 music files to this phone, no problem either.

It has a flashing light that'll blink if you had a phone call, text message, or voice mail, so that's a nice touch, without even having to wake it up from a sleep.

You can load-up your own personalized background skin or "wallpaper" to your phone, from any picture. The text messaging has a spell-correct auto function, so if it sees you're misspelling a word, it'll try & correct your typing. That's a nice feature.

The architectural framework installed on this phone is Android Operating System 4.4.4, Kit Kat. This is an obsolete operating system nowadays being several years old, but this is what you get for the much smaller amount of money you're paying for. Internet "data rate" is only 3G, if you have a data plan. I've gotten along by using Wi-Fi, without the purchase of a data plan, and that's been fine for me. In fact, I only am subscribed to text & talk only, unlimited. The talk by command function does not work functionally, and don't expect it to for the little money you pay.

If you are of the older generation, and looking to "just get by" with talking and texting, and don't have a need for pictures or video, nor data useage, nor the demand for lots of apps, either, then this phone will suit you well. Pictures are comparable to 1st generation digital cameras when they first came out. Pictures are NOT good in low-level lighting situations, either. If there's the slightest move of the camera, pictures will come out blurry.

However, if you are an intensive APP's-using person, that requires lots of apps to be downloaded & constantly used and you're heavy in to data usage, forget it. You'll need to SPEND the money and pay over $100 for a quality phone, as the speed & storage space on this phone will curtail your user demands, and you'll get very frustrated & disappointed with this phone in a quick hurry.

-- New Orleanian

The phone has a nice heft to it--it feels solid. But for something that is a communication device--a cell phone--it has a huge drawback. Notification for voicemail alert is a small icon at the very top of the toolbar. A very small icon. It would be easily missed, so a person who relies on voicemail, a person who does not walk around with their phone on a daily basis, uses the phone infrequently--say three times a month--voice mail notification becomes real important--REAL important. And this miniscule notification button just doesn't cut it. And I shouldn't have to rely on installing an app to get appropriate voicemail notification. An app that reduces the phone's security.

The camera is a 5 megapixel front camera--that seems adequate for close up photos; but like all low megapixel cameras--don't expect great clarity with distance shots--like the Golden Gate Bridge.

The best feature is the Tracfone card which gives 60 days service for $19 and 60 minutes of phone calling multiplied times three for 180 minutes with time rolled over when a new card is downloaded before the expiration date of the old card. Again for someone who anticipates using the phone only a few times a month--less than five times--that is a real bargain.

Data cards are available--and the smart phone by android was made for internet web browsing, email, Facebook, Youtube, etc. $9 got 300mb--good for maybe a coupe if weeks, or $19 for 745Mb--good for maybe a month, or $50 for 1 GB--good for maybe a month. Every time the phone is connected to Wi-Fi--there are no deductions from your data plan. So presumably, your data plan could be more flexible than the limitations might suggest.

Having a smartphone without a data plan---without ability to surf the www--is like walking around without clothes--there seems to be something not there in the phone. Is it worth $9 or $19 or $50 to be on the world wide web whilst on the bus? I sure don't think so. But the convenience of having it in certain circumstances makes the smart phone ideal for people who can live without instant connection on the www.

It is more than adequate for surfing the web, for downloading photos, for emailing, for text messaging. But there is a steep learning curve to the machine. Worse--there is no real way to quickly and easily transfer photos from the camera to the computer. Photos can be saved to Google 'MyDrive' or "Picasa"--but that seems a tad cumbersome. And those photos trapped in the camera means they are not readily available for sharing with relatives. it just seems terribly complicated--not really intuitive. (I have seen videos where USB cable can be connected to the phone and computer and photos transferred. The phone has built in 2 GB of memory plus room for a micro SD card--so presumably--the card can be taken out and attached to the computer to retrieve photos--but again cumbersome. I added a 16 Gb memory card which gives plenty of space for photos. I also found it easy to figure out how to go from Facebook to downloading photos for family/friends to view.

A word of warning: the phone out of the box needs to be powered up--plugged in to give it workable energy before it can be activated. Secondly, the phone comes without its cover. And on the back of the phone is the phone's ID number--without that number, the phone cannot be activated. So before putting on the cover, be sure to read the ID and put it somewhere so the phone can be activated. No ID--No activation. And once that cover is put on, it is extremely difficult to get it off.

The phone from Target did not come with an activation card--just to add to the overall annoyance of activation. Out of the box--it offered little in the way of accessories beyond a cord for recharging the phone; the phone will last with little usage for about a day before it needs recharging.

For a person who doesn't anticipate using the phone more than 5 times a month--tops ten times a month; for a phone used for contact with medical professionals--, for a phone where the owner wants flexibility re connection to the WWW, it is handy, economical, efficient. The price at Target was $99 reduced from about $119 normally. In the end--it seems to be a sound purchase.

I receive this phone and tried to activate it with Tracfone. Let's call it a social experiment.

Fate had conspired to deprive me of my iPhone so I decided to go on the cheap with the theory that mobile phone tech had rapidly accelerated so even a cheap phone might be good. A few months after purchase, I have been disabused of this notion.

1) Wish I had Flash!

I thought getting an uber-fast MicroSD card would make up for the lack of internal memory after or a week or two. Well, now I know better and understand why Google's and Samsung's flagship devices don't offer this option â mainly installation to the card is at app-writer's discretion and often times app updates (which are infuriatingly common) will "move" apps back into the anemic 5GB of available space on the phone.

At least the card holds music and photos fine, FWIW...

2) Wish I had a REAL camera.

No digital zoom! It's 2016 FFS! I guess I've learned that a big chunk of a phone's price is the CAMERA functionality!

3) Lag lag lag lag.

On iOS I'd get used to the OS acting as a bouncer and kicking out misbehaving apps. Sure, crash-vanish apps were a problem but at least the phone would keep running smoothly (bar the occasional insta-reboot â whoops, guess someone's app DID write over OS memory!)

With Android on this subpar hardware it is a Confederacy of Lags. You can't possible know why but at times performance crawls and there is no obvious reason.

Using this as a jukebox also made me wish I still had one of my old iPods, sadly.

BOTTOM LINE

Who is this device for?

If you're one of those Millenials who feels the need to shop for someone older and get them a phone, don't bother looking any further than this as you'll be lucky if they use any more than this type of device's limits for functionality.

If you are any younger or used to something with some merit, do not place yourself in bondage to this silly little toy. IOW Gizmodo's review of this model was pretty spot-on.

We wanted something for our son that just had talk and text capabilities that would work on the AT&T network and this one is perfect. He was previously using and iPhone 3G but cracked the screen really bad so this was our solution because we were not going to spend $$$ on a newer iPhone for him to break. We simply took the sim card out of the iPhone an put it in the LG and it worked immediately. No need to even go to the AT&T store. We did run into some problems when we tried to install a micro sd card so he could listen to music but we found a way to fix that. Apparently it's a known issue that this phone will shut down when you try to play music on it. We didn't see that part when researching the phone but it happened to us too. We were so frustrated and about to return the phone when I had an idea. Although the specs say it can support several types of music formats I ran across something on the internet that said it needed to be mp3. I converted all of the music from wma to mp3 and presto! no more problems with the music player. He listened to music all day yesterday and it never shut down on him. I took off one star for this because it doesn't work as advertised.

I wish I hadn't lost my previous 2 phones, neither of which was ever returned. This one has more colorful graphics and a few more features than the previous ones, but doesn't allow me to install my own ringtones (from ZEDGE) as my previous phone did. The AT&T people sneered when I asked them to activate my new Xpression phone, which was discontinued by LG and (according to one sales rep) hasn't been sold by AT&T "in years". AT&T salespeople tried desperately to sell me on a smartphone (which is all they sell now, except for a useless "bare bones" flip phone) but I resisted and they activated my Xpression anyway. I do not need or want a smartphone (which is much more expensive than my LG "dumb" phone [which basically takes and makes calls and messages] and requires a data plan, all of which about doubles what I pay now per month). But if I lose this LG Xpression, can't get another and want to remain with AT&T, I will be stuck. Obviously I intend to keep a closer eye on this phone!

If your looking for a low price phone, then this is a good choice.
I got this for my grandfather, he doesn't really understand a smart phone, and never fully could navigate a flip phone either.
I considered this an affordable happy medium, he can still answer it, and I can keep track of him.
The phone is rather loud for what you would think. It is easy to use.

Pro's are cost, start up time, quick contact access, great standby time on battery, I personally always liked the slider keyboards as well. It made manually adding in all my grandfather's contacts really easy. It also has GPS tracking so I can keep track of my loved ones through the ATT family map.

Con's. I would have preferred a green answer and red disconnect button it's easier for my grandfather. I also prefer the slide out keyboard of the Pantech Crossover. The operating system, you kind of have to either double press or press hard to tap the screen. Also with the internet, it does kind of work. Try and use less graphic oriented websites. You tube actually works. However it reprocesses the image to low resolution and the image is smaller than viewing screen almost like 1" screen. So just listen for the audio on a you tube video.

So if your trying to avoid a flip phone and don't have a lot of money for a smart phone. If you just need something to send and receive calls, take an occasional picture, and send texting, great phone for it's price. I hope LG tries to make an LG Xpression 3 and see what they do.

I recently had a Network Issue with my existing AT&T LG Expression 2 Blue (aka LG LGC410) and in the course of ... ....troubleshooting learned that I, as as End User, was responsible for proving the issue was NOT restricted to Just My Phone and was in fact an actual Network Issue. Lucky for me the reps at the local AT&T store could duplicate the issue on their personal AT&T phones, so The Higher Ups had to investigate the problem. Thankfully it appears to be resolved (for now?).

BUT FROM THIS I LEARNED TWO IMPORTANT THINGS
1) AT&T might try to suggest an "issue" is Your Phone Alone, so having a spare would be Very Useful.
2) AT&T ***no longer carries*** the LGC410 (Dec 2017). So if one wants to buy or replace one of these - tricky.

Purchase
The only "basic phone" available from AT&T circa December 2017 was one flip phone without a keyboard, and sending texts with a flip phone is too backwards even for me. I checked Amazon (of course!) and found several of LGC410s available. I checked back with AT&T support to mention the paradox of "can't buy one if none are available" and was told to check out Amazon (a good idea!). Being a chicken, I decided to go with a "new" (?) phone that was fulfilled by Amazon with fast-free-shipping. Ordered it, and about two days later it arrived. Yea!

Receiving
However, I really can't say if this is/was a "new" phone or not. A smart person (which I am not) would have bought an extra phone back when AT&T still sold them as they aren't that expensive. In Dec 2017, I should be happy that I can still find one of these things. I noticed that Phone #2 didn't arrive in an AT&T box but instead arrived in a generic LG box. Also the battery was pre-installed in Phone #2, and I thought the battery on my 2015 phone was shipped "disconnected" from the phone. But it's been two years and I really can't remember.

Activation ?
I read some of the other posts about their phones "not working" or "reported as stolen" so figured my best bet was to contact AT&T and see if they could check the phone based on it's IMEI number, but was told the only way to confirm whether the phone was Legit or not was to go ahead and activate it. After trekking over to where I had a landline phone, I called them back to give them the info and Rolled The Dice. SUCCESS!
As Phone #2 looks to be alive and not reporting itself as "stolen", I figure I might as well just leave it running as the new Primary Phone and stuff Phone #1 in the box. But I did learn a few extra things in the process (?).

Activation Trivia ??
- It would appear that the only way to see if a phone is "stolen" or not is to activate it
- I thought they would charge me an activation fee, but they didn't (?!?!)
- Was told they should NOT (don't hold your breath) charge an activation fee *IF*
- - - Same kind of phone (and/or)
- - - Phone #2 uses same kind of SIM card as Phone #1
- - - Can call later and ask to be refunded the activation fee
- But I recall being hit with an activation fee when I originally switched to the LGC410
- Both phones at the time looked to use the same kind of SIM card
- Called support to ask to have the $50-ish fee refunded. Was told "no". Got a $25 credit instead. :(
- So cross your fingers and hope for the best! :)

Generic Phone Trivia
The LGC410 is not the most Advanced phone out there, and I had to wipe/erase/reset my phone over the weekend at the... ...suggestion of support. I ended up low-tech hand-writing all contacts onto paper and manually re-entering them (zzz...). Switching phones to test Phone #2 meant I would lose all this info again, and I wanted to be Lazy this time. I noticed I could bulk-copy all the contacts (mostly) to the SIM card as doing it one-by-one kept giving me "data might be lost" messages. I noticed that while one could bulk-copy all the contacts, the fields for the SIM card were limited in length-of-name and only allowed 3 numbers per contact. Adjusted contacts for these limitations, and they were present when I powered up Phone #2. Had a few texts of note from this week (all others lost over the weekend) and Being Lazy opted to save them to the SIM card prior to switching phones. But they only re-appeared after I changed to Standard View for messages.

When all is said and done, this was a pretty satisfactory experience as I now have a "backup phone" should my active one get lost or decide to go swimming. Although AT&T no longer sells these LGC410s in December 2017, I lucked out and was able to get one in a few days from Amazon (yea!), and it looks to be functioning across the board. Not sure if this is a true "new" phone or not, but it looks clean, it works, and it's not being reported as "stolen" - that's good enough for me!

Unrelated: I also learned that you can return your store-bought AT&T phone to the store within fourteen days as part of the Buyer's Remorse Program. But there is a flat-non-negotiable restocking fee of $49.00. A "basic phone" runs about $49.00 at the store, so you can buy a flip phone for $49 and return it for a $49 restocking fee. ($49 - $49 = 0) Err... And this is why I opted to buy the phone on Amazon. :)

Good
Had many issues with the phone, and the worse part was that I loved it. Unresponsive touch screen and once that goes, the buttons that work can only do so much.

This is my current phone with AT&T. It's the best phone I've ever had (I've bought multiple smartphones that glitched so bad out of the box I immediately returned them and bought a flip phone instead). I hate smartphones and don't need to be connected to the internet wherever I am, unlike what most people believe these days. I honestly feel more free not being a slave to facebook and the internet.

At first, I was worried the keypad would be hard to adjust to. I've had a slider phone in the past, and my fingers, despite being pretty small, had a hard time hitting the right keys. On this phone, I've never had that issue. They keypad feels so right to me, I could never go back to touchscreen keypads (they are the bane of my existence). There aren't many usable features on this phone, but I'm assuming if you're looking at this phone to begin with, you're not necessarily looking for a smartphone anyway. Internet doesn't work at all for me. It spends forever trying to load, and when it finally does, it's such a pain to navigate the internet with this. Last few times I even tried the internet (it's been a good few months), it didn't load anything at all and I just gave up. Could be an operating system error, but could also be a service error. Too bad AT&T is so horrible I'll never know for sure. My last slider was the LG Rumor 2 (I'm guessing that's the model just before this one), and the internet worked slow, but fine, so it really might not be this phone after all. BTW, this phone is much better in my opinion than the Rumor 2.

First off, this thing is sturdy as anything. I've spiked this on the ground sooo many times, and even put a small hole in my wall where I threw it once. Immediately after being thrown into the wall, a text came through, like it wasn't affected at all (lucky for me). I have a case and screen protector, and I think these things have helped it hold up as long as it has (I've owned it 1 year and ten months now). You wont find anything this sturdy on a smartphone (when smartphones take a tumble, it messes up with the way it functions over time, and will eventually stop working in a way that you could even use it).

Texting is great. Honestly, the worst part about the messaging system in this is: A) you have to begin an MMS message BEFORE writing something long and drawn-out, otherwise it cuts you off at 160 characters and you need to finish in a whole new text message (it has confused the people I'm texting on many an occasion), and B) you can't save a specific text. There are times I've wanted to lock a message so that it saves when I delete all my other messages, but this isn't an option. You would have to manually delete individual messages around that message, which is unrealistic when you've got 300+ texts to erase. So that's a little disappointing, but not a deal-breaker.

My only problem has really been with calling. Since I bought the phone, occasionally people can't hear my end of the call. It was a VERY rare occurrence at first, but since my phone is getting pretty ragged at this point, it's almost constant. Sometimes it's a problem with AT&T/possibly the other person's service company, but I know at least a good bit of the time it's my phone. I don't/can't use it for calling anymore, so these last 2 months of my contract, I'm paying $50 a month for text, which really hurts to do. However, I work at a restaurant/carry-out, and a LOT of our customers' calls are exactly the same way, and when I answer the phone no one's there, so I do know it's a common service problem. Therefore I don't know how much of that can even be blamed on my phone (I would honestly believe that AT&T does it on purpose for me since I don't have a smartphone, I've had endless problems with them as a company).

Overall, this phone makes me so happy that I don't have a smartphone. I really do think I will buy this exact phone again once I get more money in (I'm leaving my contract and won't get another one for free with an upgrade). If I don't buy this exact phone, it will definitely be a slider phone, but from my experience with this one, this is probably one of the best ones they've ever made.

Good call-and-text phone. This is a basic phone with basic functions. Do not buy this if you are expecting to use the camera as it is only 2MP. This LG is a great non-smartphone. I downgraded to the Xpression2 after I grew tired of paying the high costs of upgrades, data, smartphone fees, etc associated with having the latest fad smartphone. The LG Xpression has phenomenal battery life. I only charge it every 3 or 4 days. Texts are easy to send on the slide-out keyboard. I use the Mobile Web to check weather and news headlines occasionally. I am satisfied with this phone.

"Upgraded" to this phone from the Samsung Flight (original), because my Samsung phone couldn't hold a charge anymore.

First impressions: wasn't impressed at all. This phone is basically the same as the Xpression 1, just different color.

- Interface and icons are not user friendly. On/off buttons are | and O respectively, but they don't tell you that unless you read the manual. Could've just used ON or OFF instead, but I guess they wanted to be difficult. You'll need to download the manual off of LG's website because a regular manual is not included inside the box. Had to look at the manual for explanation of what icons are for what functions, whereas my old Samsung was easy to figure out.

- Address book/contacts sporadically takes a long time to load (sometimes over a minute). Other times it's instant. Does not have a "search" function. For example, if you have a lot of contacts on your phone, you'll have to manually scroll down to the desired name to get the number. With my old phone, you could type in the first letter of the person's name, and it'll show their info.

- Widgets (clock icons, calendar icons, etc) are a complete mess. Good luck trying to position it on your screen. Dragging the icons to the desired position on the screen is a pain. Taking them off screen is even worse. If you like having a clock (digital or analog) on your screen, you'll need to drag the clock icon to the screen. It's fairly large, so if you have personal wallpaper (like a photo) as your background, you'll end up blocking a good chunk of it. It would've been so much easier if they could display the time in the upper right hand corner like most other phones do.

- Screen is slightly distorted/blurry when viewing horizontally. Vertical viewing is fine though.

- Camera sucks. Screen is grainy and blurry when trying to take pictures. My Samsung phone had a 2mp camera as well, but it was much clearer on screen.

- Stored pictures take forever to load.

- Using a stylus pen will not work on this phone.

Bottom line, if you like your old phone, don't "upgrade" to this one unless you really have to.

Edit: Phone says it accepts multimedia messages, but after 1 hour of troubleshooting with AT&T tech support, it apparently doesn't work. Not a deal breaker for me, but with everything else I don't like about this phone, I'm just going to return this phone and try out another one.

Double Edit: I returned this phone and got the Pantech Vybe instead. Here's my review on the Vybe: http://www.amazon.com/review/RL81D0MA0CZT9

First impressions: Much cleaner and user friendly interface over the LG Xpression 2. Icons were labeled, unlike the LG. On/Off buttons were labeled as such, and not | and O. Everything was fairly easy to figure out, without having to read the manual. There's a digital clock at the top right like every other phone (except the Xpression 2). There's a search function in the address book/contacts.

Important note: AT&T says the Pantech Vybe requires a data plan on their website, but it does not. If ordering and any site you buy from requires you to purchase it with a data plan, just call up AT&T and tell them to remove the data plan or put a data block in place.

In short, if you are looking for a basic text messaging phone to upgrade to, I'd definitely give the Pantech Vybe a try over the LG Xpression 2.
Great Product!!

Let's get one thing out of the way first. This is not a smart phone. It is a pretty good feature phone designed to do just about anything that has to do with text. Text! The slide out keyboard is a tad small but it enables me to write notes and text messages with minimal effort. It can do text related tasks from writing and receiving text messages and notes to .... drum roll... reading books on it using it as an e-reader. What? Really! (More on that later.)

I suppose I am a little different than most users because the feature I like best about it has to do with the way it interacts with my Honda Insight's blue tooth Hands Free Link. The phone pairs with my car just fine and I can answer calls by pressing a button on the steering wheel. I love this feature.

But let's get to the text tricks. The built in browser can load text websites just fine, even ones light on images. I read news articles on text formatted websites. NPR has a news site using text only. But my favorite is Inter Press News Service.

More texting abilities: I can log on to Facebook Mobile and check FB messages and even write a FB note if I want. Cross platform notes using FB! It does Twitter too. I can also check my ATT Yahoo email using the built in browser. The browser only does the most simple websites but even so I can check the weather on the accuweather site. The number of text sites and sites with minimal graphics was more than I expected.

The phone has a few other tricks it can do. If you buy a sim card for it you can use it as a good MP3 player. I use the AUX port of my Honda Insight to plug the phone into it and play music through the car's stereo using the phone's music player. (It will take up to a 32 gb sm card.) You will need that size if you start down loading books into it!! Yes, I am getting to that!

The phone's camera is pretty basic, doing 2 mega pixel photos (1600x1200). If your lighting is good you can use the built in editor to adjust the image's levels, color levels, crop, sharpen, and many more tweaks. You can get a passable photo this way. You can also take videos with this phone as well.

You can browse photos on the phone swiping on the touch screen using the photo widget. You can send reduced images while browsing photos, but I discovered a way to upload the full size image to Facebook Messages. Facebook Mobile, via the browser, is the key. Once you have the Facebook website loaded touch the messages option. When you create a new message you have the option to just send a photo and this actually works!! I send photos I have taken with the phone to myself and friends via this function. I about fell off my chair the first time a photo started to upload and completed successfully!!

Because the phone is so basic you cannot pick from a huge bunch of apps. But it has several built into it: Calculator, Calendar to make appointments, Notes function which you can send as text messages or to an email account. It has alarms which you can set.

The phone has a built in voice recorder which can be pretty handy.

A recent feature I came across is number blocking! I use this a lot now. There are a couple of ways to block a number. I save the spam call to my contacts list. Then, I press the settings icon to get me to the screen which shows "Call". It is a green icon. I scroll down to where I see call reject and follow the options.

Ok, about those books. Go to the website BooksInMyPhone.com. They have hundreds of books to download formatted for basic feature phones like this one. Once they are downloaded you install and launch them like you would an app. Who knew a feature phone could be an e-reader?! It is!

No it is not a smart phone. But as a feature phone, it is pretty good for what it is -- especially if you buy a big sim card for it to use for your music and e-books.

I've read many reviews on this thing and it seems to be a hit or miss. My phone works well. I've had it for two years and it still works great. This phone is extremely durable, but whenever you drop it, the battery cover falls off and the phone explodes into 3 pieces (phone, battery, and cover). But the phone itself is fine. It can be extremely slow, especially when you have alot of data like texts or contacts. For awhile, it served as my mp3 player too. It sounds pretty damn good for a basic phone. But then again, I have an awesome pair of headphones. But like I said, it is slow at loading alot of data. I have almost 2000 songs on my 32gb SD card and this phone takes FOREVER to load the damn Artists page. Other than that, it works pretty well. Texting and calling are super basic. My only complaint is that the touch screen is too sensitive and you might accidently end the call during one. And this phone can only hold 500 text messages at a time, so if you're a crazy texter, you'll probably be deleting your messages a couple times a day.

The sound is rather muddy but is improved if you change the setting from "stereo".

The touch screen is very sensitive yet it is more difficult than average to use the touch screen to end a call.

Using the zoom on the camera is quite cumbersome and not user friendly. The settings don't appear until you touch the screen, and then the "slide" is quite small and too close to the other buttons on the touch screen, leading it to close instead of slide. And the zoom isn't that impressive--my 4 year old phone did a better job.

Deleting a photo is easy. Whee.

Texting: well, if you have texted certain contacts recently, it will pull those up immediately but if you want to text someone else, it is a several step process to do that.

Got this phone when it was new and the latest thing before iPhones and smart phones so it's got to be 7-8 years old. Still works perfectly. I'm ordering a replacement battery for the first time. I text about 75-100 texts per day. I don't need camera or camcorder capabilities so I don't use that much. It angers me when I get made fun of for not having a big cumbersome smartphone, but the laughs on them--I only pay $42 a month for an unlimited everything plan for my old phone!! If I want to go online I use my Kindle or tv. Tech I have. I just don't want to waste money on redundancy.

The phone is OK for phone calls but don't try to play music as the phone restarts after each track. ATT replaced the phone twice and Lg has tried to fix it twice and no one will admit that there is a software glitch in the music app. I finally got ATT to agree to give me credit to purchase a replacement phone of another mfg. after 5 months of aggravation dealing with ATT and LG. This came about when I called the cancel line and told ATT to cancel my account.

I have had this phone for about 8 months now; I "upgraded" from an older Samsung that worked great, but had started to malfunction due to age and wear and tear. This phone is terrible. At least 1/3 of the calls I made get dropped due to my phone hitting the hang up on the touch screen, even when the phone is LOCKED and the touch screen is not supposed to work. Furthermore, the texting function is just awful, awful, awful. The phone can only hold about 200 text messages before they all have to be deleted, so I am constantly deleting messages with is a pain and time consuming. Also, in group texts, only the phone number of the sender shows up, even if they are in my phone book, so I never have any clue who is texting me. Furthermore, the threaded messages screen for any particular texting conversation was so idiotically designed that if a message is longer than 4 lines, it is impossible to read the bottom of the message. Only the top can be seen. Good luck guessing what your friends were trying to tell you, because that is what I have had to do. Also, there is no way to open up "saved" message drafts (even though they let you save them), so texts need to be sent right away. Lastly, and perhaps worst of all, this phone constantly makes inadvertent phone calls to random numbers in my phone book, even when the phone is "locked" and the calling function shouldn't work. I have inadvertently called people who I haven't spoken to in years at 3:00 in the morning because of this flaw. This phone is literally the worst. THE WORST.

I've owned a cell since 1993. I've had good, I've had bad. I've had broken. But I've never had a new phone that would qualify as nearly non-functional by design, until I got an LG Xpression 2.

Of course, the primary issue is the touchscreen, which a phone like this shouldn't even have. The touchscreen is both so sensitive that keys press when you hold it up to your ear, yet so insensitive it takes 5-6 presses on the screen to register a function such as, say, selecting the Phone icon. Oh, that's right, this awful thing tries to pretend to be a smartphone, so you actually have to unlock it and select the phone icon at the bottom left. After about 10 seconds of trying, you may even see the keypad come up. But, people today buy things like this because we need, like, a phone, not a wannabe smartphone thingy with a million widgets we don't need - which is why we don't have a smartphone in the first place. But, even if this were to be a half-arsed smartphone, it would need a functional touchscreen, which this does not have. For some widgets, like the calendar, simply touching the screen to select the text entry or time isn't enough - you have to mash the screen for 3-5 seconds before the phone recognizes that you want to input something where you touched.

It doesn't help that widgets only display a page at a time, but that some settings are between "pages". Again, using the calendar as an example, you may be able to fill out the text and the start time of an appointment (if the awful touchscreen will let you), but then you have to swipe down for more options. The end time is between pages, so if you want to select that, you have to flip back and forth between the first and second pages and hope you get it. Actually, don't bother - the screen isn't sensitive enough or accurate enough for that to work.

As for the slide-out keypad. Well, it's decent. Keys are hard. Assuming you can get into text mode (which requires the use of the awful touchscreen) it does the job with no frills. Keep track of how much you type because the phone doesn't tell you how many characters you use or have left. Receiving texts is, of course, extremely cumbersome, because you have to fiddle with an acknowledgement on the touchscreen, even if you're in the habit of sliding out the keypad.

I would also like to point out that my previous phone, also from LG, was the VX9100 Env2. That was a great phone, other than the weirdly-shaped '2' key on the front keypad. Everything made sense. on the Xpression 2, however, nothing does. Why there is a touchscreen on a phone for this type of market makes absolutely zero sense. But, if you're going to put one on, at least put a functional one on.

this is the worst piece of junk own... first off I'm 18 and I'm pretty good with electronics and some of the setting they basically hide. about 2 months into owning this thing the touch screen started failing, if the screen registers a tap at all (odds of that are around 1 in 5 when it feels like it) it will register the tap in the wrong place. you can't send a message without using the touch screen to hit the "send" button, if it does hit the right spot its all laggy. so the phones texting ability suckkkss, so why not call the person? nope, the speaker is low quality and low volume... over all this is the worst phone i have or will ever own, i was ever in an emergency that required the me to use this piece of junk asap it would get me killed..

Oh how I hate this phone. I have even purchased a used older phone to replace it but am back to this one now due to Bluetooth for my motorcycle helmet. The music player shuts the whole phone down when trying to go to the next track. I have sent one phone back just to find the same on the new replacement sent, must be a software glitch. I have almost gotten past hanging up on people with my face, I lock the screen after I answer or dial, but when calling someone it still happens sometimes as it unlocks itself when they answer. Texting isn't too bad, but I'd rather talk to people than text. LG, you guys really dropped the ball on this one, and maybe on purpose to force us all to switch to "smart"phones, but I don't want to pay for data and am stuck with this crap.

I purchased one of these a while back because my LG Expression (red) was worn out. If you like to listen to music on your phone DO NOT BUY this phone. If you try to play a play list or listen to an album it will shut down and reboot your phone. This is a programming flaw. I took it back to the local ATT store and they tried three of their floor models and they all did the same thing. I gave the 2 to someone else in the family and bought another original. The red ones last a long time, even under rough handling.

Screen constantly shuts off during phone calls so that when asked "Press 1 for PC help, 2 for Applications, etc" there is no dialpad, just a black screen.
This phone was foisted upon me by the company I work for; if it were my own phone, I would run it over with my car.

Bought one from the AT&T store, and my son was excited for about 20 minutes before he started complaining that the touch-screen, saying that it started to glitch. The phone kept turning on in his pocket and started dialing people. Then, about a month later, he accidentally dropped it on the floor from about 3 feet. The screen completely broke and had black spots all over it. I would NEVER recommend this phone for anybody.

This phone was sold to me as being able to play music. It will not play music in the "shuffle" mode. It will play 1 - 3 songs and does a reset and shuts off. This is the 3rd one of these I have had (previous ones were replaced by AT&T). I have had this 3rd phone sent to the LG repair facility in Ft. Worth Texas, THREE times. They either cannot or will not fix the phone. The phone is still under warranty.

The repair personnel in Ft. Worth are totally incompetent.

It is too bad I have to even give this thing even 1 star!

I hate this phone. Unfortunately, I'm stuck with it for the time being. You're going to hang up on calls constantly with your ear. It freezes up and has to be restarted ALL THE TIME. This phone is a pain in the butt, but the last regular texting phone anyone makes.

I am thrilled to have a brand new querty slider! I've been searching for quite awhile. I am not an AT&T customer, so learning how to quickly get a contact, etc. The pre-set carrier stuff is a bit of a snag, but having all the other phone features is great. Works very well.
