I'm a young smartphone denier. After a long search, this is the phone for me. It may be the phone for you too, especially if you are willing to use it on AT&T's gophone network OR Airvoice Wireless or other AT&T MVNO, or if you are willing to pay to have it unlocked. You don't have to unlock this phone for it to work on airvoice. 20$ a month for unlimited SMS/MMS/calls. Boom.

------------------
Good things:
------------------
1) Cheap as poo and widely available
-this is self explanatory

2) Is not itself poo
-I have only had this phone for about a week, BUT I'm relatively certain that it will be good for the long haul. I will update this in the future. I considered waiting to write this review until I had owned the phone for longer and could more meaningfully speak to its status as poo or as non-poo, but I wanted to get this review out before the phone was replaced with an updated version (like this one did for the low-level beloved Z431).

3) Typing is good
-the GUI is a little laggy, but the typing is not and the buttons are very very clicky and super satisfying. Easy to press. Yay. One small downside here is that the bottom row of letter keys is shifted a little bit to the left of where they are on most other qwerty phone keyboards, but I became used to it by day two. Bottom line, the experience of sending texts with this phone is very good.

4) Camera is usable in that adorabad kind of way
-it takes videos too!

5) Micro SD storage
-32 gigs. That's like, a lot of space. The music player is totally not bad, the headphone jack is totally normal and works in a notably normal kind of way, and with that much storage you can take serious quantities of 2MP pictures and videos with your adorabad camera. Also this phone has the built in ability to let you record your phone calls (???), so you can do a lot of that too if you, like me, suddenly find the need to do that upon getting this phone.

6) Good reception
-Yep! The reception is just straight-up good. I purchased the motokey ex117 prior to this phone, in my search for a qwerty non-smartphone which I could use on airvoice wireless that was less than 50 dollars, and it had such terrible reception that I could not use it inside my apartment (but if I walked outside it was fine). My apartment is not a "dead zone". Now, I'm a 25 year old non-smartphone-user writing a 5 star review for a flipping gophone on amazon dot com, clearly my expectations are not exactly stratospheric but it's 2015 and I need my phone to work *inside my home*.

7) Text messaging "app" displays your exchanges in conversation mode
-like a smartphone. this is very nice. like, you can see your texts and your friend's responses all on the same screen. 2015.

8) Allows for separate ring, vibrate, and silent modes.
-OK now this might just be me but I want ALL THREE of those effing modes and I did not realize how important it was to me until I went on this cheap feature-phone rampage and realized how many of them don't let you do this easily. With this phone you just set the "Meeting" profile to vibrate only, and then you can toggle between ringing and silent with the volume rocker and flip to vibrate by holding down the space bar. Nice.

9) Calendar seems totally usable
-I don't use it myself because I carry a paper planner (lol), but I messed around with it a bit and it is pretty intuitive and has "week" display mode.

----------------
Bad things:
----------------
1) The whole phone locking situation
-This is, in my opinion, the greatest downfall of this phone. You CAN lock the phone so that it can't push buttons in your pocket and butt dial your thesis advisor, but it is implemented very poorly. When locked in this manner, pressing any of the normal buttons on the front of the phone will not do anything (unless you press the two buttons in succession which unlock the phone), BUT pressing the dedicated power button on the top-right side of the phone, *one time*, UNLOCKS THE PHONE SO THAT ALL THE BUTTONS CAN BE PRESSED. This is, clearly, a serious design flaw. I have not found any way around it, and if someone else has please let me know and I will update this.

Also on the phone locking, when the phone is locked you are still able to press a strange "SOS" key which allows you to dial the pre-programmed emergency numbers (911 and 112. no you cannot remove them from the phonebook. Yes, very annoying.) without unlocking the phone. This means that you could potentially butt-dial 911. However, I think it would be pretty hard to do this because of how many menus your butt would have to accurately navigate.

This phone does have a timed auto-lock that you can set, which makes all of this a little less bad. But overall, it's a pretty annoying problem. For thirty dollars though, I will deal. It's not a dealbreaker for me because I usually carry my phone in a bag where it is not prone to having buttons pressed, but for someone else this could be a dealbreaker.

2) You can't change the default APN settings for the web browser or email.
-Essentially, this means that you can't use data on this phone unless you are using the GoPhone or AT&T network. So for example, if you got this phone and wanted to use it with Straight Talk as your provider (which as far as I know you can in fact do without unlocking this phone), you would not be able to get on the internet or receive email with this phone even if your plan includes a little data. For me, this does not matter because I have no interest in being able to browse the internet or receive emails on this phone. For you, it might be a dealbreaker.

Notably, multimedia messaging does not suffer from this same problem and it was very easy to set up MMS on Airvoice's network for me. Unlimited pics. Nice.

---

Sooooooo ya! That's my feels overall. I like this phone because it's widely available and super cheap. I like typing on it A LOT. I have a weirdly profound love for the camera. The GUI is laggy but not so laggy that it will make you angry. I would definitely recommend this to anyone else trying to get or stay off the smartphone train who is willing to use this phone on AT&T or Airvoice or another AT&T MVNO or is willing to pay to have it unlocked.

Just what I wanted for my 13 y.o. who's addicted to YouTube and games. I didn't want him to have a smart phone, but I was finding more and more times when I wanted to be able to reach him (e.g.: this summer when he's out and about in the neighborhood, or when pick-up/drop-off changes occur). I didn't use any of the pre-paid plans that came with the phone because they were all more expensive than our Friends and Family plan. So I just headed over to the AT&T store and had them add this phone to our plan. The only "problem" with this phone is that I thought he'd only be able to text and talk, but he can, in fact, access the Internet and stream videos and music. So we still had to battle about that (and he has to turn it in at night).

I purchased this phone for my teenager because I wanted a phone that would discourage constant use of internet. I just wanted something he could use to call and text, and this phone fits this requirement perfectly. Just order and activate a standard SIM card from your phone carrier, pop it in, and the phone works perfectly. The web browser on this phone is old school, and quite frankly terrible, and there are no apps, and no wifi - perfect for a teenager you don't want wasting time playing games and watching youtube all day on his phone. Aside from the really poor web browser, the only other way to use data on this phone is by sending/receiving photo texts. Plus, I bought this phone new dirt cheap. If he loses the phone, he can spend his own money buying an inexpensive replacement.

I bought this phone 3 times in the last 3-ish years. It's a simple, well designed, cheap little phone. As opposed to the flip phones now offered in stores that have 3 letters per key, which is unacceptable for texting, and have a confusing, cumbersome interface. This one has one letter per key and I have had no complaints on it's usability.

Of the 3, one I lost and 2 broke. (so, have a plan for your contacts). but it is that much better than the other non-smart options, so I will keep buying it.

I do miss the camera of smart phones. especially because I have kids. The trade-off is that I am present when I am with my kids. :)

I have the $25/month plan with Cricket!

This phone is working well for my 9th grader. Even though it is marketed as a prepaid phone, I was able to add it to my existing AT&T plan as a second line. I like that my child can call or text me as needed since now that he is in high school sometimes his after school plans change and he needs a ride at a different time. However I did not want him to have a full featured smart phone that would allow unlimited access to internet browsing and downloading apps, as we restrict his usage to certain times and content. While this phone does have a web browser as a feature, the screen size and usability are such that he is not interested in using it. He also can't download apps we'd rather he not be involved with (Snapchat etc.). Imo this is a great phone option if you are strict in your family about internet usage but you need to provide your child a way to call & text. And finally, at this price point it's not that painful to replace if it gets lost or broken.

UPDATE: This phone is still working out great for us. It was lost about halfway through the school year and we replaced it with the same model. I also stuck a Tile Mate on the back of it which has helped a LOT with keeping track of where it is. Granted the Tile costs almost as much as the phone but it is well worth it in the daily "where's my phone" aggravation it saves. I've attached some pictures of the phone with the Tile. My son didn't like the "bump" in the profile much at first, but then he really liked how easy it is to find.

Got it for my 11 year old. Full keyboard, camera for pictures and video. No option for wifi, but that's okay... we don't want him to have full Internet access yet anyway. Does have ability for data (web, sending pictures) but that comes through your carrier.

Great upgrade to Z431! I don't remember why I didn't buy this phone when I initially dumbgraded from my Android phone, but the extra speed and fewer glitches make this phone a much better choice. The only unfortunate defect is that the power button instantly unlocks the phone, like a screen door on a submarine! Haven't butt-dialed 911 yet, and hopefully with a case on it the button will get pressed less often. The keyboard feels noticeably better than the older model too. If I drown it in a river like I did my Z431, I'll be getting another one of the same.

This phone is great and serves its purpose of texting SMS and MMS and making phone calls. I've yet to figure out how to set up voicemail, and the accompanying guides are no help. As of May 2018 it works on AT&T's network without issue. The AT&T store employees had no idea how to set this up and believed it would no longer work because "it isn't a flip phone" like the various Samsung Go Phones still for sale, exhibiting their lack of knowledge of phone basics. You need to keep the microSIM that comes with this so that the AT&T store can scan the SIM and phone to switch from your previous contract phone. Battery life with a few calls and texts a day is still 4-6 days before getting dire.

Of course would still work with Go Phone. Also works with Airvoice wireless.

Will update with durability issues and otherwise if they present.

I got so tired of spending good money on phones that inevitably would suffer software issues or I would accidentally drown them. When my blackberry went loco, I was so frustrated that I refused to spend more then $30 on a new phone! I checked this one out at Walmart (for that price), then ordered it here for half the cost. I use mine for music more than anything, and it works very well for that except it is VERY slow to rewind or fast forward (frustrating for audiobooks.) I don't text, but I do make notes for myself and the qwerty works fine for that. The battery lasts me MOST of the day if I'm using the music function constantly. Otherwise if I just use it to talk, I get a few days out of it. The alarms work very well, and I had no trouble setting up different ring tones and setting pictures for my contacts. One word of warning, though...I could never get it to communicate with my computer without a micro-sd card! I hooked it up and it downloaded some device driver, but it would never do anything else (wouldn't show up to my computer at all.) So I had to buy a micro-sd card for all of my music and my ringtones...but I literally plugged in the card and the phone immediately recognized it. I don't have data, so I don't know if I could have downloaded music or not, but you can't transfer files from your computer to your phone WITHOUT a micro-sd card in the phone. I had an AT&T SIM card, and I plugged it into the phone and was immediately up and running. I highly recommend this phone if you're tired of breaking the bank for new phones all the time!

I bought this to replace a dying iPhone 5 because I wanted smaller size, longer battery life, fewer distractions and convenient texting with my Airvoice account. It should meet my needs but has a few glaring faults and I am planning to get a flip phone or smart phone.

PROS:
Good sound quality
Put in your Airvoice SIM in and it is ready to go - no fussing
A nano-SIM works fine - it wedges in tight enough that I've never had to adjust it
Full keyboard is good - keys are at the minimum useful size and font
I do not waste time on this phone!

CONS:
Latest texts are displayed out of order in conversations! This can be confusing because you can't instantly see whether you replied last or the other party did. Plus, when a text is split into multiples and has long parts they are not completely displayed, so you get odd jumbles of sentence fragments and have to click into them to see what they say.
LOCKING IS IDIOTIC: I sent a bunch of blank or meaningless texts to people because the keys are easily depressed when it's in my front pocket. On the home screen it also accepts any # presses, so eventually it butt dials. Think the solution is to turn on locking? Get ready to butt dial 911. When locked it still allows emergency dialing. Not a problem - what is the chance you will randomly dial 911 or 112? Turns out it's 100% because the only key presses it accepts are 9 (followed by 1 and then 1) or 1 (followed by 1 and 2). So if it's locked in your pocket and eventually accumulates "soigh9hgh4w5hj463h j kj1ji41" it will dial 911. (Thanks to this phone I learned that if you hang up on 911 before they answer they will call you back.) I turned locking off - I'd rather look like an idiot to my friends than waste the operator's time.
Battery is mediocre - lasts a few days with an hour or two of talking, even when left at my house and I haven't set up wi-fi.
MVNO use is tricky - apps (e-mail, address book, navigation...) are set up for AT&T so they don't work and cannot be removed. I haven't figured out how to use Airvoice data or wi-fi.
Notable delay in receiving key input - so you need to type slowly or you'll double type because you think it wasn't received.
Not all incoming calls show up on recent calls list.
T9 texting seems slower than just typing it all out. It doesn't even add a space after you choose a word, so you need to switch between the cursor and keyboard too much.
Looks like you need to use an SD card and card reader to transfer files (photos, music) to and from a Mac - it's not set up to communicate through USB.

I want a small Airvoice-compatible phone that I can keep in my pocket, don't need to recharge frequently, is good for texting. This phone is marginal on all those counts, so I need to look for a replacement.

Was paying $200 a month on a Verizon smartphone. made a financial decision so I bought this phone and turned off my old smart phone. I now pay $30 a month for unlimited talk and text and just use the old phone on wifi for data. this phone is really lightweight and easy to use. hold a charge for a really long time. good buy

I unlocked this phone to use it with Metro PCS. It allows incoming and outgoing calls on the network. It allows incoming and outgoing text messages. However, all the other features do not work. It does not receive pictures via text. The internet browser does not work. I contacted my provider and At&t. Neither was able to help. It is okay with me though, as I got this as a back up for my teenager when she is grounded from modern technology. I don't want her to be without communication in case of an emergency. I just need her to be grounded from all the perks of a smartphone. She thinks it is torture so mission accomplished. I'm sure all the features will be available to you if you are on the At&t network. The keys on the keypad are very tiny. She and I both have petite hands and it was still a little uncomfortable texting.

This has two real improvements over its predecessor. You can dim the display like a smartphone, and a micro sim can be positioned to work without using an adapter.

Otherwise the previous Z431 has a higher capacity battery and its less glossy keyboard is more readable. But either are a nice alternative to a smartphone--better than earlier similar ones from ZTE as java apps can be installed.

Before I broke down and got a smartphone, I had several phones like this, and the ZTE Txtm8 3g was the best. The Altair and Altair 2 are good successors.

One quibble I have is that the Amazon entry calls it the Altair 2, but I don't see any reference to the AT&T version by that name, just the Cricket version. That led to some confusion where a vendor listed a Cricket Z433 on this ad.

This phone is nice. I like that it is relatively basic but still allows texting, video recording, and photo taking. My only complaint is that the phone doesn't stay charged for very long. I am not very active with the phone. Days go by where I barely make a phone call. Some days I text only 5 times and that shouldn't drain the phone as much as it does.

The Go Phone is now partly superseded in AT&T world. You MUST go to an AT&T retail store to get it activated: they will use a new SIM card, not the one included with the phone. The 10 cents per minute prepaid no longer exists: there is only a 25 cents per minute choice. In our case, it is not a big deal, as my grandson will only use it for carrying when we are out in public together. We paid a full year for $100, which equals $8.33 a month, and we will probably never use enough minutes to spend the money out anyway.

Purchased for my father (70 years old) to use on our family plan. Just swapped sim cards and everything was set-up automatically. Works for what he wants, would recommend for someone who does not need the internet and only occasionally texts. Very similar in user-interface/functionality to the original BlackBerry phones. Better value than a Jitterbug.

This is a great phone for a great price. I got this as a work phone, and for calling and texting it works perfectly. As I am sick of being pushed into the overpriced smartphone plans and phones, which are of terrible quality, I will likely move to buy another one of these once my iphones battery calls it quits.

I will never buy a ZTE phone again. I had this phone less than 60 days before it started powering down all the time. ZTE doesn't warranty these phones so I guess it's just a big gamble. I just went with LG. Paid a few bucks more but it has a warranty. Buy at your own risk!

You cant buy this product in the store anymore! Now ATT is forcing you to have a smart phone. This is perfect for my mother in law who doesnt want to use a smart phone at all. This was a great price for this product as well.

This phone is unusable. Doing simple functions is very slow and the OS constantly freezes, even during typing. I've owned phones that were purchased 10 years ago that have snappier interfaces than this. Does not even perform adequately as a basic texting device. Keep shopping, this isn't the phone you want.

arrived before or within the estimated delivery; came new in box with charger and sim card and just needs an at&t prepaid phone plan to be activated; no actual problems

update : charger quit working after using it less than five times. i had to get a new charger, but the phone does still charge.

I wanted a phone with a qwerty keyboard that my kid could use to text me short functional messages ("come pick me up" or "can I do xyz after school?") or call in an emergency. I was specifically trying to avoid smart phones, but basic flip phones were not an option because they don't have a keyboard. This was basically the only phone that checked all the boxes. Add a basic airvoicewireless plan, and you're good to go. After a few months, still loving this little phone.

This is a great phone if you are looking for something simple. I love that this phone does not have Wifi and with ATT you can choose not to have data. This is perfect for anyone who does not want internet on their phone. You can call, text and take photos. It covers all the basics and gets the job done. For those like me who do not wish to have a smart phone this is a great option. I had no problem activating this phone within a few minutes.

This is a great starter phone for a youth. Or a great phone for the person who just wants to call and text. I had this phone for many years before upgrading to a smartphone. I ordered this for one of my children so they could have a line of communication, yet if he broke it or lost it, no huge loss. Keys are small, so someone with larger fingers might not like it. It was durable and worked nicely.

I have two teen daughters that need to be able to communicate with me (and others) via text or talk but they don't need a smart phone. (They may think otherwise. :) ) Anyway, we had one of these for years and it finally got flaky and we bought two more. They can take pictures too. Not smartphone quality, but hey, when I was a teen I would have loved to be able to take pictures whenever I wanted even if the quality wasn't amazing.

I like the Blackberry-style keyboard standard phones for texting, so when my Samsung wore out I got this as a replacement. Nothing but trouble from the start: 1) Wouldn't recognize my newly-created ATT account, 2) Had to go to the ATT store to activate, 3) After setting the auto screen-lock for 60 sec, it would not respond to the unlock key press sequence, and finally 4) after 3 weeks of trying to set it up and failing, the vendor "Speed Guaranteed" refused to exchange, saying the return/exchange period had expired. My experience with this phone was a waste of time and much frustration.

This is a $12 phone. Can't believe I paid $30.00 for it. Cheap. I wanted a sturdy basic phone but this is like a toy. navigation isn't that intuitive at first and I am used to these types of phones.

UPDATE: The audio/sound stopped working. no ringtones, message alert tones or warning sounds. I've only started using it less than two weeks ago. I have a return label printed but I can't be without a phone. Dissapointed. This phone is literally worth about 10 bucks

Love this phone! Simple and straightforward - got the AT&T plan that for $25.00 every 3 months lets you whittle away at it .25 for a call - and 10 cents per text - it's a perfectly functional phone with a small footprint - a steal for $20.00 - I'd get another one in a heartbeat

I don't think my kids need yet ANOTHER way to be connected to the internet, so this phone is the answer. We've gone through a few of these phones though. One just died, another had battery issues. But for a kid who doesn't need a smartphone, it's cheap and they can text on it. Perfect.

I used this phone so I could move my 10 cents a minute plan from an old school flip phone to something more modern. Glad to say it worked, I didn't think it would because that plan doesn't allow you to use any internet features. The keyboard is small but you will get used to it quickly, and it has long battery life, I usually go for two and a half days before it needs another charge, sometimes longer. It looks sleek and it gets the job done. Speaker quality is top tier as well. And you can lock the keypad to prevent pocket dialing (which you should do immediately because 911 is in the contacts list!).

The phone has had a lot of glitches since we got it. I sort of expected it though, given how cheap it was. We ended up replacing it with another phone that was only about ten bucks more expensive and that phone has been great. I would suggest this phone for a starter phone for a younger child, rather than some iphone or whatever, but definitely not for a teen or an adult.

I have smart phones for my personal use but use this phone as my phone for my business. I had a flip-phone before this one and it was strong and durable ...It just was old and quit working so I had to look for a replacement. I was going to buy the same phone I had before but this one was cheaper so I decided to go with this one instead (yes, I was being cheap lol). I don't do any business by text so the texting pad isn't useful to me. It's not a terrible little phone but the buttons are a bit hesitant when you press them while on the phone (like when checking voicemail, etc). The buttons and numbers are also super tiny. Took me a little while to get used to it.

All in all, again, it's not a terrible phone
It does what it's supposed to, no problems with it ...I would just much rather prefer the flip-phone.
great for my mother in law just learning to use a smart phone and learning how to text. I had one in the past and it was great!
A nice cheap phone for a 9yo without any fancy features.

This phone looked good for our needs, but it failed almost immediately when my daughter finally got around to using it. Battery ran out after 10-15 minutes and needed a recharge, and then failed altogether after very few uses. The seller, Abilee Enterprises, cited the 30-day Amazon return policy when informed that they had sold us a defective product -- fair enough, as we had waiting longer than that to even open the product, but I won't be purchasing anything else from them given that they are sending out broken stuff and taking no responsibility for it. :-(

BRAND new no issues. I bought this for my daughter for basic talk and text. Definitely cheaper than buying her another phone through the att store. A flip phone was going to cost me $60, all I did was get this one and change out the SIM card with her old one. Works fine, she loves it.

My phone was defective. It wouldn't charge or turn on. I spent an hour on the phone with AT&T. AT&T told me that the number written on the back of this phone was not a valid number and that the phone could not be replaced. Are these phones knock-off with invalid IME numbers? Now I have to purchase a replacement phone with no help from the manufacturer.
Button are very small !! They are hard to see and almost impossible to just hit one at a time. I returned item.

This phone is fit for a younger crowd. Got it for my daughter that is 11 because she cracked the screen on her other phone and I wasnât ready to spend big bucks on another smart phone. This is a basic phone perfectly fit for a child! Or someone that just wants the super basic cellphone.

It works great with att and anothers att mvno like redpocket mobile and air voice wireless but keep in mind you can only call and text under this mvnos att company because you cannot change APN settings and you will not get able to access internet or web browser however the cell is very good for a basic phone,goog battery life just butons to small so not good for elderly
Perfect basic messaging phone without wifi capabilities. Great for a grounded 16yr old boy that needs to communicate with his parents and no one else!

I bought two of these phones brand new and they came with paperwork saying they had a one-year warranty. The ear speaker went after five weeks on one phone. Wrote Blutek Intl who sold it to me - crickets! Never even contacted me. Then I found ZTE website online and emailed back and forth and today was told that this is an "out of market" phone and ZTE will not honor the warranty paperwork that is sold with the new phone. They wanted $99.00 to repair the phone - way more than I paid for it. RIP OFF! DO NOT BUY THIS PHONE AS THE SELLER WILL NOT SUPPORT IT AND THE MANUFACTURER WILL NOT EITHER.
got this as our home phone (since we aren't about to pay Spectrum for theirs) so the kids have a way to call/text without stealing our expensive phones. simple, easy to use. good for small fingers.
Works perfect. I use this phone to seamlessly replace my old Z431 AT&T Go Phone. The only thing that was lost is the call log from my old phone.

This phone comes with no games or anything fancy. It's JUST a basic phone, NOT a smartphone. Exactly what I was looking for.

Update: dropped to a 3 star because the phone is only a year old and has stopped charging. When plugged in it says charging, but had been plugged in for 3 days and the phone won't power on. Not pleased.

My 10 year old said she wanted a phone...so we got her this. Sound is ok, battery lasts forever...pictures are dismal and she cant figure out how to download games or music, but as a phone its works and the battery lasts forever.

This phone was exactly what I wanted. It is a basic phone with a qwerty keyboard. I didn't need all the bells and whistles of a smart/android phone. I have the $30 monthly plan for unlimited talk and text, no data. But you can get data if you want. Camera works good, just small view.

The keyboard works wonderfully and the screen is big and bright. Those things being established IT'S SUPER SLOW. I know, it's only a $30 dollar phone, but it's like waiting for bad loading screens on a video game. Also, the reception isn't nearly as good as the flip phone this was supposed to replace. I went back to the flip phone.

GREAT price, great phone! I'd been using flip phones, and cheapo phones... and while this phone is thrifty too it looks AMAZING and it works so much better than any other phone in it's price-point. Don't wait, upgrade to this phone. I can't believe I waited, when this was out there.
This is great phone, I put my sim card right in and it fired up just like my old one.

A great "no frills" phone at this price. Similar to the BlackBerry in its day, but at a much lower cost. Not meant as a substitute for a smart phone, but not every phone I have needs to have those capabilities.
This is just about the only phone you can get which allows text messaging , but is not a smartphone. I don't use a smartphone but I do text a lot and that is impossible with a flip phone.

I purchased this because I wanted a dumb phone with threaded group texting capability despite being touted as a dumb phone with great texting ability... this does not do that. Other than that, it works fine and the qwerty keyboard is nice.

This phone was bought for Talk and Text. Has a neat keyboard. The Camera takes Awful pictures and the Video length is very short. My husband is a Shutterbug. Not a good choice for people who like to take photos.

Works well for the money. If you want talk and text and use texting quite a bit, it is a good step up from a flip phone. I bought this and went to the AT&T store and they got me hooked up with a good plan that fits this. The other stores could not do as well. I do not regret the purchase.

No frills. Simple phone that works very well. I had to replace my first phone after being left out in the rain. I bought this model. I had to replace the new phone because my dog ate it. I ordered the same phone because I love it. I actually bought 2 phones because of the sale price. If you don't need bells and whistles, this is a great phone.
I had the phone set up yesterday and it stopped working n won't comeback on
is not the best but it works and is quite durable and i like the full keyboard

I like my phones simple and functional. This is my second one of these, the first ended up being dropped countless times and still work fine and stayed working until I managed to launder it.
This one is great, though more pricey than the first- oh well can't have everything.
Never worked properly. Didn't keep a charge. Constantly dropped calls.
Arrived fast, inserted SIM card, and work perfect! Great battery life!!!

My child keeps breaking his phones so I was looking for an inexpensive replacement phone. This phone has actually lasted the longest. The sound quality is good, the size small and convenient. Great replacement phone for teenager that isn't careful with cell phones.

This phone works great! I'm a student in college, and I was getting tired of using a smartphone ineffectively. AKA being distracted. For real, I haven't had a phone like this in almost 10 years, and this is just great! Does all the basics you'd expect a phone to do.
I've had this for almost a month. I switched over from Sprint, and AT&T's customer service was very helpful in getting everything switched. If you're converting from an iPhone, you may need to call customer service, because iMessage gets all weird with your texts, and you will still receive texts on your iPhone. AT&T will do something on the back-end to resolve this.
The pre-loaded wallpaper is eh, but I got a prepaid plan that came w/ 1 gig so you can easily download an image that fits your style.
The texting was strange, but fun to use! It's strange because pushing physical buttons is something I've had to get used to. Another thing about texting is that when you are in a group text, you will not receive the messages in a group. The messages will come in from each individual person in a separate text. I've just let people know that I will reply to them individually from group texts. Another downside to the texting is that you can't see picture texts clearly. The screen is too small to read screenshots people send, but one way to fix this is to save the photo to your phone, and then view it in your pics. Of course that's a pain, but it works most of the time.
Another strange thing I've had to watch out is BUTT DIALING. I've butt dialed/texted people about 3-4 times this month, so you have to be conscious of where you're putting your phone.
Overall, this phone is great. The call quality is GREAT. I've asked my friends if they can hear a difference, and they have all said no.
There aren't any games on this phone (why would you need them anyway?), but it does have useful tools like a calculator, tip calculator, stop watch, notes, and a world clock.
You can have different profile settings, such as silent mode, or low-high volume alerts.
OH, and the battery is GREAT. I can make multiple phone calls, text a lot, and use other things and I go 3 or 4 days in between charges!

Highly recommend this phone if you're tired of being distracted from a smartphone, or you just need a simple phone.
Very slow phone.
Good sturdy cheap first phone for teen.
This ZTE Z432 ATT Go Phone is an economical, well-designed little basic phone that works really well.
The buttons are very small, my husband's fingers are too big to use this phone. But I love it. Makes texting much easier. It's very compact so it fits in my wristlet wallet that I carry.

bought it for my mom who refuses to get a smart phone. we have cricket but cricket discontinued these phones. All i did was insert my cricket card and started working. Super simple and kept my mom happy.
downgraded from smart phone, this is perfect, durable, easy to type, texting is in conversation threads

wonderful buy! came in two days with prime and had easy set up. inserted sim card in phone and turned on, worked so easily. would recommend to anyone. I used this as a replacement phone that I had a contract with and all I had to do was go to att and get a new sim card.
Nice phone to use while traveling. Not expensive and works great.
Obviously a cheap phone, but was pretty hard to use. Group texting is a real pain on it if not down next to impossible, and I had a bunch of problems with the keyboard keys malfunctioning.

The phone works well, feels fine, and is durable. My only gripe was in the packaging. There is literally nowhere from which to open it. It can't be cut easily, and it is really sharp. Other than that however, this is a solid phone.
Exactly what I wanted: a cheap dumb phone with a physical keyboard. My SIM card didn't fit, but I was able to go to the at&t store and have them make me a new one that fit, free of charge.
This phone has been perfect for me. It's been very easy to set up, very easy to use, and I'd buy it again!
Looking for a cost efficient replacement for my secondary phone. Does what I need.

This is by-far the best feature phone (non-smart phone) that I have ever used or seen, especially for the price! If you are looking for a low-cost, durable, high-quality phone, and you don't want to spend the money on a smart phone, then this is the phone to purchase.

Sound is loud enough and very clear, got it for my dad he is hard of hearing and always talks on speaker. He also likes the buttons a lot more then a touch phone. Very easy to use would buy again for him.
Donât buy you canât activate the phone the sim is out of date. Youâll need to buy a new one. Then want to charge 50 a month for service. A contract is cheaper.
The key pad was not right for me. Too many letters !!!!! Too small.
Perfect for a kids phone.
Will not stay on. Has full charge. Just wonât work
Using this with Cricket and it's working great after months of use and even being thrown by our toddler!
Works perfect for my mother, the full keyboard really helps for texting.
Very nice phones! They do what theyâre supposed to!
Bought this phone in January worked good at first but of course now that the retun period is over the speaker has blown and you can't hear it ring.
By far the best qwerty phone I've used.
Great started phone for my daughter, menu navigation IS confusing though.

What a way to end an era of cellphones â supported for years by heavy SMS and e-mail users, the Z432 is a culmination of those preferences. However demands have changed, at least according to what phone manufactures have said and now this particular phone might well be remembered as the last that will stand out amid the ubiquitous tablet-type phones sold by every major carrier â itâs a sad end for phones with the QWERTY keyboard.

The ZTE Z432 is (perhaps) one of the last of the feature phones with a distinct QWERTY keyboard and applications to use little more beyond the most inexpensive voice-only phones offered to senior citizens. A little bit larger than a credit card and thicker than stack of post-it notes, it prominently features a modified QWERTY keyboard and camera with an image quality of webcam from five years ago. On the software side, It has a messaging application, internet browser, music player, scheduling calendar, and address book. For the sophistication and features, the Z432 rivals, in simplicity, your average discounted flip phones.

Its amazing just how quickly a cellphone can age though. I bought this phone primarily as a replacement my MP3 player and secondary use a phone â a unexpectedly good decision considering the first hand experience I would have with it. Second in cost only to flip phone, the Z432 has since been crippled by AT&T in a tacit planned obsolescence. The installed AT&T e-mail client was discontinued August 2015 rendering unusable to receive and reply to e-mails. On the AT&T support page, they suggest to use the internet browser (Netfront 4.2) but it constantly crashes with trying to load and display any major webpage â when does load a page, its like browsing in Internet Explorer 6. The AT&T Navigator â a GPS-type driving direction application - is not included under any of AT&T prepaid plans and requires an additional $9.99 a month on top of whatever gophone plan you purchase. Even my decision to use it as a MP3 player is questionable â there seems to be no way to synchronize my collection of MP3s and playlists than to do it all on the phone. On the other hand, the phone does have a bluetooth feature to connect my wireless headphones and serves a mediocre player.

There is a reason why you can get this phone so inexpensively â actually I listed more than one reason. While technically outdated in several ways, that simplicity works to the advantage of the phone user needing a no-frills phone â the sound quality is loud and clear, and the QWERTY keyboard is more responsive than any software keyboard. According to the documentation, it has a four and half hour talk time and ten-day standby battery life for the critical moments you cannot have your phone die on you. As an MP3 player, it features what you expect from a generic player with other things like being able to search by typing what you are looking for. This is a is a solid phone - AT&T gophone plans start as little as 25Â¢ a minute for local calls to $60 month unlimited text, voice, and data ensuring that by either text or voice, people can get in contact with you without budget busting contracts.

Having unfortunately bought 2 ZTE phones, I came to the conclusion ZTEs are the worst phones ever foisted off on the public. They won't hold a charge, despite having a large battery and thus need to be kept on a charger all the time. Their software is so bad, they include a reboot feature when it locks up, as both did. I bought a decent phone, broke both my ZTE's in half, and tossed them in the trash. If I could give a negative 5 stars, I would.

Ugh. I wanted to love it. I'm downsizing and disconnecting a little because I am a bit too attached to technology and it was causing me some problems. I decided to try this phone but it is going back to the store.

The buttons are incredibly small and the keyboard is over to the left some. I tried transferring some MP3 files via Bluetooth and it took FOR. EHH. VERR. I learned about the butt dialing issue so I activated the key lock and it gave me more grief than it was worth. It is also very slow. I did expect it to be slow, and I know it won't be the same speed as a smart phone or newer device. I totally get that. But STILL. Whenever I would get a text, I'd have to click on the center button, the press the unlock key button, then nothing would be there. A few seconds later, the view message option would finally show up. It was just too clunky. Instead I've taken it waaayyy back and ordered a Motorola Razr from eBay. I was a fast texter on flip phones once, I am sure I can do it again. Besides, I'm old and married with kids and no longer have as many friends as I once did, so no need to text much! ;) I wouldn't recommend this phone.

You can't transfer photos and videos from phone to pc. Drivers are loaded when initally connecting phone to pc via a usb cable. However, the phone does not show up in windows explorer. I tried loading updated drivers "join me plus" but the connection to their servers fail.

Edit: Finally figured out how to transfer photos to pc. Install a microSD card that has to be purchased separately. My phone didn't recognize the card initially even after formatting the card, the phone contacts had to be cleaned with electronic contact cleaner. Only then did the phone recognize the card and allowed photos to be saved to the card. Connect phone to pc via usb cord that has to be purchased separately. The included "cd drive (E:) Join Me" software still doesn't work but the card is recognized by windows explorer.

I know this is a cheap phone but I had a cheaper trac phone that worked better. It makes and receives calls, sends and receives texts. The operating system is S L O W !. Just unlocking the screen and getting a message notice can take 10 seconds. That does not sound long until you are staring at the screen waiting, just to get a text. Speaking of screen lock, not so much. You can lock it but having it in your pocket activates keys on a regular basis. Also, this phone has a camera on it but I wouldn't bother trying to use it. No matter how you adjust the options the picture comes out wrong or out of focus. Then the speaker blew. It still makes sound but not clear. Then there is one small complaint about the audio output from the head phone jack. It is good enough for ear buds but WAY too low for plugging into any stereo. Oh, and the phone stopped answering through the headphone jack as well. All of this in less than 1 year of use. But, the battery still lasts for 2 -3 days!

The phone was okay when I first got it. However, the phone is bad to dial 911 randomly. This is because is preselected to easily dial. That aside, the phone worked good for about a year. Then it started shutting off randomly. Also, then it started not reading the sim card constantly. It would say 'please insert sim card' when the card was already in the phone. I figured out to make it work by putting a piece of paper on top of the sim card when inserting it into the slot. That helps make it work for a while, but you have to keep doing it.

This phone will not work on airvoice wireless for group texting or sending photos (MMS). You cannot receive or send either group texts or photos. I tested this, and confirmed it with airvoice wireless as well. They said you must have a phone which supports internet messaging. Best I can tell, that's pretty much a smartphone and that's it. I wanted a non-smartphone for personal reasons.

I have owned two AT&T Go Phones. The first I purchased in March 2015 and the second in April 2016. The first failed as after one year the speaker made everyone whom I spoke with sound like Daffy Duck. I just got rid of the second one as it was starting to happen again. I bit the bullet and finally entered the 21st century and bought my first smart phone, a Samsung Galaxy J3 Eclipse. This paradigm-shift was a big deal for a guy in his mid-60's who was set in his ways with the old technology. Also, this is by no means an aspersion of Daffy Duck, his voice nor Loony Tunes. Thufferin' thasafrath!!

This phone had problem right out of the box. It displayed the wrong time, and the text capabilities were garbled. I tried to get another phone of a similar make and it had the exact same problems as this one.
My son loves this phone perfect if you want basic phone. Email, text, internet if needed and calls. Has a radio camera and flash light. Good not to fragile.

Before getting this phone, I had a similar-looking one made by Vtech that I had had for two or three years. I liked it until the end, but it started to turn off for no reason and cause me to miss calls and texts, so I decided to get a new phone. I went to an AT&T store and got the phone that looked the most like what I had had. Since it had been a couple years since I got my last phone, I figured any phone I got would be better than the old one.

I was wrong.

This phone struggles to do the most basic of tasks. Every time I answer the phone and say hello, I hear nothing on the other end, because it takes this phone at least a second or two to actually start transmitting my voice. When I get a text and hit a button to activate the screen, I then have to wait a few seconds for the text alert to appear, and then another second or two for it to show the message. The messages don't appear in any kind of order that I can discern. For some people, all their messages to me are lumped together separate from my messages to them; for others they aren't.

I didn't expect this phone to wow me. I expected it to fulfill the most basic requirements of a cell phone with at least something approaching promptness. But it failed to pass even that pretty low bar. So, two stars: one for at least being a phone that does technically receive calls and texts, and not being, say, a sausage, and one for forcing me to learn tai chi and the value of patience every time I user it.
